reviews.review:
Yummy!. In short,we ate 2 days in a row there!
Fish,burgers,sushi... it's just what the doctor described.
The atmosphere is relaxed,everyone is helpful.menus are in English too,well detailed.

Visited twice. We stopped here twice during our stay in Lisbon. There is a great selection of food from traditional Portuguese to sushi and pizza.The first time we just had a drink and a stroll, we had two coffees and had a go at the pour your own super bock! The coffee was fabulous, smooth and delicious and the beer was an IPA and tasted great. On our second visit we had a Brazilian style pork sandwich and a bowl of stone soup both were very tasty. Time your visits right as it can get very busy.

Patricia Keenan . We where recommended to go to this restaurant before our visit to Lisbon.Wow we absolutely loved it food was excellent the variety of different foods where well worth the many visits we did.

Great selection of food and drink. Not always enough space in the middle of the court to sit and eat, but some of the side restaurants have seating on the opposite side (for those having a full meal at one spot). Fun beer selections and great food from all over. Interestingly, some only take local credit cards vs international ones.
Gourmet market. Great gourmet market with plenty gourmet choices. Famous chefs have restaurants here. The only negative point is the lines on every restaurant.
Good Food/Price Range. A lot of options to lunch / dinner. Getting the food is usually fast but the experience could be better if there were more seating space.
Love coming here!. Super cool place. Very busy but well worth the visit! Several restaurants to chose from and a market next door.

So cool!. So many options to eat here!!! This was great, super trendy! The food is outstanding and I spent so much time just walking around and exploring. Be careful of the bathrooms with no toilet paper and seating is VERY hard to come by during busy times.

Everything you could want. We had heard of this but it was even better than we expected. There is seafood, pizza, suckling pig, sushi, wine and souvenirs. Everything was freshly made. Seating was NOT a problem.
Good choice and good food!. there are plenty of options with several restaurants owned by different chefs. The food was good and the ambiance is festive.

Must go for souvenirs & tasty food. Lisbon is famous for the cans of sardines & seafood as souvenirs. Here is where you will find the most authentic gift to buy. Lots of seafood in a can to choose from. Also check out Henrique Sa Pessoa - you won't regret eating from here!

Fantastic produce and gourmet food market and restaurants. This is an adventurous reimagining of the traditional City centre produce market into a stunning new venue which still provides a produce market alongside a huge communal eating hall dedicated to restaurants and gourmet produce.30+ food outlets clustered around the outside of the building - several of the restaurants on the west side serving into street cafe's outside and the others serving into the large central food court.You can order your food from any of the hot food outlets (real adventurous cooking here) take your alarm gadget to a table and wait for your choice to be individually cooked. The gadget flashes and rings and you take it and collect your meal, your wine etc and return to the long benches to share your meal in the company of gourmands from around the world.We tried a prawn, chilli and ginger starter with locally baked bread with a green wine from the north of Portugal - outstanding and then two more dishes from a different stall/restaurant; a black rice risotto with scallops and seaweed and a salmon, avocado, chilli and onion dish all delicious with a glass of a local red wine.Our dinner conversations with a French trio and a Polish economics professor.Range of food from contemporary Portuguese, Asian fusion to hamburgers and pizza (both with a twist) wonderful fresh ingredient as well as the customary Portuguese sweet range and ice creams.Souvenir and craft shops complete the picture for this must see, taste, feel and experience this exciting venue. A wonderful example of what the Granger Market in Newcastle could become.

Great food choices. The food choices were great but it was very crowded, hard to find a seat even although the place is huge. Not a relaxing atmosphere but definitely an experience. Worth a visit just to see the place.

Avoid if you would like to taste Lisboa. The market itself worth a visit, especially the flowers...But for food, simply, this is not the right place. You can find some authentic and orignal stuff, but the real life and real food is just around the market, outside, where you'll find some good, old-fashiones local bistros, for much less money. And generous portions, and you can eat together with local people, or even witht the staff. Very friendly people and good qualtiy food. My advise your be "Casa CID", a fantastic place where time is stopped...
Relax space with good vibe. The time out market has always a good and relax vibe. Ideal for a quick meal, with great options, great desserts and a variety of restaurants withe tipical food.

Tasty but Crowded. My sister and I have different eating habits, I'm an omnivore and she's very nearly vegan so eating together while traveling can be difficult. Time out Market made it easy for us to find something we both wanted to eat. It was fun walking around and checking out all of the stalls before we decided. We came at a very busy time (Friday evening) so it was extremely crowded and tricky to find a table. Our meals were wonderful and we enjoyed the hustle and bustle of the people around us.

Not the average food court. My husband and I tried Time Out Market for lunch and had great meals. This market has wine, beer which you can have to enjoy with your food. The food offerings are from chefs in local restaurants. My husband had read about Sea Me in review and was very pleased to see a Sea Me stall. He ordered a cod dish with turnip greens. He really enjoyed it. I had a fig salad which was great. Real figs, not dried figs. Very good. It was a bit difficult finding a place to sit but once that was done, eating was great.

Dinging and portugal experience. A must stop if only for the size and variety of options for dining. Dozens of different restaurants are housed here along with special shops for local products and foods.
Wonderful Market. Great local fare with a cooking school and other attractions. The local ham is excellent from the vendor there...try the acorn fed for a real buttery texture!

Take what you want man!!. TimeOut Market might be a very landmark in Lisbon, a nice structure renowed-factory looked offering many dishes from many countries. There you can have a pizza, taste some very sweet cakes or the typical portuguese codfish croquettes or fried gren beans as well or instead you could have "Bacalahu Batateiro" that I suggest, just another typical portuguese dish offered in this excellent food market based on codfish, carrot and vegetables and having the look of a cake. Don't forget to taste some "panini" with ham or get some particular wine in the appropriate "loja". Ah, looking for some gadget or souvenir? There you can find it!
Great selection of foods . Something for everyone really enjoyable. Take your time and walk around don't just jump in to the first one you see definitely almost for your trip

Nice but not mandatory. There are 2 parts to the market.
One is a regular fruits and vegtables market.
The other is the culinary part. There are many restaurants of various kinds. It was crowded when we visited and the food was OK, not more.

Brilliant concept restores life to the market. The atmosphere is really good and the variety of food stalls excellent. In the centre are tables where you can eat from ant of the stalls; around the edges are established seating areas where restaurant service is available, there are also shaded outside eating areas on the west side overlooking a small park.The fresh food market has moved to one side but seems to be open only in the morning.

Perfect stop. Our hotel was located very close to the Time Out Market. This place is the perfect way to start your day off with some caffeine, breakfast or swing through for lunch. There are great options to eat just about anything and a cool atmosphere inside. I would recommend going to Sea Me for Seafood. It is a great choice especially if you can't make it up to Sea Me for a proper meal.
Great. The pleace was amazing. Everyone will find something to eat there. Good atmosphere and friendly ppl. Watch out for pocket thieves. Stopped one trying to rob ones wallet.

Great place top fod. Top quality choices of local and international food outlets. Can eat at the counter of some or find a communal table with the hordes.It is so good we have eaten three times here. Add a wine, beer or coffee and enjoy the experience. Very busy at lunchtime.

Amazing huge food hall!. This was a lucky find - I assumed it was a market and went inside to look and found a huge food hall selling pretty much anything you could want! I visited this place a few times during my stay. Great place if you're traveling alone and don't want to sit in a restaurant, also for groups as there's something for everyone!
Great market.. Absolutely loved this market. Great food on offer. Lovely ambiance. Also some very interesting stalls selling other things than food.
Average market. Food prices were more expensive than a lot of nearby restaurants; essentially like a large food court.

Sweet Food Market. Foodie heaven! Tons of booths with all assortments of food! Wine and beer in the center and cafe. There's chicken, carne seafood, multiple different chefs and lots open seating. Next door is regular market but it wasn't open on Sunday.
Food court on steroids. 1/2 of Mercado de Rivera is produce, fish, meat, etc. Other half is food court. Wonderful food selections, mostly frequented by tourists. Very busy but great people watching.

Vibrant place for lunch. Stumbled across this place while walking miles around Lisbon, Various outlets selling food almost like a food court, the various Portuguese dishes being sold along side more conventional lunches means that the fussiest of diners would find something

A plethora of options, all in one place!. I stumbled on this place as I was strolling around Lisbon, and I was so impressed! On that particular day it was my Canadian Thanksgiving, so it was such a great experience to be able to share a 'communal' meal with those around me.This is a fantastic market where you will find many different types of cuisines, with food outlets outlining the periphery, and dining areas with communal tables in the centre. I came here several times during my stay in Lisbon, and on each occasion, it was quite packed.I chose to purchase food from several establishments including 'Chicken All Around' where I purchased the Piri Piri Chicken that was quite tasty (but the service was horrible), including a seafood establishment where I ordered a 'marinated salmon with guacamole'; I was expecting a hot salmon dish, although perhaps due to language barriers, I was given a raw salmon ceviche. It was quite tasty, although I was a bit surprised....As mentioned, there are many types of cuisine available as it is more of a tourist destination, so in addition to traditional Portugese cuisine, you will also find sushi, Italian, North American comfort food, and and great international desserts.I would definitely go back!

Very different. We arrived early evening at our nesrby hotel and wandered over not expecting much - wow. The atmosphere and choice of good was simply overwhelming- we chose one of the 'Iconic' chefs and gad the best cooked cod in white sauce ever. The octopus with sweet potato was out of this world. With wine shared starter of goats cheese honey and rosemsry and 2 deserts the bill came to E47. Great vslue snd grest atmosphere

Great place to go. This is a curated gourmet food court. Fantastic food with lots of options for every family member, including one that served gluten free dairy free organic food, which one member of our family needs.Open all hours, very casual

Busy but well worth it. We came here for lunch on Saturday. It's a large market with lis of food choices. We ended up at one if the fish places and had a great meal, then we had some meat, cheese, and wine. Everything was amazing. Only drawback was that it was stop busy we had to walk around for 20 minutes to find a table. Still with it though.

Gourmet food at casual setting. Great place for adventures dining, lot's of options, responsible pricing, inexpensive beer and wine by the glass, should find something even for the pickiest eaters. A must when in Lisbon anytime of day!

Weird . Até at time out place. It is weird. Nice food but weird. Don't go as there are so many special places to eat in Lisbon that cost the same or less. Visit as it's interesting in a sense, eat if you want good food with a fast food feeling.
Great food. Very touristy...but still very good food reasonably priced worth going to.Portugese wine is a treat

Market Lisboa. This used to be a vegetable and fish market before and now is a beautiful place to eat. It has all types of food from different countries, tapas, sea food, cakes, sweets and plenty to drink.

Excellent place if you don't know what you want to eat. The market has sooooo many street food style stalls in all sorts of food: Portuguese, Japanese, Mexican etc. It gets pretty jam packed in the evening, so go early to get seats. This is easy for Brits who tend to eat much earlier than the Portuguese do (~8pm)! We went for lunch and dinner, and always enough choice to eat something differently. The food seemed reasonably priced, however we did have the most expensive Portuguese custard tart there (€1.50 rather than the usual €0.90 - €1.10) however it was a very good one!

The ULTIMATE food court. Imagine being in your local mall that has a nice food court. You walk down an aisle and there are say 7 or 8 well known vendors.Well,multiply that by a factor of about 5, and add a few more aisles. A HUGE selection including Seafood, Meats, salads etc etc etc.Each "restaurant" which is really just an open kitchen with bar stool seats has space for about 10-15 diners. Then, on the inner area, there are additional tables and chairs and you will see 100s of people jockeying around for a seat.If you go with more than just a couple, prepare to separate,or post yourself in a stationery position and wait it out. It's quite a scene. But the food is fresh and lcuisine is local.

Food Lovers Dream.. If you love food do not miss this place. Imagine a food market of all the best food put together! I could come back to this place every day for a week and be spoilt for choices. We had a few cod cakes from two different places and a squid ink risotto with scallops and wakame seaweed from Andrade Silva. Octopus salad from Marlene Viera and a sucking pork on brioche with pickles from Henrique Sa Pessoa which was amazing. After all this I still wanted to eat more but couldn't fit more in.

Great meeting place for food and drink. I have been to the market for, both shopping and relaxation . The fish is excellent but don't go on a Monday for fish as no fishing done on Sundays . In the actual converted market there are stalls the whole way around serving freshly cooked produce . You can have a drink and chill out here but it can get very very busy and noisy . Great atmosphere though .

Eat drink be merry. Down on the waterfront by all the new tram line building and rail terminus is the old market that is now split as a fruit and flower market and multi vendor food hall.Many of these are popping up around Europe like a Disney style food court. So the Americans have done this style of eating for years but now Europe has it and beer to boot.Great idea with many many food stalls around the room, so you pick your style of food and or drinks and take a bleeping alarm depending on the stall and then find a seat on the long Beer Keller style tables. Then when your food is ready off you go and collect it, eat and be merry.Even on a weekday lunchtime it was busy and in the evening it is very lively and social. No fixed demographic we sat with one couple in their 20's on the left and a group of 9 all in their 70's on the other side, all having a great time.Nice social way to relax for an hour before hitting the City of Lisbon again. Highly recommend it. Try in the day if your nervous in crowds to get the idea then you have to try an evening session.

Good fun. It was a really nice surprise to find this market. Great atmosphere, lots of food to choose from and a fun place to go if the weather isn't too good. The only slight downsides were that some of the more popular food outlets had quite long waiting times and a few parts of the chicken dish my husband tried weren't cooked all the way though. My food was lovely though!

Outstanding idea, well executed - a must go for Lison. I had read about Time Out Lisboa and had it firmly on our to-do list for the 3 days we were in Lisbon. The location is really not next to...anything. It looks closer than you would think on the maps and in the hot sun a walk is not a good idea. The only place where you might connect here naturally is if you want to come down the Ascencor de Bica from the Chiado area. If not then get a taxi / tuk-tuk as the walk along the waterfront is not the nice picturesque stroll you might imagine.The Time Out food area is next to the real fruit market and a park. A group of excellent restaurants have been invited to build stalls here. The range is truly incredible and the food to a very high standard. You have two options - sit in the middle and each stand in a queue (great if you can't agree)...but the wait can be rather long as each meal is cooked from scratch. Possibly more relaxing is to pick one venue and sit on the seats at the back of each.As you might expect - it was packed.Just go...and if Time Out haven't built 5 more of these I'll be stunned.

Attractive food court. The place is conveniently located and very accessible. The food court housed many local celebrity chefs and famous restaurant outlet. There are also several beer and cocktail station. Food are great with good value and ambience is casual and nice, mixed of tourists and locals. I recommend the little cocktail bar where you can see the bartender mix you drink directly in a modern food court and it taste nice too. Empty your stomach before you go !

Good place to eat. It is very good place to eat. You can find domestic food (try cod with white sauce if you like fish). Only problem is that is crowded and if you are in bigger group you will have problem to keep group on one place. Prices are ok, portions are not big ones but very tasty.

Memorable Place to Grab a Drink and Some Great Food!. This is a great place to sample a variety of different food and drink offerings! I would highly recommend the Gin Bar and any of the many many stalls offering excellent foods for sampling. It's a laid back and easy going atmosphere offering a wide variety of things to try! A great place to start as you work your way towards the centre of Lisbon.

A tasty experience . Is something different to do for a lunch. The place can get crowdy and not finding a place to sit down and enjoying your good might become annoying.
Totally recommend Tartar-is!

Nice for tourists, but that's all folks. You can taste some interesting dishes but at the end it's all fast-food pretending chief's cuisine.
My advice, just take a look because the place is very nice

Nice place, good food !. We had the lunch at the Time Out Market. This place is a big food court where you can find Portuguese And international food.
Prices are on little bit expensive for Portugal but everybody can find something to eat And drink.

Wide range of Selections, Long Operations Hour. A good bunch of restaurants with good vibe. Operating 8am till 11am daily (can up to 2am during weekends), we who stayed Lisbon for 4 nights and can't help ourselves to visit there at least once a day! Morning like 9am is lesser crowd whereby there are more people after 3pm all the way till night, it is a warehouse style canteen hence the ventilation is good and spacious at the same time.Try the Balcahau (salted cod fish) at SEA ME, one of the local dishes in Portugal, wine & proscuitto (dried meat) is good for night snack, fish soup and stone soup are good for a warm breakfast. Tea time? Nata (Portuguese tart) is a brilliant choice. Souvenir such as wine, canned fish and handcraft item are available in the market as well. Wide range of drinks kiosks are available in the middle of the market, from coffee to beer, cocktail and ginja (cherry liquor), all in good flavors!Have your good food, enjoy the people watching and take in the vibe :)
Worth a visit. Great place to spend a couple of hours. Plenty of options for tapas style lunch with a few drinks. Would recommend a visit.

Fun, if touristy. We went for a casual dinner on our last night in town. This is a great place to sample food from the celebrity chefs and most popular restaurants and speciality food shops in town. (Expect to encounter other tourists, but don't be put off by them.) Prices are reasonable and the food is 5 star quality. A fun place to seek out a taste of Lisbon--perfect for a first or a last night in town.

Good place for cheap but very good food. I was recommended this place by a couple of people at work, as a good place to unwind at. They were not wrong. It is hard to describe this place. Its like a very nice, large school dinner hall (hogwarts size) with very long tables and all sorts of artisan resturants around the outside, beer and port sellers in the middle. Get there before 7.30Pm as it gets very very busy, even on a tuesday night. Later in the evening there is a live entertainment as well.I ate in the Miguel Castro e silva along the back wall, having a duck meal for 9.50 euros. Very nice indeed.
Where eat something .... A place where we found a lot of diferente restaurants, different food. The market is a bit noisy. Good restaurants to lunch and dinner.

Amazingly delicious!!!. I pretty much ate every meal here during my 2 days in Lisbon. This is high quality gourmet meals at a reasonable price in a fun and lively atmosphere. Highly recommended to come here, grab a meal and a glass of wine.

Great range of local cuisine. Very well laid out group of culinary stalls offering excellent local cuisine, most suitable for a snack or light meal. Clean well placed tables allow you to eat your selection right there. Good place to explore local cuisine.

Blown away by the variety of choice. We have heard about this market, but actually thought that we will not get to see it during our visit to Lisbon. We did not even know where is it located. Can you imagine our surprise, when we wandering around Lisbon in our last day in Lisbon is search for the last lunch in that amazing city we came across the place. It is superb location, since it houses so many different dining places under one roof. There is also a market, where you can find fresh fruits and vegetables. Anyway, we found it hard to pick where to order food. All the places seemed really good. I believe it will satisfy any taste. Of course it is not the place to eat in the romantic atmosphere. You order the food, get the buzzer and just find a spot by a big table. Unfortunately I cannot remember the name of the place, we ordered food from. We had cod fish with hummus and spare ribs. I would definitely recommend the place to people who want to discover different colours of Portuguese cuisine. But if you like to dine in the quite restaurant, you better pick another place. Enjoy.

Magnificent. Brilliant. Just brilliant. Brilliant. Go. You'll love it here. If you don't like it here then you need to re-evaluate your life. The duck croquettes and the tuna dish from A Cozinha da Felicidade need Michelin stars.

Not your usual mall restaurants. Portuguese food made especially for you. Walk arond to see what each of these open kitchens is offering, make your choice and wait until it is freshly prepared. Find a seat, have some wine or beer and relax. Soon you will be savouring a delicious meal.
Fantastic bacalhau!. Try the Bacalhau here and see if you can identify the flavours ;)Alexandre Silva is the booth to stop by during your visit in Mercado do Ribeira in Lisbon.

A must see. For a quick bite to eat of local cuisine, go to the Time Out Market. We went on a Tuesday afternoon and it wasn't too overcrowded. In a group of four, each one of us found food to please their tastebuds. Incredible fish and seafood dishes. A definite must.

Great atmosphere well worth a visit. This place is a must experience. We were there for lunch had duck croquettes,sardine dish & octopus salad. Service was great as was the food & beer. Long tables so inevitably you share with others. We made friends in the very short time we were there with other tourists. Place is clean. We would go back on our return to Lisbon.

A nice time out treat . Stopped in this market to buy some fruit and found this wonderful prepared food market This is terrific for many different tastes We had a nice treat of cheeses and cured ham w a nice local red wineFeeling fortified we could continue our march through the lovely sights of Lisbon There is something here for everyONE!!Try it today
Great food . Lots to choose from and not expensive. Portuguese, Thai, Italian and more. Next to cais do sodre station.

Great food experience.. A lot of variety to choose from. We tried the cod/potato/scrambled egg dish from Miguel Castro Silva and found it very good. The beer experience in the center of the food hall was a let down. They featured 5 beers but only had one (of course the lager) available.

Great place for food and hanging out!. Wonderful place where you can easily spend hours eating and relaxing! We had a delicious Portuguese vegetable soup at one of the little organic restaurants. Lovely place!
Amazing food . Well you can't find a better place to eat lunch than here. I had octopus which was beautifully presented and tasted wonderful.

Quality food reasonable prices. Excellent selection of quality food. Prices reasonable. Good atmosphere. Worth a visit. Was busy - we went Sat night but still able to find a seat. Food didn't take too long.

A Foodies' Paradise!. Great Ambience, tons of food options, amazing beers, lovely music. A lovely place to eat and visit in Lisbon. The variety of food options will leave you dizzy, make sure you go with a good appetite so you can try out different items. Lovely place if you love sushi and sea food! Well priced too.
Great selection of good food! . We went to the Asian place and the food was delicious! Pretty pricey for what you're getting but all the places in the market were a little over priced.

WOW!!!. Many diferent kind of foods from the siply to the finest!
Very nice enviroment with nice people.
Don't miss!!

I could spend all week there!. Amazing place, huge choice of places to dine at with a wide range of culinary delights. It gets really busy so can be hard to find a seat during lunch but it's definitely worth a visit. Best indoor street food place I've been in Europe.

Food lovers paradise. Great choices of diverse food and Portuguese wines. Sushi, noodles, grills, meat, seafood....OMG the choice was so difficult....I need to go back!! So many foods and wine to try and so little time. One night is not enough...the food was amazing, cooked to order and very fresh. A great selection of wines as well to match with your food or just to try. My first time to Lisbon and Portugal and I was so impressed with the wine, so many diverse grape varieties, every one I tried was balanced and delicious. A great experience.Tip...As a foodie, I suggest going early in the evening to make the most of it and ensure you get a good seat.

Great place for lunch. So much to choose from that it became difficult to make the final decisions. We went with two different types of pizza, a half chicken and some awesome sangria. All was delicious and reasonably priced as well.

So worth going to. My friends and I eat in many excellent places around the world. We are planning a trip for our friends to come to Lisbon next year and although not luxurious this is so worth visiting and we Will be back. The key is to order food only from the 5 chef kiosks - don't order from the others unless you want average food?You may need to pay a little more and wait a little longer but the food from the chefs is worth it :)Relatively inexpensive the food was very tasty and made for one of the best lunches we had.Although not listed widely the restaurants don't really start serving food until between 12:30 and 1pm.

World of food in cool surroundings. Your can eat your way around the world here. The buzz is amazing from more relaxed lunch times to crazy weekend evenings. Just a drink or a full meal, either works to enjoy this place.

Great Market - Great Food. This market has many food options as well as a traditional fresh food market. The prepared food area is spacious, clean and quite comfortable. We used the market as a great meeting point for our party of six. The market is across the street from the main subway and train station which is on the river. This market is also close to the LisbonBikeRentals which was very convenient for us. This is a great place to unwind, eat and relax a little on your touring of Lisbon.

A GREAT SPOT FOR A DIFFERENT TASTY EXPERIENCE!!. You will feel the tradition compared with the modern ways of cooking and serving at exactly the same (huge!) market! the place is full of crowd (locals mixed with foreigners!) and the sense of this environment is great!! it looks like an adventure!! highly recommended!!

So many choices. Where do I start? This is a high end food court where you can find any style of food imaginable, from steak to chinese to fish to tapas. It is in a large hall with seating in the middle and surrounded by the variety of food purveyors. What a great atmosphere! We went on a Monday night and found it very busy. Can't even think what it would be like on the weekend.We tried some cold meats and cheeses called Mista which was excellent. Nice bottle of wine for 10 Euros and we were set. Definitely going back on my next visit to try some other foods.

Wonderland for foodies. pros: Great variety and quality of food, atmosphere is nice. you can keep coming back and you always find something new and tasty.cons: not enough tables to host the thousands of hungry tourists. sometimes you need to search for a sit for long minutes and it can be frustrating to a point. all in all, Loved it, and would be back again for sure.
Such a great place. I simply loved it, i was just there i ate from the asian lab and it was amazing.. Crowded but worth visiting.. Suggested if you are in Lisbon dont miss it amazing at night.

Good vibe. This is a new or better saying an Old Market with new interpretation. One half you have the old veggies and fish market and on the other the new area with restaurantes an a new vibe.There are several options of restaurants where one can chose from pizza's to typical Portuguese food. Tables are collective and it gives one a chance to meet other people. Normally it is full during summer time and worse at night but nothing that will make you quite.

Amazing food.. Time Out Market was one of the highlights of my few days in Lisbon. The food was excellent, I had grilled prawns from one of the fish vendors and the atmosphere was lively and bustling. Definitely would recommend.

Lots of different things at a high level. You can have a lot of different things in the time out market. On one side you have small cuisines of the chefs that have a good name in Portugal. It's really worth it, they do high class cooking and its not so expensive as in a restaurant. All the other restaurants are mostly restaurants that you can find elsewhere in Lisbon. They are excellent too.We were at Tartar-ia, at Henrique sa Pessoa, at Alexandre da Silva and it was very very good. It's a place you have to go to when visiting Lisbon!

Great variety. Busy place, but the tables turn over quickly so small groups can usually find a place to sit after a few minutes. Bigger groups may struggle unless you go outside peak times.Loads of variety and everything we tasted was lovely. The proprietors are happy to explain concepts or dishes. Everyone we spoke to had perfect English.Very good spot.

Hope they do this in every city!!. My husband and I always want different things for lunch/ dinner. Timeout market in Lisbon was the perfect option for both of us. We stayed in Lisbon for 3 days; on two of them we went there for either lunch or dinner. On our last night there we got 4 different dishes from 4 different places just so we won't miss out on anything. Love the quality of food; I even googled if this idea was implemented else where just in case we missed it in madrid or something!!!

Overrated. A promising concept rendered void by inflated prices, constant crowding, and the near impossibility to get a seat inside for more than two people at any given time after 19h. The esplanade is nice but expensive, and not really worth it considering the high number of good alternatives in the area.

A very big table . A very big table full of flavors
Here u can't find anything to eat and anything to drink
Definitely a place u have to visit

So Good! Wish we had a market like this at home!. What a great market! Unlike others we visited while in Europe, this is definitely more chef-driven. Each counter offers a distinct menu with sizable but reasonably priced plates. With two people, you can split a few plates - everything we tried was delicious - we even went back on more than one day.Its also a fun environment with a beer garden feel and music in the evening.Do not skip this if you're headed to Lisbon.

Foodies, people watchers paradise at really good prices!!!!. Inventive, authentic, hot, tasty to die for!!! We went twice over a ten day break but could have gone everyday. We had pork, escalopes, duck dishes and desserts. Tables get full quickly. Decide what you want, get a table and then go up individually to order. They give you a buzzer that vibrates when your food is ready. You will not be disappointed. If you want to buy fruit or veg go before 12 noon. Go upstairs and take a great pictures from above. It only takes 20/30 minutes slow walk to get there from the main square on sea front.

A great way to see local arts crafts and food. Held on weekends it alternates with the farmers marketStarts I. Friday and ends Sunday all of the exhibitors are selected and carry the Portugal certification markThe items range from Leather and cork goods to tiles and jewlry to food and wineThe pork sandwiches are quite good along with the local sausages if you want a quick mealNice way to see some of the arts and crafts of Portugal

Experience Lisboa Gastronomically!. What a great experience in this indoor feasting market! All of the top chefs have small outlets for you to try the latest culinary menu items. They have everything from fresh seafood, burgers, rice dishes, sushi, Asian style, charcuterie and even pizza (why you would even eat pizza in Portugal I don't understand, but something here for everyone. The Sea Me and Tartar-ia were exceptional - sea bass, tuna and beef tar tar as well as scallops and mango sala! The Roasted Sardines and cuddle fish at Sea Me were exceptional. We loved this market, went back to visit it again before we left. Wanted to make sure we tried a little bit of everything. This is a great concept that everyone can enjoy!

Excellent atmosphere and experience; hit and miss on the food. This was an awesome place (we went twice) and overall, it's a must-see & eat. Love the idea of bringing together so many great restaurants and vendors. There are expensive options and cheaper ones, so great for all budgets. Here are my recommendations:Sea Me: We easily dropped 40euro here and there was 1 standout dish - the cod on spinach. It was fresh and well seasoned. The gazpacho wasn't great. The tuna tartar didn't have enough citrus, in my opinion... and the scallops with corn were delicious, but we only got 3 for 8euro. So, not the best of values - but not terrible.Croqueteria: from the main entrance, it's located on the back right hand corner. This place provided the best value, taste and it was really simple. Highly recommend the Game meat croquette!Creme De La Creme: This is a soup place located on the right hand side next to the test kitchen. I am a huge lover of soups, and this is one of the cheaper food options at 4euro a bowl. I missed this place the first time I visited, and I kept thinking about how I needed to try out their caldo verde... seriously couldn't have been more disappointed. It was really flavorless, lacked proper seasoning and just tasted like I was eating watered down chicken broth. This soup made me angry. Overall, we weren't able to find an "amazing" dish or vendor that blew our minds here... but it was still a fun experience and I'd return a 3rd time to sample other places.

Location is loud and crowded.. For us it was too loud and crowded so we did not stay for dinner and went to a smaller place nearby which gave us a better Lisbon atmosphere. Seems a little hyped. I can't say anything about the food quality of the different places.

Put this on your places to see. Big open space. Lots of seating and even more delicious food vendors. These are all top notch places to eat or even better, grab a glass of Portuguese wine. Opens until late, but not as late as you would want it to be. Good for those that love food and wine. And also those that want to try something more local and new instead of the same stuff you'll get at home. Lighting is dark. So you are better off Instagramming your food for lunch if that is important to you.

Modern Marketing. Came to the food market a couple of times whilst in Lisbon... A strange place... Seems a shame to have removed it's originality and it feels like you could be in any "cool" city. That said, we had some good oysters and nice Portuguese food that was a bit more adventurous than the dishes in small local places. Worth a look as its right on the water front anyway.

Beautiful food but not as good as it looked.. This place is a lot of fun and you have tons of choices but most of the food we tried was only ok (or not quite ok). We did have a pretty good slice of pizza (order an Aperol Spritz from the pizza place, it was so good). We also had great eclairs from the eclair stand.Go to meet people, have a drink and a little something to eat but skip staying for dinner.

Can't miss this.. We were in Lisbon for one night, and stumbled across this food heaven.We loved the vide, the assortment of foods and drinks to choose from.It was by far the cleanest well organized market I've been to in Europe. Perfect for a Saturday lunch and wine.Don't miss this one!!

Good choice and value. Visited a couple of times whilst on holiday. It's busy, but the place has a good vibe and there is loads of choice at great value. Would highly recommend trying the Alexandre Silva kitchen as it was brilliant - we had 2 starters (sweet peppers and bread with cheese), 2 mains (seared tuna steak which was fabulous, and an incredibly tasty duck confit) as well as drinks for about 50 euros. The food was delicious and the service fast and friendly. We also tried Asian Lab... That was a decidedly more underwhelming experience. Service was slow, the staff were rude and seemed confused. The pad thai was good but the penang curry left a lot to be desired! I would avoid it as there are better options. Cinco has a fab cocktail menu at good prices, so give that a whirl as well.

Great selection - the trouble is finding a seat. We visited the market at around 2:30 on a weekday in Oct and took in some good food, but had to stand to eat it.. Lisbon is busy in Oct too, not just the summertime. This is certainly an interesting place but I'd go earlier or later next time and find a seat first and then get food.

Something to please everyone!. This amazing place ( why aren't there dozens of places like this around the world???) is located in the old mercado or market of Lisbon by the waterfront a short jaunt away from downtown. It is now home to a smaller vegetable and fish/meat/dairy market that surrounds a central area where dozens of Lisbons top restaurants, bars and fine food stores have small versions of their main locations. We first visited the TimeOut Lisbon Mercado early one Sunday evening. This is a time when foreign tourists often get caught out - since there are few restaurants open beyond about 4 pm on Sundays in Spain and Portugal. But the mercado with its dozens of small but ample kitchens was buzzing with activity. In fact it never seems to really slow down at any time ... on subsequent visits it was always full of hungry folks, both local and foreign. The food that we tasted was delicious and well-presented, and while some of the kitchens have a few stools at the counter, mostly you just take your food to one of the many long tables in the center of the hall, and join with the rest of the world there. Lots of opportunities to meet people, both locals and tourists. Our dishes would often come from different restaurants, according to our personal preferences, which meant that everyone got to eat what they really wanted. Result : happy campers! I repeat - why aren't there more places like this around the world? Its an idea whose time has come.

Variety of food and drinks and nice atmosphere. An unexpected find as we weren't looking for food but worth a visit as you can find cooked and fresh food and a wide range of quality and prices. We found it was too crowded but that's just holiday period. There were gourmet wines and cheeses but also average meals. We only stayed 15 minutes and stopped for dessert.

A first rate food experience, offering a great venue and choices. The layout for this food hall works pretty well. Central tables surrounded by numerous stalls of food with a couple interspersed in the middle.There's a great selection of various Portuguese and other foods so choosing what to eat is tough. Additionally, provisioners for port/sherry as well as the various tinned seafoods and butchers should be visited.

Great chilled place. Great place for a spot of food / drink and music with a cool vibe.We tried the beef tartar which was fab along with prawns and mussels had a spot of havana club cocktail from the bar. Dropped by a second time and had the Santini ice cream which was relish

Tasty, affordable, great food. The place has a lot stands of great restaurants. Very tasty food, very effective service and even when crowded found a place to sit and eat.Ate from 3 different stalls and all of them was good.

Great place to feed your face.. I researched this venue prior to our trip to Lisbon and was pleasantly surprised by how much great food there was to try here. The variations are endless with huge seafood, wine and snack options. Dont miss the canned fish shop where you can buy excellent products at a fraction of the US prices and they are legal to bring home.

A Great Place to Eat. We love this place and have had lunch there on a number of occasions. There is something for everyone. We have had the sushi, wine and sandwiches - all very high quality.The place is very busy on weekends, so it can be difficult to find a seat during those times, even though it has a very large seating capacity. It is definitely worth a visit.

You will not be disappointed by anything you choose to eat or drink!. We stopped to eat at this fabulous food court around 10pm on a Monday and found the place hopping with young and old. We had dinner and drinks for less than 20 eauro each and were able to relax and enjoy the atmosphere until 12:30pm. A must do!

Nice visit. Old Building transferred in a food Hall where you can buy various (portugues) food. Nice concept with large tables, if you are lucky to find a seat. Weekends a No go, very busy!! Normal prices.

Don't visit on an already full stomach. We visited after a rather large breakfast, so weren't up to trying any of the food outlets, but there are loads to choose from and the food that we saw others eating all looked pretty good. Next door is an indoor market with a huge range of fish, meat, fruit & veg, and plant stalls, which is well worth a look for the vibrant colours and (not unpleasant) smells.

Wide variety great experience. This reminded me of little Italy in New York or something that you might across in New York. An open market that serves a wide range of food. Great experience for a casual quick lunch outing.
Loved it!. Spoilt for choice. Top chefs of Portugal cooking up the most fantastic food! Huge variety of stalls. Top class food

Nice environment and great food!. For the travellers that have been to NYC, the Time Out Market resembles Eataly, with one part dedicated to a market. The other half has different restaurants that offer several types of food. From sushi to traditional Portuguese food, you can have a very nice meal for a fair price. There are also options for drinks. However, be sure to get there soon or be patient when looking for a seat, the place gets really full.

A great treat for Food Lovers. A smorgasboard of different food outlets under one roof, TIME OUT offers a unique ambiance in an old market place. Bustling with clients at all hours of the day one can enjoy a variety of foods to suit every palate from pizzas to organic foods to fresh fruit juices, the list is endless. With a common sitting area, everyone in the group can get their own food (while one in the group has to be assigned to secure a table, which can be a daunting task).

A must place to go!!!. We loved it from the first look around. Hundreds of people sitting from morning till midnight and having the fun of their life! We recommand on silva comfot food, its fresh, welldone and full tastes.

Good in a pinch. It is a really interesting space and it was fun to wander around and look at the different stalls. We were glad to stumble in out of the heat and found the choice of wines by the glass good value. But better food can be found elsewhere for much, much less.

Choices! Choices! Choices!. I accidentally stumbled into Time Out Market and I'm glad I did. I was taking an uber from Belem to the city center, but ended up getting out of the uber early as traffic was horrific and I was starving. My uber driver told me Time Out Market was good. There were so many choices to eat, cute little market shops and I noticed they teach cooking classes in the center. I would have loved to have taken a cooking class. The food was great. It's set up cafeteria style, so you get to share the giant bar height tables with strangers, which is half the fun. It was crowded, but worth having so many options.

Gotta Eat Here. You can get exactly what you want to eat any time of day without waiting for restaurant to open at the "right" time for lunch or dinner. It is always packed. You can see what you get before hand.

Something for Everyone. This is a busy market that has everything you need in one place. Fresh food if you want to stock up or just pick a vendor and eat in the Time Out area. Too many choices to list but well worth the visit!

Very busy. Lots of food stalls to walk around and find what you want to eat, then find a table somewhere and enjoy. However when I was there it is so busy there were no seats.I didnt fancy ordering food and walking round with it. However it all looked amazing. So would suggest to give it a try but try and avoid the busier times.

Curiosity. This is a very surprising aria to visit, a good selection of little restaurants who offervery good fast food for a very reasonable price.If You select one of the top Chefs from Lisbon who have a little restaurant there, the quality is super.Very very good

A thousand delights under one roof!. This is an absolute must when visiting Lisbon! The Time Out Market is filled to the brim with pop up's belonging to Lisbon's finest chefs/food establishments. We were so overwhelmed with all of the choice that we went back three times during our one week visit to Lisbon. The beef tartar was among the best we have ever had. And pay the Ginga stand a visit (Ginga is a delicious cherry liqueur drink drunk by the lcoals). There should be more Time Out markets like this across the world.

Food heaven. Came to Lisbon on the last stop of a 13 night Med cruise. We were handed a map at the port which was sponsored by Time Out Market Lisboa, and being big food fans, decided to visit.It's in an oldish building. There is a traditional market on right side selling meat, fish and flowers and the modern Time Out Market is on the left.It is like foodie heaven when you walk in, small outlets/restaurants all around the outside with tables in the middle. There is something for everyone, from traditional Portuguese to Italian and Oriental. You order your food at your chosen outlet and are given a little buzzer. You go find a seat and collect your food when your buzzer goes off. It looked busy on arrival but there were plenty of seats once you walked around. There were stands selling beer, wine and cocktails amongst the seats.Because we only had the day in Lisboa, I kind of wish I had tried some more traditional food in the winding Lisboan streets. However, that's not to say I didn't enjoy the food and experience of the market, which I recommend highly!

Great place.... ...to get something to eat if you're out with a bunch of friends and can't decide what to eat.Great offer from Sushi to Iberico to Pizza and Burger. Desserts... beer and wine. We were about 30 and everyone left happy and full for the night out. The more the better, so you get the chance to taste most of it!Too bad, that we only get there once.

Weekend trip. This place was great it has a fresh food market in one side and a cooked food market in the other but very trendy and up market food with really top chefs. Really lovely place. We found it very head to find but we went really looking for that we were looking for a different market and we're sieved to this. It was actually just by the train /tube station.

Good Collection of All Restaurants. I had my lunch here. There are different kinds of restaurants and there is always something good you find to eat. There is a common area and all restaurants are around you. Of course, besides restaurants, there are wine bars, Gin Stations, ice cream shops and butcher's. Good to eat there once.
A Must to visit. Great place - maybe little too crowded, but no wonder, because the variety of food and drinks you can get there is amazing. We've tried several places and we weren't disspointed.
Good times!. Though crowded much of the time, the menu choices are divine. Highly recommend the Tartar-IA (fresh and yummy!). The Eclairs are to dye for!
a must to see and to eat. Time out market Lisboa is a must to see and to eat. If you come later in the afternoon, it is less crowded.

Hang out here anytime.. Really interesting top quality restaurant/produce food hall concept with lots of 'stalls' provided by local names offering take away food that can be eaten at the many communal tables in the central area.

For the masses. Being that we arrived late and the host of our apartment suggested going here we did. The concept is great. Big sharing tables with the choice of all types of food. It felt a bit like it was made for the masses and also its all a bit on the pricey side.
Amazing place !!!. This place is a blast :) so many good restaurants in one place !!! Love it!! Seafood, burgers , pasta ... desserts :)

Great food and wine....really crowded.. This is a must visit if you're in the Chiado district. Great food, beer and wine. My only gripe is that finding a seat is cut throat at busy times. The kids loved it here.
Great buzzy place to eat. Timeout market has so many options for eating and drinking. It seems to be popular with locals and tourists alike. Very enjoyable.

Buzzing!. Timeout is so fantastic. Filled with people and lots of great food and drink choices. Sometimes it is hard to find a seat though. We loved it so much we visited twice. We had excellent sushi, amazing seafood and we bought some great wine and port from the bottle shop. Highly recommend a visit when in wonderful Lisbon.

Busy, Fun and Yummy Food. Visited on a Friday night and arrived at around 9pm. The place was packed with both tourists and locals so we had to hover about a bit until we found a place for 4people to sit but it gave us plenty of time to survey all of the food options. The atmosphere is very buzzy and there are tons of options to choose from. I have been visiting Lisbon for 8 years now so it was really great to see a new place thriving with local small businesses offering something new and exciting and regenerating an old market that was previously not in such a good state of repair. Once you have filled your belly there are plenty of good bars within a short walk in the Cais Dos Sodres area which was very lively on a Friday night and would rival Bairro Alto - it seems this is now the place to go for a night out.

A great experience in Lisbon. Experienced the culinary side of Lisbon, with some great chefs serving amazing food. The experience is great, with so many well known cafes serving food and drinks at a single place.

A most. During your stay in Lisbon if you re a foodie this place is yours. Although at lunch time it is packed you find a nice variety of different local and fusion food to taste. Make sure to pass by once during your walk around the city....

Must go for a bit of tasty fun. I just loved the concept. The best food is from the back 4 outlets. Try a dish from each. Very well organized and clean given the numbers they pump through. The black risotto was my highlight.

Fresh, fast and fabulous food. We stumbled across the Time Out Market - fortunately as we were just turning our minds to lunch! It is a large venue with many different food vendors, catering for a huge variety of tastes. There are plenty of benches to sit at to eat and drink (although we were there for an early lunch so I would expect it to get busier later).The venue is bright, airy and clean and our food was fantastic. We also had a lovely glass of wine afterwards. A great place to visit when in Lisbon

A very good experience with high quality food. At this venue there are a number of resaturants with a common seating area we very much enjoyed the atmosphere and had very good lunch at very reasonable prices.It is a place you should visit when in Lisboa, everyone an find the right dish for him.

This is a place for tourist but it's worth a visit. Yes it's Time Out and it's a known website for restaurant recommendations, however there's at least 20 different stalls inside that sells all varieties of food. Expect Portuguese, charcuterie, cheeses, seafood, sushi, burgers, tartare, beer and wine stalls. It's also next to the Chas Do Sodre stop so it's very easy to stop by and grab a quick bite or a quick drink before exploring chiado and Bairro Alto.

Our daily "go to" for all meals. We were lucky enough to have Time Out around the corner from our apartment so went for most meals. The concept is basically a high end food court. Many different cuisines options in addition to alcohol and desserts. Outdoor seating and more casual indoor seating is available. Some menu's include english while I also found that I needed to ask for an english menu. ATM also on sight and also a place to try the famous cherry liquor in a chocolate cup.

Dine here for variety of top restaurants . Timeout market is located opposite to Cais do Sodre metro. A minute walk u will find many popular restaurants are here, free seating with many variety of foods, beverage and WC (free). Open from Thursday to Saturday 10.00 to 02.00, Sunday to Wednesday 10.00 to 00.00. If u wish to try many different type of dishes, or dine with a bunch of friends, here is a good place. Some people comment pricy, I would say u can't compare with street foods because some of the stores are cooking with famous chef and a proper restaurant, only different is you can't dine in a proper restaurants feel and romantic atmosphere but the whole environment is not bad. Worth trying!

Great!. Great food, very nice people! It is a little bit hard to find food if you are vegan, but it is possible. The market is a place where you just forget the outside and you come into a whole different world. It's great!

I could live there!!!. Even if you only remotely like food, you should not miss this. Now, if you are a serious foodie, you must plan a trip to Lisbon just to visit it! Go early (it opens at 10am) to avoid the crowd, and you will be spoiled for choice: meat, fish, seafood, sushi, tartares, burgers, wine bar, gin bar, beer bar, coffee bar, and the list goes on. I'm definitely going back!!!

A must for food lovers. This market is incredible. There are stalls selling everything from pizzas to sushi, fish and meat dishes, desserts, beers wines, smoothies, you name it.
You buy from the stalls and sit at bench type tables in the open hall.
Best time to visit is for lunch.

Great place for a drink or bite to eat.. This food hall has a huge selection of foods available ranging from local Portuguese to East Asian. Visited for a dink in the afternoon which was fairly busy, then returned for dinner. A great place if you're in a group and want to have different types of food and drinks. The place was buzzing in the evening. It's totally worth having a good walk around to decide what you want to eat before hunting down a place to sit. You may have to go in shifts to get your meals as your spot at the table will go in seconds. Although this seems to be a tourist hot spot, the value for money and quality of the food produced was great. I'm sure you get great food from all the stands, but I highly recommend Asian Lab. Well worth a visit if you're having one of those evenings where you can't be bothered choosing a restaurant for the evening.

Fabulous Fine!!. If and when you are in Lisbon, this place is a must on your agenda, for whatever you may feel like. It is a self service kind of place and you sit where you can find a seat, so great for people watching! BUT mostly come here for the excellent food and drink choices. A variety of vendors (some exclusive restaurants included) are present and everything is fresh, and delicious! Definitely a highlight of my Lisbon experience and would go back daily if I could... You can pick up a quick bite or spend a leisurely afternoon just sampling a starter, main and dessert from different vendors. Busy, but a fabulous atmosphere!

Vibrant and interesting place for lunch. It might get a bit overwhelming as there are plenty places you choose from to eat. We tried a seafood place outside first (razor clams and fried squid on photos) and enjoyed the food but it does not have the atmoaphere of the inside food market. Then went in and tried Henrique sa Pessoa. I can recommend highly. Delicoius fresh produce - we had the fish and mango salad with salmon roe - amazing! Dont miss the top floor - in August they had a pop up arts market. You can also find great views from there onto the food hall so worth a visit.

Quality food worth paying for without costing alot. Wondered around twice picking out what to eat, picked this nice one on the corner offering Ox burger with fries. Being gourmet It was not a burger in a bun and the chips werent just boring chips.... the ox burger alone had so much flavour and taste its better than any london restaurants I have had. Was the food highlight of my entire Lisbon trip, wine is cheap too! In short....affordable, high quality, excellent location near the centre of Lisbon, not crazy crammed, food with flavours!
Great place to eat. If you love food and people this is the place to go. We came for the dessert, but next time we will definitively come for the full experience....

It's right in the heart of the center Lisbon. Hot outside? No problem!. Hot outside? No problem! This place is right here - where you enjoy undiscovered Portugal's history. A drink or two of a wonderful Portuguese wine will inject fresh power in you!

Excellent venue. It's called a market but it's not like any market I've been to.It's a warehouse type building with restaurant kitchens all around the perimeter . Great long tables and stools in the middle . There are also wine, beer, coffee and dessert vendors.The food we tasted was really good,so good that we ate there3 times. Some top notch chefs have a kitchen here. Good prices too.
Great Food market. We stopped here a couple of times for meals, lots of various vendors to choose from with different types of food.

Great place for food. While this is very touristy, we did actually have good food and there is a good variety of food. It was also good to get local products to take home. So worth checking out. Also the area where it is is nice to walk around in.

Great Food, Hectic Setting. We enjoyed seeing the variety of restaurant options and the one we settled on was great. Problem was because of the crowds, it was difficult to find seating for a group of eight. We were able to sit together for dessert. Great flower stalls and easy to get to location.
Perfect food and lovely ambient. Wonderful atmosphere filled with smell of delicious food and tasty Portuguese vines! Perfect tourist spot and remarkable memory!

Tourist trap!. Full of slightly anxious tourists. Why go there when the area around Cais De Sdre is brimming full of great restaurants. Food not bad just the atmosphere of being inside a stuffy hall when there are superb and not so superb places offering real food prepared in real kitchens all over the area. Must suit cruise tourists!

Fantastic!!!. We loved it here!!! Great selection of very good food and drink to choose from. Everything we had was of a very good quality and reasonably priced. Henrique Sa Pessoa was our favourite and we enjoyed a delicious bacalhau dish. There is also a very nice atmosphere and vibe. We visited both lunch and dinner. Would definitely recommend.

Wonderful market and eatery . We are in Lisbon for 10 days and would come here every day there is so much to try. The quality of food is amazing and the atmosphere is great! A must visit spot while in Lisbon.

Very busy and hip place . Also known as Time Out Mercado da Ribeira, Cais do Sodré I went there on Friday night. Too many tourist and visitor make it difficult to find a seat. opened in May 2014, the new food court at Mercado da Ribeira – Lisbon's biggest fresh food market – has become a firm favourite among tourist and locals. It was originally fish, fruit and vegetable stalls on the other side of the huge 19th century building still sell their wares every day, except Sunday, until lunchtime. Good food. Hip place. Worth to visit. But be prepared to fight for sitting place.

YUM!. With so many choices, you will see your indecisiveness to the fullest! Great for quick lunch, casual eating with group of friends or family never agrees on what to eat, this place accommodates all! From light snacks to dessert you will find anything you want. A must visit place in Lisbon. My personal favourite, Tuna tartare, Portuguese octopus and of course Portuguese white wine. Yum!

WHAT A FIND!. From fresh produce to prepared food, this place is very special. We rented an apartment nearby and the fruit available was varied and excellent quality. Go early! I would say the prices are reasonable. Now for the prepared food. Yes, there are lines in the evening. This place is incredibly popular. You can dine in and sit at communal tables or bring it back to your location. Each item was prepared to order and we liked it. The chefs there are Portuguese and the cuisine is mostly that. Yes, there are Indian and Asian choices, but prepared by locals. Young and old alike are fans. Alcoholic drinks are available. The hours are long. It is open late. A great gathering place.

Take your pick!. Love this place. Several stalls of exceptional chefs with interesting menus in a food court type atmosphere. We ate here twice and had exceptional food. It's a food court, so don't expect ambience, but the food is top notch! Love this place!

Great vibe. My wife and I love this market. My wife loves the eating and drinking area and the choice and quality is superb. I love the traditional market side with all the fish.In terms of eating I prefer to have snacks here during the day rather than having a full meal.If in Lisbon you should come here fr both atmosphere and food quality.

Fascinating market with excellent food choices. Excellent market with a very modern food hall where you can choose from a variety of food outlets by a number of well known chefs. A really good way for them to showcase their dishes and with good choices of wine.
Lack of atmosfere . Nice food, but really big and quite expensive. When net so buisy it lacks atmosfere. Not so great for vegetarians.

'Organic Market' - rip off!. I came to the organic market tempted by their juice. I watched it being made, it contained literally one pinch of spinach, a slice of lemon no more than 2mm thick, less than half a teaspoon of ginger, and a slice of pineapple, with water. This cost €4.50 (+50c to take away). All I could taste was watered down pineapple, not a touch of ginger. It was such a dissapointment. I was tempted to refuse to accept but it was the end of the day and I was in no mood for an argument. Won't be going back!

Referred by a friend, not disapointed. Our friend told us we absolutely had to try the Ribeira market (which houses the Time Out market) so we went there for lunch. IMPORTANT TO NOTE: Portuguese people have their lunch breaks from 2 to 3pm, so try not to go within those times (we didn't know...) And they have dinner later than North Americans so try to go before 9pm. We had the cod gratine with veggies at Henriaur Sa Pessoa and it was delicious, then we went back for dinner and we were desperate for a salad (oddly we didn't come by many during our 3 week trip) and found salads were only available at Cafe de Sao Bento, it definitely did the trick!

Great place to eat. So why only 4 stars? The only problem is that everybody wants to take a bite. Place is over crowded. Have to wait in line to order food and then wait 15-20 minutes to go get the food and also also wait for a free table to eat your food. You spend a lot of rime waiting. But the food is good. Not expensive and not cheap.

A must visit. Any and everyone who visits Lisbon must visit the time out market at least once. I was delighted with the variety of food. There was just any and every kind of cuisine available. I went in for the catch of the day fromone counter which was grilled seabass with some vegetables. Also the goat cheese salad is a delicay here. Desserts were too good but i had my favourite chocolate cake. On my second visit I ate cod fish burger and was not disappointed at all. The place was packed and we had to really look for a table.
Fantastic!. A must see and eat. This hidden oasis is right off the waterfront. We went back again and again. Well done!

Great buzzing atmosphere with so much choice!. A lot like Spitalfields market in London, the Time Out market has a great atmosphere, is always busy and every choice of global street food you could possibly ask for! There are traditional Portuguese meats and cheeses, there are Indian and Thai curries, and seafood there are sandwich bars and gourmet pizza and burger stall. There are places you can get snacks and places to get full meals with bottles of wine. There are stands with alcoholic cocktails and fresh fruit smoothies and also bakeries with Portuguese and french treats. We stopped here for lunch and had a charcuterie board of meats and cheeses and breads to start and also chicken Pad Thai noodles. We accompanied that with freshly squeezed orange juice and strawberry smoothies. An odd mix but anything goes in this place!You just find somewhere to sit (you may have to do a lap or two) and then go and order whatever you fancy! (you could order first but then you risk not being able to sit down when you have already bought food.

A Cornucopia of Culinary Delights. Terrific concept near the docks at Barrio Alto. A fully functioning market under a steel canopy roof, one side of which has been opened to a cafeteria style central refectory to which you bring the food you have ordered from counters manned by well-known restauranteurs. All these chefs also serve drinks. A little pricey per portion, but delicious!

Nice place to visit and try Portugese cuisine. Located at the railway station (end station of green Metro line, Cais do Sodré). However it is a market, prices are above average. We just tried a few snacks here but normal lunch seemed quite delicious. Worth to visit, even if you just want to grab something or want to have a proper lunch/dinner.

You'll come back . This was a brilliant discovery. We walked in to find first a fresh fish and fruit and vegetable market but in the other side was a wonderful space of food, drink, social gathering and fun. All the food is wonderful and is a true cross section of Portuguese and international cuisine. Of course the pato Negro always wins. In terms of drinks there are 8-10 specialty bars serving Cocktails, wine, tequila. Gin. Juices and more. You may even get lucky with someone serving a fizzy mixed berry sangria. Slightly in the pricier side of things though
A must. It's a must stop for all the foodies in town! The different restaurants and food choices are spectacular! For desert, you must have a gelato at Santini's. Enjoy!

Average gourmet food court. Had high expectations but was disappointed. We ordered 2 steaks from the "best steak" cafe in Lisbon - asked for medium but came out more on the rare side (17 euros each). We came again and bought salmon and risotto (9-11 euros each) - 4 shrimps for the prawn risotto and basil risotto was not flavourful. It is busy and is a nice experience (with many different choices from drinks, dessert to mains) but do not expect restaurant gourmet food or cosy portugese feel. They cater to the hundreds so the food is "fast gourmet".

Amazing choice.. Great atmosphere! . We met friends here and were amazed by the great selection of top class food and drink that was available. Even if you don't want to eat go for a look! Food was fantastic and reasonably priced! Great spot!

FABULOUS!!!!!!. I was shocked when I saw this Eating Emporium!!!It is fabulous, great vibe and great food. Many restaurants and lots if seating area. Late nights and very late on weekends with Fado music! A must see in my opinion. I loved being there!
Must see. Huge hall with tons of different food varieties. A little over crowded and higher pricing for getting a taste. Some experimental food creations.

Wow. We didn't eat here because we just had dinner but strolling through was fun. There is an incredible variety of food stalls, from traditional to comfort food to pastry stalls and even a hot dog stand. The place was packed and the people seemed to be enjoying themselves. Prices seemed reasonable and wine and beer were served in glass. Very elegant but obviously very popular.

Good food for sure, but a bit of a zoo!. As the title suggests, if you are patient or not in a big hurry, there's a wide variety of food to sample and share with friends at long tables. We happened to stop by about 1 pm, and the lines to the favorite restaurants were long, as were the waits for seats at tables. If you want to see the local produce and wares market in action, you need to come in the morning.

loved it. we went back here twice because we loved it so much and were staying within a 5 minute walking distance (which was quite fortunate). Highly recommend the seafood rice (or prawn rice) from Marlene Vieira and the suckling pork from Henrique Sa Pessoa. They will blow you away especially the suckling pork! It gets to be quite busy so on the second day, we went early (around 11:30 AM) an started lining up when they opened for noon. love the feel of the place too. quite bustling and jovial.
Brilliant!. Absolutely brilliant! A very modern place to eat where they have something for everyone: burgers, fish, beef,pork, beers wines desery amd the list can go on. A must see

Alexandre Silva no Mercado. Spoilt for choice as to which establishment to buy from. You can have a starter at one outlet, a main from another and a dessert from yet another. Drinks are available at many stalls. We tried 3 outlets and the winner was Alexandre Silva.I liked the vibrating flashing informer device you are given to let you know when to return to the outlet to collect your food.
Lively place for foodies. Absolutely loved this place. so much variety, so many great places to eat. got to try food from celebrity chefs and drink great wine. It's a must for food lovers.
Excellent selections. This is basically 5 star dining on the cheap. You can easily try several different chefs and everything was excellent.
A great find. loads of food and drink to choose from even variety of markets to shop at. only point very busy can get difficult finding seats at rush times

Good Food Selection at Time Out Market. The atmosphere is good, noise level perhaps too high. Good selection of food from the many different vendors. Mainly tourists were eating there, but well worth a visit when visiting Lisbon

Great Choices Here. There must be 50 food stalls at this market offering a wide variety of Portuguese food and wine items. It's all here from meats, vegetables, pastries and chocolates. You pick what you like and eat it in the central food court.

Varied and delicious food. I visited, having got off the blue line of the yellow bus tour at about 3.30pm. I did a circuit and then went back to to a place for a salad (not massive) mango, avocado, salmon roe and a raw fish whose name escapes me plus a glass of blanc de blanc (E5) all in total was E9.5.I wandered on and bought a custard doughnut (massive and E1.5). Communal eating in shared tables (low and high). Great quality, variety and good prices (not cheap but not expensive).I'd love to stay nearby to eat every meal there.
Variety of food and more. U can pretty much find everything here: burgers, fresh fish and shushi, fish and chips, steaks, desserts and traditional portuguese objects. Fair prices! Must try!

A bit manic. Interesting concept- various restaurants have set up stalls with a few of the remaining food and flower shops. You have to order at the counter of your chosen restaurant/food type and then eat at communal (small and large) tables in the centre. There's a few touristy stores too.All creating a noisy and chaotic experience! There's a very good and proper restaurant on the first floor - Pap'acorda ! Check it out!

Brilliant spot. Called in here after reading up on the reviews and must say it is a lively place with some brilliant places to eat. Anyone who visits will be sure to find something that suits their eating or drinking needs.

Lots of good food in one place. This is a very large collection of food and drink providers all in one place. Its really nice to observe the different types of food that Lisbon has created all available together.Obviously the food and drinks are slightly more expensive than available locally but there are a few people who all want to get different food and drinks but want to eat together the market is ideal. The food is generally very good and the market is well worth a visit.

Something for everyone. A gigantic food court next to a busy inside food market. There were so many different foods to choose from, I wanted to come here every day... It is very noisy, so no intimate dinners here. But perfect for a family with many different tastes.

Mediterranean kind of food hall. To be honest, this is not really special in my personal view but it was nice. It is just like any other food hall that can be found anywhere in Bangkok but with Mediterranean style. A good experience still.

Perfect lunch to kick off our Lisbon city break. Great food market serving restaurant, quality gourmet meals in a hipster food hall manner.Had our first lunch in Lisbon at Marlene Vieira on the 2 course and drink deal. The roasted veal was delicious, very tender + well seasoned- plus apple pie dessert was yummy. Excellent value.Can't wait to return to try some of the other food stalls.

Massive Crowd. Went to this place at 3 pm on a Sunday figuring the lunch crown would have dissipate but was I wrong. You could not find a place to sit. The crowd was enormous. Other than that great place for food.

So much to choose. Approximately 30 restaurants sell food. You can choose one item from several restaurants. Share different dishes with your friends. Seating is limited so grab a spot and hang on to it. On a Saturday night the seats are quite competitive.
Great high-end meal for cheap!. My husband and I had such a fun time going from booth to booth, and the food is restaurant quality. So fun!
Excellent Food and Great Athmosphere. So much choice of really tasty fresh food, something for everyone, real good buzz about this place, would definitely go again.
Great place. So much choice that you can come back for lunch all weekend. Inexpensive decent wines which means you can easily lose a few hours too.

Must see and experience. Half of this place is the usual Market de Ribeira, interesting and tasty...part of it they turned into this fancy food court - lots of offers, pricey but worthwhile and most importantnly the atmosphere is great. We were around lunchtime on a weekday and it was full of people, so it was interesting for people watching, but a bit overwhelming in terms of choosing a dish and taking the time to window shop. woould love to go back at a quieter time
Food Fare. Excellent quality food at reasonable prices, but can get very busy during the day and night. Lots of variety of things to eat no one could complain.
Great selection. This place is worth a visit, it's got a great selection of places to eat.Worth a trip for tasty grub,slightly more expensive than usual
Fun, fun. A very fun and happening place. Lots of great choices in food & drinks. Seems always crowded with people. The chefs are amazing in their variety of food selections and presentation.

Great options. Pretty much everything you would expect food and drink wise in Lisbon. Great choices. Great buzz about the place in the evening. Can be a bit of a struggle to get seating around 8 or 9. I was on my own and found it hard to get 1 seat. Would definitely be hard with a group of 4 or more. Get there at 7 and spend a few hours trying the different options and soaking up the atmosphere.
Fun place to hangout. Loud place, but great experience for being in a room filled with people. A few vegetarian options inside -- check out the Asian place, Portuguese pumpkin rice, etc.

Market. The proverbial "you can get whatever you want " ice cream, wine, lunch, beer, hunk-o-meat, cakes & pastry, everything else! We just came for ice cream, and it was the best ever! Great place to start from or meet at! Close to metro, tram, and train!

Great place to visit to get an enormous set of food choices in one go. This is set up like a basic food court but don't be put off by that.
