The food quality is very high -- I ate at a Seafood place called Azul (separate review) but also snacked at two other spots: one that serves croquettes and another that serves roast suckling pick with crispy skin on a roll with freshly made potato chips!

Worth a visit, great for groups struggling to decide where to eat - so much choice.. We hit the Time Out market at a non-peak time; 17:00 or so - so it was reasonably quiet - plenty of space for us to sit and we were able to sample a couple of the food spots in quite a short space of time - no queues.We ordered small plates from a number of places and enjoyed everything - drank some, ate some more and left after a couple of very enjoyable hours.The Asian Lab Vietnamese spring rolls were a highlight.The pizza place did Somersby cider which was a nice change from the Super Bock - and their pizza was damn fine too.Great for groups having a problem deciding on where to go to eat!We enjoyed going at a non-peak time rather than when it was very very busy later in the evening,

"A Little Bit of Contemporary in an Historical Town". Loved this place. A traditional market place feel with a modern contemporary twist. A variety of different eating places under one roof. A canteen style seating arrangement which on our two visits was very busy and we struggled to get seated but finally managed after about 5 minutes of wandering around. What I loved the most was all the different food choices. Prices varied from budget to high end so something affordable for everyone.
Good traditional market & food. Must visit & enjoy traditional gourmet food. Great wine and cutting edge culture...well priced for foodies travelers
Yummy!. I would suggest go there before noon so it's not so crowded. Lots of tasty food to enjoy. As the dishes are not so big, you can try many varieties.

Nice although bit commercial food market. Nice place with a large choice of different food.
Prices sometimes high when compared to the rest of Lisbon. Nevertheless we had great hams, nice wine , great oysters and nice croquettas

Some of the best restaurants in Lisbon all in one place!. This place is one of the best ideas somebody ever had. Inside an old fish and vegetables market now lie small spaces representing some of the best restaurants in Lisbon. By walking 20m you can go from the best steak in town to sushi, or southern specialities. A place to go, preferably for lunch or dinner on week days. There is really a lot of people for dinner on weekends.

Typical Time Out ruining things. The sole reason we ate here was because we had just arrived and it was opposite where we stayed.The croquettes were great but anything else we ate was mediocre and half hearted. Typical of Time Out places really - killing the authenticity and soul.
Tasteful, delicious, trendy!. A must go place to visit in Lisbon. All types of snacks and delicious meals. The location is amazing and the prices are reasonable. A must go-to place when in Lisbon!
Fun, must visit. If you are in Lisbon , do not miss this. An evening of good tapas, porto, wine, warm food, live music and free WiFi.

Busy spot for a stop. Had an early morning coffee here as the different stalls prepared for the day and decided to pop back for lunch and a beer.There was plenty of choice and we enjoyed watching what others brought to the communal benches almost as much as our own selection.
Very cool food court !. This food court isn't like any normal food court, it has many different options from different chefs, it's trendy and modern, loved it !
Great place to try different food.. I have to say I loved this place. It's a foodie's heaven. It can be expensive so make sure you have a good walk around before you choose. Enjoy

A cheap , convenient, economical way to enjoy Seafood lunch, dinner or any local food.. Take the tram back, get off at the Time Out Market Lisboa, cross the street and you will see all the food stalls you could see and pick whichever you grave for.Besides that, in case you don't want to eat there. Go to the fish, seafood stalls - they are fresh and weigh by kilos so you could bring to the hotels with kitchen allowed, Enjoy the best seafood steamed, grilled..........I love their seafood.
Soo sooo good, nice and lively <3. Everything we ate here was delicious! Could me a little bit less expensive but ok. You must try curry at ASIAN LAB <3
Nice and noisy. Nice place. But very touristic and popular. Very crowded, so very noisy. I wait 30 minutes for my lunch.

Excellent food for great price. This is an excellent place to eat in Lisbon and albeit has a touristy feeling locals like it too. You have a wide selection of "restaurants" to choose from and they offer everything from the famous codfish to Asian flavours so please walk around the place before deciding what you'll order. The average price for a plate and a bottle of water is about 12€. The place is quite busy in the weekend evenings so even though you get your food fast you might not find a place to sit very easily. And the most important part: their WiFi works perfectly. ;)
Great food experience . Must visit, must try. Great place if you want to taste great flavours. Nice atmosphere, good location and various of choice. Grilled octopus salad is highly recommended.

Great variety of excellent eats!. We went to the Time Out Market for lunch on our last day in Lisbon. It wasn't quite what we were expecting - we had visions of the Boqueria Market in Barcelona - as it is extremely modern. This said, it was a great eating experience. It's essentially a glorified Food Court - but it is glorious. We were able to sample a number of dishes from a number of vendors. The Sardine Nigiri from Sea Me was my favourite. You can also enjoy a variety of beers & wines - not your average food court.One warning - this isn't a cheap meal. We spend a fair bit of $$$, but the food was excellent. Enjoy!

Great place to grab a bite to eat. Lots of different food vendors. Yes there are a lot of tourists here, just like there are in most of Lisbon's central area. But the food is really good and is a decent price. You can try a lot of different Portuguese specialties there and all the food we had was good.
Just a Word.... woooow. . So many options From all over the World. Excellent portugues food. Very clean, well located. You have everyting in Just one place. We'll be back.

Good food but so touristy . The food is great (mostly a selection of chef food) but the ambience is very touristy. The market has little Portuguese charm that you would otherwise find in a local taverna or pasteleria. Also expect to pay more for the food because of the Time Out badge.

If you're vegetarian don't bother!. There must be around 40 stalls but nothing decent for vegetarians... I went with a group thinking it would be an easy win to suit everyone as being veggie I can be a nightmare to feed in Portugal (but this is Lisbon right... surely...).What a total disappointment as there was only one stall I could eat at (sold a small selection of bio food but can't remember the name) and it wasn't good at all and really expensive!I make it harder being intolerant to gluten, but I think the only other options for veggies was pizza anyway. If you are a carnivore you'll enjoy the market more. Wake up to veggies and healthy people please Portugal! - take a leap out of Cape Town's books as their food markets are a whole lot better! :(

A perfect place. Very nice atmospher, the food is excellent and a lot of places to choose from. The setup is small shops/restaurants with a veriety of different cuisines. Start with something small, perhaps oyster, go for something else as main or mains then finish of with something nice as a desert. There is also i big selection of wines, beers etc. and should definitely finish with a glas of bottle of madaira.
Fab Food. Great choice of food at great prices. Just sit next to anyone else from around the world. Loved it. Around 15 Euros for main dish of salted cod with chickpea purée. Divine.

Crowded place. The food is nice! Only it is an commercialized place, so crowded, expensive and long waiting time to order and get your food. in the evening, it is fighting for chairs, so if you are lucky you can eat standing somewhere on a table paying 50% more than in a restaurant around the corner
Tourist Trap for Lunch. Quality varies between stalls and you must look around, expensive, touristy, no locals eat here. Would not reccomend

Superior food court. Let's be clear- this IS a food court so be prepared for hustle and bustle, difficulty finding seating at peak times ,eating off trays and a noisy atmosphere.Not a relaxing venue but worth the effort.We went at 8.30pm on a Tues to find it rammed,so finding seating ( communal benches) was a problem. You can choose from 20 or so good quality food outlets catering for all tastes but at busy times like ours the one holding the seats can be alone for extended periods while the other is queueing to order.The more you diversify the choice the longer the ordering process. Some outlets give you a buzzer to let you know when the food is ready but others expect you to wait.We got starters first , identified main courses then found seating.I had a bad experience , twice, at Sea Me , a rated seafood stand where a young staffer lacked basic server skills when he completely ignored me when I tried to buy wine ( he started cashing up the till in front of me, which took ages, and not once did he look up and acknowledge my presence) and again later when I wanted food. He clearly did not 'see me' on either occasion! But our other food experience was good despite queues at popular stalls. Food was a little pricey but very good quality.Very popular with larger groups ( couples tend to get estranged as mentioned earlier!) and young set, it is to be experienced at least once.At some stalls you can sit at the counter at the back, so it is worth a good look round before finalising choices.

We have already visited 3 times during a 4 day trip!. This food hall has it all. Top Lisbon restaurants offering signature dishes less than the regular prices. Fresh seafood, local dishes, a chance to mix and match to suit all budgets. Busy each time we went but doesn't take long to locate a seat and then take it in turns to venture forth & return with all manor of interesting dishes.A MUST when visiting Lisbon!

Stumbled upon this gem. We randomly walked by this market and wandered in. Half of it is a "regular" market, and the other half has been converted to a high end food court of all of the best restaurants in the city. We ended up coming back a second time because the food and atmosphere was so good.

The ideal place for foodies. Plenty of variety, good service and very close to the central areas of Lisbon. A one stop shop for naughty natas, Portuguese specialities, cocktails, patisserie and even thai food! Would have visited more times if we'd found this place sooner. The toilets are quite grim though so make sure you take your own tissue.

One of the best place to have a meal!. We went without expectation about el Mercado da Ribeira, and was perfect because we were very well surprised of the Time out Market. We discover that 5 of the best chef of Portugal have a restaurant there!

Saturday lunch. We visited on a busy Saturday but had no problem getting seating for 4. Boys had Superbock from self service bar and girls stayed with vino verde. We tried a selection of tapas and all were good. It's a lively spot and good for people watching.
Great food and little stalls. Especially the place to buy sardines is good. It kind of has an American food court mall feel to it but it is definitely worth a trip.

verry funy and typical. You'll have there all you need to spend a good evening with friends or in couple.
Everything is possible up there.

Great place for a quick bite while in the area. Yesterday, we were in Cais Sodre on a search for crepes and were headed to a nearby french restaurant when we stumbled upon this place. We found crepes and so much more. The food options are plentiful, which made it hard to decide on a lunch spot. There is a chef's table in the market which would allow you to sample a food from a few different stalls, but we settled on chow mein at an Asian spot (forgot the name), with fresh squeezed juice from the juice bar, followed by crepes from the ice cream shop. We left full and happy without breaking the bank. Recommend.
Good place to eat on a rainy day. A good selection of restaurants and bars. The quality of food is good but it can get too noisy as it has too many seating places.

Take Time Out for Time Out. This is a welcome addition to the Lisbon eating scene, offering a buzzy street-food vibe to a beautiful old market building by the railway station do sodre. It's a vast room with high, vaulted ceilings with long, high tables running the length of the space. Around the perimeter are perhaps fifty pop-up restaurants offering everything from Asian food to Ceviche fish dishes. We chose Confraria, selling the best, juicy and messy burgers with fries and a beer. You may need hosing down afterwards, but great flavours at a reasonable price. There's several bars dotted about specialising in wine; beer, gin and Lisbon's famous ginja – a sticky cherry brandy. Atmosphere is great and the seating encourages conversation. Great place for a quick bite and engaging environment – recommended.

Overcrowded and noisy but they serve great food!!!. It is definitely worth going, at least once. Locals say that this place is overpriced. But any other touristy place in the center of Lisbon has very similar pricing, and very often much worse food. I highly recommend ox burger or black rice with scallops with a glass of wine at Alexander Silva stand (north left corner). The price of the meal plus glass of wine was around 11-13 EUR.

Huge variety of food in a nice setting. Excellent place if you fancy trying different foods. The setting is not optimal for large groups as getting food scatters the group. Getting beer was cumbersome, better order drinks with your food. Nice experience though and the main reason to go (food) was very good.
Eating. Loved this place, great atmosphere and not expensive, should meet everyones tastes. Can get there by metro, bus, tram.
Good place to eat . This is a very good place to eat. Clean environment with a nice variety of restraunts. Timeout market stays open till 0030

So good, went there 3 nights. Being a vegan in Lisbon is like finding a needle in a haystack....impossible!! However this delicious gem offered food for everyone, any age and with multiple food choices you will never leave without a full belly.

Everyone's happy!. You can find most types of food at this market. Asian, seafood, gourmet sandwiches... you name it. We went on a weekday for lunch and it was perfectly busy (enough to keep you entertained and feel the bustle but not enough to get annoying and not find a table). The food we tried was amazing too!! Everything everyone was eating looked good to be honest.

Food just ok and closed seating area. We ordered several dishes, all were just ok. It was also stuffy inside and I definitely would recommend dining with an outside seating area on a beautiful Lisboan summer night.

Yummy grub. Essentially a collection of street style food vendors serving restaurant quality food on a tray. You then go sit down at one of the numerous long tables, but prepare for a wait as seating is in short supply.I had the cod fish omelette from the "Portuguese" named vendor, which was delicious. The fruit juice vendor however, pretty much screwed the pooch with my order and so I walked away with what was essentially a liquefied mango. Not the worst thing I have ever drunk, but slightly disappointing given that times magazine has approved all these vendors.

Good concept of a food hall of dishes from around the world. Good concept of a food hall of dishes from around the world. Probably about 30 stalls serving a vast array of food and a central seating / eating area.

Very good. I was a great expirience. I was there 2 times. I had a great meal. One thing you have to know wat you want to eat because there are so may things to eat ... you will lose a lot of time to figer out wat to eat. It is a good place to find out things about portughese cooking. Very good see food.

Perfect spot for lunch / dinner with friends. I visited the market 3 times during a week stay in Lisbon - twice for dinner and once for lunch. The best thing is that everyone can find something for themselves. The food stalls range from seafood and sushi, traditional portuguese cuisine, desserts to asian food. A must try was proschiutto and ginja.

Went everyday!. The food here is 5 stars! Something delicious and gourmet for everyone. A friend of mine recommended we go here and I went back every night. A great selection of foods from some well known chefs (and not so known.) Make sure to eat here if you find yourself in Lisbon.

Excellent!. I was greately surprised by the quality of food there. It's not like a classical street market, you can actually find a food from good Portuguese chefs there. Once I ate octopus rice and the second time salmon steak tartare. Finished with excellent cakes, I cannot decide what was better to me :) I absolutely recommend it!

Wonderful place for lunch. Loved it here. Had a couple of different dishes/tapas. Finished off with warm cheese from the cheese counter with 2 glasses of red wine which we were able to try before we bought. Suits all pockets and caters for everyone

Something for Everyone. A bit hot and crowded but tons of fun. So many choices. Adults & kids will enjoy many choices. Great for couples or big groups with shared tables. Some nice cocktails and great wine. The guys at Silva have great wines and killer meats and cheeses. There are many new and established chefs offering small bites or plates. Gourmet good hall with some pedestrian items mixed in for kids or less adventrous. Check it out.
Lovely place. Lots of little (pop-up) restaurants. Acceptable prices and delicouis food. Fish, meat, pizza, sushi and desserts. Take what you want and search for a table.

Foodie's paradise!. The time out market is amazing and so delicious! So much variety and we were impressed at the quality of food and how everything was plated/presented. This is a foodie's paradise and contains food choices from all over the world. I have recommended it already to others who have visited and also rave about the food here. Hope you enjoy!

Fantastic choice. We came here for a late lunch during our visit and absolutely loved it. It was busy but we easily found seats, and we tried a number of things from different restaurants. Steak sandwich, seafood pastries, pizza slices, delicious Portuguese wine... Everything was delicious, I honestly couldn't fault it at all. Very reasonable prices, we paid from around 4-6€ for most of our dishes and the portions were mostly much bigger than expected. I wish we had had more time to go back and try all the places we wanted to! This would be on my 'must do' list for Lisbon.

Top chefs tasters. We ate here twice,for lunch and then dinner. It's a large market hall with communal seating and some 14 or so mini kitchens where the top rated Lisbon chefs provide a limited selection from their menus. Great concept. You can buy a different course from different stalls and get wine from another or get a whole meal from just one. It's busy right from lunch to midnight so you just turn up, grab some seats and choose. We loved it.

awesome market for lunch options. just too many options for food, drinks, dessert, whatever - our sandwich from one of the chef stalls was good not great but just one of the 20 other vendor options - and many looked awesome, wish had more time in lisbon to visit again

Really fun!. This was super fun, budget friendly and showcased all the great foods and wines from the region. We enjoyed special hams and cheeses with fig jams and the most delicious homemade breads. Yum!

Great variety of restaurants. The timeout market is a must go when you are is lisbon. Take the metro to cais do sodre and try the many options in the market. I'd recommend croqueteria for an appetizer, than the tartaria for a nice beef tartar. For desert grab a santini icecream, probably the best in town.
Lunch . The best things to do so many choice of food amazing AMZINING if you in Lisbon must visit top class food at very low price

Must visit place if you're in Lisbon!. We went here for lunch and were pleasantly surprised by the quality of food and range on offer. The prices are fair and the food delicious. Would recommend the eclairs to anyone with a sweet tooth. We'll definitely be back here before we leave Lisbon!

Loved it. We decided to come here early in the day to try and beat the rush. Got to time out market around 11:30. Great time to go, lines aren't long and tons of seats open. We had a great meal and loved the juice stand. Would have went back if we didn't go on our last day. And were pleasantly surprised with the prices too. My husband had the chicken chow mien from Asian Lab and it was fantastic!
Big, big food courts . It's like a big food court with lots of selection where u seat on one of the high benches/chairs where u can chat with ppl next to u and enjoy ur food
Interesting. Fresh produce, beef, pork,seafood. Numerous restaurants preparing Portugal meals. Saw similar in Buenos Aires Argentina. I like them

A gem!. Don't think of this place as just another food court! The quality is impressive - I tried 3 dishes (from two different outlets) and all three were extremely tasty. A good place to go if travelling solo. You just find a place to eat on the long tables. Great place to meet old and new friends. Really pleased to have discovered this gem!
Creative and delicious food. It's a happening place. It's noisy. It's crowded. The seats are benches. But, the food is creative, delicious, and well priced. You cannot go wrong.

Great concept - brilliantly executed. This place is a gem - it was recommended by one of many helpful Uber drivers during our trip, so we visited twice! The selection of food and drink is fantastic - largely local and all prepared on site in mostly visible kitchens. Quality looks great too, but as my wife and I are 'Vege' (Pescetarian) we didn't try many of the food types as they are largely meat-based. The highlights for us were the fresh (organic) juice bar (who also make amazing protein balls!) and the central wine bar and 'self-serve' beer bar (the only place I found in Lisbon that serves IPA).Bear in mind that lunchtimes and weekends are (very!) busy.
Great place to sample authentic Portuguese food. Delicious sampling of various Portuguese cuisine. Great prices and great assortment. I had the best Bacalhoua a Brás.

Good Food. The place has great advantages.You get to taste different types of Portuguese cuisine, taste different wines, and you will find there any type of food you can think of. Another thing is that the environment is great, music in the background, and mainly you sit with other people and if you are lucky, you will get to meet people from different countries. The only downside is that is very busy, and can take some time to find a place to sit.
Nice place... for tourists!. Authentic waste of money if you are in Lisbon. You will like the place (is a very traditional fish market), but be ready to pay London prices.

Food food food. This place is a great stop in Lisbon. There are dozens of restaurants; from Portuguese to French to Asian. There is so much diversity here that it may take you at least a good 45 minute just to decide where you will get your food from. This is a must visit! The prices were not bad either.

Foodies delight. The array of food to try is amazing. Great fun to walk around. Your eyes take in beauty of the food and your nose smells the wonderful aromas. The hardest part is what to choose to eat.
Great selection of beer wine and food. A nice food court in an old fashioned setting. It just works as everything is available under on roof

What a great idea !. So many food choices from top chefs ! It's like a mini Lisbon in one place ! If you are staying a few days , make sure you visit more than once. Apart from mini versions of top restaurants you also have your typical market with fruit & vegetables , flowers , meats, fish and seafood if you wish to cook- prices for raw produce are very low, the lowest in the city actually , so don't bother to shop in supermarket , just shop here, the fish is the freshest you can get - but show in the morning as the raw produce market closes lunch timeish!

Great food!. We went here twice during our 7 day stay in Lisbon. The food was amazing, we tried several of the restaurants between us and it was all good (restaurant quality unlike similar ventures in the UK). Pricey considering it isn't a restaurant though and does feel a little like you're paying more for the choice when you could get a cheaper meal in the more pleasant surroundings of the restaurant (I think they all have their own restaurants in Lisbon). We always found it crowded, a bit tricky to get a seat so we always made sure we found one before ordering. Convenient good 'grabby' food though and would definitely go back.

over 33 food markets in one place! Bliss. We were delighted to find this gem in the heart of Lisbon. If you love food then this is a mouth watering experience. The choice is unreal and all food looks amazing. Has to be seen to be believed

Cool. Whether taking a fine dining and making it casual or searching for street food, this market have the mission to give you the best of each city and bring it together under one roof. The market has a very special offer, top chef stands at low prices. I highly recommend going here and enjoy!

Trendy, Tasty, Traditional. Such a wonderful place to spend the day while it's getting hot in Portugal's beautiful capital. You can hang out in the market while having great local food, everything fresh and fancy, but not overpriced at all. My favorite: Check out SEA ME! Chef Denise and sous chef Gessica will make you a true believer if it comes to try sardines or the traditional Portuguese dish Bacalao. An absolute MUST SEE in Lisboa!
Eat, eat and eat. Great way to get a snap shot of the food scene in Lisbon. Take a single diah from as many places as you can!

Foodie Paradise. Wow. The food was amazing. So much variety. One could eat there every day for months and not repeat an item. I wish we had more time to spend here... And that Time Out would build one in Chicago. Had fantastic gelato and purchased sausage and cheese to take home, which was shrink wrapped in request. Highly recommended.

Such a range of tasty food.. Just a fabulous experience, with the biggest difficulty being how to narrow down your food choices! Go early or late if you want to get a seat easily, but you'll get one eventually. A real foodies paradise.
Taste buds fête . Oh my lord!Food lovers,this is the place for you...market meets all you can eat...it's a must do when decide to visit Lisbon...vegetarians welcome !

Excellent - go after 12:00 and Go hungry. Went too early hoping for breakfast but most stalls are lunch/dinner places so weren't serving. (FYI Good veg market next door only working until noon ish. Better than supermarkets for fruit and veg)The stalls vary from simple to full restaurant quality meals. We shared a few dishes from 3 different places. Can recommend the croquette (get the selection) the salmon burger with cuttlefish ink bun. Plus anything form the stalls at the far end as there were too many among things on offer. You sit in a communal canteen dining area which is very cool and plenty of places service alcohol. Will be going back to try more...

too crowded. is interesting the concept and you can choose different kinds of food and have a nice meal... but you need to have patience especially at the lunch and dinner time. You have an good corner for beer .
Beautiful!!!. Very nice market, a little expensive for the low budget travelers but worthwhile seeing! A must to see really

Great food options. Awesome food choices and a small outlet of the best shop in Lisbon, A Vida Portugesa. It's right across the street from Cais do Sodre train station so it can be easily visited before/after a trip up the coast to Cascais, for example.

Great choice, great food, great environment. We happened to walk past this gem and walked through the back entrance on the day of the fish market. What a lovely surprise to enter the food hall. We ate here 3 times and loved each meal. Good quality food. My favourite meal was at Cozinha da Felicida - just wonderful. It's handy that you can get a good meal here at anytime of the day when a lot of the other restaurants were closed. We ate around 6pm - before it gets very busy apparently. It's easy to get to - we walked from Praco do Comercial, just 10 minutes or so.

By far one of the highlights of Lisboa!. This is a huge market stall with a variety of fine wine, cheeses, and assortment of Portugese and fusion food! I had my first taste of Vinho Verde here so it holds a special place in my heart. Tried a raw tuna dish which was delicious. Wish we had more time here ... a must visit if you're in Lisbon!

GREAT PLACE. Great place to visit and consume outstanding food. I cannot make a single recommendation, but what I´ll say is to try every establishment. We have visited this market every evening during our stay in Lisbon. One caveat to this market is that the priceses are on the steep side, but well worth it!!! I must say: A MUST!!!!
Something for everybody. A good restaurant market with good options. Kids were able to choose what they want and we had japanese (small portions :().

Time Out should be in every city!. Time Out Market Lisboa was a fun spot for a Sunday afternoon. We were between meals but wanted to have a snack and drink. We loved strolling through to see some of the foods and wines we'd heard of but had not had a chance to taste. Although this wasn't as "local" as some of the other places we'd been, I'd still recommend it to get your bearings and plan some of your visit to Lisbon. We split a dozen oysters and vino verhde while we read a Time Out for a few more ideas in our last hours of the day. I suppose that was Time Out's goal :)

Old warehouse near waterfront filled with small stall restaurants and a tired fruit/vegetable market. No impressed, but it cooler inside rather than walking in the 102 degrees outside. Otherwise, I was less than impressed. Good for a snack or to pick up some flowers.
Good but busy.. Extremely busy on a Sunday night, struggled to find seats. Useless if you're a veggie. But good beer and wine and atmosphere.

Amazing food market. Best food I had in Lisbon! This food market is the place to be. Amazing food for good prices, great quality and lots of choice. I wish I could go there everyday! If you go there, you will want to try everything!

Great food, free wifi, get out of the heat. Lots of good food and drink options - something for everyone. Free wifi to plan the rest of your day. Not air conditioned but they have fans that keep it much cooler than outside.
Good concept. Good concept, it gives another life to the market but to expensive for the quality of what they propose, you can see that its a place that was done to turist.

Holiday visit. Stumbled upon it by accident but a glorious oasis of food & drink beautifully presented. These is something for everyone here; chicken, burgers, sushi, fruit, cheese, wine, beer...you could spend a whole afternoon here easily.

Not amazing, if you've actually been to a "mercado"before. Do you have a mercado in your hometown? If so, feel free to skip this.There is a variety of food, which is very helpful if you have people with opposite tastes in your group. Everyone can have their own cuisine, nocompromise required. It's a lively scene too. This is where positives end. Market is HOT. AC is not enough to offset this crowd, period. This place is much pricier than the sametype of food anywhere else in town. No privacy. Looking for a spot to sit down is a challenge, and you will be an inch away from strangers - this is the opposite of "privacy" and "romance"Also, walking here, the streets were not the most popular of all. We were unsure at times, and thought about hiding our obviously expensive items from plain sight.
Much variety. There were many food ( Sushi, Burgers, pastries, cheese, Portuguese , Pizza, Etc) and drink (wine, beer, cocktails, coffee , fresh juice). We really loved Time Out Market.

Finding food. We stumbled upon the timeout market and found the concept quite interesting, nothing like we've seen before. There's a lot of food stands to choose from, including traditional portuguese food,sushi and so on. Worth a visit

Fun and enegetic. Stopped here for Saturday lunch. So many choices it was difficult to narrow it down so eventually we opted for the 8 piece snack menu from Marlene Vieira. Six of the eight were fish which was ok with me but a little less exciting for my seafood intolerant wife. Anyway, we both enjoyed the food and the fun presentation. Had a couple of glasses of very good wine from another stand. Overall it was 2 1/2 hours of great entertainment.

Cultural Food Court. Lots of delicious foods and a few shops, but also quite busy on a Saturday making it warm and difficult finding seating.We ended up eating at one of the perimeter restaurants and sitting outside. Definitely fun to see the market, and perhaps grab a snack or drink! Overall, I would probably recommend finding a restaurant for a big meal.

Touristy but not to be missed!!. This is a great mix of half, a fruit and veg fresh market in the morning and half, an abundance of restaurant counters to choose from. It means a big group can choose the cuisine of their liking and still sit together with their friends and family. We spent about €16 for a nice lunch including wine. A really cool experience
Cool place. Try the sangria here!! It is sensory overload! ! They have do many selections of food & drink..you could stay here all day

If you love food. Great place to eat and drink. Maybe little more expensive as other places but you will get a really good food. The best thing is that if you are a group of several people then every body can choose something they like. Pizza, seafood, hamburgers, portuguese food, cakes, etc. Have tried risotto Negro and bacalhau which was great.
Lunch. Highly recommend. Went there for lunch and there was so much to choose from. High quality food. Family friendly. Only problem was waiting for a seat because it is so popular.

A bit pricy but fun atmosphere . Enjoyed this huge market. Lots of interesting food stalls. I agree with other reviews that the prices are higher than you will pay in most restaurants, but the quality looks to be really high and chef driven. I forget the name of the stall we ate at, but the entrees were in the 10 to 15 euro range and really delish. Also a bar in the center so you can get a glass of wine or beer and wander to find the food that suits your fancy.

Very busy, but great vibe and awesome food!. It is an extremely busy market and if you don't go early it might take some time to get seats. I would definitely not suggest going in big groups as you most probably won't get seats together. The selection of food stalls are varied and we tried 2 stalls - one for a Portuguese roll with truffled foie gras (seriously delicious!!) and also some sushi later. Once we were able to squeeze ourselves into seats we were just sitting and enjoying the vibe over a couple of beers. There was some music and dancing and overall it was a very fun evening. They also have very good free WiFi.
Loved it!. If you enjoy the bustling atmosphere of markets and excellent food then you're in the right spot! Definitely check it out on an empty stomach, there are just so many choices.

3 days in Lisboa . Wow what a market!!! Not only was the decor very cool and stylishly done but the food stands were a great selection of modern day Portuguese food from the city. I would recommend the "croqueteria" for some petiscos to take away for later with a glass of port wine!!

Best food in Portugal . I wrote a review of this under Mercado da Ribeira. It was the perfect place to eat for my family as we all have very different tastes in food. I ate from a stall which I think was called Alexandre Silva. I had a tuna dish which was divine. My family of 4 all ate from different stalls and the quality of each dish was top notch. If in Lisbon this market is a must.

Time out market is an awesome place!. Seriously, this place is an awesome. The food, beer and wine choices are amazing. The atmosphere is warm and perfect for hanging out with friends and family, or grabbing a bite to eat. But give this place some time, you may get overwhelmed with the many choices. :)

One of the places you must visit in Lisbon!. Ohhh these markets! I just love them! Gourmet food everywhere you look, fancy, hip and cool even if it's just a burger. You can have what ever you like and in a big group it's fun to go and nobody has to have the same meal! And then beside the restaurant market you have the food market, where you can buy your own stuff to cook at home. And many of the places are small and you can just sit down with a glass of vine and watch the cook make your meal! It´s fun to have a little bit of taste from different places, don' spend all your hunger at one place.
Cool but pricy . Very cool, many things to eat and drink, clean and with shick, however not cheap in the other hand you have massive variety

Great Market to browse eat and drink. if you are going to lisbon you need to head to this market incredible food great wine...and perfect for souvenirs. Check out the Tinned fish section the owner speaks english, french and spanish he was able to talk to my french wife and crack a joke with me amazingly good tinned sardines and horse mackerel!!Busy and pricey but food is delicious !!Well worth the detour Enjoy :)
Brilliant stop for lunch. Modern food market, great selection of places to eat. Fast and friendly everywhere we went. Very good for an easy, cheap and delicious lunch.

Busy, pricey but an experience!. We stumbled across market after walking a little off track from our hotel and our curiosity got the better of us and we headed inside to be met by a huge hall of food outlets offering an array of traditionalAnd modern food.The hall was very busy and the seating is canteen style communal dining, with take away from the food outlets enjoyed at the central tables. We walked around each one to make our decision and ended up headed back to the one of the first we saw where we enjoyed a meal of Veal Rice and the chefs special of basil risotto with prawn tempura. The food was ready within 10 minutes of ordering and we were given a vibrating buzzer to alert us when it was ready. Although it was a expensive given the setting the portions were large and the food was good. Advice is definitely to take the time to wander around and see what is on offer, and look at what others are having... This preventing me from ordering a very overpriced traditional beef dish! A good experience and a fun way to spend an evening.

For every taste. Visited this market many times to try some different places in it, the food is delicious, but overpriced if you consider Lisbon average prices. Probably you pay more the stylish place than the food itself, but it worth a visit.

Not worth going . If you expect delicious food and great service, please do not go there, the majority of stuff are rude and food are expensive, I would prefer to go to a proper restaurant, never come back! Watch out one shows seafood risotto, do not buy, they simply put some clams and rice in water, top with 2-3 small pieces of fish, that's it!

Must Try. I love the time out market anything you could possibly be in the mood for they will have it and more! I have visited the Time Out market countless times now and certainly am not sick of it! Everything from traditional food to pizza, sushi, best burgers and much more. At the weekend there is normally a dj playing music in the middle of the market which brings a great atmosphere. Its full of all different people, locals, travels, students and business people the diversity is huge! Price ranges from 4-17 euros. If your on a budget grab a huge slice of pizza or if you wanna spend a little more get grilled fish with a glass of vino verde.

Gourmet food of any kind. Huge gourmet market, food is delicious and in great variety. Sure it has disadvantages, you can spend 15 minutes walking around trying to find a place, and prices are higher than generally in Lisbon. But still 5 stars. You probably don't have such thing at home.

Amazing spot!. This place is amazing ... we went several times, eating at a range of different stalls and restaurants. The atmosphere is fantastic, the food and drink exceptional. You can find cheaper at local bakeries or cafes or restaurants, but the variety and ambiance make it worth it. What a great concept!

Excellent Concept. This is an amazing concept and range of foods on offer is fantastic. We chose to eat from Sea Me and it was really good.. The onky down side in its popularity is you'll struggle for seating. It's like a cattle market..

Lunch - with many choices . A great place to visit for lunch or dinner, not your typical food court. It is fine dining at reasonable prices and a great variety of restaurants under one roof - so something to please everyone.

Good food, great ambiance. Had a traditional prego sandwich here and surprisingly it was the best prego I had in the city. The great thing is that there is something for everyone here, including great gourmet food at affordable prices at Silva's stall. Finding a place to sit through is tough!
just ok. novel idea but seating very difficult to find. Just worth a one off experience. Lots of choice of food stalls a sort of help yourself sort of place with general seating if you are lucky.

Great, and busy, place for a meal. Bear in mind that this place is crowded at any given meal time, since it is one of the current hotspots of the city. However, due to tha amount of seating space and food offer, it is worth a visit and one of your meals.

Great concept! . I recently visited time out market and had a great experience. It resembles a huge food court in what used to be a fish market. You can walk around and check out menus to different restaurants and chefs (no typical fast food chains). In the middle they have wine and beer bars. You can do a beer tasting with Portugal's very own Super Bock. I had octopus rice and a beer. Everything was delicious! It's a great place to go to, there's something for everyone!

Somewhat chaotic, but worth the time and effort. The Market gets crowded after 8:30-ish. So for a better and calmer experience you may want to visit earlier. I te at the Asian booth - and the chicken in the noodle dish was way over-done. It was a disappointment

not cheap, but good food!. Went here August 2016. We ate here twice, one for dinner and once for lunch. Note that most places open at 12 midday, not earlier, so breakfast could be a challenge. We ate from different stalls, and I couldn't tell you the names, but with your back to the entrance, head down to the back left stall, they have awesome thick cut fries (like potato wedges), wife also had their squid ink and clam risotto. I had a tuna steak sandwich from other place which was good (not sure if it was 14 euros good). Love the concept, and the food is quality.

Good but pick meal times wisely. Massive selection of eating places and a good range of different foods all set around a large central seating area. The main problem we found was between 1pm and 3pm there was a distinct shortage of seats and people wandering round with trays of food and nowhere to sit.

You should try it!. Really tasty, various food and at good prices. You need to try all the sea food and, also, the pork cheeks.Another thing on your list should be the wine.This is one of the best ways to know the Portuguese people. They are relaxed and funny.

So good we ate twice in one day!. Time Out Market was a really neat experience. We ate there for two meals during our one day in Lisbon. The market is right across the street from one of the metro stations. There is an area with fresh fruits, vegetables, fish, and flowers. There is also an area with many food stands with everything from pizza to burgers to sushi to local cuisine. My wife had the ox burger at Alexandre Silva and really enjoyed it. I had a shrimp panini from one of the sandwich stands and thought it was great.
Busy, but good atmosphere. The Time Out Market is a busy place, but has a good atmosphere and there is much to choose from . Not cheap , but well worth it.

Very Very Very nice food, but not cheap!. Here you get everything what is special for Portugal. Very nice food in best quality in a cool surounding, the old market hall. The waiting time was very high and the prices too. It's unpleasant that you have to search for a table after you ciked up your food at the stands.

Fabulous Foods That Will Pease Everyone. We caught the metro to Cais do Sodre and walked across the street to the market. They have lots of fruits and vegetables but we weren't there for that. We wanted to eat. You have to walk around the periphery to see what you want and you want everything. I settled for sushi and my niece had roasted chicken. If there's a few of you going grab some seats while the others get the food because they go fast. There's a great coffee bar in the center.

Wonderful place foe dinning. This is like a food court where you could find a lot of varieties of food. Some of the restaurants will provide special recommendations everyday. The food taste very good. A bit crowded, be patient when waiting for a seat.
I cant even . AH MAY ZING.. You must hit this spot up. Both our meals were to die for. We both wished we would have went back for 1 more meal ! :p

Overpriced and underwhelming. This is one of those typical markets that have been taken over by "foodies" - in this case Time Out. The most famous places from the city have been invited to open here to make a 'curated' food venue. They charge more money than they do at their other locations in the city. The choices are not exciting, the prices are too high and the building is too hot. I would much rather go to an actual market where some old ladies are cooking up the good stuff.

Amazing choice and quality. We came across this market whilst looking for a place to have dinner, what a great find. A large hall with central seating surrounded by a range of great restaurants. From traditional Portuguese food to sushi, Thai and many many more, the range and quality of food were excellent. Additionally there were great wine, beer and cocktails available so is a great place to try many different dishes. One thing to note is that we went on a Monday which meant that there was not a great selection of fish available but other than that everything was great.

Deliciousness all around!. It is practically impossible to select a place to eat around here! So I came back three times! I had cod with turnip greens and baby potatoes, shrimp, various croquettes and of course.... salmon tataki at Henrique sa Pessoa's place! Wine selections were great, and for something sweet a couple of scoops of ice cream at Santini's. You should definitely go there when you are really hungry...

Always entertaining!. This was the ancient central marketing in Lisboa (like Les Halles for Paris).But it was transformer 2 years ago by Time Out magazine for Portugueses and tourists to enjoy. Fantástico idea!It houses very good restaurante and gourmet atores. Either you like wine, beer, water, coffee, bakeries, food, sweets... You are at home. A little bit noisy during the day, perfect your is at Sunset and beyond. During the morning you also may experiente a little of old days as the vegetables and fruit marketing still works. And at night try the "Pap'Acorda' restaurante. Fashion, exclusive, pricey, "go to see and be seen", but marvellous food and drink. Book always beforehand. "Ribeira market" (previous denomination and how Lisboetas still know it) at its best!
Love, love, love this place . Best food Hall I have ever visited. Fabulous food, huge choice and reasonably priced. A must for foodies visiting Lisbon

Very popular and trendy food hall.. Great choice of Portuguese food and drink, served in a bustling hall. Find a place to sit on one of the long tables, and a clever little device given to you when you order will buzz when your food is ready. Great atmosphere, worth a visit.
Overhyped. Too busy waiting for food at both places we ordered at. Too expensive. The food wasn't that great. You won't find a space to sit at unless you wait on someone.

Great place for lunch and people watching. Lovely selection of food places. Perfect place to sit at the counter, eating fresh seafood and watching people. Shame about the massive Time Out branding everywhere though......

Great Selection. The market has around 20 food venders, each selling unique foods. There is something for everyone here, from sushi to cod to hamburgers. While it is difficult to find a table and chairs, especially for a family, it is well worth it, as much of the food is delicious. However many of the wines and sangria are odd, so stick with beer. Overall a must visit in Lisbon.

Delicious! But no a/c. Great choice of food and drinks, seafood, meat, Asian, traditional Portuguese food... All that you desire you will find there! Great atmosphere and a lot of people! Recommend to come in the evening since there is no a/c

Cool Market Vibe!. We really enjoyed visiting the Time Out Market - a great array of food to choose from and really nice atmosphere. We visited around 7.00pm and crowds were too large, still plenty of tables available. We choose to dine on the bar of one of the restaurants - a great experience. We will definitely return to try something else.

Not for vegetarians . Crowded, noisy, not as good as food markets in London. Saw a lobster get hacked to bits while squirming which really put me off eating here. Absolutely nothing for vegans, maybe some pizza for vegetarians. Queues and crowds also unpleasant. Went round the corner to a pizza restaurant.

Good and affordable. Many stands are affordable and you can chose among a lot of different kind of cuisine, like portuguese, italian, japanese or chinese. We went for lunch and it was not very crowded.A good choice if you want to try different dishes.

Great food choice in Lisbon. We went to the market a couple of times during our stays in Lisbon. There is a very rich choice of portugaise specialties at correct prices. We tasted excellent bacalau with local alentejo withe wine. All food is prepared in front of you if you can find a place on the corridors seat in front of the comptoirs which I recommend. I wish you good appetite

Gourmet Cafeteria Style Eating. Amazing and cheap options for lunch or dinner. Mostly seafood and traditional Portuguese and fusion menus. Great, open-air, cafeteria style seating, energy, and people watching. Close to the city center, but with a very local feel. Reminded me of a more upscale Faneuil Hall in Portugal.

Blown away..... From the outside the Market looks like a plane hanger but nothing prepares for the explosion of senses once you walk through the entrance.
Rows of great food, drink and bustling customers enjoying the culinary delights.
A MUST stop when in Lisbon.

Good, but too crowded.. There is waaaay too much people here ! But you will understand why by going there. Prices ranges from cheap to a bit expensive (for the city) and it is really good from my experience. The only trouble is that it's too crowded

Something for every taste. This enormous food court is worth seeing. You'll find fish, meat, chicken, vegetarian - whatever. You buy what you like from counters circling the big hall and you eat at bars and tables in the middle. Some have outdoor tables too. There's something for every budget.

Super choice of eateries and lovely atmosphere . So glad we called in here. Buzzing with people eating and drinking. So many different types of street food and drinks to choose from.
Even if your not hungry or thirsty please just wonder through, it's worth the visit!

Trendiest place to lunch or dinner . This was a good market and now transformed into a multi restaurant place where you can eat or have a drink. Do not miss it because is really nice and for all budgets

Good selection . Time our market offer a wide selection of different types of Portugese and international food. Had some pretty decent oysers. A great cheese plater. A lovely glass of wine and a delicious pastry. I ended up paying just over €20 which is not bad considering. Not the cheapest place in Lisbon. But worth a look
Amazing place for foodies . Visited the Time Out Market twice whilst on holiday. Really amazing variety of food! Try the goats cheese, rosemary and honey on toast and the chocolate and Ginja shots!!

Must visit. The place is amazing even to decide your next food experience in the city. Enormous amount of options, nice souvenir store, you can buy food to go, or get started in one place, main course on other and dessert in a different one. Or not! Interesting, modern, noise, cool and beautiful! Loved everything that I tried...
Great experience. Great way to sample food from some great portugese chefs plus great gin and beer stalls. Well worth a visit.

Nicely organised and a good range of food. Whilst this lacks any authentic 'feel' of Portuguese markets, this is a well presented food hall with high quality food stands. Everything is clean and well thought through, the place is cleaned regularly and everyone we encountered was really polite. We arrived at 12 midday and didn't queue for anything and found a seat easily. The pizza/calzone was delicious and very reasonable (€3 a slice) and so was the cake. You pay more for the juice smoothies and the coffees but all was very high quality. It's so easy to navigate. Whilst I don't think you get such a 'taste' of Portugal than if you had found a vendor on the street, this is definitely a good experience, especially with a group of people with different tastes in food.

Wow . I passed for more than 10 years in front of the market and I never got the opportunity to enter. I gave a shot and I got amazed wow very good quality of restaurants and businesses inside. Wort a visit from the nationals and tourist

Great place to grab something to munch!. The time out market has a nice atmosphere, great food and is centrally located in Lisbon. Make sure to grab some seafood and local wine when you have the chance!

Fantastic market for foodies!. The Time Out Market is brilliant, to say the least. So many delicious food choices, a great buzzy vibe and the location is easily accessible. We went at night so the rest of the market stores weren't open, and from what we could see I think it would be worth visiting to check them out.

A place to eat and have a good drink.. This is a very crowded place at all times, a tourist and locals favorite place to stop and try the various dishes of the local cheff and traditional food... It's not a must see ... The food is OK ...

a place to visit. This is an amazing place for hungry people. So many variations of food, the good smell,... hard too choose what to eat. The only negative thing is that it is very hard to get a sitting place.

Hip, modern, interesting, fascinating but overcrowded. One of the top tourist attractions in Lisbon. Fantastic place to see, to eat and to discover. Chose your meal from one of the many restaurant branches available. Unfortunately it has become so popular that it is inceasingly difficult to get a seat these days. Especially when you are more than 2 people. In spite of that: a must see.

Street food at its best!. After reading about this place, we just had to try it out. It is surprisingly well organized. You enter what appears to be an enormous food court, with wooden long tables and chairs in the middle with kiosks for dessert and wine spread out here and there. There is everything and anything you can crave for. Now just because this place is described as street food, do not expect junk. The fares offered are upscale meats, seafood, coldcuts, sandwiches, desserts, wine, etc. The prices are certainly not low but you still pay less than in a restaurant for probably the same dishes. It is a welcome haven when you want to get out of the heat and just relax with a platter of oysters and a nice glass of vinho verde. We quite enjoyed our experience at Time Out.
Busing place for lunch. A great place to go for lunch loads of differant foods and drink the place is busy and very lively a great atmosphere

Great food, great atmosphere!!. The Time Out Market was a great visit on our trip in Lisbon.It is a large hall with modern furniture, and a neat, clean layout with easy to follow signage and free bathrooms. The food was amazing! I ordered pad Thai and a chocolate mousse dessert which were professionally prepared and presented. Only negatives would be:-food wait times-finding a table to sit at(But it wasn't extremely long for either)Definitely visit it..! Close to trains, buses and ferry stop!
unfortunately not anymore a a secret. do go you can choose almost any portuguese food or japanese italian etc. during summer a bit crowded and have to fin a place to seat

Here you will find a dish for every taste. Great concept, such a variety of high quality gourmet food.
Come very hungry because you would want to try everything.
Highly recommended

Good place to eat and shop. Called in here twice having come across it when walking near the river. Large selection of bars, restaurants, cafes, food stores. Found an excellent stall which displayed a selection of open toasted sandwiches. Chose two (three pieces in each) which were made up to order. While waiting, bought some beer from a nearby bar. So good we went to both twice. Very good quality and good value.

Best food ever!. Absolutely spoiled for choice. Something I look forward to every time I visit Lisbon. The garlic prawns are a must-have if you like seafood but I couldn't pick a favourite meal if I tried. Over 30 options and have honestly never seen the place closed as it stays open so late. Always packed but the atmosphere is electric and there always seems to be somewhere to sit, no matter the amount of people. The Mary Poppins handbag of venues! Honestly unmissable if you're in the area

A must in Lisbon. 40 plus food court type vendors with top of the line food at good prices. Order from several different vendors and find a place to sit while your order is prepared. Don't miss this...

Bustling and fun. This is a great place to know about but we were happiest eating on a terrace. On busy nights if you eat in the concourse expect a demoralising trawl for seats and a cafeteria experience. Food was variable - shop around and you'll be happy. There are also a small selection of shops including a great wine one with friendly staff.

Amazing! . My boyfriend and I visited here twice in our week holiday recently. It is amazing and cannot recommend it enough! We didn't find it over priced as some people have said on here. There are so many different options you'll be spoilt for choice. It was busy but not uncomfortably so. We didn't find it difficult to get a seat and we went both at lunch time and the evening. Music is played and the atmosphere is fab. Definitely go and experience it!!

Too much to choose from. Get there early for a seat!. So many good restaurants to choose from here. Whether you're after traditional Portuguese food or a big juicy burger, you will definitely find something that hits the spot here. Prices are very reasonable for the quality of the food. Place seems to fill up very quickly from 7pm each night so would recommend getting there early if you want a seat.
Best food. Tuna tartar is very good. Try the local beer, you can serve yourself. The chefs corner is the best. Choose the daily choice of fish. Five stars ❤️❤️

Dinner at Pharmacia Chef Felicidade. Ate a very interesting salad here - grilled goats cheese, ice cream, berry fruits and mixed leaves - yes an unusual but tasty combination; refreshing and satisfying for dinner on a hot day; also ate duck croquettes with orange jam for starters - delicious too !! €15 with wine and water - lots of interesting meat dishes on menu for around same price. This food hall is filled with kitchens from local restaurants where you can either sit at the counter or at high tables in the centre. Wide variety of choices - worth a visit !!

Great choice of eateries not too pricey. We were visiting Lisbon as a group of 4 all with different tastes including one veggie, so this was a great place to go as we could have what we wanted from each of the 'stalls' and the drinks and cocktails went very well. There is a large selection of various food stalls where you can pick from various types of cooking from local Portuguese food to sushi, burgers, seafood and Asian stalls. It's a great place to go with a group of people as everyone can have what they fancy. Once you have ordered your food you are given a flashy alarm that goes off when your food is ready. Would definitely recommend a cocktail with your food. A great place to go to get away from the heat of the city.

Everyday meal choice!. This place is what hotel concierge called hip place. In here u can find everything u want to eat. From local to western, Chinese or Japanese. Seafood, curry to desserts.
Good location, nice crowd, yummy food Till late. How can u resist ?

What every city should have. Probably the biggest surprise of our visit to Lisbon was stumbling upon Time Out. What we thought looked like a traditional farmer's market (which it also has under the main roof), is actually a foodie heaven meets communal-food court concept. I'm guessing around 30 restaurants under one roof with a great casual atmosphere. Worth a visit every day next time we come back to Lisbon!

Something different in Lisbon. Time Out Market (Ribeiro Mercado) is fun to visit because it summarises Portuguese food. However, similar markets can be found in many other cities around the world. Stop there if it is on your way.

Go early . This place gets pretty crowded so be there by 12 if you don't want to queue for lunch. Great choice and you can have a little from a range of providers if you can't decide. It's indoors so is quite noisy and like eating in a shopping mall. Not a nice atmosphere.

Choices that are pricy . Set-up: big food court with all kinds of stalls selling (quality) food or drinks. Tables in the middle for everyone to eat at. Busy place. Prices well above local prices. This place has anything you want when it comes to food. Lunch, dinner and desert, drinks, sweets and appetisers, it's all there. Some of it is pretty good and worth the money but there are some awful ripoffs going on. The seafood is mainly goodGin and wine bars goodPastries goodPizza, overpriced cardboard Get a local to advice you on some dishes, they know their stuff.

Well organized, but solely tourists. This place was worth a quick walk around but I only spent about 10 minutes here. It was packed with tourists and I didn't see a single local walking around. I'd recommend Mercado de Campo de Ourique over this one if you happen to be in the area.

A must visit. OMG this place is amazing. I spent the afternoon cursing the limited size of my stomach. The market is packed with places to eat full meals or try lots of small plates, would definitely recommend the latter. All the food I had was incredible and I love the fact they put on classes, have open kitchens to watch the chefs cook and placks explaining why individual restaurants/chefs were choosen to be included and other information.Fantastic! A must visit for any foodie!

Extremely corwded. No place to sit. We had to eat while standing. Not a fun place nor it's a good lunch or dinner outing. Fighting for a chair to sit down is not a good thing to do if you are going to eat. The food after trying few different restaurants is not that good either. It's not worth it.
went 3 times. Great buzz, this place has fantastic character I was so impressed I brought 3 others for my return visit.

Good food nice atmosphere . Mercado da Ribeira is currently a trendy place in Lisboa. It has several restaurante inside that serve great food and all types - from a burger, Asian to the typical Portuguese food. It is normally packed with tourists but has a great vibe with its shares tables.

A must visit. This is an amazing place. There is an array of excellent food and drink available - too much choice! We visited on several occasions and throughly enjoyed each of the meals we selected. Prices are competitive too and there is a pleasant and positive buzz around the whole place.

Sushi. We visited this place in the afternoon and took the sushi menu at the sushi stand. Sushi was ok but we had better. We went back the day after in the evening and there were lots of more people. Would advice to go in the afternoon.
Mostly food. More a place to eat than anything else. Food must be good as the place was absolutely packed. Not somewhere to look for bargains.

Don't Miss!. Our guide told us about this place, so we decided to try it for dinner one night. WOW! There are so many great Lisbon restaurants represented here. It is like an upscale food court, with an opportunity to try lots of different specialties of Lisbon. There are long communal tables to eat at. It leads to lots of friendly conversation. We had a list of different foods to try, such as Ginja (cherry liquor) and Santini ice cream and got to try them at Time Out. I had a steak sandwich with shrimp at Cafe de Sao Bento. Super! Although it is crowded, this is definitely a don't miss sight in Lisbon.

Excellent variety of dishes. My boyfriend and I ate at the Time out Market twice during our 2 night stay in Lisbon and were not disappointed! The market does tend to get a bit busy around dinner time and it is very cafeteria style so unless you want to be walking around with your tray looking for a seat I recommend having someone you're with save you a spot while you get your food and then have them go get theirs. Besides that, the food was amazing

Interesting High End Food Court. We had dinner plans elsewhere, but we stopped in when it was convenient to see what it is all about. The food, restaurants, and stalls looked solid to us, and we might have come back had we had time. It is not a traditional market where people are selling fish and vegetables. It is prepared food.My wife and I also had a brief discussion about the potential conflict that arises when a travel book company opens a facility that competes with other restaurants and venues. The market appears to be very successful, so it would not surprise me if we saw more Timeout venues in other cities, which does pose issues.

Good variety of food. Very nice and quite organised place. Hard to find somewhere to sit down and eat if you're there around 2 p.m. Other than that, good variety and found an excellent artisanal sangria.
great choice of food. A great place to eat with artisan foods from many of Lisbon's top restaurants. Each person can choose to eat from a different restaurant and dine together in a central area.

Great for groups. Good atmosphere, was really busy when we went so struggled to find a table, but a great idea for the right occasion. big groups wanted different food, or after a nice but casual meal

We came every day!. We were in Lisbon for 4 days and this was an amazing find! Everything was top quality - from drinks to foods to ice cream. And it was great to know that you could try the best of the best. We tried Pink Port sangria (amazing), ice cream, the Asian lab as a good change, the meat / cheese platter was awesome, and the duck croquettes with orange marmalade were excellent!

Tasty but overpriced. This food market is definitely worth a visit in Lisbon. At the market, you can find numerous options for food from local to world cuisine. During my visit, I tried local fish soup and Codfish cakes (Bolinhos de Bacalhau) from one of the restaurants, which were quite fresh and tasty. However, we found the market overpriced and touristy overall.

Nice place for fast dishes with food. You have a vast selection of food from anywhere. The dishes are expensive if you compare with a nice restaurant. The place is beautiful inside. You can have some good wines and beers inside. There is also an Ice cream place.

Great place to eat and drink. Full of little restaurants with a big central island with tables. You will find from local portuguese food til any kind of food burguers, pizza, asian, sea food etc... Good enviorment!! Don't miss it

Great atmosphere at lunch time . Visited on a Tuesday lunchtime (13:00ish) and spent a half hour walking around looking at all the stands. Decided to try a cured meat platter from a stand on the right hand side of the market sign - great food and very reasonably priced.
Incredible amount of choice and well worth visiting even to try a few small plates.

Overcrowded but worth it. So happy we made it there on our last day in Lisbon.It was totally overcrowded and the people were quite angry and impolite - probably cause they were hungry Prices could have been a bit cheaper vut everything in there was screaming - eeaaaat meeeee!!!You might be waiting in line for a long time and you may have to search a seat for hours but it's worth it

A must see whilst in Lisbon. . Scrap all the historical buildings, bus rides, tram rides and whatever else there is to do in this amazing city and come here! Suitable to all types of travelers including those going solo. Lots of amazing food outlets, plenty of seating, and plenty of alcohol!!

Simple, fresh and tasty. D. . And a bit overcrowded at peak time.Definitely a place to visit in Lisbon. Ice creams at this wonderful shop are also excellent and made with fruits as opposite to flavored taste.

A taste of many good restaurants. We were warned that this place is a bit touristy, but after a few meals in which at least one of our group had to settle for a kind of food he/she likes less, we decided to try this place where each can order from a different restaurant (=food stall). So one had sushi, two had hamburgers and one had pizza - all very tasty, and then we had some excellent deserts. Not cheap for this type of eating (sort of take out) but at least everyone ate what they liked, and the quality was very good.

Great selection - communal dining. This was unusual in that there were maybe 20 different restaurant shop fronts inside a large hall and no matter which you chose to eat from most of the seating was long communal benches in the centre of the hall. Great selection of food for all tastes- Asian, American and Portuguese restaurants all together in one place! Really good food and a great way to satisfy everyone in a group. Extremely kid friendly environment.

Lunch @TimeOut Market. Our last lunch in Lisboa was at the TimeOut market. We went there via bus 738 from Baixa. The place us very well organized, there is a lot of diversity on the cuisines offered, from local portugese food by famous chefs, to asian cuisine or hamburgers and pizzerias. Vegan tip: ok,there aren't a lot of options for us, but I chose from the only asian restaurant the vegeterian pad tai (without eggs, "no ovos,por favor") and it was great.

Great Place to eat. We had walk around to see all the food stalls, there is so much choice! It was great we got delicious pizza for the kids and we had fish from another stall. Busy but good atmosphere. Only (small) drawback is that it's quite pricey.

Amazing food!. Portuguese food with a twist! This was incredible. Try as much as you can. We shared dishes and it meant we could try more. Only thing to watch out for is cost...this is pricey considering how cheap Tasca is in Lisboa. Worth a visit tho!
Fun Mostly Good Food Crowded. We had fun eating here, but it's quite crowded. I can recommend most of the food with the exception of the Asian Food.
Not a bad stand there!. We were 9 people who each ate a different stand and every single thing we ate was spectacular. I would definitely recommend Tartar-IA's tuna tartar. Delicious.
Very cool !. Different kind of food and drinks ! Great sea food . You can pick all you want to try and enjoy it :)

Salmon tartar. You must try it!!
It is amazing and one of the best things I have ever tasted.
Drink and desserts are also outstanding.
It will be a highlight of you time in Lisbon!!

Good food very busy in the evenings. There is a really good selection of food here. It gets very busy in the evenings so hard to find a seat also people were pushing a little bit. The sushi was really good.

Must visit . Went here twice on our trip to Lisbon. In my opinion it's a must visit. Open late everyday. It's like a high class food court. All different types of food and so many options. Everything I had was delicious!

We ate here every day. This place is awesome with all the best restaurants in the city offering either takeaway or sit down options under the one roof.
We went for lunch every day and snacks late arvo on the way home from he beach. Go there and try all the cities best

Best food market . Definitely the best food market in Lisbon
Plenty of options from local to foreign food. It does get busy during lunchtime (understandably) but you can usually still find a table to sit
Recommended
Fantastic place!. All-in-one. Restaurants, shops, market. Well-prepared food, decent wine and beer, nice prices. Very wide choice for everybody.

Great discovery. Nice place with many facilities (toilets), very clean and with a wide range if food offer. Be careful, it can be a bit more expensive than in other traditional restaurant. You pay for the trendy and touristic place.
Good lunch spot. Plenty of restaurants to chose from, most of them of decent quality, It's a bit crowded usually but with its location a good choice while visiting Lisbon

Great venue, lots of choice but very busy. Conversion of an old market hall to a gourmet food court is an idea other city planners should consider. Arriving at lunchtime, it took some time to look around and we settled on seafood at Sea Me Peixaria Moderna, a branch of a well known fishery in town - where it is apparently even harder to get a table. The food was great, and there was so much choice from Portuguese, seafood, steak, egg tarts, ice cream etc, around a bright central dining area. The hall was massive and bustling with locals and tourists, with specialty stalls selling local tinned produce or cured meats dotted around. A very enjoyable lunch.

Just avoid Monte Mar. 27€ for these two plates at Monte mar, please avoid! 5 tiny squides for 13€, disgusting not fresh octopus rice for 14€, so small quantity and not good.... If you go there avoid Monte mar...I did this mistake..
Overpriced food but good for beer. Avoid this place if its food you are after. Most of the food är mediocre and the portions are very small. You are warned.
Food Porn. Your one shop stop for all your hunger needs! So many options and so lively. One can easily spend a few hours there. Must visit in Lisbon. If not hungry still cool to check out.

Refused a fresh fruit drink as it was too near closing time. We came here for a look and a drink. As it was a hot day we opted to visit the fresh juice stall in the middle. After figuring out what we wanted I attempted to order from the staff member who had stood and watched us in our deliberations. He refused saying that he was due to close in 10 mins. I guess as it wasn't his business he didn't care about customers or income. It wouldn't have hurt him to say he was closed when we arrived but I suppose there is no fun in that. Anyway the whole setup liked a great idea but we took our custom elsewhere.
From tradition to modernity. Here you can shop for bacalao and Portuguese foods and vegetables but also to enjoy lunching and dining except the day of closure (Mondays).

You can not go wrong with this upmarket foodhall. This is an upmarket food hall co-located with the food market. It got a central area with long bench seating or there are side lanes where you can sit at each restaurant at the counters.Most of the food stalls are run by the most famous restaurants in Lisbon, so this is a good opportunity to taste what the upmarket restaurants have to offer, but still do it in a relaxed setting without any dress code. The other good thing about this place is that you have food options for everyone's taste and if you are fed up with eating sardines or steaks swimming in milk, then you have other options for non-Portuguese food.We came here at midday and it was mostly empty and you could get seats very easy. One hour later at 1 pm, people were having difficulty getting seats.
Quick, modern, excellent cooking. Food court concept. Good experience on seafood stall. Clearly beyond fast food, surprising and novel combinations.

Loved it!. An absolute must visit if you are in Lisbon! Time Out Market is a fun, hip place to eat - it was so great that we visited a second time. There are so many fantastic options to choose from and the quality is outstanding. We were a group of 8 so it was difficult though not impossible to find seating at lunch for all of us together.

Too noisy, no place to search and the food is so and so. This is a new trend in Portugal: they renovate these markets, transform old fish and vegetable places into trendy tray restaurants and if becomes a fashionable place. Seriously I don't get it, it's impossible to get a seat, especially if you're more than two people. You wait in one line for food and then you have to go to another for wine or beer, it's terribly crowded and noisy. Lisbon has fabulous cheap restaurants. This is not a good choice.

Worth it !. We went there during the evening for a special dinner experience as we expected it from the other reviews and we were delighted ! As expected, it was really crowded and loud inside. We didn't wanna look all over the place for a seat so we sat at a table on the outside part of the Time Out Market. We picked a seafood place. There, we ordered some clamps and crabs, which were really fresh and tasty. The staff was also very nice and gave good advice. Finally, the cherry on the cake was an "éclair au chocolat" we ate at a French place inside the Market. The night ended up a little bit pricy compared to a regular restaurant in Lisbon and the crowd spoiled a little bit the experience but it was worth the detour !
Nothing special. As in the entire Lisbon too many people. Confusion, high noise, impossible to seat and rest. Bad experience. In grneral,Lisboa was a bad experience

A Must stop. I totally recommend it. In a single place, you have so many gourmet options to choose from. I really like it. A watch out: just because it has a "food court" type of approach it doesn't mean it is inexpensive. You do have many options of food and prices but in general is gourmet food. You can go for tapas or for a full meal. It is a big area, very nice looking while informal. We tried food from TARTAR-IA and MARLENE VIEIRA. Both delicious!.

Amazing Indoor Market for Cheap Eats and Drink... The time out market is a gem, a huge old restored indoor market.
