Dozens of small "stands" selling cheap eats and drinks,fruits vegetables, and other wares including local crafts. This is just a cool and fun place to hang out and eat. Also an easy walk from the Baixa/Chaido district if you have a late evening hankering for a snack or meal. Definitely on the list of top 20 things to do while in Lisbon.

fantastic food/drink and ambience..a place to eat, drink and greet. A fantastic venue near the railway station with an internal market full of vibrant high quality freshly cooked food joints, drinking outlets in the centre, and lots of seating. Am a vegetarian so Lisbon can be a challenge but here there are plenty of options whether Asian/Thai or simply an outstanding veggie burger. The wine sold here is by people who know their wine and are proud of it. A must visit eating place for anyone going to Lisbon. I believe Time Out are opening a venue in London soon.

Delicious food !. We visited this market based on some of the reviews that we read and it did not disappoint, there were plenty of choices and the food tasted great. We really enjoyed the seafood options, Santini's gelatos and the fresh fruit juices. The only downside is that there is a long wait at some of the stalls and it is not easy finding a place to sit but well worth a visit if you want to have a variety of food to choose from.

Great concept, too busy. This place looks great, but finding a table and getting a family to sit down and all eat at the same time is just impossible itches want food from different vendors. Quite frankly the place looks great but it's hard work!!

Fun place to eat with a bunch of options!. Old indoor marketplace(warehouse style) converted into a great place to hang out and eat. Worth taking the time to walk around to all the different food establishments before making your choice of a meal. Not great if you're looking for quiet, as the acoustics are barn-like, but that's part of the experience while sitting at the long community-style tables. Across the street from the main Cascais-Lisbon train station and a metro stop.
Lovely .... Great to sample local produce and at great prices.A must for all natural food food lovers..Lovely way to spend any afternoon...

Great quality. We had lunch here during our visit to Lisbon. We had taken a Backstreet Lisbon food tour and first we strolled through the market side and then opted to eat our lunch in this market as opposed to a restaurant. We each ordered from a different food stall and shared our selections. Everything was gourmet and wonderful. Earlier we had watched our chef select an enormous tuna from the fishmarket and we tasted it as he made it into tuna tartar. The pork belly was amazing as were the cheeses and desserts. The only problem is that it is extremely crowded with locals and tourists at lunch and finding a place to sit can be very challenging. It is definitely worth a trip.
Fun experience . Really nice but a little crowded. Many lovely places to eat. Don't go too early for your lunch but go a little bit later. It is really worth it!
foodies delight. must stop by and flavor as many of the stalls as possible.....really good fresh food + if opportunity exists, take a cooking class!!!

The sauce is NOT free !. I went there today and I ordered a chicken piri piri.. I asked the waitress if she can put a bit more of piri piri ... Her reply : "no if you want more you have to pay 0.80 euros"... I am like in which restaurant they ask you to pay for a sauce especially when it comes to the meal that you just ordered... There are tons of places in this market, friendliness and customer service go a long way, I am sure you will find better in another place.

Also Known as Mercado Di Ribeira. This was recommended as an eating place by my hotel receptionist and it was a great find. A bit like a very up market food court it had many "food outlets" with central seating. Just find your food and your wine and settle in. There is ample choices for every taste but a bit pricey but very atmospheric. Fish was obviously on many menus. It was a great casual eating affair.
Evening hangout. Perfect place to hangout in the evening after a long day. With live music and tastes from all over Portugal. A bit on the expensive side through.

A fun place to steep yourself in wine and food. This is a fantastic gastronomic experience and not one for just walking around for 15 minutes. Here you can buy fresh food and drink and enjoy whilst the wider market activities go on around you. Fantastic fun.

Loved it. This is an amazing place for food lovers and those that are just hungry. Great selection from simple to more fancy food - meats, cheeses, seafood, wine, cocktails, sweets. Full of people, so not very easy to find a place to sit.

Fresh foods market next to Time Out! . Right next to Time Out is a fresh food market so all the food prepared at Time Out is super fresh. Large modern open shed with so many varieties of different food and deserts. Grab a glass of wine and walk around till you decide what you are in the mood for! Very cool concept and cant wait to visit again! We need this in Cape Town!

Time Out Market Lisboa. Time Out Market is very famous in Lisboa, every Portuguese will recommend you to go there. It's exactly a food court, and every shop has its recommended food. The whole area is clean and decent.

Perfect for Lunch. A great stop off for lunch, with a wide variety of choices... from croquettes to sardines, fresh juice to a great selection of desserts. A good atmosphere too, and although slightly on the pricy side definitely worth visit. If you come early enough (before noon I think) the traditional market next door is open too.

Complete rip-off. I was really excited to come here as I am a sucker for a good market (and good food in general). I looks very cool on the inside with all the stalls circling the long tables in the middle, and there's a good vibe. However, prices are unacceptable! Felt like being back home in Copenhagen with these obscene prices. Ordered fried calamari, a personal favorite, and it tastes good - but certainly not worth 9 euros for 8 little rings. Unless you just won the lottery, I wouldn't recommend this place. It's such a tease with all the yummy food, that I'm guessing most people can't afford - at least not enough to buy a full meal.

Cool gastronomic experience. Time Out Market is a must-seen in Lisboa, although you can find a similar gastronomic markets in other towns nowadays. Still, it's a place to hang with a large group of people, having different courses, of international and local cuisine. It can get kind of crowded and the prices are not that cheap, but overall a very good experience, especially when DJ starts to play.

Definitely worth going, at least once!. There is a huge range of very good food here. We went at lunch two days and although it was busy it was always easy to get a seat. Food is served quickly and both times the quality was very high. A definite go to for foodies!

Overrated and overpriced. It was nice but way too crowded and overpriced. The burger and salmon tartare were great but expensive. It took a while to find a place to sit for 4 people and it was so loud, you could hardly have a conversation. I think there are nicer places with better food to eat!

fun to walk around, but at busy times you might have difficulty finding a place to sit.. This is a food mall with all sorts of local specialities as well. However there are tables in the middle and it can be quite full and then difficult to find a seat to enjoy the meal

Great place!. We went here as a big group of 16 people on our first evening in Lisbon. Not a great idea because it's extremely crowded and you'll barely find anywhere to sit. So I would not recommend going in big groups but max 4 people and Also go without small children. But the place itself is very very nice for eating and hanging out. It's noisy, crowdy so it's cool to hang around there, like a food bar. You'll have a difficult problem though, to choose what to order since there is so much to choose from. Definitely recommended!

Overcrowded and incredibly loud!. We went there in the evening to have dinner with a friend. However, after an exhausting day in the city it was just too loud and overcrowded for me. You have to wander around quite a bit with your food until you can find a space to sit and it's so loud that you can hardly have a dinner conversation. Surely a nice place with a many different dinner options but not really a nice place to have dinner.
Great choices of food. . A lovely place to sit and to sample lots of quality food. There really is something for everybody and the quality is very good. This is a must visit when in Lisbon.

Lots of Good Food. This is a historic market that now serves as the showplace for a bunch of Lisbon food purveyors. A broad variety of food with lots of Portuguese specialties. It's fun just to walk around and browse or to buy sardines and other local specialties.
Great market. Ok prices. . Lovely building. Great concept. Some prices are very reasonable, others are a lot less. There's a big choice of products local and international.

Recommend!. Great place to get a little taste of good Portuguese cuisine. We happen to be there during UEFA Semi-finals (Portugal vs. Wales) and the place was definitely packed but the vibe and energy was incredible! Would definitely recommend a visit!
Favourite part of Lisbon!. Came back to Lisbon early to visit again! Yes it can be busy, but that's part is the charm! Delicious food, at reasonable prices - favourite part of our break.

Wonderful gastronamic experience. Not a food court, but a very large food hall with small restaurant stalls around the perimeter, some operated by award winning young chefs. We had some of the best food of our month long trip to Iberia, including giant prawns, reimagined Portuguese dishes and great wine and desserts. We stayed in Chiado/Bario Alto and found it easy to walk down the hill or take the funicular to this amazing place. Very crowded, but still very accessible -- you must go here!

Was an excellent place to visit and eat at. It was excellent. Some people say it is full of tourists. Maybe. But it is also full of excellent chefs and we had a truly wonderful time here. Great food. Great wine. A must-see.

Busy, buzzing food market. Dropped in here for lunch on a recommendation. Multiple food offerings from perimeter stalls and communal central seating which was very busy. Great choice and good quality. We had a meal from Henrique sa Pessoa, which was excellent.

A must see. You not only have to see this, you have to try this ! A big covered market place with tables in the middle and a wide variety of little food shops surrounding them. There are food and drinks for everyone s taste : soft drinks, cocktails, beers, pasta, fish, meat, ... What an experience !

Great choice of food and wine and fresh produce market. . Do not miss this place on your visit to Lisbon. There is a great market where you can get fresh veg, fish and wine. And then in the main hall lots of sections around the outside where you can choose what you wanted to eat. We had a really nice burger and some Wine. To be honest it's hard to go wrong here. But it is really busy and you might have to wait. So my tip is to go to the wine counter, taste a couple of wines, buy a glass and then find a table. If you do it that way and know where you want food from it will make it easier.

Fine dining in a food court setting.. This is the most extraordinary food court you will ever experience. The restaurant/stalls are operated by some of the most recognized chefs in the city. You can mix and match every course of your meal and then share with your companions. We ate at one of the stalls and then at their full-sized restaurant located elsewhere in the city on another day. Restaurants all offer wine and beer to accompany your meal. We went for lunch on one day and went back for dinner on another. You can also sample various different types of drinks and oh the deserts!! Some nice food shopping to be done and food/drink gifts to buy.
Cool place, great choice of food. The atmosphere is super nice and there is a huge choice of food for all tastes. Definitively recommend it.

Unexpected creative dishes with a twist, inside a food court. Seen all those US type food courts of horrible fried foods and never dared to eat there? Well, here you will enjoy. Creative dishes all around, with a twist to the classic, like tartares of raw fish, spanish tapas, japanese noodles, grilled hamburgers, ripped baby pork, spanish jamons, salads, etc., etc. There are a dozen of good food stalls. You order (with eyes bigger then your stomach), you pay, you get a beeper, you sit down, you drink your first glass of wine, beeper rings, take food to table. Eat and enjoy.
Must visit . Must must must. You'll find all the food you're looking for and if you want to quickly buy souvenirs they have A Vida Portuguesea and a few other shops

Amzing. Great idea and execution. Place is buzzing with excitement. Lots of people of all ages enjoying every kind of food. It is well organized, clean and cool. Place to go and have a lunch or dinner. Relaxed and close to many tourist attractions. Should be in every city!

Popular food court scene in good area. This was recommended to us as convenient to our hotel & offering many choices of eateries. Both were true. It met our needs for an evening when we wanted to enjoy our hotel & not be out late. We tried some empanadas, port & chocolate volcano cake--the latter saved us. :-)
Simply Delicious!. We had a fabulous lunch at a seafood bar in this market. Delicious oysters, scallops and tuna accompanied by a glass of rose.

Extremely busy but interesting. This place is a must see in Lisbon. We did not eat here because it was to busy. Interesting for food lovers because of the variety of food next to a produce market, fish market and meat market.

Must see for foodies.... Was a bit sceptical about such a touristy market run by Timeout but am pleasantly surprised. Its not really a market in the traditional sense but an upmarket hall of food counters round the edge of the building with mass seating in the middle.Food is outstanding, great atmosphere....we came at 3.30pm so I think later than crazy rush at lunchtime. Such a wide variety of freshly cooked food...seafood, suckling pig, burgers, pizza, sushi....a must-see in Lisbon if you love food!

Super cool. Lots of choice.. The restaurant side of the market is amazing. You could easily eat here every day for weeks and never have the same thing twice. The prices are a little high compared to other restaurants nearby, but they're still cheap when compared to London or NYC prices (where we're from), so we were happy. The duck risotto from Marlene Vieira was particularly nice.Try to avoid peak lunch and dinner times if you want to find a seat.

Good variety, our food was great. Rarely, when we go out as a family, do we have as many options at once as we had here. We could have eaten all from different food providers and styles of food if we had wanted to - we ended up choosing two places. The food was very good, the only difficult thing was finding a place to sit down with the general hustle and bustle. Overall very good, could have been great with a little bit more space to sit down.

Good food, very crowded. Nice food for a reasonable price and some, but not many, vegetarian options. It gets very crowded though, finding a seat is dificult. If you are hungry in the area, it a nice place to visit. The asian stall had great curry.

Not everything is a whow .... We ate in the Time Out Market at ALEXANDRE SILVA. The cod (with spinach) was not fresh at all. Lots of salt to hide the real taste of the cod. Go for another restaurant ...

Dinning . Awesome place to eat great Portuguese as well as cuisine for very low price. Lots of friendly staff and people. Vinoh verde is must to try there. I enjoyed it but I still prefer the vinoh tinto best!

Great food market!. This is a large indoor food market with many different options (Portuguese, Thai, sushi, pizzas, noodles, etc). Great to stop in for a nice lunch with a glass of wine! Generally the places with the name of the chef on are the best options. It is difficult to find a seat during the lunch rush.

You must visit here but come hungry!. This place is a must!So many places to choose to eat from it’s hard to decide what to have!We opted for burgers from Honorato – the best burger that I have ever had! We had an X-Burger and a Mercado burger - amazing and all cooked fresh to order.Followed by macarons and eclairs this was a fantastic place to eat!

Definitely a Must-see. Thia is a must-see in Lisbon. Full of delicious and gourmet options for fast and affordable food; chic and popular at the same time. A fantastic option for locals and tourists and missing in tourist guides issued a few years ago. DON'T MISS IT.

Must do for food . A big food court with so many options of food. So many people, so alive! You can have the most simples dishes and snacks, but also great Portuguese food, chineseFood, deserts, it is great. When in Lisbon please check it out.

Great place to spend an evening. My eyes were popping out of my head as I moved from stall to stall. When I finally settled on the tuna with sweet potato, honey and chives , I was blown away. Super wine and beer. I can certify that yes I did have the "Best Sponge Cake in the Universe" . Super concept. Well done Time Out and Lisbon

Great Food Hall. A great funky, fun food hall in an easy location. A good spot to allow everyone to choose a different chef/food (from traditional Portuguese to Thai or Sushi) or sample your way through the meal. We liked the casual (yet upscale) atmosphere and found a variety of things to eat to please everyone - even the kids will enjoy it. A good stop for the curious or the picky alike!

AMAZING PLACE TO EAT!!. It's basically a food court/market gathering the best Portuguese food from Lisbon, from pregos to bacalhau, and of course, booze.what an awesome concept..An indoor market which contains all of the best Portuguese restaurants and other international cuisine under one roof.Overall a great experience, but can get busy around lunch time as to be expected . Shop around the counters for beer prices you will be surprised how much they vary considering they are adjacent one another.
A must place to lunch !. Lot of selection, reasonable priced and great atmosphere ! A must place to eat at once when visiting in Lisboa !

Really awesome concept with average execution. It's a really great concept and we overall enjoyed the experience. The market is crowded at late lunchtime, around 2PM. It was very difficult to find a seating for a group in the same area. Food took a while based on expectations given the environment. Our group of 14 ate from 5 different places. The overall feedback was the food was good but not great. There is definitely a huge variety there. One could eat a a different restaurant daily for a month!

Favorite place to eat!. Felt like a kid in a candy store when I walked in here. This large gourmet food court with an adjacent market reminds me of Whole foods market here in the states but jammed packed with renowned restaurants. This is great for someone likes me who keeps a list of recommended places to eat but with no time to visit them all. After browsing for about 15mn, I decided to go to SeaMe-Peixaria Moderna. I had their sardine sushi (sardinhas niguiri) and codfish sushi (Bacalhau niguiri) along with a refreshing glass of rose. That food was melt in your mouth delicious! Only regret was not getting more of the sardines. They were definitely my favorite dish. I love that it wasn't just tourists there, lots of locals frequent this place as well while on their lunch break. This reminds me, it's hard to secure or keep your seat during lunch hours. In our group of 3, 2 of us split up to wait in line while one person held down our seats. Quick tip, after talking to some locals, i learned that the best places here are the ones all the way in the back, featuring the Chef's name.Great easy wifi.

Great place to eat!. This market is like a huge food court in a warehouse. We went there to eat dinner & it didn't disappoint! From traditional Portuguese dishes, charcuterie, cheese and amazing seafood, to pasteis de nata, gelato and other amazing desserts. Some of the pop-up restaurants are run by well-known Portuguese chefs.You can also buy hamburgers, hot dogs, pizza and Asian food but my recommendation would be to try some of the amazing local seafood. We had grilled octopus with potato & spinach, sardines & tomato on bread and grilled prawns with seafood rice. It was so good we might go back again! Food is freshly-cooked and reasonably priced. Make sure you get there by about 7:30pm because seats are hard to find after that!
A lot of options for food :). A place where you have no excuses to not eat. So many options of restaurants that for sure you will find something nice to try.

A must do dining experience. This is the real deal with only one challenge- getting a seats your party.After that its just wonderful. Superb food which you pick up yourself from various stands- they give you a buzzer to tell you when its ready. We loved it.

Upscale fast food. Many Lisbon restaurants have a "fast food" outlet open in the evenings at the Time Out Market. Go with a group and you an all have different foods. While fast, most places still seem to cook to order, so it may take 5-10 minutes to get your food. There's a big seating area, at long tables -- and may be really crowded and hard to get a seat for groups. It's a few minutes walk from the central square.
Lots of food!. Good place for dinner! They give you a tablet that buzz when you're meal is ready. During that time find yourself a table and have a drink from the beer or wine bar in the middle.

Upmarket Food Court . What a place to be especially at lunch time it's full of tourist buying lunches from the many different stores under one roof. Not only is there food already cooked but raw ingredients as well because on either side of the central eating area there are fish and meat stores as well as fruit and vegetables available as well. Food wise there's lots to choose from pizza to chicken burger, Thai noodles to sushi and Lisboa special - seafood.

Fresh architecture concept. Never got past that.. Go for the chefs restaurants. Not hamburgers or sushi.
The rest is good but nothing special nor cheap. Might as well waste your money and TIME in something good.

Great for Lunch or Air BnB. This is a great little food court with lots of locale fare and drink. There is also a farmers type market attached on the side.If you are staying in a place with a kitchen I recommend coming here to get some local items to cook at home. However you must do it early because the market closes at 2pm. Apparently it is open very early however, I think they said 4am. You can get all you need here, produce, fish, eggs, etc.If you don't come for the fresh food you can go to the food court that is always open and get some really nice local dishes, drinks, Vinho Verde, etc. There are also a few crafty shops, wine shops and other little things to take away. This would be a good stop mid day if you are walking around Lisbon in the Bario Alto area.

Definitely worth visiting. You can find something really delicious here. Sometimes it's hard to find a free table to eat during the peak hours, the place is overcrowded. But if you're lucky enough, you won't leave the place until you're full.
Unmissable. Great food and wine. Large selection. Street food. You can choose affordable and more expensive food.Charming market.

So much choice of quality cuisines . I'm so glad we went here! The food that we ate was unreal and we wished we could have eaten at all of the other food stalls as well. The prices aren't cheap but the food is still great value as the quality of produce and cooking is extremely high. If we stayed in Lisbon longer we would have come back.Great alcohol and dessert choices as well.They also so wine tasting upstairs. It gets busy in there but there's plenty of seating.Highly recommend checking it out.
Great place. Went there because of friends and time out recommendation and have to admit the place is worth it. Lots of food and drinks.relaxed atmosphere and free booze if you are lucky:-)
dinner at the Time Out during Lisbon visit. great experiance, a lot of different food offers for all tastes and budget. A good mix of locals and tourists.
Amazing food. There is a huge selection to choose from, comfortable environment very modern and clean, the only downside would be that it's hard to find seats after about 8pm

Greatest selection of food in town. The Time-out market is an amazing place. Dozens of small shops gathered together under one roof where you can find great food, from Portuguese to Asian to Italian. Fish, beef, sushi... Everything at it's highest quality. Take your time and enjoy as much dishes as possible. Another plus is that the market is opened until late at night.

Such a variety of food to try!. This was one of the best places to eat while we were in Lisbon. There were so many options and you could taste a bit of everything. Each stall served its own range of starter, main, dessert, and drinks but we found it best to pick and choose from the huge variety. A must visit!
Ok market. Good for food (although I didn't eat here) but not close to much in the day and the market is somewhat overrated. Not much other stuff apart from food.

A food fest in the heart of Lisbon. We absolutely loved this place, not far from Chiado and the waterfront in Lisbon,
ideal for a family with varied eating requirements.

Fantastic spot for lunch or dinner. A modern, funky food court that caters to all ages, testes and budgets. We sampled or way through different cuisines and were greatly impressed by the variety and quality of food at acceptable price levels. Touristy and busy? Yes...there are certainly a lot of travellers tasting their way through the booths but this should not put anyone off visiting this bustling venue located across the street from the train station.

Cool food market -slightly pricy . Cool atmosphere -loads of different food options. Catering for more upper class food so not cheap for what you get but not going to break the bank either. Concept is cool -like upmarket food court. Most places have tap beer but price does vary so compare. Free wifi.I had pizza a pezzi which was very disappointing and wouldn't recommend but hubby had very tasty croquettes from croqueteria.

Great place to eat, hang out. Great place to go and eat, drink, and hang out. Across the street from the metro/train station. An abundant amount of choices to make when picking out food and drink. You have chef-owned kitchens as well as more larger restaurant. This is the biggest food-court I've seen and loved it

You can NOT miss that . This is just amazing. You can find different kind of food ..very cheap .....and .....very good. . This is not the fast food type food court you could think of. This is really good. The ambiance is great and you can see that there are as many locals as tourists. We will come back!!
Great atmosphere and food. Bustling with life, and great place to grab a piece to eat and enjoy the friendly atmosphere. A must-see !

Delightful and Delicious!. My husband was apprehensive but I'd read ahead. The result? He was pleasantly surprised and I was satisfied I was right. Wonderful food options, friendly and pretty vibe. Awesome!

Inexpensive Gourmet Food. If you want delicious gourmet food for a very reasonable price this is the place to go. They have something for every palate from appetizers to dessert . You can buy good wines & beer. A casual atmosphere so you can dress casually. A great place to meet friends & have a good tasty meal.

Good options. This is an upscale food court with many local options. Good solid food choices. Great for families since everyone can wander around and pick out what they want. Everything we tried was good. It was a bit overcrowded on a Sunday afternoon - I believe because many people were fleeing the heat and it was a poker place to sit and chill. We went back during the week and it was much more manageable. I would recommend it.

Very different than a real local market but ok for a short break. We walked through,would not have a whole meal there but pizza was ok.Expensive for a small square,3 euro but fine, with buffalo mozarella.Its kind of a gourmet fast food station which is trendy but lacks atmosphere.There is a nice shop with handcrafts and retro soaps.Nearby outside on friday there was a nice craft market and I loved the silkscreen thirts a woman designed(camaelion,crabs,plants) and there is some original jewellary as well.

Wonderful food. Very crowded.. This place has such an amazing variety of wonderful local dishes, but was terribly crowded. Be wary of thieves as well, I had my cell phone lifted here. The croquettes were my favorite.
Lovely market ! . It's a beautiful place with good variety of food :) one can buy food here as well as just to eat your lunch in this place :) meat, seafood and fish, vegetables , everything :)

Time Out have killed any traditional feeling in a market (Now a generic fancy food hall).. Really disappointed. Don't know what the market was like before but felts as if there was nothing authentically Portuguese about it. Most couples or families were tourists. Appreciate that it tries to support local, but does it also stifle the up and coming or aspirational food outlets and chefs that don't have Time Out support. What's Time Outs policy on retention and introduction? Seems to create a dilemma for them as to be contemporary it has to change with the times.Much better few hours and Euros spent at LxFactory (R. Rodrigues de Faria 103, 1300 Lisboa, Portugal).

Don't miss it. Don't miss it . Very good food . Long wait for the food but it is really worth it. You have a lot of food to choose from but I loved the chicken. There is a fresh juice place in the middle that you should not miss either.

Love it!!. We loved this place!! There is something to everyone: from pasta to asian food; from meat to sea food; beers; wines; sweets; etc... You can go wrong in there. And also teh place is amazing, huge and nice decor...

Good food. We ordered from the Henrique Sá Pessoa stall at the top end of the market in the middle. The food was delicious especially the roast pork on a purée. There were all sorts of stalls from Asian to Burgers with drink stalls in the middle; so something for everyone. I also bought some inexpensive tinned sardines and octopus from Conserveira de Lisboa which are cutely packaged. Best to grab a seat first and then go get your food. We got there about lunch time and it was packed with tourists. It might be less busy after peak times.

The place to eat. Imaginative use of the old food market, lots of outlets of high quality food , you can get just about anything here front Portuguese food, to Thai food, pastas, ice cream , wine, beer. A Lisbon must visit.

Vibrant food court. This is a fantastic place to eat when you have a variety of palates to please. In addition to the convenience of variety, the atmosphere is fun and lively. The food we ordered was fantastic! We wanted to go back but ran out of time. I would definitely go back in the future!

Crowded but fun. We had dinner at the Time Out Market while in Lisbon. The energy was incredible and the selection of food choices was great. What better way to meet fellow travellers or better yet, meet locals than to sit with them at long tables while enjoying a delicious meal!

Worth a Visit, But Be Prepared to Pay a Bit More For a Meal. Fresh, high-quality local and ethnic main courses, snacks, desserts, coffee, juice and alcohol. A bit expensive and very touristy, but it's a fun place to go once or twice.

Make up your mind quickly. So you can grab a place to eat! We were travelling with lots of family so we staked out a spot and others orders what they wanted. Great food and wine options to try. Highly recommended!!! Get there early or off peak. Unfortunately, too many loud singing Germans were in town for the Bayern Munich game during our lunch. I wonder if these German fans realize what jerks they look like, wandering around lovely Lisbon and among very understanding Portguese and yet still acting like such idiots, singing soccer club songs in the open eating hall. We are "dumb Amis" and we would never behave that way. So rude. What is wrong with German soccer fans?
Nice food. Great place to explore different types of food! Lots of small food stands, something for every taste. Enjoyed it, especially the sushi stand!

Great food and atmosphere. Great food, good for a group as everyone can choose what they want, whether it's just an ice-cream or a steak. Can be tricky to find a seat at peak times but persevere, there were 6 in our group, we visited 3 times and managed to sit together each time. Opens until late on a Sunday.
A MUST see in Lisbon. Go sit at one of the counters and order away...delicious seafood options and great service! This place is huge so go try alittle of everything!
Overpriced tourist hang out . While in other parts of the world this kind of food market is more econimical here it is more expensive than local restaurants. Did you notice there are no locals here ?

The Market by the river. Very popular, reasonably priced, good range of culinary options, and tasty food. Have the option to have a glass of wine or beer. Because of the peak holiday season the place was crowded with high demand for seating

Such a cool place to visit for the best selection of food!. We visited at lunchtime on Saturday and was greeted by such a massive selection of different food and drink we didn't know where to start. Lots of long tables with benches go through the middle of the place and the only problem you have is choosing which food to go for. We went for Asian food which was fantastic, freshly made and beautifully presented with a quick turn around. Special mention to Toranja.pt which is a stall within the Time Out Market which sells artwork. We bought some awesome placemats which were locally designed.

Whew. It doesn't open until 12:00. And the boom the whole place fills up, we didn't order the best, should have looked at what locals were eating. Wish we could have bought some of the fish etc. but no place to cook in the hotel.

Nice concept of many food options. Seems to be a new concept in many cities getting many mini restaurants under one roof. Just like food area in mall but more upscale. Nice atmosphere with many choices. I had some kind of cod and potatoe pie which was good. Others ate Thai food which was just ok. If you are in a group wishing to eat different foods this would be a good choice.

Relaxed, great variety of cuisines. Great fun - treat yourself to a variety of tasty dishes from sushi to assado to gelato. We went mid-afternoon on a Sunday and it was easy to get a table and relax over a glass of wine. Recommended.

What a place!. Hola all,We went mid week around 3:00 and the place was packed...a testament to how good the food and selection is. As a group of four we found a place to sit first (not the easiest task, but people are constantly coming and going) and went out in pairs to get our food.There are over 30 gourmet food stations to select from and most offer wine or beer with your meal. The atmosphere itself is electric and even if you don't plan on staying for a meal, it's worth a drop in just to see the place.

Worth a visit!. Many choices of food under the same roof. So you can go there and have a little bit of everything. It can be a bit crowded so prepare to have to look for a seat during the busiest times. We went there for lunch, and had a cheese platter, some pata negra, pastel de bacalhau and prego, which were all good. The wine was also good, and I also liked the sangria made at the wine bar. Would definitely go there again! We even bought some Azeitao cheese to take home.
amazing food selection. This is the best spot to have some quick Portuguese food at a good price and good quality. I like the fact that I can choose from an amazing variety of foods.
Great food but a bit crowded. You can choose from portuguese food, to snacks and even sushi. The offer is good, the prices are reasonable but is always crowded at lunch and dinner hours.
Sad!. One of the most important markets in Lisbon, was transformed in some place with expensive food.Only for tourists...
Great Place for lunch. Really good food stands: Modern and quality food at fair prices. Very unusual for Portugal, in my experience. Absolutely worth a visit.
Cheap, great atmosphere, and great food & wine. Really enjoyed spending time here in Time Out, the various stalls offer some delicious food and the wine is extremely tastey. Would visit again.
Eating out. A wide variety of foods but very busy and hard to get a table. Quite expensive for what you get. Worth a look.

Great selection. If you are like me, and had a hard time choosing a restaurant or not knowing what to eat because you wanted it all, the market is a great spot. The prices are touristy, but you can make your own tapas type meal here and enjoy a variety of flavored in one stop. I wouldn't come across town for it, but was handy when I got off the team from my day trip to Belem and was hungry.

Great food selection but very crowded. This market area was very impressive and filled with fresh food and prepared food stalls. The first challenge was deciding what to eat. I got a potato pizza that was delicious. The second challenge was finding a place to sit. The food was tasty and reasonably priced, but it took a very long time to find a place to sit - even as just one person. If the weather is not too hot, I would suggest that you get food inside but then go eat outside to avoid the crowd.
So many choices . What a place , you have food for every taste and more, even you have a restaurant at the first floor, very interesting menu

So much affordable food, so little time. We planned to browse and buy a snack for our lunch at the Time Out Market (aka Mercado da Ribeira). We arrived early expecting to look over the fresh fruit and vegetables, but that part of the market seems non existent, being used by tables selling old coins, postage stamps, and typical flea market fare.When the food section opened we discovered a whole new side (literally) to the building. Our snack became a grazing session starting with irresistible fresh, enormous oysters at Monte Mar washed down with boutique beer, followed by prosciutto and cheese toasts washed down with a glass of red wine, then a pork roll (disappointing compared to the other myriad of options available), followed by a chocolate eclair (authentic perfection by l'eclair Patisserie Français and served with authentic French charm with a glass of sparkling wine. We love local fresh produce markets, but nothing prepared us for this experience of fine dining grazing.

Not the best option for breakfast. Expensive, not a great variety for breakfast (more for fast snacks during lunch). Several lunch spots, not too great atmosphere, quite clean (closer to foodcort, than to a market)

Fun atmosphere; tasty food. The setup is simple - a selection of the best Lisbon eateries invited to open up a stall around the outside edges of a large communal seating area. This makes for great choice, reasonable prices and a nice buzz to the place. Choice your timing carefully as it does get busy.

Endless gastronomic pleasure . An excellent spot for a gastronomic pleasure indeed. A great variety of local food as well as some other cuisines (Chinese, Japanese). Loved a fig salad and tuna tartare. You can also find a bar there with a great selection of wines. A very famous spot)

Brilliant food hall concept . Amazing selection of small kitchens serving some utterly delicious food. Informal setting, communal seating, it's just a great concept. Compared to "local" restaurants it's probably a little bit pricier but well worth the visit, not only for the vast selection of fresh food on offer with some of the most talented young chefs but also for the amazing ambiance in the hall with the food markets literally next door. The place is full young Portuguese professionals enjoying an informal meal with friends..... You can't visit Lisbon and not check out this place - we were there the night Portugal win the World Cup and the place naturally erupted but it was just so civilised.........
So much choice , so much fun , so so good!! . Such a good idea with so much choice and something for everyone! Amazing! Will defiantly be back!! We loved it!! ✌️

A choice for everyone. We visited the Market two days in a row because we thought it was a great choice for everyone in our party. One of my kids is very picky and she was delighted to find a place where she could order Asian noddles and that's what she ordered two days in a row for lunch. The prices are right for the quality of food you're getting. Also, we didn't have problems finding a place to seat, mostly because we were having late lunch or early dinners. This place reminds me of The Ferry Building in San Francisco, but much bigger, and in my opinion nicer. The choices are amazing, you can order food from well known chefs for a reasonable price ,affordable wine ,and the quality is great .Just go!
Too crowded . Probably a great place to eat however is overcrowded and noisy. Do visit the market early in the morning (fish, flowers and fruits)

Huge variety of choices!. We visited time out market again on this trip after having been for the first time in January. It didn't disappoint the first time and it definitely didn't disappoint this time either. I love the huge variety of different restaurants here and you really can get whatever you fancy at the time! We visited the same food outlet as the first time we went and it was still fabulous. We shared a francesinha and some stuffed mushrooms before also indulging in some oysters! The food is all really fresh and you don't have to wait long at all for it, just take a seat in the massive dining hall and enjoy the atmosphere!
Lots of variety in this upscale food court. This is like an upscale food court with different vendors to choose from for your meals. Pretty space near the water. A bit pricey in my opinion.
People watching. Lots of stalls with great local chefs, all types of cuisine, lots of energy and a great location between Chiado and Belèm.

Family lunch. Plenty of choice from hot and cold savoury dishes or coffee and delicious cakes Wine or beer also available Service was good and our hot food was ready in minutes even though we were there during a busy lunchtime

Great Fun. Very tired, hot and hungry we stopped in here on the recommendation of a friend. A bit chaotic but interesting and great variety of choices from traditional Portugese to Sushi to Hamburgers. Something for everyone and great fun as well. Don't miss in Lisbon!
Vibrant foodie temple. A great place to sample modern Portuguese food. Good with children, everybody gets to eat their favourite food with the large choice available.

Great place for dinner (variety and great prices!!_. We just returned from 2 weeks in Spain and Portugal, and we loved our 3 days in Lisbon. This market was recommended to us by other tourists, and we loved it! All of the restaurant stands are chosen/hand picked, and they are all amazing. We ate dinner here each night, and it was a fun environment and fantastic food for the price. There are places for gourmet hamburgers, croquets (I highly recommend the goat cheese and onion ones), pizza, and every kind of fish and seafood imaginable. We would grab some sangria right up front, and then just go to different food stalls for each course. Do not miss this!! Way more fun, variety, and cheaper than going to any restaurant.

Nice place!!!. The time out market is a nice place. Ideal to have a good lunch in a nice atmosphere. The portions are ok and the price is correct. You can eat whatever you want ( burgers,fish,sushi,...)

Fun spot!. We were traveling with our millennial kids and stopped here for dinner on day 1. It is a fun and energetic atmosphere that really helped all of us get our vacation to Lisbon started on a positive note. Lots of great food choices.
Really fun food Experience. An unexpected and great place to eat/drink, with hundreds of fresh and quality choices. Wish that North American food courts could be like this!!!!!!!

Great concept, but I wouldn't be back. I really wanted to like this place, especially after reading all the reviews. At Marlene Vieira, we got the duck risotto and Sunday special (veal), and also a pork dish at the place next door. All were good, but not memorable. We did like the cocktails at Cinco Lounge, but it was very very light with alcohol. Overall a cool place, but not worth coming back to

Incredible variety . There is every kind and f food you can imagine here. It is a huge place that is a food court of the highest quality. So many choices! Be sure to walk around the whole place before you decide what to eat and drink!

Massive choice. This is quite a classy market place, the food hall is great, very modern with a large choice of stalls. I had Thai noodles which were lovely along with a chilled glass of sangria which had a berry mixture added which was a lovely touch. The next day we went in again as we got off the ferry and had a cake each, my husband had the cheesecake and I had chocolate torte both were very nice and reasonably priced.
Great food, great prices. Sometimes very crowded, try to go around 7pm. Weekends, don't go. Crowded!Chefs food, with a big bar and great environment.Love to go there, a chefs dish for 12€!

Busy and yummy food market . Tons of different yummy stalls to choose from. A big Cafeteria. You order your food from a booth and take it when your buzzer beats. Hard to find seats but the food is awesome.
Wide variety of eateries. Great place to please everyone. Had a wide variety of foods from local favorites to pizza. Lots of desserts too. Easy to find.

Indoor Plaza of delights. A ancient market revitalized by Time Out magazine is now a trendy set for cooking/eating experiences. You may choose a delicacy, the perfect ice cream form Santini's, a gourmet menu by one of the many Chefs. Pick up your choice and sit at the many tables there. You even can buy your goodies from the local market which continues in an aisle aside.

A brilliant marketplace. Well this really is a treat if you're in Lisbon - Timeout market is a market of 2 halves - the right hand side is a traditional market, lots of fruit and veg on stalls. The left hand side is a renovated warehouse style building with eateries around the outside and a huge number of tall tables and stools in the middle. It's been very cleverly done and I think it's a real asset. If only we had one in Manchester - I think it would go down a storm! We ended up going here twice - the first time we ate lunch. There are lots of seafood places to choose from, some amazing looking food as well as places to get wine, beer, desserts, ice cream. The evening was perhaps even busier so we just grabbed a dessert and then moved on. It was tricky finding space to sit so I'd recommend finding somewhere to sit first and then getting food.It was packed both times - seemingly with tourists and locals. Fab atmosphere. I'd really recommend it.

Food court for tourists. It's a food court for tourists but it has been done quite nicely. Good for fun, buzzy group dining if you want to sit at communal high top tables, see/try a range of dishes and are not too fussy about quality. Don't expect staff to be overly friendly - they are under the pump and don't try to hide it. The Time Out advertising sponsorship everywhere obviously doesn't really help to create an authentic atmosphere, and because the market area is completely separate it lacks that bustling vibe. But it's fun and if you want to get chatting to other tourists this is a good place to do it. Word of advice - if you order drinks at the same time as food, ask them to give you them straight away, otherwise you face waiting for your food to be prepared with nothing to drink (easily 15 mins or more).

Time-Out restaurant. this is a converted warehouse that has numerous restaurants in it. Most of them specialize seafood. It is a port city after all. My friend got octupus and I had fish, good food, reasonable prices
Great atmosphere . Excellent for casual food of many different types and cuisines . Did stick to Portuguese and was very enjoyable . Very groovy although we went at 3pm so not as manic
Bustly lunch. This is a great place for lunch and well renovated space. We had a seafood meal which was very good for the price. It was a good place to sit down in between sightseeing.
Something for everyone. What a wonderful concept. Many of the fine restaurants all in one place in Lisbon near the water. Amazing food choices. All fantastic!!!

great food, fun atmosphere. Time Out Market offers a wide variety of foods to try, with a large central eating area that is great for groups, or for meeting new people. I was there during the EuroCup, and they had huge screens streaming the matches. Would recommend for a casual meal, particularly if you're with a large group of people and can't all decide on one type of cuisine. There's something here for anyone!

Brilliant for something to eat, very lively. This has just about every food group you can think of and ideal if you have a group of you all wanting to eat something different. It's busy, quite noisy but in a good way... You'd go to a quiet restaurant if you wanted quiet! Here you can try all sorts of food from vendors around the edge and then sit on high tables in the middle, it was a great experience. Would certainly go back.

Everything you need to eat in Lisbon. It may seem like a cop out but whether your time in Lisbon is limited or not, the Time Out Market works in that it allows you to try everything great about Lisbon's food scene. Every stall here has a story (the stalls each come with their own brief write ups) and legacy in contemporary Portuguese food scene. Seafood, steaks, down to the best tinned sardines and tuna - they've got something for everyone by some renowned chefs. The best part, the cocktails and beers available here make for a great afternoon meal.Like the mercados in Spain, the idea is very much a communal "food court". You pick your food and find a place to sit, which makes for a great if not always comfortable ambiance (for some reason the tables are designed uncomfortably high). The food pricing seems pretty standard - mains go for roughly 9 euros and above.

So many delicious options. I was so excited to try this food hall and I was not disappointed. It is spacious with many many delicious options including the delicious gelato place Santini (though with less flavors available than its sister store I went to in Cascais), padrone peppers, oysters, octopus salad and many other Portuguese specialties. There were also pizzas, hamburgers and other dessert places.

Great variety, fresh food. This place has a great variety of food, many stalls are represented by well-known restaurants. Plenty to choose from in the food court downstairs, but the place does get very busy during peak hours. There are restaurants upstairs for more comfortable seating. Some places take credit cards, but some only take cash, so have some handy. There are a few ATMs in the complex though.Walked past the Monte Mar outlet in the food court and was captivated by the fragrance of coriander that was being prepared on the bench. Had the clams in garlic sauce and it was fantastic. Also tried the Le Eclair stall with some beautiful creations. The other local product worth trying is Ginja de Obidos, sour cherry wine, located on the external row of shops of the building. Only 1 Euro for a shot of Ginja served in a chocolate cup.

Worth a visit. After a long, walk around Lisbon we stumbled across the market. There was LOTS of choice and the food we ate was delicious. There is free wifi. Try and get there early in order to visit the fish market next door. You could easily spend all day there, trying out the various food/drinks!

Great choice, nice choice, modern market athmosphere. From gourmet burgers to traditional but revamped Portuguese food you find everything here, there are even gin and tonic and ginjinha stalls. The atmosphere is nice and noisy, feels like the modern, hip spin-off of a real market. It's the perfect choice if you are with a group, here everybody finds something for their taste.

wow. Biggest, best, most attractive food hall I've ever seen. Long communal tables are shared by patrons of so many food sellers I could not count them. Everything you would want is here, from oysters and champagne to Thai noodles, charcuterie to cakes and deserts, tapas to full breakfasts! Open from morning to late at night. Lovely food and wine shops around the outsides, and a fab market for fish and fresh veg etc in the mornings. Fantastic for groups who want to eat different things in different quantities, tourists and locals alike seem to come solo, in families and couples. All food seems to be available to take out too. I demand the like in the UK, pronto.
EXCELLENT !!! A MUST DO. It's not tradional food, you're not among the locals, but it's worth every penny (euro)/ Great food from high classed chefs.A must do.

Good fun, but go prepared!. The Time Out market in Lisbon is a great idea. It is part of a genuine fresh produce market, which should not be missed. The area where you eat is beautifully decorated and inviting. Large communal tables are used for dining, you cannot book, just find a space. The idea is that you choose your meal and drinks from the outlets that surround these tables, take a seat and then go and collect your order when it is ready. My advice to to wander around and look at all the outlets first to see what is on offer (many have daily specials and plates), then find a seat, then go and order. It is also worth noting that there are restaurants with waiters and tables along the outside edge of the market. These do delicious food served in a more orderly manner. The interior can be very hot, is noisy and crowded. Not a place for a quiet chat over a relaxed dinner. Food is hugely varied and inexpensive. Definitely worth a visit, and the street immediately around the market are worth checking out for more dining and drinking options. The market serves food until late (midnight I think) and opens at 10am.

WOW! Big variety of good quality food.. Absolutely loved this place. Fantastic choices of great quality food. Fun community tables that accommodate large and small groups. Clean, energetic and a great place to people watch. AND they have free wifi!!! You wont be disappointed.

Must Visit. Array of food and drink places in a great location. It allowed me and my friends to sample a variety of different foods but still sit together. We all tried something different at each of us raved about our choices. Great food and reasonable prices! The galato was great too!
Most of the food stalls are chains . Was expecting more local food stalls, the majority of them seemed to be chains with a market feel to it

Overpriced food comfort for tourists. A food court with many stalls serving food of varying quality but uniformly low value. Some good to very good food offered at prices that exceed what can be had even in an upscale lisbon restaurant. The added value is the simplicity of not having to make a reservation, the comfort of being surrounded by your peer travelers, and the variety of food offerings. Stall attendants often between aloof and downright snobish. This is nothing but good "food truck" food at restaurant prices and restaurant slow delivery speed.

Very busy but worth it!. What a nice threat this is. Expect a lot of people around lunch time, certainly in the weekends. The regular Market adjacent to it isn't as crowded as this area. Lot's a food stalls for good food, good wines and awesome desserts.

Gourmet Food Court. This is a food court in downtown Lisbon, or short walk from cruise port, composed of dozens of gourment food vendors. I ate at Performa and tried a fish entree and sandines sushi. It was delicious. So many options that it is hard to choose. Would definitely come back here. Gets very crowded.
Fantastic food experience. This is a faboulous food experience. You look for a table, choose from more than 50 food and wine bars and discover all Portugal has to offer on your dish.

Mercado da Ribeiro - plenty of choice!. What a discovery was this foodhall/market with plenty of excellent portuguese restaurants! Plenty of choice to pick your food/wine & desert from restaurants of all kinds (we enjoyed the seafood restaurants!), just pick them from different spots (you can actually check the food being prepared) and then find seating on one of the long tables - great formula!

Center Market. Wonderful variety of food offered, great market on the other side of the venue. Open air market offering fruits, vegetables, herbs, fresh fish and meats. The resturant side offers a variety of local businesses that are wonderful!

Very good food from diverse restaurants at a large range of prices, in a very crowded and noisy environment. It is a beautiful old market. It is a large space, with a very high ceiling, usually crowded, which makes it a very noisy environment. If you don't mind the noise, you can enjoy different types of food, drinks and desserts amongst the animated crowd.You can either have a full meal in one place of just buy smaller portions from different places. At some places you can have a meal seating outside, at others you can have a meal seating at the balcony or you can grab a table (or a spot at a large table) in the middle of the place. It is not going to be cheap (unless you just eat a hamburger or something like that) but it is not going to be too expensive and it is going to be worth it.There are specialized wine places, gin places, beer places, cheese places, seafood places, traditional Portuguese food or traditional with a touch of modernity and authentic delicacies from around the country.It is definitely worth a visit.

Disappointing . Looked amazing but dishes didn't live up to expectations. €8 fried calamari = 10 little rings! Black risotto with scallops was unpleasantly cheesy. €8.50 for 3 little & thin seared scallops whose flavour was overpowered by some brown sauce spooned over the dish. Blew €60 on 6 average tasting dishes. Good to visit but choose carefully!

Great assortment of food. I like every effort of creating a nice food court. This was not disappointing. There are lots of different foods for different tastes.It seems like there should be more tables and chairs to the amount of restaurants. Maybe some more facilities. Some less popular parts seemed rather run down.

So many food types to try. This is an amazing place to visit. It is the largest food court I have ever seen. It has many different places selling food around the edge and you sit on tables in the middle. Once you place your order they give you a pager so that when you food is ready you go back to collect it.The only draw back is that it is very busy and difficult to find a table so if you are with friends, find the table first and one of you keep it whilst the others order the food, otherwise you are wandering around with trays of food and nowhere to sit.Also finish with the ice cream, it is amazing.

Sweet Mother of Food!!!!. This review will be too simple if you want to eat amazing food, and have more options than you could ever hope for go here. Like now! Just make sure you stop by Santinis Gelato on your way out or you might as well plan on just returning for your next meal until you grab some.
Best place for great food!. Best place for great food! Food from all over the world and off course from Portugal. Oysters, burgers and a lovely wine bar.

Great food and atmosphere . On a Monday for lunch the atmosphere is great and it is not too crowded. Portions are a bit small, but worth the money. Fresh ingredients and chefs who know what they are doing. Can recommend the grilles octopus from Marlene Vieira and the salmon with guacamole from Alexandre Silva!
Lovely food!!. We ate here thrice during our stay and loved it. There is just so much variety and cuisines from all over the world! Must eat here atleast once during your stay!

An expensive but nice day at the Market. Time Out Market Lisboa is an renovated part of the old food market down by the trainstation. The market is built up around different foodstalls who sells specialties like various types of ham, cheese, bread and so on. The Market is targeted against tourists, although a few lisboans also go there, it is expensive enough. Very often crowded you will have to look for a place to sit, often smart to come in group of three or two to hold on to seats while other people order food. If you are looking for an authentic food market you should check out the other ones situated around the city.

Unexpected great eats!!. Brilliant selection of food varying from takes on original Portuguese cuisine through to South East Asian although we ate mosty local dishes. Excellent wine merchant. Central seating area with great atmosphere. Can order from any or a mixture of the vendors if not everyone is in the mood for the same style. Open till late!! Most stalls stop serving at about 23:00 to 23:30 but better to arrive around 21:00.
Great place. Huge selection of food, all seemed of high quality with reasonable prices. Great atmosphere. Highly recommended, especially for larger groups.

Exciting food hall. We have been there a couple of times during our three weeks stay in Lisbon and I have to say - what a fantastic idea! Different restaurants under one roof - everyone can choose whatever he wants. Excellent quality but on the weekends very busy.

Seafood aplenty. It's a great place to grab a quick snack or enjoy a number of different dishes from the many stalls on a long afternoon. We tried a number of dishes and wines and never left hungry or disappointed. I recently took my colleague while on business trip and she enjoyed the food and atmosphere very much as well.

Spoilt for choice!. Great indoor venue for casual dining with communal tables covering the centre of a huge old Warehouse/Market. Restaurants of all kinds line the walls all round and you really are spoilt for choice with all types of food available at a good range of prices. Some places also have seats around their counters from where you can watch them cooking your meal if that's your thing! The communal tables however are great for couples or groups who want to eat from different places. Most restaurants serve both beer and wine but there are also drinks stalls scattered around as well. There are also some great looking ice cream and dessert stalls for your dessert course! All in all this is a great laid back place to sample a variety of different cuisines. Totally recommended!

Mercado da Ribeira (that's how portuguese call it). The official name os this place is Mercado da Ribeira (that's how portuguese call it).Lots of choices for lunch, dinner - and check out happy hour too!From Traditional Portuguese food till japanese food.The place is a original "mercado" (market) where they used to sell fresh fish, meat, fruits, veggies and flowers.

A smorgasbord of tasty Portuguese food and wine. We went to the market three times for snacks but you could graze all day there. Three sides of the market are lined with food "stalls", some representing well know restaurants in Lisboa. Tall benches and stools line the centre along with some drinks "stalls". You can eat fish, meat, starters, mains, desserts and drink wine, beer, cocktails and coffee. It opens at 1200 for food but we managed to get a coffee before then. It closes very late.Next door is a small fruit, veg, fish and meat retail market.

Best food choices in Lisbon. The market is a fabulous place to eat. There are so many choices and food and wine is delicious. A great place to cater for all types of eaters. We ate here some of the best food we had eaten in Lisbon. The wine recommendations were wonderful.

Amazing find in middle of old market. Did not know this was here but should have realised something was popular by stream of tourists heading this way. Over 50 small food outlets to cover all tastes & a large open eating area with fantastic buzzing atmosphere. Only down side is finding somewhere to sit & eat your food when it is busy. Amazing place for people watching whilst enjoying great food

Great fun with friends. Came here with my husband and my two friends. Great selection of food and a great buzzy atmosphere. Can't remember the name of the place where I ordered food but it was at the far end in the corner, teriyaki chicken. Delicious and very reasonably priced. Really broad range of people, from young to old from all over the globe, brilliant! Only problem was finding a seat, but after a bit of moving around we managed it and had a great evening.

Fine Dining & Best Pao do Lo. Oh where to start??? We only discovered this treasure our last day in Lisbon. Had we visited earlier we would've returned one or two times. The top chefs have mini-kitchens and it was so hard to choose from octopus rice, cod with asparagus, grilled squid, octopus salad, cod risotto, they fry their potato chips to order. The Portugese wine selections are varied and top class! My date ordered the amazingly delicious cod risotto which took forever, so we had my octopus salad as a starter, drank vinho verde and munched on potato chips until the risotto was ready 20 minutes later. Not exactly fast food but it was all good. For dessert seek out the Pao do Lo still soggy in the middle eggy sponge cake near opposite the Time Out shop close in the desserts/snacks/sundries section. OMG, we now regret sharing just one as we were not able to find another as good in Porto our next destination. We tried three there after doing research but they did not compare, at all.
Very nice place. Cool place, lot of choice. A bit crowded though. Burger place is ok, although won't blow your mind. Good feeling overall

A must place to eat!!. With over 30 eating establishments to choose from this makes it a great spot to stop by and get a bite to eat. The word market doesn't necessarily conjure up images of fine dining in my mind, not at least until now. This place has some of the finest restaurants yet is gentle on the pocket.One side of the market you can find your typical fruits and vegetables another side fish and meats and another side small restaurants, wine and beer stalls and coffee shops. I'm truly enamored with the set up and sad to leave tomorrow.I hope you really enjoy it as we did. If you do be sure to come back and give me a thumbs up!! Thanks! Enjoy!!

Great vibe - great food. You might struggle to find a place to park your car, but if you get this venue it's certainly worth it. You can basically choose any time of food and consume it on the shared floor surrounded by all small restaurants based at this historic market site. We chose the eatery "Miguel Castro e Silva" for a duck dish (Pato a Braz) and it was delectable and well worth the wait!
Great trendy market . This old market has been redone. It now houses mini versions of some of Lisbon's finest restaurants. There is ample communal seating available. Well worth a visit and a meal

Superb choice in a great atmosphere. After several bad experiences of the Portuguese tourist restaurant (they can't cook green veg properly - always overdone!), we were delighted with this. Time Out have done a terrific job of converting half of a tradition market. Here we found it possible to assemble, for a reasonable price, an evening meal of high quality from the amazing choice of food outlets. The atmosphere was extremely enjoyable. A must for anyone visiting Lisbon.

Heaven for foodies . Time out market was like heaven on earth for me. It was really busy and crowded but the delicious foods on offer made up for it. I particularly enjoyed the chargrilled sardines at monte mar and the crispy chicken peri peri at Miguel laffin. I'll make a beeline for the time out market next time I'm in Lisbon. There is also a nice cafe out side to drink beer in the sun.
Great little area to visit. Loads of choice good value And worth a visit just to people watch. We didn't eat here but so much choice I could of chose anything.

Super atmosphere, food, value, amazing choice. Time Out market is a great place to eat the huge hall is surrounded by over 20 restaurants, the centre full of tables. Great fun, good food and good value. We were lucky to be there the night Lisbon played in the Euro 2016 football finals - fantastic atmosphere.

Must visit !. I would say it's the best place to eat in Lisbon . I loved the concept of the place: there are many different restaurant sections of many different cuisines all around , with the sitting area in the middle. What means that if you are group of people, everyone can eat different kind of food in one place. Time out market is always very busy , but it was not a problem to find a table. Food we tried was delicious . Such a shame we find the place at the last day of our vacation. Highly recommend to everyone .
Wow! . A must stop for food lovers. Many options for affordable price, great cocktails even. Close to the night scene of this great city which makes it a perfect start of the night! Don't miss it!

A must visit in Lisbon!!!. The Time Out market in Lisbon is a must try experience. A great opportunity to check out the local foodie scene with an excellent range of choices. Most important lyrics for me was the chance to try fine dining plates from some of Portugal's great modern chefs at truly affordable prices. Great atmosphere with a local feel. Highly recommend a visit!

fun place to be, good food. We enjoyed out time there, there was a Euro2016 match going on and the ambiance was great.It is hard to find a place to sit, so it would be a problem for large groups. Plenty of variety, food can be expensive but everything we had was delicious. Market closes but the "food court" stays open really late

Lots of choice but VERY busy!. My party were split down the middle with the Time Out Market, I really loved it! I thought the amount of varied foods on offer was fantastic and what I ended up choosing for myself was really so delicious! I had a beef, fois grois and truffle sandwich with fries. GORGEOUS!My brother-in-law went for a veal risotto, again, he loved it. My husband however really didn't enjoy our trip there. It is very noisy and packed to the rafters with people, it is obviously a tourist trap and can be quite stressful when there are a few different people in a group getting different foods from different stalls then trying to grab seats together. For me and my experience of the food I had, I'm giving it 3/5 but more realistically, I think it'd be 3.5 / 5 if there was such an option.We finished with cocktails and the traditional custard tarts which were lovely – but we only visited once during the holiday and I probably wouldn’t go back in a rush.

Fabulous Eating Place. Having walked round the sights of Lisbon we were ready for a break and found this Eating Mercado. It was very large full of different bars and restaurants, the atmosphere was amazing and a fantastic place to nibble on tapas and people watch. We loved it!
Fun dining experience. Plenty of dining options here. It could be a bit hard to get a table during lunchtime, but the food was terrific.

Crazy busy place with great choices. Time your visit wisely and scout a table first at this popular food court mercado. Lots of great choices of food from some of the areas best eateries all under one busy roof.

Plenty of options, must try!. Even though the Marketplace is always packed, the food variety and quality there makes up for it. There is everything from sushi to steak to wine tasting. Grab a comfortable table and enjoy a football game on the screen while eating the world on your plate.

Little bit of everything at restaurant prices with school dinner service!. I don't want to sound too negative for we had an excellent meal at a decent price (€30) however having been to the food cart shed in Copenhagen we expected something a lot more edgy. You walk around and pick your favourite, then elbow your way to a table most likely with no room for your pals. Have to abandon your seat in order to collect your dinner on a tray (à la primary school dinners) and still play proper dollar. We visited the CL chicken emporium. Stunning food, lovely juicy buttery chicken, couldn't fault it. It is certainly not a 'must do' in our humble opinion but we enjoyed our meal.

Very cool place. Great place with a buzzing atmosphere. We had sushi that was some of the best I've had anywhere in the world. The guys in the restaurant were friendly and gave us few freebies to try. Highly recommended!

Dinner at Time Out on 8 July. Time Out Market is a nice Food Court with multiple options and common seating. Since I went there on a Friday night, it took us lot of time before we could find seating. It was crowded but the crowds were also energising. A German couple joined our table and we could strike up conversation about Euro2016, German teams and their loss to France, etc. Most outlets seemed mid- priced and we did not look out for "affordable" ones. Pleasant experience.

Humming air ;). I love this market it is thriving with relaxed bustle in a laid back atmosphere .Everyone is someone here and long high tables mix everyone together without deteriorating their privacy . One of you feels like fish , another like bio vegetarian , another juicy meat and a further wants Sushi , well you have come to the right place plus it is delicious . The prices are as reasonable or extravagant as you desire. Definitely go and join the hum buzz as an onlooker a communication thriver . Have a wonderful time.

A hectic oasis of gastronomy in the middle of the Lisbon desert.. I have a double-edged impression of this place. Firstly, its one of the few (perhaps a dozen) places in old Lisbon where you can have a contemporary meal done in the 21st century, as the standard here is pretty horrible. Theres a good choice and the process is tourist-friendly. The staff is nice too. On the other hand, this joint is somewhat synthetic and corporate and doesnt really tell you much about the city around you. Theres the usual post-modern fusion of various couisines, slighly small portions of modern takes on this and that. The hall is always overcrowded, noisy and it tends to be a problem to find two seats once you order your meal, let alone hear each other. The pace is afterall authentic: it is nearly impossible to eat calmly anywhere in Lisbon. I would suggest going here once you cant eat a poorly prepared bare cod with lettuce any longer, but you dont think you got a local experience while doing so.

A great food market!!. We came here for dinner on recommendation from people also staying at our hostel. It was a great experience and had top quality food and wine for very reasonable price! Although the market definitely caters to tourists more than locals, there was a good selection of traditional Portuguese food with a bit western influence. I would recommend eating here.

Fantastic selection & quality. Went here with a friend for lunch and was not disappointed. There is a wide variety of food outlets to choose from which all seemed to offer locally sourced produce. The stalls sit around a large seating area so you can easily browse and buy from different places and still sit together. It does get a little busy so be prepared to wander around a while to find somewhere to sit, especially if in a big group or at peak times, but it really is worth it! Oh and the ice cream stand...just try it!
Wow. Amazing food market near the station. Many different eateries around the market all reasonable priced. Well worth a visit even if its not to eat and soak up the atmosphere.
Super, must do. Big market hall, Great place to eat with lots of restaurants and long tables to eat.Different styles of food...choose the one you like.Not expensive

Food hall on steroids!. Brilliant setting, in a giant warehouse.Hundreds of meal options with various types of cuisine.Everything we ordered was fantastic.Beware, it gets busy from ~8pm and big groups could struggle to find seating.

great for lunch. It's a bit like Mercado San Miguel in Madrid only larger and a bit more 'commercial'....but VERY nicely done, with very wide range of food and some very high quality as most are done by local chefs, not just 'fast food'.....highly recommend trying Henrique Sa Pessoa's place (named that way)....ate their twice and it was outstanding! can get wine, beer, drinks at most places and it's open late....midnight or later on wknds.

What to try first!. We loved this place. The atmosphere was great, if a little like a school canteen. The selection from the different restaurants was very varied and the food of a high quality. I thought the little beepers they gave to let you know when your meal was ready was a very nifty idea. Ideal for all ages and all tastes.
Lovely food!. Very lovely mini restaurants in a cozy market hall. The food is freshly prepared with great love and tastes delicious!

You can here what ever you want. It is a must visit. We have been there during lunch time. It is crowed so it is better to come between lunch and dinner. There you can find all types of food and it is very good, gourmer I would even say. The best meals we had in Lisbon. The atmoshere although crowdy but cozy and modern.
Interesting place . Very interesting to turn such a warehouse like area into a very fun food market. Many local people came and a good place to taste different styles of food
Good food but a lot of people. . It's very difficult to find a table to sit. The food was delicious. It's a tourist place and the price is for tourists too.
Delicious food, interesting venue.. Great place to eat and drink with friends. Really enjoyed the oysters and the suckling pig was superb! A must visit when in Lisbon.
Amazing . I mean. Go! Too good. It's like the Eataly of NYC just amazing amazing so many options. You have everything you can imagine. A+. Go go go!
Good market. Very nice atmospheric market, the food and drink certainly look good quality, could imagine it being very noisy when full. We had a walk upstairs to look at the old fashioned tiles.

Great mix of cuisine . Generally love food market places so maybe a little biased. This place was great with lots of options to choose from...location is perfect as was the atmosphere especially while Portugal was playing in the euros.Dining area was very clean with staff constantly cleaning the tables as people are coming and going! Only fault with the place was lack of toilet facilities which was quite difficult to find.Other than that, worth a visit!

Great experience . We ate here twice during our 7 day holiday. Many of the locals eat here which I consider to be a good sign. Lots of pop up style food outlets of many different styles of food, I found the hardest thing was to make a decision.
