Once you have chosen your food you are given an alarm which will sound when the food is ready, in the meantime you can go to find your seat and choose your wine from the wine bar in the centre, there is also a beer bar too. Great atmosphere and I think this is a must visit during your stay.

Foodies Delight - Food Mall. This place is a foodie heaven. There are approximately 30 restaurant choices in a giant food market. Located near the waterfront and near a subway and bus stop; it is easily accessible. There are some fantastic restaurants here and the prices are affordable. Hours are from 10 to midnight weekdays and 10 to 2 a.m. On Friday and Saturday. Alcohol is available, so many come here late into the evenings. This is a definite MUST do in Lisbon.

Spectacular, delicious and noisy!. You can sit and eat in the middle of the place surrounded with small restaurants with all type of food. You just go and buy from the one you choose and other members in your group can choose whatever they want!
Great choice of food. So much to choose from..spent hours eating here. It's not cheap though...like most fashionable markets

Good food, queues and confused but so worth it . Visited twice, really good options for various kitchens. A bit tricky to find a table for larger groups. Frustrating part is to queue for 15 minutes to a counter, just to hear they are out of almost everything. Hey, if service attitudes we're ever trained in Portugal, one would write a note on the board which items are out and what is left....
GREAT. Great place to walk thru and see,smell and taste so many different places to eat drink and pass the time away.A must when visiting

Tons of food to choose from. My wife and I went here for lunch. After walking through the vast booths to choose from, we decided upon one chef that had fresh fish and a killer risotto. I don't think there was a wrong decision that could have been made. We sat across from a lovely couple from Denmark and talked while we ate. There was a nice community feel to it despite the presence of many tourists. Everyone spoke English. We also had a shot of tequila and gelato before and after our meal. There was a lot to.choose from and one could eat every meal in this casual food court style location with amazing food.

A market to sit down, I like :). We are are young couple and we really had a blast at this market. There's a vibrant atmosphere. We sat down and got served right away with an amazing fish dish. Everybody is talking to one and another, so great way to meet people and have a good time together.

Great food at Time Out. A lot of choice at Time Out in Lissabon. We tried 3 restaurants, from sushi, fish and more fish. Everything is really fresh and it struck me that the chef's where very creative in making stuff I never had before. Cuttlefish in a black tempura was strange to look at but tasted fantastic. So try it out !

Place for food lovers/explorers!. Its a great food plaza to be at- we went for lunch once day and ended up hanging out for a few hours, trying a verity of food! Do some research on which places to eat what, as it can be confusing to decide there (esp if the place is crowded). But the best we had was Fried squid in black tempura batter!

Not to be missed while in Lisbon. Excellent place to try a variety of local and international dishes. We had an early dinner and thoroughly enjoyed it. Sea Me warmly recommended but we also tried other restaurants and everything was delicious. Very nice and pleasant atmosphere. During the evening we understand it get very crowded, we were there at 6.30pm and it was very good timing. Highly recommended"

Don't wait until you're hungry.. Fell upon the Time Out Market almost by accident - wandering the streets and open air markets led us to this gem of a place. Sadly we arrived not long after breakfast, so no space for any of the very tempting sights and smells. Did manage to squeeze down a coffee though!Give it a look in if you are nearby.

Great place to sit and eat. This would be a great place to sit, eat and drink the afternoon away. This square with outlets of many famous restaurants in Lisbon (you have to be invited to have a stall here) gives you so much choice of what to eat and drink - it's lovely just to get a selection and munch your way through it with a glass of vinho verde.

Spoiled for choice. The market is very impressing with the style, taste and in detail. All foodies involved were of the highest calibre, I had some croquettes which had some very exquisite choices besides the original which was very good.

Great selection of top notch food. Plenty of lovely choices here...should be something for most people. I had prawns and rice, very delicious (can't remember which part I ordered from). Good way of having good food in very laid back setting, or for a quick bite.

A Feel Good Food Market. This food market has an outstanding interior design satisfying already your eyes. The architect managed to create as well a room were that does not challenge your ears. In fact the noise level is quite decent. As for the taste there are plenty of thing you will like and some you will not. I was very pleased by Honorato, Vítor Claro and Santina, but disappointed by Sea Me. However, you will definitely like this place!
Great for food on the run and with a group. A wide selection to choose from - cooking classes too! Kept missing the market, but the food section has alot to offer

Something for Everyone!. Slick, modern, and chic, this place has something for everyone. All sorts of cuisines to choose from, it felt to us like the place the locals go. We just had drinks and a bowl of freshly made potato chips - warm and delicious! We also had fun sitting at the large communal "bar" tables and watching the match on a large screen TV with the crowd. So many delicious things to try - we plan to go back!

Over-priced, but you can get dinner late. We went to the LX Factory at 10p and were not impressed since the restaurants were few and we were turned away for dinner. Time Out market provides a great atmosphere to have dinner late ot just sit and have a drink.

Foodies heaven !!!. Wow,loved this place.....Hubby went traditional I went for pizza slice,Daughter went for snacks and cake!!Something for everyone,and great to sit and people watch...If you like food and wine,then you must visit this place!!!

Fantastic variety of choices. There are a multitude of restaurants to chose from. The one we chose did not have a pleasant front end person at all. Food was just OK, nothing special at all. All in all. the market restaurants seemed trendy but a bit over rated & priced.

Don't miss this market!. Perfect place for lunch or dinner - there are so many different gourmet food choices to choose from. We were there during the Euros, so it was fun to watch the games while eating. It can get crowded but it's worth the crowds. This was my favorite place to eat in Lisbon. And, don't miss the ice cream at Santini's!
A bit overrated. You can do better in terms of getting better value-for-money food elsewhere. This is convenient for those who don't have sufficient time to explore.

so so. too crowdy (which is ok), but the problem is that all the prices are overrated...there are so many places you can eat in Lisbon, and this is good place to see and try, but really has nothing authentic and very expensive.

Friday night!. We came here quite late on a Friday night roughly around 9:30pm and wow it's busy! Think it closes around 11pm ish?Come off metro Cais do Sodré and it was just across the road. Great atmosphere and plenty of different stalls of food to choose from. Think locals come here to meet up and eat before going to bars and clubs. So you will end up having to get through some drunks to find a seat. There are plenty of seats, but it was so packed it took us a while to find a seat. If there's two of you, find a seat first then go to order. All the stalls with give you a buzzer, once your food is ready it'll let you know. Ladies toilets is a long wait, but atleast there is a toilet. Would love to try to book the chefs table booth, where they show you how they cook the food and serve to you. They also shows how to make pasteis those Portuguese tarts =)

Noisy & Crowded. We walked through the market during the day and the food area, came back that evening, not a place we wanted to eat in, very noisy, very crowded and checking round over priced, far better places to eat in the surrounding streets.

Fun place for lunch!. Very crowded, but a great vibe and SO many choices for food, beer and or wine. Reasonably priced and not a long wait in line for food orders or to find a seat. The vegetable and fish markets next door close at 2 p.m. But Time Out market is open through evening.

Buzzy thriving marketplace . We stumbled on the Time Out Market. Wonderful food stalls with fresh food, great for groups and kids. Feels right for lunch or snacking. This is a market primarily with food that is prepared to eat on site, not one where locals shop for meals to cook at home. Small cigar shop in the Time Out shop was a nice discovery

What a great surprise. A real find in Lisbon market, this super food court has everything from good coffee to a whole suckling pig roast!Clean, modern with good facilities, make it a 'must do' on your visit!
Very noisy, crowded and expensive. This is a tourist trap. It seems the food served is pretty much all good, but we found it was better to wander the local streets and eat like a local.

A very nice place to chill out when it's so hot.... An indoor place like a mercado with big screen TV, wine, food and shopping. The wine here is a lot cheaper than those in wine tasting. Nice atmosphere here.... could have spent the whole afternoon here.

WOW, A Foodie's Delight. This place was recommended to us by friends and we had no idea of what to expect. Bottom line is - the place is fantastic. There is something for everyone. We cannot say enough about Chicken All Around. 4 of the 8 of us had a dish from CAA and everyone loved the food. The other selections from the various vendors were very good as well especially the pizza vendor.
Don't miss out on it. If you have one meal to make in Lisbon, be sure to make all the efforts to be at this place. Impossible to regret, awesome food, great cratf beers, tasty wines at a good price.

Fun place . Visited this indoor market on a visit to Lisbon. It's huge with a very big selection of eateries. There are long high tables in the middle, you order your food from wherever you want and they give you a buzzer that tells you when it's ready. It's buzzy and fun.
A great buzz and any food or rink you could wish for. We called in here a couple of times and just sat with a drink a people watched. We didn't eat here but it all looked amazing. Well worth a visit.

Great place to eat, drink and be merry. Time out was on our list of places to try... and try we have... multiple times. Plenty of seating, huge selection of food types from fresh fish. Chicken and burgers to desserts and wines and a tequila bar. Prices are very reasonable, and the best part is the atmosphere. We found it to be mostly locals which was good to see. It's right down the street from the metro and the funicular. Everyone took cash while some also took credit cards. If you don't have cash there's ATM machines.

Best place to meet locals in Lisbon!. Great indoor market place to find great food and mingle with the locals from early morning until midnight. And the biggest fresh food produce market in town is right next door. Don't miss this urban gem in Lisbon!

A must for anyone who likes the food of Portugal. Hams , cheeses, wines , seafood , pastries, everything you always wanted to try distributed in boxes of the best suppliers of Portugal . A lovely market full of delights .

Next time I'm here I'll eat at the Mercado (Time Out) almost everyday!. Terrific! There are so many choices to tickle your tastebuds that it is impossible to explain. So, I'll give you the highlights:Don't miss the duck croquettes La Orange at Felicidade. Sensational!The King Crab Salad at Sea Me is awesome.A Special Portuguese Multi-flavored sherbet @ Santini. Best I've ever had...and unique!OR...Any gelato at Santini. Don't even think about getting desert anywhere else!Honorato for any burger ... They have about 10!Skip the Asian Lab. The Thai food is brutal. The gyoza are ok but there are much better choices.
Over-priced but Interesting. Food is priced too high here but there is a great selection and it is tasty. I found that the Pericles at the market were high as well. I'm not sure I will be back.
Cool place!. Good restaurants and fantastic quality. Go here if you want to take a break from your tourist visas have a breakfast, lunchbox dinner at any time. Nice designed hall, good market.

BIggest foodcourt I have seen :). As long as you are actually not looking for american food, this place must be heaven. A lot of small "restaurants" under one roof and with one area for eating. The whole family should be satiesfied.

Great place and plenty of options. The Time Out market isn't the average food court. There is a wide variety of Portuguese and other foods. Something for everyone's taste. From fried croquettes and Portuguese Tapas/petiscos to very elaborate modern interpretations of traditional Portuguese dishes. Sitting together on long tables with locals as well as foreign visitors makes it also a social happening. All dishes are served on real plates. No carton cups or plates here. Prices are reasonable, yet similar to most restaurants.

Girls short break. If you love food I'd strongly recommend spending the afternoon and/or evening here. Not for those wanting an intimate meal for two. A huge variety with over 30 kiosks and a great atmosphere. Would recommend the tempura green beans sardines & shrimp, black pork cheeks, Serrano ham stuffed figs, duck turnovers, Penang curry , gourmet ox burger, carob fig and orange cake and not forgetting the Portuguese custard tarts.

So many delicious options. This place is amazing. SO MANY delicious options. Get here early, have a friend grab seats for all of you (this place gets crowded, fast) and then purchase your food/drink. It's honestly easier to have a person or two save seats while others buy their lunch, go in shifts. If you get there early enough you'll have plenty of time to look carefully at all the options. And there are A LOT of options. But everything from savory to sweet to veggie to fish to meat to pizza to fried chicken to a variety of sandwiches is available.
All Portuguese cuisine in one place. Touristic busy place with a great choice of Portuguese dishes and several bars. Nice place to have a lunch in Lisbon.

A food lovers heaven. We were told about this whilst in Lisbon. And thank goodness we were. It is a mass market of all kinds of cuisines, with Curries, Steaks, Deli's, Pizzas and desserts to choose from. We got some Portuguese style Chicken and a Gourmet Hot Dog. Best Hot Dog ever. And the Chicken was mouth watering. With an Eclair and Portuguese Creme Brûlée tart to finish between us. The only danger is there is so much choice that you don't know where to even think to start and choose from. Every market stall looked delicious. If you love food, you have to go here.

Great atmosphere. You should bisit this place just for the atmosphere. A very busy, buzzing food market with vendors from all over Lisbon. I met a local there who told me: "This place is amazing. The atmosphere is great but the food is s**t!" The food is not that bad, just a little over-priced. Be prepared to eat standing ip at one of the counters unless you have sharp elbows and can fight your way to a seat. Geared up to cater for tourists from cruise ships this place is worth a visit just for the atmosphere.

Awesome place to try Portuguese food. I stumbled on the Time Out food market which is a very cool food market in a warehouse style building. There's loads on offer and is all great quality. The pricing is a bit more expensive but you can try a bit of other food.

Busy food court. Many excellent culinary choices for lunch. It's a large food hall connected to a farmers market.It was packed with tourists many sporting Tupperware T shirts. Must have been a convention nearby and they gathered here for a midday meal. The various stalls have food from excellent chefs, but it's not a place for a relaxing lunch. Just too frenetic. We bought some produce instead and decided to grab a meal on Avenue Libertade.

All the good restaurants of Lisboa in a single place. The renewed Old Mercado da Ribeira now with several small subsidiaries of the best restaurants in Lisboa is a must see in the Portuguese town . One of the advanteges of this place is that you can taste diferent sections of the Portuguese Food in a single place with good prices.

What a find!. I was worried that Time Out was the sponsor and that it would be touristy, but it was definitely where young chefs come to try out their restaurant ideas and it is amazing!We tried so many dishes from many stalls, each one better than the next. Lots of local dishes, but with a modern twist. A very fun place to grab a glass of wine and just enjoy some good food in a casual setting.
Great Choices of Food. We had our lunch here after our tour of the Belem area, via tram. So many choices and good dining vibe.We enjoyed our lunch stop.

Great time here!. A paradise for food lovers who can, hopefully, make a choice out of the numerous food stalls represented by some of the great restaurants in Lisbon. To get the energizing atmosphere absolutely an item on your Lisbon to do list.

Great Place to eat. This a great place where you can pick and choose from several kitchens of many of the well known chefs in Lisbonne . So if you want the starter from one you can take the main course from another and you pay get buzzers that will let you know when to come back to pick up the food. You sit at large and long tables with everyone else on stools . It is open until 1 am . They also have food shops and the local market is here as well.

Nice eating spot!. A nice popular spot that allows you to decide between a long range of cuisines. From traditional Portuguese up to sushi, this place has it all and the mix of modern arrangements in an ancient building works really well.The long tables allow you to eat and meet other attending people which can be a cool thing if you're up to it!

Gourmet food court. That's the way every food court should be. Outstanding culinary and drink offerings both in Portuguese cuisine and foreign fares. Numerous stores to browse. Only downside, a bit pricey

Great place for variety!. This was a life saver for a group of picky eaters visiting the city. Everyone was left to pick whatever their heart desire. Endless choices, I tried plenty of amazing places. Cute gift shop as well. Farmer's market just next door. Just a little difficult to find seating during peak hours.

The place to eat in Lisbon. I got into the market when strolling around the city waiting for my husband and I was amazed. First by the traditional market that surrounds the place, then by Time Out that is inside Mercado da Ribeira (Ribeira Market). All around there are food stores, with various specialties from fish, sea food, meat, Japanese, sweets, veggie to ice-creams, pastas, pizza and everything you would like to have. I like the system they have: you order what you want - they give you a device that will start ringing when your food is ready, meanwhile you can enjoy walking around and seeing what else is there. And the food was very good.

Great food court. This food court should not be missed! You will find wine shops, cheese shops, butcher shops, Asian food, typical Portuguese food, juice bars, a little shop and you can take cooking lessons. All in a very urban and modern environment.

Great concept!. We loved this place, great concept with really interesting food from some lovely restaurants - it varies from some good chicken/pizza to a really top end offering from the likes of Alexandre Silva & Marlene Vieira. We ended up eating here three times we liked it so much .

Not to be missed in Lisbon!. We really enjoyed our evening at timeout. The food and drink selection is amazing. Our choice of dish(seared tuna) was perfect. The gin bar staff were so attentive and made epic cocktails. A great warm atmosphere and a lovely way to enjoy an evening out and about in Lisbon.

What a fun spot to visit....a must for foodies!. The roots of the market dates back to the 13th century but is now a major foodie hang out! With communal seating for over 700 people, both indoors and out, too many different resturants to count, every type of food you can imgine from tapas, to amazing fresh seafod, fantastic pastries and desserts. Fun to explore, eat, drink, and just have a foodie day. The market also has fresh flowers, fruits and veggies, cheeses, meats, seafood, and specialty items.

Visit the Mercado da Ribeira (in the same building) before going to the restaurants. The market is very interesting and the restaurant area offers a lot of choices of Portuguese and international food. Do not miss

Amazing choice of food. Not your usual market. Loads food outlets, lots of seating in the middle of the market. You can come here and just drink, it gets pretty rowdy at night. You could begin your night out here or it can be your night out, we loved it.

Great find!. Stumbled upon this treat, thought we were just going to visit a typical old market but next to this was the timeout part. Amazing food to choose from and cool, lively atmosphere. Was the perfect break during our walking marathon!!

Fantastic restaurants bad hygiene . During our holiday in Lisbon we stumbled across the Time Out Market. It has a great range of eateries with most tastes and budgets catered for. The relaxed atmosphere is very much Lisbon...buzzing and relaxed. In regard to food and quality i'd give it 5 stars. It's downfall is the hygiene in the main eating area. As we sat to eat a pigeon flying overhead pooped on the table. Again, as disgusting and shocking as this was it's bound to happen in an open space such as the market. The main issue was the cleaning. One of the cleaners came over and took a used tissue from his bin to wipe the initial poop. He then proceeded to wipe the rest up with his cleaning cloth which he used for the our table and others without any sanitising spray or cleaner. Heaven knows how many tables got wiped with a cloth covered in germs from pigeon poop. Hygiene training highly recommended here.

A fun place to find great food and just hang out!!!!. Stumbled on this neighborhood gem of a casual eating hang out. It is a giant market place with tables in the middle and a multitude of what seems to be an endless number of booths serving up creative and seriously great food. There is something for everyone here from sushi to Italian to desserts to burgers.....

Feast. So much food, so many choices!! Where to begin. One could eat hours around this place, lots of local choices and a bunch of global favourites mixed in. Lively atmosphere, it felt like a variety of locals and tourists visiting every night and it feels like it's buzzing with an energy high in the evenings! A nice spot to meet with friends and share a spread of good food. Noise and crowd makes for a chatty meal and there are a couple cool shops on the edge to pickup gifts and local designs. Easy access from the train station and an equally as big fresh fruit & veg market next door. Just don't "push test" their avocados... She wasn't happy about that.

Wonderful foodie experience. Across from the Sodre station, you will find a great place to wander, eat and drink. Dozens of diverse cuisines are offered in a clean, high-end but reasonably-priced food emporium. Makes plan for a lunch or snack! Highly recommended.
So many great food options . A local told us this was a great place to go and try higher end restaurants food... And it was! Great atmosphere and wine chooses too!

Huge selection of great restaurants. This is a must-visit location- even just for a coffee, or a visit to the fruit/vegetable market in the same building, though the food selection is very good also.It's a great, informal food hall, mainly self-service, though you can sit at a bar in most of the outlets.Every taste is catered for, from vegetarian, to full roast chicken, to great steaks, and fish. Very good value throughout, and everything seemed to be cooked fresh to order.

Food for all. These little shops hold the keys to unlock the savory goodness of your dreams. The quality of the meat, vegetables, and bread that are used at these places is to die for. The suckling pig sandwich from one of the shops just melted in my mouth and all I could do was wonder where the hell the sandwich went. They have great drinks there, fantastic music, and simply good hearted people.If in Lisbon, do yourself a favor and take a TimeOut.

Fantastic place to snack. I was really surprised how many different food stalls there were to choose from! Must have been about 40?! At least. It's not cheap, but there are SO many different food choices. We went a bit later in the day, and the shops weren't open. Save for one tinned seafood seller. Bought tuna and sardine pate. The food here is all so fresh, and all I tried was incredibly yummy. Go hungry, and perhaps go twice!
good seafood. full of food and a true heaven for foodie. We love the gelato and seafood. They also have wine, beer and other food.

Options galore, great food!!. Picture a gourmet food court. Absolutely amazing. Our biggest problem was trying to decide where to get the food from. Everything looked and was delicious. An absolute gem in the middle of a big city. Looked very packed but seats open up fast and food came out pretty quick too. ITS A MUST!!!!
Great!. Hip and trendy place to have something to eat or drink. Friendly people, fun ambiance and great food and drinks!Must visit!

Nice food market. This is not at the center but one can walk from chiado for having a great verity of food in many styles. U can find there many many restaurants from Chinese to american and Portuguese. The atea is nice we walk there after eating. Prices are about 15 euro p.p. not cheap for portugal but not expencive (for fast food). It is next to the food market so. When the markrt is open u can visit there too.(we were there on weekend and the market did not oparete.Enjoy
Check out the Time out. Big market Place with fantastic Food and Drinks and Special Little stores! All restored with modern flair! You've have to go there and try some specialty from Lisboa!

Time out or wasted time!. Stumbeled over this gem while doing Lisbon by walking around aimlessly. Saw a cool building and decided to check it out and it was the BOMB! Great food, something for everyone and cheap. I would recommend you to not miss it. I will try to eat lunch there every day during my stay.A W E S O M E!

Options, options, options!!. This place is awesome!You get the chance to try different Portuguese cuisine in the one location - I went back twice and barely scratched the surface!!!Located opposite the Cais do Sodre metro station, the converted market retains some of its old charm with vendors still selling their produce. However, the main section of the market now contains over 20 bars and restaurants, with everything from a bakery, to a burger joint, to seafood, to gf options, to a wine bar!!
Great for watching the football. Reminded us of the mercato in Florence but without the fresh sections. Food on offer was average. Great place to park off and watch the euro cup with locals.

good food, not excelent. I visited the market during May, had great expectations and probably that is why it was a bit disappointing. the location is nice, a lot of choices, but don't expect a lot from the taste. The atmosphere is of an "traditional" food market, but in the end you get only a "fast food" taste.
A taste of Lisbon. Ideal place to come and sample all the great food, drinks etc that Lisbon has to offer...if you are short on time this is the place to sample the aforementioned
Cool visit. If you fancy some food and drinks close to Cais do Sodré this is a good option. There is an are where people can enjoy their food and have a rest.

Loved it - highly recommended. This is a very interesting and fun place - so many dining options to choose from, not enough time. The atmosphere is vibrant with people from all over, mainly tourists (I think). This place in not inexpensive and is not like London's Borough market or Spitalfield's market. It has a contemporary edge to it and is a convenient way to try several Portuguese dishes in one place (e.g., a Francesinha - a traditional sandwich from Porto served with a fried egg on top; try one from the Miguel Castro e Silva stall). You can pour yourself a beer from a draught tap, get a coffee, or just feel the vibe of the city. Highly recommended.
YUM!. Time Out Market is great! Plenty to choose from, upbeat atmosphere and yummy food! Be there early as the food market fills up fast and the fresh market closes at 1pm!

The best place for 'foodies'. We went here just for some snacks as it is a 'food market' but were blown away by the choices on offer so we had to come back another day to try more!We went while England were playing in the Euros and I was delighted that they had a big screen up as well showing the action. Loads of choice of drinks as well as the food so be prepared to spend some serious time here.

Such Fun. Fantastic food at a very reasonable price from loads of outlets. This place buzzes, find a food place you like, order food, find a bench. Mix with tourists and locals all happy, all milling about, an experience not to be missed.

A little bit of everything . This place has it all, so I found myself there a couple times during my trip, twice at the hamburger place, pizza place and the fresh juice stand, and off course a few other things around there. There is a sweet place that sells quindin, it's known to me as a Brazilian dessert made with coconut and eggs, this particular shop makes it in different flavors, since I like it so much I had to try all the flavors, my favorites were the traditional of course and the passion fruit was GREAT!!

What a gathering spot. At first I wasn't sure I liked it, but the market really makes things convenient and gives you the option to do everything from have a cup of coffee in an old cafe, to buying fresh fish, to sampling portuguese or other types of food in a quality, if not a bit crowded setting. REally is worth a visit.

Cool experience. Very chic, good up scale food, casual surroundings and modern. Great choice but not that cheap. We got peri peri chicken and rosemary fries from a chicken place there, which made ur tummys hapy for sure!
Cool Food Court!. A new, casual and contemporary food court offering high end cuisine and products - fun place to get a bite!

Excellent food and variety!. The new emerging Portuguese cuisine is evident in this bustling place, build on the Food Court concept; Amazing choice and many new dishes, mostly seafood with a take on traditional and local specialties. The place is always packed and has a good mix of locals and tourists, and the price is always right!!!

If you have enough time. The place itself is very interesting, with a wide variety of see foods. We visited this market during peak lunch time. Expect to wait min. 20-40 minutes. The quality of the food is OK, but the place is a bit too touristic.

Very touristic, especially the prices. The Time Out market is a beautiful market to look at, the building is great and well-maintained and the atmosphere is buzzing. With tourists however. So this is not the place to spot locals or to eat for Portugese prices (read: low prices). It's nice to stroll by all the different market stands though and see how they prepare the food.
Loved it!. Good food and drinks, and atmosphere - especially concidering it's a big foodmarket. Perfect for lunch or an informal dinner with friends.

A 'must do' on Lisbon attractions. Very impressed with the overall appearance and buzz of the market. Chefs seem so passionate about their food, and you're bound to find something to suit everyone's taste! Also, everywhere very clean, and people are soooo friendly, what a great way to spend an hour.

Busy place, but a good opportunity to taste small local dishes. Place with typical Portugese foods, as well as crafts and drinks. Although it can be very crowded, the atmosphere is fun. Famous local chefs serve affordable dishes, so you can enjoy their unique food creations.
Nice place to eat. very near to Cais do sabre Metro station. this market is divided in two aprts: atraditional markert and a place to eat. Very nices places to eat

Fantastic way to eat and drink. Just fell upon this place by accident - Amazing atmosphere at meal times (which in Lisbon seems to be just about any time!). Choose from a range of places all cooking fresh food as well as lots of salad, cold meats.... in fact everything you could want plus vast range of drink options. Then you need to find a seat at the long tables - this can be a challenge!! Real experience and a must on any visit.

Absolutely love this place!. This place is great! Lots of choice of food, drinks and a great atmosphere. I would recommend finding a seat before ordering your food as it gets fairly busy! The salmon I had from Alexandre silva was fantastic and perfectly done. I will be spending lots of my holiday meals here sat he choice, atmosphere and value of food is great! On the way out of the market there is a lovely fruit and veg market too!

Great start in Lisbon. Walking around waiting for our room in the hotel to be ready we get tired and ask a tuk tuk lady driver, Teresa for a recommendation and she takes us hereSo good we plan to spend each meal time coming back!

Nice place for a bite and a glass. Different stalls with great food quality but a bit more priced than the average: you may have several different culinary experience. Wines and beers are also well granted. Perfect spot for a bite with friends on an informal evening

Great place for lunch. Time Out Market is a concept based on Mercado San Miguel in Madrid. Stalls right round the edges of the building have been set up by some of Lisbon's best restaurants and there is ample seating space- provided you eat early! The choices are a bit overwhelming, but there's something here for everyone.
Many Food and Drink Options. Interesting area filled with many shops and plenty of eateries that offer a large variety of food and drinks. Something for everyone.

Great... Lots of choices....and atmosphere. The octopus salad was amazing. Time Out is a huge food court with tables,counters, and seats surrounding the bar areas. Great quality food at reasonable prices.

Delicious Food at Reasonable Prices. Wonderful food court with gourmet choices at reasonable prices! Many of the chefs here have their own Michelin recommended restaurants (according to our guide). But the food they sell in their stalls were priced well and were delicious. My husband especially enjoyed his crispy suckling pig sandwich! We wanted to come back for dinner but did not have the time to do that anymore.Note: We can early, around noon, and easily found a table to eat in.

Great place to eat. Can't get enough of time out market. Go in the morning if you want fresh fruit and veg and fish. Open every day all day. Fun atmosphere and excellent food. When everything else is closed on a Sunday night this place is still buzzing. The 5 chef stalls at the end do incredible food!
Amazing cakes!. Visited here while in Lisbon and wow they sell some fantastic cakes. It is open until late which was great for us. What can I say... Delicious.
Brilliant.. A large market area with street food served all day. Long tables are throughout the middle of the market. Suckling pig was so good.

Loved the variety and the informality. On my arrival in Lisbon, my two friends took me here. Many many food shops, with a huge variety of cuisines. A large seating area in the middle, with high tables with stools.I had clams in garlic, cod (bachalau of course) and pork, bread, cheese. A great introduction to Portuguese food if this is your first visit, and a great reminder if it is your 23rd (like me).Go even if just to see the variety, and it is right beside the Farmers' Market down by the river. You will not be disappointed!

Very busy but still worth it. Went on a busy Saturday lunchtime, so had to hang around for somewhere to sit for quite a while. Lots of places to choose interesting food from. I had a delicious salad with figs, cheese and ham and some duck croquettes with marmalade jam. my husband had Asian food which he enjoyed. The beer was good and although the place was busy was a good atmosphere and nice to get a break from the sun. I thought the prices were Ok, Would like to visit again.
Lots of variety. Go to this market if you want variety amongst your group. Each will be able to choose what they feel like eating.

Several restaurants in one. Part of a markt was transformed in a multi restaurant place. It's a sort of modern cantine surrounded by all kind of restaurants, some of them belonging of very good portuguese chefs. A different place not to miss in lisbon.
great place to sit and eat. they have great variety of food and lot of space but it is very busy place. it is must visit place for tourists and highly recommend it
Dining in Lisbon. This is a wonderful place to get great food and try a variety of dishes prepared by local chefs. The Portuguese wines offered by the glass at each booth are well chosen.

Relaxed Dining & Drinking. Huge choice of local and international cuisine in a very casual dining hall. If you're in a large group and can't decide on where to eat then go here as you'll be able to satisfy everyone. Pricing is reasonable from all stands as well. During peak times they take your order and provide you with a buzzer which goes off once your food is ready to be collected. This means you don't have to stand around waiting and can get back to enjoying your time with your friends. We used this place as the start point of our nights out as its walking distance to the rest of the Lisbon nightlife.
Top & Fun. What an experience! Great place, a lot of people, plenty of food, great variety, not cheap for portugese standards, but it is full of tourists. You should go, it is quiet an experience.

Market (fruits and veg) is great, food OK. The local market of fruits and veg is good, the food hall is good too and with lots of choices, but prices are not cheap at all by average Lisbon standards. Atmosphere is nice though, and very clean. If you like fresh fruit, the best value if just choose what you want from the local fruit market in the same compound and sit and eat at the food hall with your meal. The fruit stall to most left (near an entrance) when exiting the food hall is the best value.

Out to eat. What an amazing venueHas to be seen to be believedIf this was local to me I would be so overweight There must be 40+ places to choose to eatWe went twice and was impressed both timesGreat vibeVery highly recommended

gourmet food court. I expected a commercial not so great food court. This destination is gourmet with a Capitol G! We watched Europe soccer match with hundreds of Portuguese
Really fun and great food

Food. Awesome open market. Tons of food places to choose from. All authentic dishes that are reasonably priced. Everyone is friendly and very helpful. Tons of choices from chicken to sardines to sushi. I highly recommend it to anyone who is looking for a laid back dining experience.

Lots of choice and great atmosphere!. This is a great spot for either a casual meal or a snack!
There's an abundance of choice ranging from traditional Portuguese delicacies to twists on other cuisines and lots of desserts to top it all off!!
It's a great spot to waste an hour or so in the afternoon.
Lovely roof and open plan eating or traditional restaurant upstairs.. Huge choices here. Worth a visit. Do go upstairs to look at the roof and look down on the myriad munching masses.

FOOD FOOD FOOD. Love this place. If you love to eat but cant make up your mind, or you feel like eating everything, then this is the place for you. Over 20 different restaurants to chose from with a variety of food options from Pizza, sushi, burgers, local fish, everything.

Handy place to eat on first night in town. Got into Lisbon around 1700 and landlord of the flat we rented recommended this place for a first night out. It was good fun, interesting idea with about 25 different restaurants round the outside of a large communal hall, it is essentially a large canteen. Some of the food styles are doubled up so there are a couple of Burger joints several fish bars, Sushi, Veggie, Pan Asian etc. There is also a cocktail bar and wine bar in the middle and also a self? service beer place in the middle which seemed to be more faff than it was worth. Overall good fun, pretty good food and great for people watching.

Every stall offering exceptional fare. We spent our last evening in Lisbon at this huge food hall where the range of cuisines is huge and every stall offers taste tempting dishes. Bright, clean and modern it's a delight to eat there despite the crowd (a football match was on the big screen while we were there and the place was packed - just added to the atmosphere).

A wide range of outstanding food to chose from. The vibe at this modern, funky market is incredible. Every day of the week, was packed and all the meals we had there were incredible. You can order tapas, sushi, Thai, Italian, pastries, ice cream etc. The chose is endless. The food is served in TimeOut plates and the wine in beautiful wine glasses. The plates are cleared on a regular basis and everything is well organised and runs smoothly.
Amazing food. Had some amazing food at the market. Prices are a bit higher than the rest of the city, but definitely worth it. Free wifi also available.

Very hip place!!. You really should not miss a visit to the Time Out Market in Lisbon! Our first stop was the Port shop where we learned a lot from staff. We learned where Ginja was made and then lessons in Port and Portuguese wines. Then on to wander all the many food stales! Truly an amazing experience. Honestly would rival anything in New York City! It is a upscale place with foods of the world. Amazing hand cut meats which caught our eye. Although pricey again we learned a lot from the staff at the stale.There is also a gift shop selling all things made in Portugal which was neat.Well worth a stop and if you are taking the Hop on Hop off tour, the bus stops right in front of the market on your way back into Lisbon from Belem. Another note is the Ginja shop just outside the market. We really enjoyed the Ginja Sangria and chocolate Ginja shooters:)
must visit!. one of the best markets I've visited, nice idea to gather stands of best restaurants and food of Lisbon. Will not be disappointed - GO!

Good for a quick meal. A very nicely done venue...the food is a bit pricey for portions on the small side...big eaters will not be satisfied. MY wife and I each tried fish dishes from a different vendor..the fish fillets were bait sized that we use in the US. A few potatoes and veggies as fill ins

Expensive. A great place to eat and an excellent idea from Time Out. There are food and drink stalls and you choose your food and sit wherever you like. The crockery, cutlery are all the same so there is one 'clean-up' crew. We had 'fish and chips' and 'porkburger and chips' with a glass of beer and a glass of wine - cost about €27. The food was good and the atmosphere worth experiencing.
Great Market. This place was amazing they have these small restaurants featuring all types of portuguese cuisine, very nice to try all sorts of foods.

eating out abroad made super easy. Timeout truly struck gold with this idea, and this marketplace is a bustling hive of both tourists and locals trying to get a good meal. I think it is slightly pricy, but it does not lack quality. Of course, be intelligent, and don't go to a Portuguese marketplace hoping to eat the Asian food. Had bday dinner at Azul, seafood corner on the left of the main hall. They had an outside eating area which is much like alfresco dining anywhere. Had very nice lobster and also recommend the razor clams. Service was very good there. Returned a couple days after the bday and had a less specific experience. It did not disappoint. Watched Italy beat Belgium with sangria, octopus rice, croquettes and more and it made for a very pleasant night out. If you're not sure where to go or what to eat or even both, you'll find something you like here.
Trendy local foodmarket. Wide selection of local specialities with a huge dining area. It is in the same building as the fishmarket where you can see the daily catch from the Atlantic.

Lots and lots of Lisbon restaurants are in here....many choices!. It is fun to first walk around and see all the different types of food you can get...then you can get a little here and a little there...try lots of things. A fun place to be and good on a rainy day.
Lunch. Awesome ! Good location , plenty of choices , plenty of seating. Be sure to check out the sea food! Definitely worth a visit for any food lover!

Tasty food hall. It's another successful tasty food with good design and lots of selection. There is something for everyone and it's not like the other tourist traps that everything tastes the same. A good place to get a casual bite in the middle of the day

My opinion goes against the tide. No doubt this area had a great atmosphere. I have been there several times until making up my mind about it. I will not be going back. Although promoted as a place for locals, it isn't; it's too expensive for locals. The food is very average and below average in some cases (there are many better restaurants). Although the idea of sharing a tables with lots of other people it means that if it's more than one person going, prepare yourselves to fight for a place (speacially at dinner time). You will be going round in circles finding a spot to seat and eat - by then your food will be cold. The logistics are a negative.

Visited 10th june 2016. Highly recommended eating place. Lots of fresh gorgeous food to chose from. Ordered shrimp and rice and wine from sea me which was reasonable at €15 roughly then went on to have espresso and dessert. Very impressed and excellent range of choice

Great food experience . We were recommended to go here by the owner of the hotel in which we were staying. We were both so happy we took her recommendation!! This market is full of amazing restaurants!!! There is so much to choose from. There is something to suit everyone. You can pop from one stall to another and try the cuisine. Great experience would highly recommend!!!

Just CHOOSE --- food and wine. A gigantic old market hall where there is little stand next to little stand. Just think what you want to eat --- look around --- it is there somewhere.International, starters, main dishes, portuguese cuisine, desserts , wines...An experience

Do not leave Lisbon without stopping here!. Great market experience! The main hall has among the best foods Lisbon has to offer, a little bit of everything! The adjacent hall houses kitchy little booths with great souvenirs, and the other side of this hall opens to a huge farmer's market. So many options for everything! The location is perfect, just off the centre, right by the water. Great opportunity to eat your weight in deliciousness and walk it off. A must do for a wonderful day of exploring Lisbon, not to be missed!

So good, visited several times.. Fantastic atmosphere, plenty of food choices and great background music. It was difficult to find, I realised when leaving I had walked the long way and through the city. There is a met station literally outside the front of the market. All indoor which was great for when the weather wasn't brilliant. Visited April 2015

Arrive hungry, leave satisfied. So glad I came across this place. A huge warehouse with a variety of local foods, masses of people (shared tables with barstools/benches)…I tried a little bit from different shops…i felt it was on the pricey side though and hopefully prices will be adjusted. The variety of food can cater to many types. You might find it challenging to find a place to sit on weekends and in summer time and queues may be longer than usual. Perhaps avoid the weekends…check schedules and skip the queues.
Busy place. Good selection of food but not always easy to find tables free to eat at especially if there are more than two of you. Fruit & veg market next door is interesting

Simply delicious!. The Time Out is part of the Ribeira Market. A place that offers the vest of Portuguese gastronomy with good price. Many renowned chefs have their spot there. Delicious food all around, and a place very well organized, clean, very pleasant.

If you have no other foodie experience in Lisbon, have this one.. My husband and I brought his 12-year old and 14-year old kids with us to Lisbon for a vacation following a conference in Lisbon. We spent a total of 9 days in Portugal and visited Lisbon, Sintra, Cascais and much of the Algarve area. Of all of the places we ate, in all of the regions, in all of the settings, the first thing my stepdaughter said when we returned was how much she wished she could go back to this market, which we visited on the advice of a local Lisbon colleague. I agreed with my stepdaughter completely. The price is seriously right at each stall, and my only regret was that I could not try everything on the trays of strangers sitting around me. Moreover, for impatient diners, this is not the sort of place where dinner lasts hours, unless you linger over beer or wine. I recommend taking a circuit of all of the stalls before deciding. We ordered beverages from one stall, each of us ordered a main from a different stall, and the kids snagged dessert from yet another stall. It was delicious!

Great options for lunch!. We stopped here twice for lunch during our trip to Lisbon. This is a great place if you need to accommodate many different food preferences in your group. The market vendors offer a mix of traditional Portuguese, modern flavors, and world cuisine--everything from sushi to hamburgers!Many places also offer tapas sized options which is a fun way to experience many different items.Tip-Take a lap before deciding where to dine and also check out what they other diners are enjoying to help select the best option!

ABSOLUTE MUST!. A foodie's paradise. This place offers everything you could possibly want from the best of Portugese cusine to Sushi and chocolates. I ate here 3 times during my stay in Lisbon. Only thing is depending on how many you are with, seating can be difficult to find.
really good experience. really good place to go after a walk around Lisbon. you have lots of choices and there are amazing restaurants there

Happening Place on the Weekend. We came on our first evening here and really like it. So many great choices for eating. Not cheap but everything is fresh and tasty. Clams and grilled squid from Sea Me were delicious. Salmon and noodles from Noodle bar hit the spot too. We also tried charcuterie sampling from Mantegeria Silva. They helped pack left over for picnic next day. There was music playing American tunes and people danced. Great fun. Hard to find table but if you wait a bit, people do move out.

Plan "Time Out" in Your Trip. A very busy, internationally traveled scene you will come upon when arriving at this fantastic concept. I did my research and found that there are around 30 different food stalls in this market. I went twice on my trip; first out of sheer hunger and the second because of convenience. It is located right across the street from the hub of the Cais do Sodre station. After a gorgeous sea view with sub par coffee in Estoril, I longed for some real coffee. I knew I wouldn't fail here and I didn't! The place was hopping with live folk-rock music on a Tuesday evening. I ordered "um garoto" which is an espresso with a dab of milk. Once fueled, I surveyed the display of modernized Portuguese dishes. I ordered octopus rice from Miguel Castro e Silva, which was the Portuguese version of octopus creole (southern Louisiana). The octopus was really tender, flavorful and not chewy!! I topped it off with the sweetest berry-based sangria from Marlene Vieira that ever touched my lips! All of that was 15 euros!! Next time I went was my last night in Lisbon. I was walking along the Tagus from Praca de Comercio, which is a breathtakingly peaceful walk. I figured for the price and the choices I would head back there. I stopped at Conserveira de Lisboa for a pretty wrapped tin of sardines for when my heart sinks missing Lisbon. I wanted more octopus but it seems that every place was out. So I made my selection at Miguel Castro e Silva again. With all the choices this stop was very friendly and service oriented. I had my last bachalau a bras for a while. It wasn't the best but it was dang good. I stopped by a cake place but forget the name but I will never forget the passion fruit pie I ate there. In the end I stopped at Casa da Ginja for a bit of smoother than average ginga before my last sunset for this trip. Go to Time Out!!

Disappointing. Portuguese Market Replaced by OK Whole Foods. WHenI first heard of this market, I wanted to go. I expected a Portuguese version of Barcelona's Mercado de la Boqueria or London's Borough Market. Unfortunately, when the global Time Out events schedule/lifestyle guide took it over, it created a food court version of its standardized global model. This works for a magazine listing events, it doesn't for a market. Instead of a market or interesting set of food stands, there is a homogenized food court in the now-standard mid-2000s Williamsburg hipster style. There were some places selling Portuguese items, but not that many, and they pretty bland with limited options. My advice is to skip it. There are so many other places in Lisbon that taste better, cost less, and have something of the country that you are visiting in them.
Go There!!!. Don't miss is a good place to take anything to lunch, snack, drink from Portugal gastronomy. Chesse, Wine, Pastel de Belem...

Lots Of Options Under One Roof . Lots of good quality stalls in one huge market. Probably more expensive than local prices but well frequented by both locals and tourists. Plenty of seating. We'll worth a visit

OK if you don't mind a long wait. We ate here for lunch in June 2016. The food hall is attached to the daytime fruit and vegetable market and worth a visit to see the numerous food outlets along all sides. Apparently a few of the outlets are from extremely well known chefs. It is enormously popular and the waiting time for lunches were around 25-30 minutes. Seating on the long benches waiting for your machine to light up to tell you your meal was ready is a real pain, especially when they serve your drink at the same time. However there are outlets serving spirits, cocktails, wines and soft drinks separately, so perhaps they are the answer! Food was fine, not especially inexpensive but the place has a buzz that could appeal to many.

Best place to eat in Lisbon !. This is by far the best place to visit and eat in Lisbon ! There are douzens of small restaurants that serve high quality food for a smal price. They offer everything from starters to fish, meat, pizza, sushi, other asian food etc. Definitely worth a visit especially because other touristy restaurants tend to make sneaky profits with expensive drinks and "appetizers".

Awesome food, but get a table fast!. We first heard about this "market" from our Air BnB host upon checking in. This market is similar to a mall's food court but a million times better! We were told that all the amazing chefs in Lisbon who have their own restaurants have a stall here to sell their amazing food in smaller portions and less expensive. There are stalls that line 3 of the 4 sides of the room so there are plenty of options! We went here twice actually. My recommendation is to walk around and decide where you want to eat. Then if you are traveling with someone else, choose who will stay in line to order and who will go find seats. This markey gets VERY crowded and it can be quite difficult to find a seat (especially if you are traveling in a group).

Food Heaven. This market offers all manner of Food from light snacks to full meals and it is set in a warehouse type building with rows of wooden benches & tables for seating. There is Food to cater for all appetites as well as plenty of local wine & beer and this is a must visit for anyone who likes their food

Buzzing!. We were recommended Time Out by a friend, and visited here twice. Other reviews have detailed the in's and out's of this venue, so i will just add that you must go if you are in Lisbon, its worth it if only for the atmosphere. Its location right across the road from Cais de Sodrie railway station makes it very easy to get to, and once there, its very easy to spend a good 3 hours (at least) soaking up the fantastic atmosphere and enjoying the brilliant choice of food, wine and beer of offer.

Good and fresh food!. We enjoyed our stay there, especially because we arrived a bit earlier than noon and we had the opportunity to look around and to order before it became crowded. We also liked their ordering system which avoids the long queues that were formed in order to pick up your meal. Thumbs up for their organization team!

A lot of flavors under one roof. These type of food markets are popping up everywhere in Europe, but this is one of the biggest I have seen so far. A lot of flavors from a lot of different cuisines in one big hall. From traditional to modern Portuguese cooking, Asian, burgers, and much more. Really nice to explore and try different dishes. Although the size of the hall is huge, the atmosphere is still nice. Really worth a visit when you're in for a snack, lunch, dinner or want to eat in something else than a traditional restaurant.

An great place to see and experience. If you are a foodie like l am, then this market is for you! The time out experience offers a good selection of foods from simple to sophisticated and there is plenty to choose from amongst all the food outlets here! I would highly recommend the cod, olive sprinkles, sweet potatoes and heavy cream meal for a main and a piece of cheesecake, both are so delicious!!

Gourmet food at reasonable price in lively and friendly setting. This is a must in Lisbon. In one spot you get great food, for all tastes. There are booths for wine, beers, desserts and of course all sort of excellents Portugeses specialties. This is The first place I would recommend to someone just arriving in Lisbon.
Wonderful. We stumbled upon this and had the most wonderful burgers, wine and beer for lunch. Very reasonably priced along with most food in Lison. Go, go, go!!
Nice place to serve dinner!. A lots of restaurants together in a big place, plenty of happy people, good music and noisy atmosphere!

What a foodie heaven. Found this by accident. It was packed with Lisboetas eating and drinking. There is an abundance of outlets selling almost any type of food you could ask for and reasonably priced too. Something here for everyone.

kitchen variety at its best. located in the heart of Lisbon this market hall provides absolutely everything one can wish for - the food varies from simple to very sophisticated and you MUST try the seared tuna Steak on carob buns..

Nice to see. You find places like this all around the world. I've seen them in Amsterdam, Rotterdam, Copenhagen and Madrid. The best thing here is you'll find the best of the best restaurants and not just some food. So, nice to see, nice to taste one night, but nothing that I didn't see before

Amazing market!. It's a beautiful spot to head to if you'd like to have a break from the sun. There are cooking classes, fresh fish, fresh meat, lots of wine... you make it, this market has it! Worth heading upstairs to get good views of the whole market place. There's also a very nice shaded park as you leave. Nice spot!

Excellent & buzzy. What a fantastic idea! Tens of different restaurants set around a central bar and selling a great variety of foods at reasonable prices. And next door a proper market selling fish, meat, port, vegetables and artisan products.We only eat there one lunchtime and the squid we had was a little disappointing but the octopus was good. But all made up for by the good (and a good choice) of beers and the buzzy atmosphere.

Great way to sample many local restaurants in one spot.. We went to the market thinking it would be a regular open farmers market - it was, next door (with raw meats, seafood and veg) for those serious on cooking their own dinners. This side is for people wanting prepared food - and many gourmet choices. We went on a Saturday afternoon and there were long wait time at most restaurant outlets - certainly NOT fast food, but the quality of the food served is like in a restaurant. Just that you have to find your own table and bus your own trays of food and drinks. And seats can be hard to find on the weekends. Prices are similar to those in restaurants, but no tips needed.
A must when you visit Lisbon. Not cheap but very enjoyable, great variety of foods, nice clean place to seat, toilets need improvement. Paid Parking is comfortable

a must do for all foodies. This is a place for foodies. This is the best way to tried Portugal food, see and taste. Has a little of everything. The only thing is finding seats, cuz it is so popular with the local. A must do.
must see food destination. Very buzzy, popular with local workers also, not all tourists.Fab food cooked to order, try Alexandre Silva stall in the top corner.

So much goodness!. This market gets called a "food court", but it's nothing like that! Amazing restaurants all come together for a feast of the senses. Fish, beef, sushi, pizza, wine, coffee and all done at the highest levels. You can sit at the "bar" of the restaurant or do takeaway and eat at the communal tables which is way more fun. We had the best sangria and conversations!The vibe and energy is electric. You shouldn't miss this place!

Great Renovated Food Hall with the Time Out branding. Ok ..... The prices here are in the "expensive" side for Lisbon but compared to London it's still good value.Just stroll around, sample the food, wines & beers and of course the various foods on offer....A great afternoon out!
Up to date food court. All around easy way to taste diffent portuguese food. Very smart food court for all taste. At times is very busy ,expecially tourists

Best food in Lisbon!. What a find! This bustling market is absolutely incredible. When you first enter you have to do a full tour just to find out what's on offer!
So much fresh food and great drinks on offer, in particular a lot of fish. I had pork loin which was just delicious.

Drink and snack. Very cool market with many restaurants many choices! Everything looks delicious very regional. We had a drink and order some snacks because we weren't hungry but there was a lot to chose from. Very hip looking place too perfect for doing some shopping too.

Lively but hard to get seats. This place is a mix of a vegetable, meat, and flower market, as well as a restauraunt type kiosk market. It's super authetic and lively, but note that it's often hard to find a place to sit.
Atmospheric and tasty. Quite packed and expensive, but very tasty and different foods. Lots of table space to sit down and eat at.

Don't forget the Tartaria. Don't sit in the middle of the hall but on the outside ring! This kiosk is specialized in fish and beef tartare. We really enjoyed the salmon tartare, beautifully decorated with rettich spaghetti and with a lovely avocado/mango creme. Have a nice glass of white wine and let all the magnificent tastes touch your mouth. You can choose three sizes. On Monday there is no fresh fish so the tuna is not available, but I didn't mind tasting the salmon twice. The day after we enjoyed a life cooking session at lunch time where we were served delicious risotto and a superb chocolate mousse for only 12,50 euros.I will definitely come back to Lisbon for this place!

Brilliant design for an indoor market. This is an indoor market with cafe seating and real china! It is contemporary in design, in a very historic building. Time Out did an excellent layout and created an easy traffic flow throughout the site. The restaurant design for the kiosks is brilliant, 2 sided, stools on one side to watch food preparation and plating and also the center core of the marketplace or the pick up side from the kiosk and seating in the vast middle of the market. Genius!!!!

Spoiled for Choice. Time Out was recommended by a very friendly 'mixologist' (Frank) from Matiz Pambolina Bar. He raved over the Leitao Confit (roast suckling pig) served up at Jacinto Machado within Time Out. Wow! Beautifully crisp (black) on the outside and tender as anything underneath, served with pureed sweet potato and some veg (not sure what it was). Anyway, it was to die for!!Time Out is an old Market renewed into an array of fantastic eateries, maybe 25/30 or more along the sides. There are rows of benches running through the centre where you wait for your food to be prepared and then called when it is ready. Wt is so good we returned twice more trying some Pad Thai from the Asian Lab and steak sandwiches from yet another establishment. There is beer and wine available to drink and I don't believe we paid more that €10 for any of the dishes. Fantastic!!

Loved this place!. Came here twice in the two days I was in Lisbon. There are several different kinds of food (tapas, pizza, hamburgers, sushi, seafood, pasta) and also coffee and alcohol bars. Definitely worth a visit.

This is a working vegetable and flower market.. A large part of the market area has been turned into a large eating and drinking area served by numerous professional and international food and drink stalls where you collect your own food and drink, consumed on huge wooden tables with other people. Great Portuguese food in the main, although a few other country food types are available.

Amazing variety of different cuisines. This is an amazing place to eat with so many different types of cuisines and lots of wooden tables and chairs. It seemed to offer very good value for money and there are free, very clean loos accessible which is a bonus.
A must visit. Quite an interesting place that one must visit during a Lisbon stay. Lots of choice in food at different price levels makes choosing difficult :-)

Great market. Not a market really but an open style food court which houses some great mini restaurants. Loved the many types of cuisines, the options for drinks. The decor and the ambience was clean and lively, truly a leveled up food court. We enjoyed our lunch stop, it can become crowded.

A great place to eat!. We came here twice on our visit to Lisbon. A friend from back in Canada who was from Portugal texted us the suggestion to go. It is a giant food court with at least 35 gourmet restaurants, showcasing Portugese food. We were very pleased with both our meals. The night we went for dinner, there was a live band playing. Made for a great evening. A must do!

Perfect Place to try different Portuguese food.. After a long day strolling around Lisbon, We went to have something to eat at the market. We really enjoy the different types of food and the opportunity to take a break of a long day walking. The prices are reasonable. Do not hesitate on stopping by.

Must visit if you are in Lisbon. I wonder why this concept of serving no frills, fresh gourmet meals at resonable prices ( possible as they are located inside a market) has not spread to other cities. We did not have a bad meal here. Great place to hangout anytime of the day.

Food court on steroids!. Have visited this Market four times in the last two years, great food and drink, superior selection, quality and value. Great vib at night or in the afternoon. Would recommend highly for a casual, bustling experience
great place to eat. Great place to try something different, a lot of choices - seafood, pork, soups,etc. There is good selection of wine as well.

Chelsea piers-East. A really nice old Euro style market building put to a new use. The old iron framework with its high ceiling has been cleaned up and is the home to 35 restaurant stalls, each with its own point of view. Many of the stalls are chef- inspired takes on different cuisines with a Portuguese slant.The seating is first come, first seated and you must stand in line to order, then wait. When the food is ready, however, it is very good. I ordered a roasted suckling pig sandwich with cracklings and chips for E9.50. The guys had pork cheeks over pureed potatoes with brown reduction for E10 and an octopus salad for E8.50. Beer and wine are available and there is no tipping. There is also everything from Asian to Pizza and more.Be tolerant of crowds and watch your pockets. This is a one time visit unless you favor a hectic meal. There are a number of crafts and chochkie shops. All in all, a worthwhile place to see. Part of the market still functions as a supplier to restaurants. The project is 2 years old and appears to be growing.chef

Something for everyone!. Went there not knowing what to expect. It was great. Go early. We went at 7:00 and by 7:43 it was packet. Get your seat first. I ate at Henrique sá Pessoa. COD with chick pea purée. Excellent. Not very big so grab an appetizer. My husband got the chicken soup at Miquel Laffen---Fabulous. Also a roasted chicken. You won't be disappointed. Also menus in both Portuguese and English.

Many choices, many people... The "free table hunting season" starts now!. Lots of restaurants to choose. During the weekends it seems to be always crowded and you need to dig a lot to find a free table. Don't expect too much attention from the restaurants' staff. You can find from traditional portuguese food to asian food. Tables were not made to be confortable. Eat & Go. Noisy.
Buzzing gastronomic delight. Loved the vibrant, gastronomic diversity of this place. So many choices but locally seafood is best. Busy, lively and a must-visit for lunch or dinner.
Wonderful!. That was a great idea to gather all the best shops under one roof. There were cheese, hamon, bakeries, souvenir shops and others. Worth visit.
Foodie Paradise. Visited her on a Saturday afternoon, and it was mobbed. It was really hot out so it was very humid inside, seating very sparse so you wouldn't want to go with a big group.
Food Market. Its a great place to go and choose the type of food you would like. Relaxed atmosphere , at times too crowded and noisy.

So awesome!! A must visit. The Time Out Market is the perfect place to sample modern cuisine in a relaxed and cool environment. As a group of four, we shared many dishes in order to sample a little of everything. The pizza was excellent as was the bar in the centre of the building. It does get very crowded so you may want to consider an early lunch (get there at midday), to ensure you get a table. Particularly if you're travelling with kids in a pram. There are also a few lovely homewares stores to pick up something to take home.

Foodies heaven?. This place was great, mix of cuisines from all over the world, but not skimping on traditional Portuguese fayre, good selection of beers and wines too. If you're organized enough, there's a section where you can take lessons, including making pastel de natas, arguably the best things by about Portugal

Casual but quality food choice!. It is not a traditional option but I got a good surprise by seeing very popular restaurants and shops here and casually offering food/drinks with reasonable price! Depending on time, it can get very busy and very difficult to find even one person's seating! However non-busy time, it is very relaxed and it was a good idea when I got tired of walking, just dropping by here and have a quick beer. Good concept!

Make Time for this place. An excellent find - walking in through the tiles entrance to the grand market awaits you. The Produce market and Flowers were amazing. To the left you have all the foods to entice you.Delicious meals to snacks and gorgeous cakes. Some nice stalls also selling things from perfume, gifts to wine and ports.
BEST PLACE IN LISBOA. this is the most amazing place in Lisboa. One should go like 2 or three times at least. In the morning, lunch time anda dinner time. Simply amazing.

Amazing Choices for Lunch. From Sushi to Steaks and everything in between. Miss this fantastic food hall at your peril. Make sure that you visit early as it will take 30 minutes to see what every kitchen has to offer. Decide on your style of food,find some chairs and leave somebody to look after your seats whilst the others fetch the food. The alternative is to wait on somebody's shoulder until they have finished their meal. GREAT GREAT VENUE.

Lively!. A short stroll from Praca Comercio, this is primarily a very popular food hall packed with stalls offering myriad choices. Centrally-located long tables and benches provide seating for those fortunate enough to locate a free space! There is also a small farmer's market located within.

A busy scene!. Lots of food to choose from. Get your starter one place, your drink from another and maybe your main choice from still another - if you crave variety! Try to go before 12:30 if you want to be sure of a place to sit! There is lots of seating area but also lots of people.

A Must Experience. A great fun atmosphere ! Excellent choice of food with such a variety no one will go unsatisfied! The "find your own table and family style seating" is great. You meet different people while enjoying your food, drinks and good music! Don't forget the deserts, a nice glass of wine, beer and so on!

Good idea but not very Lisbon. The idea of using part of the large market for traditional food stalls is very good, but obviously the branding is too much London (where Time Out originates from) and not much Lisboa, the food is pricey, but on the whole good, there are only tourists here, which again gives the place more of a train station feel
Lots & lots of food choice . High end street market food .. End of..go a few times and try the different chef delights ! Great to after some sight seeing or wander near the river / bridge area.

Great place to shop or eat. We were disappointed with the pingo doce suppermarket near our accommodation so it was wonderful to visit this excellent fruit and vegetable market and the Time Out food hall next door. You can buy everything here to cook a healthy meal or join the locals in the tempting food hall. This looks a reaaly inviting place to eat and was bustling with lunch time patrons. Worth the detour if you enjoy fresh foof markets or if you are in the neighborhood and hungry.

Culinary Heaven. Time Out market is a great place to go and try different Portuguese specialties without having to commit to a main course portion. The hardest thing is to choose where and what to eat, since numerous renowned chefs are present. We ate at Henrique Sa Pessoa - salmon tataki and pork and sweet potato purée - and then headed to Santini for ice creams. Delicious!

Get yourself a 1.50 duck croquette!!!. We visited this place after seeing the great reviews on trip advisor and it didn't disappoint. The food and wine available from these little independent stalls is amazing and extremely well priced.I can't remember the name of the stall but it's important to grab yourself at least one of the duck croquettes because they are incredible. I was discussing with my partner what we were going to eat from the stall when we saw the duck things and a local woman queuing behind us overheard our discussion. She was queuing to buy 10 of them because she thought they were that good. So that was it......SOLD! And they were amazing!! To find them.....With your back to the ladies toilets go to the left side of the stalls. Keep walking past about 5/6 stalls and there's an option to turn left. The stall on this junction is the one you need!The only bad thing about this place is that there is not near enough seating. We wandered around for 15 mins before asking a fellow English couple if we could use the end of their table to put our wine down whilst we stood up to eat!So my advice is try and get a seat before getting your food (we went on a Saturday so it's possible it might be less busy in the week).

Propably very good. On their doors it says open 10 - 24 but most of the places open at noon. I had checked there the night before, and I took the opening hours literally and was there one hour too early. I had a flight to catch, so I couldn't stay to try any of the booths. Looked nice though.

This is the one. The best place to eat in Lisbon. The name already says it's a market. A food court was set up in one of the areas and you have a vast array of the most delicious Portuguese meals at very reasonable prices.

Fantastic! First sit and then order!. Old market converted into a food hall with stalls featuring famous chefs. Extremely busy, but not at all impossible to find a place to sit. Just stand behind people who are almost done eating and wait a little. Then sit and order. We ordered first from Alexandre Silva. Their pimientos padrón were great but the bacalhau had a strange taste to it. Do not recommend it. We then ordered with grilled tuna sandwich from Sea Me.Unmissable for lunch when in Lisbon.

Great place for lunch.. We came across this terrific food court by accident and went in to escape the rain. What impressed us most was that all the food and drink sold had been tested for quality by Time Out's experts and it showed. There was such a variety of local produce that it was difficult to choose.The building itself was impressive and had been adapted well. Seating was communal but it was an interesting way to meet other tourists and locals too.You can stroll along westtwards from the Praca do Comercio or take the green Metro line to Cais do Sodre and walk across the road.

A place you definitely SHOULD visit in Lisbon. Amazing place for all the people enjoying nice food. Really good renovated with a lot of food choices. They have even cooking lessons.One of my favourite places in Lisbon :)

a wonderful surprise. The Time Out Market is a magnet for tourists and locals alike...so yes, it is crowded. Don't be discouraged, you will find a table and the rewards will be plentiful. Many of the best food producers in Lisbon are represented here. The atmosphere is buzzing and the value undisputed. During the early part of the day there is also a fruit & veg, fresh meat and fish market as well. It was one of the best experiences in Lisbon. Treat yourself.

Foodie Heaven!!!. This place is amazing for anyone who loves food. Time Out Market is located conveniently by the train station/major bus stops. My boyfriend and I were in Lisbon for one week and went back twice because we wanted to try as many food stalls as possible. There was a huge variety of food to choose from - we had lots of savoury dishes and dessert as well.
