The food court gets very busy and can be difficult to find a seat, but the crowds didn't bother us. If we lived in Lisbon, we would come here all the time. We especially liked the food stall with nuts and candied fruit, the stall with a huge variety of different cakes (can't remember the name), and Tartar-Ia.
foodies stop. Great food drinks and music long tables get your started from one main form another and sweets had a green chicken first class

Renewed old market. Very modern type of market. They have about 25 different food places of all sorts and a couple of outlets for special drinks. You will find those that suit your main dish, some for dessert and also a few to take away local products. Overall: you will always find something to eat there no matter what you are looking for, as many reviewers said before - don't look for a comforting quiet place for a date night!! It's a market so you will sit next to each other side by side with visitors from a variety of countries. It's a great place to have a local dish and a chat with other foreign visitors. Definitely recommend!

Foodies. Great Selection, very upbeat place, awesome.......!!!!!!! Great find, if you are not sure what to do for Lunch or Dinner, highly recommend going....great place to people watch too, be prepared for a wait and a battle for a seat.

Great Food. This market was recommended to me by someone who had been recently. We went for a late lunch on a Saturday, and it was still quite busy, so goodness knows what it would have been like at traditional lunch time. It didn't take us too long to find somewhere to sit though. The food we had was really tasty, especially the cod balls. However, things did take a while to get at times (you have a little pager that let's you know when it's ready). I also thought it was quite expensive for each item of food given how cheap food is in Lisbon. Also, it was a nice day and it's all inside, which was a shame. Basically, if you want a massive selection of food, and price isn't an issue, this is the place to go.

Great Atmosphere, Full of Culinary Options. There's definitely a great vibe in here! I visited here twice and tried 3 different restaurants none disappointed. Some of these are Michelin starred restaurant outlets, others are acclaimed chefs all under one roof. There's communal seating all around. Your choice of lovely eats and wine. There's a beer bar. There are savory options and sweet options as in food stalls dedicated to chocolate, desserts and other local sweets. There are stalls selling local goods. I grabbed some amazing sea salts and lovely handmade soaps. Time Out Lisbon is very central, easily accessible from the center by walking or by public transportation. I can't wait to visit again.

Modern Food market!. Time Out Market is based on a very central location near the river. I know the same sort food halls from Amsterdam, Rotterdam etc. and I really like the atmosphere in these markets. People are sharing tables. Buy small dishes from different shops, and get their drinks at the bars in the middle.What makes this place even better then the market I have been before is that all the foodstores are small kitchens of great restaurants from all over the town. So when you really enjoyed your food you can go to the actual restaurant and try more of the great food.For a cheap diner I advise to go somewhere else, but if you like to try different kinds of food then this is the place to be!
Food for everyone here!. Fantastic foodie experience . A must whilst in Lisbon! Huge area with over 30 different dining experiences ! Reasonable prices too!

Busy and hard to find anywhere to sit. Reached by Tram 15 which stops outside, this is effectively a warehouse with market stalls around the sides selling various versions of street food with random crammed bench seating in the centre.Costly and with no where for our party of 7 to sit together we did not stay to eat.
Very nice place. This lace is very pleasant to eat. A lot of choise a lot of flavours. a lot of nationalities the service is very kind.
"just fab". An excellent venue for food and drink whether in a group or just a couple. Atmosphere fab could have eaten here everyday

Great choice. We went here on a Sunday at about 11pm as most other places were closed. There is so much choice here it caters for all tastes and most of the food is reasonably priced. Would highly recommend a visit here.

Great buzz on a Saturday night. Great food hall in the Sodre market. 20 plus eating options all of those we tried were good quality. Not easy to get a table so patience is required. Would highly recommend the steak stall - superb sirloin cooked medium rare.
Must visit- great selection. There was so many choices we had difficulty in deciding.In the end we had a yummy plate of jamon and a delicious cake

Really Cool Hipster Market Right Outside Main Metro Station. I call it a hipster market as a compliment. It is a really cool spot, had live music on Saturday night, lots of great bars lining a main seating area, some craft beer, fine wine, and great cheese places as well. A cool spot to wander around even if you don't buy anything and enjoy people watching. Also, a free bathroom as well.

For every taste. Lovely and unconventional restaurant hall where there is food for everyone regardless of what kind of food you want - and then you can sit and eat together, even though you choose food from multiple locations.

The best place to eat in Lisbon!. I do not know why more cities do not have a place like the Time Out Market. The Market is like dozens of permanent food trucks in one place. It is the best place to oversee and sample the food of Lisbon. It is open from 10 am until 12pm. We ate there several times and enjoy each visit. Do not not miss this place.

Wonderful selection of gourmet foods!. There are at least 50 food purveyors in this very sophisticated food court, offering a huge variety of gourmet prepared foods in a nice setting of shared high top tables. There are plenty of wines, craft beers, and cocktails to choose from as well. A delightful way to make sure everyone in your party finds foods that suit them. The place is packed with both locals and tourists, and is just lots of fun! We enjoyed it so much for lunch one day, that we returned for dinner another evening. Highly recommended,
Great variety!. We came here 3 times over the course of our stay and had totally different meals each time. Best part is, no reservations needed so just show up and eat! Great!

A great experience dining. Great for lunch but be prepared for crowds and challenges finding open tables. Dinner on Sunday night was much easier and all restaurants were open. Excellent food! A great experience.
Amazinh. The food court is huge with every kind of food you can imagine. 4 and 5 star chefs at almost every station. Don't miss this. Great for dinner, drinks or dessert.

excellent food just watch your money. The food and drink is excellent and very reasonably priced. Easy to get to right next to the cais de sodre metro station. Just be careful of your bags and also watch you don't get shortchanged.

Lisbon in a pill. This is a fantastic place!!!Buzzing all day and late into the night, with incredible selection of food and drink. Very relaxed atmosphere, live performances and all you need for pretty much any part of the dayIncredible place and an absolute must place to visit when in Lisbon

Picky people, go to Time Out!. Having a hard time deciding on a restaurant? Search no further. Time Out has EVERYTHING. Great for larger groups because of the community tables. Prices may be slightly higher than average, but the food doesn't disappoint. In addition to the many restaurant stalls, there's a fish/vegetable market that runs until 2pm, an organic market, and flower market. A must see and really fun place to hang out.

Wonderful atmosphere and food selection amazing. A converted market with many individual units selling different food. A bit like the food court principle in the UK but so much more style and the food quality is fantastic. Also music on in the main area at night. Papcorda restaurant upstairs towards the front of the building has a signature chocolate mousse to die for, don't choose anything else or you will regret it!

Perfect place to eat. We highly recommend to go for this place. It's big but clearly. Very delicious plates and a great variety of all kinds of food.We stayed for over three ours and enjoyed every minute of it!

Food Lovers/Explorer. This should be on your must experience list to do in Lisbon,the food was great alot of authentic to choose from, myself i took a traditional choice of #Black #Pork Stew from #Alentejo...it was good, and don´t miss the Charcuterie plate before, if you are not too hungry take the charcuterie plate only, it comes with a side of freshly baked bread....and if you luv beer then you´ll feel right at home, mind you it´s crowded crazy in there so seats are a hunt, tip if you are two find a seat first before you order food, and ladies do try the #Berry #Bubble...it´s refreshing, preferably before you find a seat..hehehee.i will add photos later, since i don´t have them on my PC.

too crowded, expensive and not that special. I've been to a lot of market halls before (scandinavia, asia,...) and love the idea of buying stuff and eating it right away on the market. this one had sort of an "artificial touch" like it's made just for tourists.it is crowded, it is huge and we ate for lower prices in a cosy little restaurant.

Eat at Time Out. Time Out Market is in Lisboa near Cais do Sodro train station.In one section,there are fresh vegetables and fruits.İn the other section,there are many small shops selling foods.You can find many different fööds to eat.Soup.meat,fish whatever you want.

Foodies! This is your place.. I went to Time Out because of my huge love of Borough Market in London, and I was hoping it would be similar. It's a overall similar idea: some areas with grocery-purchasing options for taking home (read: for locals, because I don't cook on vacation) and a large open area with a number of food stands so you can try various options. I could go eat at a place like this every day that I'm in the same city. There are also a couple of higher-end touristy shops too if you're looking for a souvenir or two.

Lively busy place . This place was recommended by a local man that we know . Nice area , easy to get there by metro . Place it self is ok nothing fancy . However , you do get a big selection of food , so there is something for everyone. We stopped at the Miguel Castro e Silva ( the simply Portuguese ) caught our attention. We had the gourmet burger which was nice and tasty but... Yes there is a but coming.... It was quite red inside . Way too red/ rare for my liking . But it was nice I must admit.
Take a seat. Time Out market is a perfect place for a drinking and eating. A large variety of food offerings. The place is big and crowdy, but it that is what you like, this place is for you
Great Food. You'll find whatever you feel like craving for in this place. Food is international cooked in Portuguese way. But everything's great.

What a place to eat! En every kind of of food and drink, heaps of people and a very good staff. Time out is an old market converted to a hall filled with tables. In the middle you can buy beverages in almost 20 stalls, in all different styles of drink.And along the walls are all kinds of small restaurants, where you order your foods, pastry and what ever you fancy!Great staff cleans up everything after you.Be aware... It;s always busy. Do not come with a large group. You will never find a place to sit together!
Classy food court. The place is a nice surprise in Lisbon dining scene. A place where you can find the best food in town, paying little. Been there twice during my visit and wold return

Loved this place!. Time out Market definitely worth a visit, some 30 places to eat - everyone sits together at long tables, great atmosphere - there is also a fresh food market which closes at 2 - good so nice, no fast food!!

Lively place. We came here on a Thursday evening and they had a band. It can seem chaotic at first but it is worth wandering round to see what you want to eat while also keeping an eye out for a spare seat. Once you have found seats get someone from your party to go and get the drinks/food. The outlets give you an electronic device to take away. It vibrates once your meal is ready.

As impersonal as an airport hall. Went for lunch, food was good. There is plenty to choose from, true. What I didn't enjoy was being pushed about by a zillion of people - mostly tourists like myself - milling about tray in hand, hunting for a place to sit. There is no service, you just order and pay, then wait for the buzzer they hand you to go 'buzz'. If you enjoy large crowds and a constant loud hum then this is the place for you, my unknown reader.

Great place to try fresh food. This place is fantastic to buy fresh fish,veg etc on one side or go to other side and try different type of dishes in lots of small restaurants.Must see when you in Lisbon
Don't miss it. Great variety of food and drinks, we were here twice to try out different restaurants. It is a good place to try out modern Portuguese food.

Worth a visit. We went on a Thursday evening and it was crowded. You may have trouble finding a seat. The long tables make it easy to talk to your neighbors and the atmosphere is very festive. The variety and quality of food is remarkable. A very nice way to spend an evening.

Affordable, Delicious Street Food From All Over The World. We visited the Time Out Market on a few occasions during our stay in Lisbon as it had a great variety of food and was cheap. I would definitely recommend a visit. Ohhhhhh & the atmosphere is buzzing

Nice idea, way overcrowded. A great idea, but it was too crowded when we visited. This is a combination of a food market with tons of foodstalls and little restaurants. Unfortunately it was impossible to find a place to sit down so we moved on. Admittedly, the weather was poor when we visited. On a good day there is quite some space outside, so may be better when the sun is out.

Awesome market for lunch. We have something similar to this in South Africa, so I had an idea of what to expect. An awesome indoor market with a variety of really cool and interesting food and drink options.

Busy and fun food hall. We've been here quite a few times and it's a great place for lunch with friends or family, as long as you don't mind being seated at big long tables with lots of other people.The former market hall has small restaurants all around the outside and you can find all sorts of different food. There's lots of local specialities, seafood, pizza, burgers and croquettes.It's probably not so suitable with small children or if you're wanting a quiet relaxing meal.

Cool place to eat. If you are in Lisbon, make sure you go to the fresh market (get there before noon or it is closed) then have a bite at the Time Out Market next door. It is a beautiful place. The food court is a fun place, with young chefs proposing menus, desserts, and other places offering a wonderful selection of wine by the glass or sangria.

special place, worth the visit. It's a real special place, a lot of restaurants, good food, a lot of people, not cheep, but good quality. You could meet a lot of foreigners, but I lot of local people else well. We liked it a lot! Visit this place, at list once. Nice shops too, a bit expensive though. You can walk to that place or just take a taxi for 5 euro.

Fabulous place to eat. This place has a bit of everything that is special to Portugal.. In fact we ate there every night. We just couldn't resist the zillion choices of food and wine available here. The vibe is great as well..

Very high quality food at a low price. We visited here on a Saturday afternoon which was quite busy, queues were about 10 ish minutes and finding a place to sit near impossible! Once you were prepared to deal with this though, the food is quite good. I had croquetas which weren't anything to write home about but the very cheap and lovely prosecco (and pizza) from the pizza place absolutely was! Generally speaking it's hard to have bad food here and worth going if you want to sample bits and pieces before deciding on what type of restaurant you want to have dinner in that night.It's right opposite the train station so very easy to get to but it's difficult for a place like this to have any sort of proper atmosphere when it's that vast. I would have loved to have done a proper shop through the farmers' market bit of it and brought home some raw ingredients to cook. This is also offered by some of the stalls in the main arena and might be worth looking into if you have the chance to do some self catering while in the city.

Loved Time Out Market Lisboa. Loved the concept, loved the food and loved the price. Enjoyed fish and chips, pork confit with sweet potatoes and cod with spinach and carrots. I am not a dried cod fan but the other two were delicious. I would definitely want to return and try all the different stalls if it was geographically closer to me.
Portuguese Expericence. A well set dining area with many shops selling tapas and wine etc. A definite must whilst in Lisbon to try the food
Dinner in Lisbon. A real amazing place where u could choose food and drink.people are nice and the atmosfere is very relaxed.I recommend it
Top on rainy days. Very nice indoor food and drink market where you can eat, drink and dine in a trendy atmosphere with trendy music and DJ's.

Shopping, eating and relaxing all under one roof.. Visit the indoor market where you can buy fresh fish, meat, flowers, and produce and then stop for a bite to eat one of the many restaurant offerings or even the special chefs lunch at the Academia Time Out (small cooking school) located in the large facility. We had a 3 course meal with wine for under 13 Euros and it was excellent. The chef and his assistants were very attentive and the food was prepared right in front of us. It was a great meal.

Take a load off! . Came across this really cool place just walking around. Enjoyed my first Portuguese beer & a charcuterie. You can eat a much or as little as you like. Something there for every taste.

Excellent Dining. This is a must if you're visiting Lisbon. We came upon it by chance, entering thinking that it was just a market but were pleasantly surprised at all the different 'mini' restaurants. We walked around for approx 15 minutes trying to decide what to eat because you are spoilt for choice in choosing superb, quality food. Whether it's for lunch or evening dining you will not be disappointed.

Worth a visit but be prepared to wait for a table. We visited here on a grey but warm Saturday lunchtime. The place was pretty busy, with queues at most of the stalls and food bars. However, the people working there are fast and efficient in getting the punters through, so we didn't have to wait long to be served. There's a decent selection of options, although seafood/fish dominates slightly. The arrangement is that you buy your food and then find somewhere to site at one of the long tables ranged through the middle of the market. If you order hot food, you'll be given a disc which lights up when the order is ready. While waiting, you have the challenge of trying to find seats - be patient because that can involve quite a bit of walking up and down the rows. The market itself is not east to spot from the road. We had walked along the river bank from the east and then into the station (Cais do Sodre). The market is across the road and about 30 metres to the left.

Nice place for a quick bite. This was a nice market to have a quick bite. The prices are affordable and the food quality is very good. We had oysters and sushi, all tasty. But it's not a place where you should spend so much time. I would more recommend you to go to local and small restaurants than eating here. One further thing to say, we didn't understand why the price of pasteis were that high. Everywhere else, even in the most touristic famous shop, it was less.

A Taste of Everything, Great Food. The Time Out Mercado da Ribeira is a very trendy place to visit in Lisboa. In the center of this big warehouse is plenty of seating..unless you go for dinner time (20:00-24:00). Then, it will be very difficult to find seats for more than two people. Surrounding all of the seating are a multitude of restaurants with anything you can imagine. They have traditional Portuguese cuisine at many of the restaurants, lots of seafood, Asian cuisine, pizza, gelato, desserts, and much more! Everything is delicious but you do pay for it. Compared to what you would get at a restaurant along the streets in Lisboa, Time Out Market is a bit pricey, but it is a tourist attraction so they can raise their prices because people still go. I like to go once in a while when I have a guest visiting because they always love all the options and the bustling atmosphere. Definitely give it a try or at least a walkthrough when in Lisbon!

Good variety of food. Very interesting place a must to see, however go hungry. We didn't and missed out on some great looking food. Very clean, a lot of choices in food types. There are 4 drink stations, beer, wine, alcohol and non alcoholic beverages.

A touch of genious and great fun. NOTE, tripadvisor: This market should be categorized under 'restaurants' rather than 'markets'.We went to this marvellous food market - or rather a restaurant market - for lunch, and returned for a second lunch the following day.The concept is superb: sample the food of great Lisbon chefs on pleasant stalls in a covered space that contains additional treats, such as organic fruit juices and specialty chocolates.The two fish and seafood stalls we chose were awesome: superb fresh atlantic ocean fish (the hake was absolutely stunning), and clams ans shrimp and calamari and octopus, simply delectable.Service was jovial and totally enjoyable.Lovely people and lovely atmosphere.

So many options!. This place is excellent! I went with a group of friends and we all got something from a different restaurant all located inside the Time Out Market. There is something here for everyone and the food was fantastic. We also shared a bottle of wine and the restaurant you buy it from will provide the wine glasses. The challenge is to find a seat. This place is very popular and busy during peak lunch and dinner times. There are a lot of authentic Portuguese cuisine options to choose from and great deserts too. I highly recommend going at least once.

Amazing Food and Market experience. This gourmet market is just so cool!! There's a million food options, mostly Portuguese with a twist. It's just so amazing and I think most chefs are kind of famous. Food is not expensive and it's on the way to Belem

Enough choice for everyone. - Location: ***** / *****Comment: located right beside the ocean, very accessible by any types of transportation.- Ambiance: **** / *****Comment: crowded but not too much. Pretty noisy but at the end it represents what it is suppose to be, a market...- Decoration: ***** / *****Comment: The place is located in an old hangar which was nicely rehabilitated with some nice wooden canteen tables and chairs and some industrial lamps.All the different places you can order at all share a similar black board with their name on it on top which brings a bit of harmony in all that chaos. - Service: ***** / -Comment: self-service- Speed: ** / *****Comment: most probably highly depends on the amount of people. We where there on a Sunday when most places are closed in Lisboa, which most probably increased the waiting time.- Food: ***** / *****Comment: You will find all kinds of food. Going from the elaborated codfish dish or crispy pork to a simple hamburger or pizza.- Présentation: *** / *****Comment: this is of course very dependent of which stand you ordered your food. Not all of them apply any particular importance to the presentation- Quantity: ***** / *****Comment: more then enough. We ordered at 4 different places and all of us had eaten enough - Price: *** / *****Comment: now this is the little down part of it. This place was quite more expensive then the rest of the city center places we went for lunch.__________________Overall: 32 / 40Comment: overall this was a nice experience. A place which is worth visiting even if your not hungry

Excellent food, but very popular and hence crowded. This was my second visit and I really enjoyed the quality of food and wine. The experience of walking around the different stalls and checking out a variety of cuisines was very interesting as well. Finding a spot to sit down was a challenge, but we managed after 10-15 minutes. Unfortunately, the place is becoming popular with stag dos and can be a bit rowdy.

Make this part of your trip to Lisbon. I wish every city had a market like this. The food from the stalls was great, the set up was well thought through, there were loads of options for everyone with a perfect leaning towards local dishes. I would recommend everyone to visit this market on a trip to Lisbon. It's not fine dinning but the place was very clean and the food and drink great. Perfect for large groups to crowd around a big table for everyone to choose something different. Things are sensibly priced as well.

Nice experience but difficult to find a seat. A big place where you can find between 20 and 30 chefs cooking specialities: from hamburger, soups, organic food, portuguese bacalhau and specialities, asian and japanese food, pizze but not pasta, .....and sweet portuguese dishes and ice cream.Everything is good or very good; est for adults and teanagers but more difficult for young kids.The only problem for the dinner is that everybody is nervous and fighting to find a seat for himself and friends/familly.It can be disapointing with kids because very noisy.Not tested for the lunch, may be more appropriate with kids.

Lots of choice, but impossible to find a place to sit when its busy.. Had soup from one of the stalls and a bacalhau (cod) dish from another stall. Soup was ok and the cod dish was nice. Well cooked with a satisfying cream sauce. Biggest issue is seating. If you get your food from a stall which does not have its own seating, but relies on you finding a seat in the communal seating area, then you could be looking around a long time for a free seat if it's very busy. And you may not find one at all (this was my experience).

What a find!. We accidentally found this market and were really impressed by the selection. We ended up having Portuguese style burgers. After ordering and paying we were given a small electronic device which acted as an alarm to collect our food. Make sure you get there early - we struggled a bit to find a place to sit and to be honest no one seemed sympathetic enough to offer seats to a 'single' mum with three young children. In fact an older couple slipped in and took our places while I tried to get the children's coats off so they could sit down. At any rate, the burgers were collected and the children gobbled them down. Overall really neat place to eat, with loads of selections for food, and a great community feel.

I love these markets!. I have never tried ox before. I can now say I've tried ox and really enjoyed it. Lots of restaurants to choose from and always bustling. A tad on the expensive side, but definitely worth a visit. Located right downtown a 10 minute walk from everywhere it seems like. Open late.
Best Cafeteria style ever!. Very stylish design with everything you could ever want to eat or drink. After work business clients and up-scale atmosphere. Only problem was it is very expensive

Foodie delight. We have visited the market twice so far and every time we discovered new things.There is a good meat ( fish and beef) and fruit and vegetable market. Once you have finished wondering around the food hall is simply amazing. A good selection of different cuisines and desserts and wine and beerHighly recommend a visit to this market

Gourmet bonanza of Portuguese specialties. To some degree, this is a place to shop and enjoy different aspects of Portuguese crafts, books and pre-packaged food; but mainly this is a place to come and eat heartily with a multiplicity of options. You can have a starter at one stall, a main meal at another and dessert at another. The place only has really good stuff, and there is a process of curation to make sure that you are getting the best. It is not inexpensive - but there are many options form just a soft drink to a full course meal. The ambiance is great in the renovated old market and everybody seems to be enjoying themselves at the refectory-style tables.

Back again... but this time I brought 60 friends!. I came across Ribeira Market last year and was so impressed that I took a corporate group in April 2016. The only downside is that you cannot reserve seating for a large group, but that said we didn't have too much problem in finding seats in blocks of 4 or 6. They all enjoyed it as much as I did on my first visit and testimony is that some are now recommending it to their friends too!To say it is very busy the service is relatively quick (10 - 15 min wait) but it is great fun just embracing the atmosphere.

Loads of Food Offerings. We went one night for dinner and there are many local choices of food for dinner. We went early so as to avoid the crowds but it was still crowded. You can find many good choices and lots of fresh fish.

Loved it ...... What a fabulous place which we came across quite by accident thinking it was just a fresh produce market. The concept is brilliant. Many food stalls have come together in a great environment to bring together a huge upmarket food hall. The produce looks as though it all comes from the surrounding fresh food market. Mostly local and organic produce is used. There are so many varieties of food and drink to choose from and it's all eaten in a common area so if you're with a group of friends and everyone wants something different...no problem! The place has a great vibe and was very busy.

Something for everyone. Amazing atmosphere, great choice, well organised and not at all expensive.
A must see whilst in Lisbon!

Lovely Saturday Destination!. Wheteher you're with your friends, your lover or your family, if you drop at the Market, you will be pleased to have a great selection of the most delicious food - we tasted many of the dishes and were amazed about the great taste, even the bacalao, otherwise a rather tasteless cod, was full of flavour at one of the chef locations. Great desserts too. Not to mention the wine. Try the white sangria with red fruits. It's lovely too.

Spent an entire day here!. By far the coolest market I have ever been to! Spend most of the day here sitting at a table drinking wine, and sangria and eating little meals throughout the afternoon. Amazing mussels (Spanish style), tasty fried green beans, peppers padron, on and on. Some of the best restaurants in town have kiosks here - don't miss it. If you find yourself in Lisbon on a rainy day - camp out and enjoy every minute!

Average food - nothing special. We tried a hamburger and some things from the organic stall. The hamburger was not well seasoned. Also salt and pepper was missing. The things from the organic stall were not freshly made. The humus came out of the fridge so it lost the taste, the carrots were weak and not crunchy, the veggie balls were poor in salt and had a bad consistence. Furthermore I wanted to eat a warm dish, and the staff told me, that they won't serve it any longer. For me as a vegan, there were no more possibilities to eat in the time out market... Not a vegan friendly place.

Exceptional and amazing food market - the Mercado da Ribeira. Sited in the ancient former fish market, this is a huge market hall transformed by Time Out with 30 or 40 food vendors' stalls selling all sorts of 'real food', plus some proper restaurants. All fresh food, freshly cooked, in dozens of different styles and accompanied by whatever you wish - wine, beer, fruit drinks, ginja (wild cherry liqueur) etc. Both Portugese specialities and international dishes like sushi are available, salads to steaks, Alentejo ham, fish and seafood, veggies, local desserts & ice creams etc. An astonishing selection. You order at one or more vendors' stalls, and either take your food or first an electronic pager to be paged when its ready, to a high stool on one of the long communal tables. You could eat here every day for years without repeating your choice. Our selection was very good salads but hot food is as available as cold. The place was very full when we visited, with both locals on their lunches and tourists, but a little swapping stools about was going on everywhere to get groups and couple their seats together, all very good natured. A great culinary experience.

Great way to try a wide range of cuisines/food in one place. Very nice way for everyone to eat what they fancy whether it's a burger, pizza or seafood and sit together. The options we tried were a bit hit and miss - some fantastic seafood from two stalls but some mediocre deserts and complete tourist rip off cappuccinos. Seems to also be somewhat a victim of its own success: even very early there were very few spaces to sit even just for two of us.

Pretty cool market!. Lots to eat here! I'd heard about it on a blog before coming to Lisbon and made sure I hopped off on my bus tour. Lots to eat - mostly portugese food. There were a few french bakeries there, which were nice too.

Great selection of food - something for everyone!. We strolled around the market part first and it made us wish we were self catering so were able to buy and cook something. We then walked through to the food stalls and although it doesn't have quite the charm of the Boqueria in Barcelona there is an amazing selection to choose from. We went just before 12 so managed to find a seat easily but some of the stalls weren't quite ready to serve so we sat and enjoyed a lovely fruity sangria first. We chose several things from the top end/more Portuguese stalls and really loved it. They were very tasty and reasonably priced for what we had. Afterwards we saw that on the outer walkway quite a few of the stalls had a few bar seats on the other side where you could order and sit slightly more quietly and not all these were taken. Great place to discover!

Loved this place!. Absolutely loved this place, spent a few hours here, the food selection is unreal and you could wander around, you have to be quick for the seats! I had pizza and goats cheese salad, my friends had the curry and the burgers really enjoyed this. If you like your grub this is a must! Sat outside then for a drink and there was guys playing music, well worth a visit!

Loved this place! . I loved this place! It had everything from florist stalls, fish market stalls, a variety of restaurants, and even organic food stalls. There was even a cooking space for classes to cook your own food. Dessert shops and a huge beer spot in the middle of the space. Every time I went, I tried something different. I even had sangria at lunch!

AMAZING!. This market was so much fun. We spent several hours sampling anything and everything in sight. Everyone was friendly, everyone spoke English and everything was delicious. It's a great way to get a handle of Portuguese food trends.
Foodie hangout. A chill place to enjoy your dinner with friends. Local and international food is served here. Foid price is acceptable.

Make sure you include this in your trip. An amazing place with a vast variety of food and drink from around the world, with plenty of local dishes too. We ate here twice, but could easily have eaten every meal here and never been bored.The main hall can get pretty busy, but there's usually enough seating for everyone (though no tables as such, just tall benches with stools). Sometimes there is also live music or a DJ, but thankfully not too loud to stifle a conversation.I'd recommend trying the chicken vindaloo, even if it's not quite as hot as what you might find in the UK!

Lisbon Break Away. We visited here as a group of 8, although it was difficult to get a table there was plenty of choice. Really great buzz about the place and great ambience.Recommend -Super bock beer 3 Euros for a largeThe table are large and shared, it gave us the opportunity to meet some wonderful people.Gluten free catered for.

WHAT A GREAT PLACE!. This is not just a simple market. It is indoors and is quite large, and there are many restaurants represented. All local - no fast food stuff. You just buy whatever you feel like eating and sit at one of the many high-top tables in the center. I've never seen a place similar to this that is so well done and inviting. This is truly a special place.

For Foodies But Go Early. Both the fresh market, especially the seafood section, and food court areas are worth a visit! In the actual market, you can learn a lot about the local fish, cheese, cured ham and snails! All the vendors are are Portuguese and very friendly. In the dining side, there are plenty options for food and wine! Our favourite, by far, was the Henrique sa Pessoa stall. Our recommendations: Suckling Pig with sweet Potato Puree and a Slow Cooked Egg with Truffled Potato puree, Prosciutto and Asparagus. The market and dining hall are nicely set up. Bathrooms are clean and free.TIP: Go early to avoid crowds and get seats for lunch. The better dining options are open at noon to take orders. Scout out what you want and be the first in line.

Excellent. Great choice with a cool market setting, a lot of choice of starters, wines and local beers, seafood, barbecues, pizza and local sweets, good prices and a bohemian atmosphere with a mixed crowd of local and tourist guests.

Great atmosphere and food . I visited the Time Out Market as a solo traveller yesterday and loved the atmosphere and food on offer. There was a wide range of cuisines to choose from and the food I tried was to a high standard. The communal tables meant that as a solo traveller I felt comfortable sitting down to eat, without feeling that all eyes were on me. I was able to relax and enjoy a bit of people spotting, before reading without being moved on to clear the table.

Fantastic!. This is the place to enjoy a splendid array of the best of Lisbon's cuisines. There is something here for every taste. A new concept to our family, we came back twice! It really is that good.
Great spot for food and drink. Awesome spot for a drink and great sampling of food. Very cool place. In addition to the food there is a lovely flower and produce market there as well.

Don't see the attraction. People rave about this place, but I couldn't see the attraction - though it may be that it's a victim of its own success. Rammed with people, very difficult to get a seat (which are very uncomfortable when you do), and then you have to fight to hang on to your seats while members of your party go running around for food. Neither relaxing or enjoyable. Wouldn't recommend for elderly people or children. Also, the toilets were filthy.
HAM AND WINE!!. This was part of my tour!! The ham and wine was fabulous and the atmosphere was really great too. A great place to see the locals having fun.

A foodie's food court!. You must take time out for the Time Out Market if you're in Lisbon! We made several visits here in our month long stay. The food options are excellent, the service is wonderful and the price is reasonable. You can choose to dine at the market or, as we did several times, get some food to take home for dinner. The atmosphere is very cool, it's like the foodie's version of a food court. Very cool place. Highly recommend!

Lots of choices. This was our first stop in Lisbon and we were not disappointed. They was lots of different food items to choose from , whether you wanted Portuguese staples, or sushi . Different sweet items for dessert as well. It was well worth the trip.

Good food, lots of choice and affordable. This place is an absolute must-try. There are lots to choose and it caters for anyone's range in budget and cuisine. The only thing that you might have to worry about is the portion of food which is quite hit-or-miss.
Wow. Found this place by accident but what a lucky find it was fantastic as was the food,people and people again, looks like the locals really use it so well worth a visit

Unusual dining expereience. At the end of the day it's just a very large food court but rather better designed than your normal mall one with a better class of restaurant and a staggering variety of places and cuisines to choose from. Also by its very nature it's a lot more interesting than a normal restaurant due to the number and variety of people milling around. Had a bit of bother finding a seat for 3 but managed in the end . Food could have been warmer and thought the take on gambas al ajillo unusual.

I Need Another Time Out. This place is exceptional. It took me 15 minutes to circle all of the chef booths to see what was offered and even then I practically had to flip a coin to decide where to eat. I don't think you can go wrong. The atmosphere in Time Out is very modern and I hate to say hip, but that word comes to mind. Glad to see all of the local eateries otherwise you might think you were in Seattle or London. Food and wine prices are very reasonable and offer a high value We don't have anything like this in the San Francisco area.

A great place to get a bit(e) of the Portuguese culture. If you want to eat, drink or shop (real) Portuguese items, this is one the best you will find in Lisbon.Very central - easy to commute - with a wide variety of preferences, per se and money-wise.
Wonderful!. Great place to indulge in the traditional and the new. Amazing food and amazing prices. the concept is so good. And don't miss the art gallery upstairs

Highly recommend! Best Vindaloo!. The market is very centrally located and offers a huge range of different food choices including traditional Portuguese dishes. We visited twice in the four days that we were in Lisbon and both times were very enjoyable. The prices vary but you can find a reasonable lunch or dinner or just a snack if you're passing through. There is a lot of seating and we didn't struggle to find places to sit. There was live music in the evening which was enjoyable and not to loud as to stop conversation. The food we had from the Asian outlet was brilliant, nice fresh fish and the best vindaloo! Would very much recommend a visit.

Great food choice.. Definitely a place to not miss in Portugal, with so many restaurants with portuguese food, the environment and atmosphere so friendly and warm. I went to dinner there a few times because was so many food to try that I couldn't try everything in one night. Was AMAZING.

Huge foothill with variety of eats. Set in central Lisbon this large food hall has the best of Lisbons Portuguese dining and drinks and serves them under one roof.Very well located opposite Cais do Sodre Station train & metro stations.

Very good experience. It is difficult to evaluate the quality of the food as there are so many diffferent stalls, offering a wide variety of food. We were very happy with our choices. The overall atmosphere was very good. A bit difficult to manage place for 6, but t worked out OK

Perfect place for a foodie!. We tried one of the country's most high-profile chefs stand: Henrique Sá Pessoa. Everything on the menu was very tempting, but I heard Henrique Sá Pessoa was the best place to get some pork dishes, so we ordered the crispy skin suckling pig sandwich with homemade pickles and the 24h confit suckling pig with sweet potato purée. We were not disappointed by any of our dishes. The pig was cooked perfectly. I really enjoyed the 24h confit, which was very moist and the crackling thin and crispy. The sweet potato purée was nice and smooth with a hint of orange which gave a bit of acidity to the dish. The only thing I didn't like about this market was the lack of space to sit down at rush hour. People were taking their seat before ordering their food, which was a issue when you had your food and couldn't find a seat to eat it.

Loved this place. I have to say this was one of the best eating experience I had in Portugal and I actually went twice. Very good selection of food, excellent vibe and fun atmosphere . Would go again and again!!!

Plenty of choice at variable prices. Somewhere worth a visit for a casual lunch where everyone in your group can have something totally different. Prices vary depending on your choice but enough to chose from to fit any budget. The seating arrangements are ad hoc and will not suit all I suspect
Lots of good food, very noise. Noisy place, but a lot of options of food, fish, meat and deserts. Very central place, nice place to start the night.

What a great idea!. This has to be done for a lunch when you are in Lisbon! Many chefs are there with different stands and you can get street food and seat with you family. And you have the choice fish, sea food, gourmet hamburgers, roasted chicken, sushi, pizza, soups, pastries etc...Everyone choses his food and the family get to lunch together. The ambiance is also very cool. I loved it and it's cheap!

Good choice of food, in revamped industrial marketplace. We visited early one morning as the food hall was setting up for the day, and returned later the same day for dinner. Finding a spot to sit to eat our food took a while, but it was definitely worth waiting for. Some food outlets take non-Portuguese credit cards while others do not. Take plenty of cash!

Briliant repurposing of great building!. Essentially, a food court supreme. Interesting, innovative chefs have opened satellite food spaces around a large hall with high tables and stools. Delicious choices and there is even an outpost of LaVida Portuguese!

So much choice!. We went there because our tour guide said you could find anything you wanted there. And he was right. The food that we had was really nice and even the big tables that you need to share with complete strangers are quite nice in this setting! It has a nice and busy atmosphere and it's quite cheap to eat! Great stop.

Great place!. I happened to stumble on the market during my day in Lisbon and it was a highlight of my trip. This is a cool space with many local chefs and restaurants to choose from. It was nice to just walk around at first to see exactly what to eat. I ended up with some very yummy boiled codfish. I definitely recommend checking this place out!

A must when in Lisbon. My wife and I found this food market an amazing place to go to eat. There is a wealth of choice from sushi to burgers, risotto to Pizza. The market is encircled with many food stands cooking amazing dishes using fresh ingredients to different styles.The centre of the market has benches for you to sit and enjoy the food and environment, coupled with drink stands such as wine bars, beer stands, cocktails and Coffee.Reasonably priced and very family friendly.A must when visiting Lisbon

Great place with multiple options . Great place for Sunday brunch , lots of options to choose from , Asian , Portuguese and European. Unfortunately I chose the wrong option from Asian lab , being a Asian , it was the worst beef vindaloo I ever had , actually it was not even remotely close to vindaloo. My wife chose the cod with asparagus which was good . Good choices for drinks , I chose cool as cucumber a cocktail from one of the bars . Overall nice experience.
Good variety. A very lively place with a bustling atmosphere. Lots of choices of food, reasonably priced, mainly for consumption on the premises rather than to take away.
Fabulous find. Great spot for lunch, choose what you want and off you go!Amazing choices for food and wine and a brilliant place to spend a few hours in Lisbon.

Amazing big space with plenty of food choices. Amazing place - impressive - tons of food vendors with a wide selection of quality meals served on proper plates. Loads of seating and a great atmosphere - a must to see and eat at. The food market is next door opening early but closing around 2pm but the food part is open all day and night. We had an octopus said - delicious with some lemon granita and some croquettes from 3 different stalls. FAB

Something for Everyone. Great place to eat and socialize. They have multiple eating establishments of all kinds. We ate here two or three times over a three day period. Great location near the metro station and within walking distance of the center of town. Taxis available outside as well if you want to use as transportation. Besides restaurants, they have desert shops, wine stores, cocktail bars, wine bars, beer bars and gift type shops.Great concept and highly recommend it at least once on your visit. The perimeter is all food vendors and you order like fast food style, but the food is restaurant grade. They typically give you a pager and when your food is ready, you come back and pick up. The only downside is finding a table to eat at. Think of the food court at a shopping mall. Best to find a seat first if you are party of two or more. They send one or two at a time to order. Just have someone guard your seats while doing this. Some of the outer restaurants have their own seating outside or along a bar which is nice. Overall a great experience and recommend it.

Loved this place . There is tonnes of choice at this great huge open market. Restaurant around the outside vary from Portuguese to Asian cuisine. Being In the British timing for dining is helpful - get here early lunch time for an easy seat, if not be prepared to hover. Good fresh food market next door.

Must do when in Lisbon.. What a wonderful place. Take a stroll around the food market and then sample the best food that Lisbon has to offer. There are so many different options to,choose from wether it's a full meal or just a drink and ice cream. Very busy at the weekends but also efficient and a great place to people watch.

A MAIN ATTRACTION. Never seen anything like this market - various vendors who make upscale, authentic Portuguese cuisine for the masses at reasonable prices. We went twice for lunch and once for dinner. You can find almost anything you're craving, from bacalao to suckling pig, charcuterie, cheese, wine, gelato, pastries, beers, wine, cocktails, etc. The market was packed during lunch. Finding seats will NOT be easy. If you're traveling with others, have someone search for seats while you order your food. You'll have to be fast and a bit aggressive. We had better luck finding seats during dinner.

Brilliantly done. A fantastic venue serving all types of food from around the world but mostly local restaurants using local products.The food hall is setup with eateries around the circumference of the space with large tables stretching the length of the hall in the centre. Basically, find the food you are after, pay, grab a seat and enjoy. Also, beer, wine and spirits are on tap here and are of the highest quality.If your in the area please do pop in. It's a great place to eat, drink and people watch.Recommend
very tourist. it is in the name, it is a tourist place still ok but not authentic. Would not rush back. The stalls are ok but I have seen a lot better in farmers markets without the hype prices.

This is such fun.. This place (opposite the Cais do Sodre) is a really fabulous place to eat. All round the sides are a huge variety of little kitchens. You can choose whatever you like and then eat and drink on stools and benches in the middle area. Lunch or dinner. It is always busy, so get there early and bag your stool.

Chill out lunch and dinner . I think it's a cool place to have lunch or dinner, so many options. We had sushi, risotto and dessert and they were all fulfilling and very tasty and fresh . I like how they serve gourmet food in such a cool, laid back environment

wow!. Found this by luck. Its a gorgeous structure with many local dining options. The food is above the average price, but not extreme. It's definitely a wow sort of place with fantastic food and drinks.

Great idea, lots to choose from!. Had read about the market before we visited Lisbon and decided to pop in for lunch one day - as a group of 4 we all ordered from different stalls as there was so much choice (seafood, Asian, traditional Portuguese, sandwiches, beer and wine bars, cakes and patisseries to name a few!). Each stall uses a pager system so you order, pay and take away a buzzer which flashes when your food is ready. It can mean that your group are not all eating at exactly the same time but generally the food is ready within 5mins no matter where you order from. Quality of the food was excellent and very fresh. We all really enjoyed our dishes although prices varied - we paid the same price (9 euros) for a small dish of tuna ceviche as we did for a whole chicken! Can recommend the dessert stall on the left as you enter from the wholesale market - amazing chocolate mousse and pavalova cakes!

Yummmy. Food was wonderful. When you walk in the aromas of the various cuisines is exciting. We walked around a few times before deciding what to eat and drink. We were not disappointed. We ate here a couple of times and sat outside in the bar space in the evening Recommend a visit

Great Idea for A Food Court. The Time Out Food Court is arguably the most brilliant idea of utilising the fish market and turning it into a food court with so many varieties of food including 5 celebrated chefs of Portugal serving a scaled down menu of its actual menu. Very trendy and upmarket look. The presence of security officers walking around the area makes it really safe for all diners to eat in peace without fear of being pick pocketed. A must visit when in Lisbon.

Such a wide variation of options. Lots of choice of food to have. We went here for lunch and were impressed. Seating is a little strange but it's a market not a restaurant so it met our expectations. Food itself was lovely though
Great Food and Atmosphere. I would recommend the chef restaurants (which are on the far end if you come in from the main entrance), they have the best dishes and the prices are reasonable as well.
Need to have a go. It is a nice mix of all you could want for a quick snack in the capital. The concept is good but we would need more tables and chairs probably.

Fun place if you're in the mood for everything. Go! We were apprehensive about this being a tourist trap with sub-standard food at an unreasonable price but it was great. Wonderful traditional prawn rice, great drinks and all at affordable prices. Easy to find and get to, and open all hours unlike lots of other eateries in the city.

Fantastic selection of food. Time Out Market is a wonderful place for foodies. Great selection of food, reasonably priced and very very tasty. My friend and I went there a couple of times and the food was great. It is quite busy but we always found a nice place to seat and it didn't feel overcrowded. I'm sure you can find cheaper places to eat which are just as good but the market offers such a great variety and it is wonderful to stroll around looking at all the delicious dishes.

Great selection of "take-aways" under one roof!. As well as a traditional market (covered) selling fresh food, the market has a huge variety of take away cafes (you order your food and they give you a buzzer thing to let you know when your food is ready!) - there are loads of communal tables.

OMG what a discovery! A must do when in Lisbon!. Found this place by accident, what a great spot. Tons of restaurants to chose from, every kind of food imaginable, amazing atmosphere and priced very well. All that was missing was my girlfriends for a girls night!
A must-see in Lisboa. This market is just great! If you are looking for some really and extraordinary food, you must go there! Unfortunately not cheap (especially for the size of the servings)!

Great food but too busy & too many people. If you ask me about the food there, it was excellent, but the lack of seats was a nightmare experience. We were there twice, the first time we went a bit earlier, it didn't take us too long to find seats and we really enjoy our food very much. A black squid ink scallop risotto from “Alexandre Silva", seabass seaweed salad from "Sea Me” & Pa Thai from "Asian Lab", all were wonderful. so we went back there for our last lunch of our trip, but it was a bit late, citing the peak lunch hour. We first order our food from different stands and looked for our seats, it was a huge challenge to try to find 2 seats. I think it took us over 20 mins to to secured a standing space to eat. By then my food had already gone cold, so it wasn't as tasty as it should have been. So all in all it was great place to eat as there are many choices but beware of the hour you choose to go there.

Fun in the market . What an amazing market. So very clean and well organised. Fantastic food and drink. A chance to pour your own beer! Too many delicious goodies on offer to eat in one day! Return visits a must!!

Never Thought Food Market Can Be this GOOD. Don't go at normal meal times because it would be packed and especially if you are there for the first time, grabbing seats, deciding on what to order in this fabulous eatery will be somewhat of a challenge.You can eat like a king for 20 Euros, at least 3 courses, plus a drink or two. Start with the cocktails that are clustered at the middle. The pick gourmet dishes from famous chefs or local delicacies and then wind out with Portuguese desserts that might tempt you to order more to take home.It is just a 12-minute walk from the Rossio Plaza. If too tired to walk, the subway stop is across the street.

You simply have to go here. Following the excellent ratings on TA we went here for lunch. It is simply a very large hall fu of eateries of all descriptions, dimly walk around until you find what you like, order your meal, they give you an electronic buzzer that tells you when you're food is ready. You then join the masses looking for seats in the centre of the building, a bit frustrating but all part of the experience. Not to be missed!! Be warned, some taxi drivers have no idea of the name Time Out so use the Mercado da Ribeira to get to the right place

Best Tuna Sandwich. The place gets very crowded around noon, so I would suggest you to get there a bit earlier.The Tuna Sandwich that they make is certainly the best I have ever had in my life, as you can see from the picture attached, the Tuna is sightly cooked so it retains all its taste.We also had some `local` sushi, and also in this case it was yummy.The food is delicious and the staff friendly an overall I would say cheap.
Perfekt street food. It is a great place on Friday evening. You can get one impression from Lissabon. The food was excellent and cheap :)

Lively venue. A wide selection of food stalls around central seating. Good for groups as everyone can choose their own style. Efficient paging system to alert you when food is ready. Always seems busy and their is a lively atmosphere.

Excellent Food. This was a real find and we had most of our meals here. The variety of food is amazing and there is a real buzz about the place with a great atmosphere. The shared bench tables mean that you get the opportunity to chat with your neighbours. Staff at the stalls are very friendly and helpful but it is busy at most times of the day!

Casual and fun. If you love good food and want to try out different things, this is a place to go. Time Out Market is a refurbished fish market, now filled with food-stalls of various kinds and also fresh produce and wines to buy home with you. You can eat a lunch or a dinner here - or even just pop in for a drink or a coffee - though I do recommend you take the time for a meal.There is a lot to choose from between Portuguese and international cuisine, sea-food, oysters, fish, meat, vegetarian, desserts...If you come with a big group, be prepared that finding a seating for everyone can take time; you shouldn't also expect to all be able to get your food all at the same; the idea of the place is that you wonder in, order&pay what you'd like to eat, find a vacant seat, sit down and wait until your buzzer tells that you can go collect your order from the stall. Tip: order starters from one place, main course from another... Share portions between friends... This way you can taste a lot of different things and the sometimes long waiting times for your food won't matter.

Great orientation of Lisbon gastronomy !!!. This place is must visit in Lisbon. We started our trip with Timeout. It's one of a kind food court which has stall from some of the best restaurants in Lisbon. You can sample various cuisines , wines, desserts all under one roof. The set up is beautiful . It gives you an opportunity to meet fellow travelers as you enjoy the fantastic food there. Loved it and would recommend this to everyone travelling to Lisbon .
Great atmosphere . Loads of food/drink options all day and into the night, as well as morning produce market. Very vibrant atmosphere with groups of locals and visitors alike. Don't miss it!
a very casual place to have a lunch or a dinner.. Very friendly atmosphere. Every body can choice his meal.Lovely with kids. all the countries foods.

An absolute must if you are a foodie. Will go back to Lisbon just to go here if nothing else. A foodies paradise and buzzing with energy. One dish stood out which was risotto with lemon coriander and swordfish - subliminal. How I wish I had this place on my doorstep, I would be a happy girl.
Fantastic 😏. Multiple stalls with fresh produce. The foodhall amazing... All types if food available, bars, coffee... Really nice atmosphere. Will go again.

Great food options. The Ribeira Market is a trendy place with plenty of stalls that serve delicious food. If the market hall itself is too busy and all the seats are taken, go to the outer ring where you can sample food from the same vendors. We had a wonderful sushi at Sea-me.
Fun visiting stalls and deciding on dinner. Great food and wine options. It was hard to settle one just one vendor. Food was excellent. IT was so much fun to people watch as well.

Plenty of food options! . I was expecting more of a market to pick up fresh foods but found this restaurant market instead. They have many different kinds of foods and I found a few good vegetarian options (tartar-ia is good). It is fairly busy but there is plenty of seating! Also try one of the many crazy desserts.

VARIOUS AND DELICIOUS TASTES. Against the "Cais do Sodre" and in a beautiful building, you can find the kitchens of some talented chefs, also you can eat whatever you want at canteen style desks, seafood, steak, sandwiches, hamburgers even sushi, you can live very different experiences at this Mercado...

Incredible food hall, one of the best in the world. Time Out Market Lisboa is an excellent place to explore the different facets of Portuguese cuisine. We were able to sample baby pig, charcuterie, croquettes, tartare, ginjinha, vinho verde... the list goes on and on, and it's all under one roof. There is also an incredible store of tinned seafood; these make great gifts/ souvenirs, as the labels are all 1950's classics. This place is a CAN'T MISS stop for any foodies visiting Lisbon!

Very Touristy, Very Busy, Solidly Meh. Visited for lunch thinking I could kill two birds with one stone by also picking up some produce & fruit for a picnic. When I got there, all the produce stalls were closed, which was obviously a bit of a let-down. The central food-stall area was INSANELY busy, even on a weekday. Lots of the food smelled good but it was difficult to choose because getting a good look at any of the dishes was tricky and not everything had a price listed.I settled on a dish which was so-so and a beer which was more than the going price at smaller cafes. Overall, this would be a fine place to stop if you were starving and needed a quick bite, but I would definitely not have gone out of my way to stop in.

Novel experience. We dropped in the Time Out Market for lunch, there is lots of choice and a really good atmosphere. I had mussels which were really fresh and tasty my husband had the cod which was delicious... Finished off with a nice cold glass of wine... Worth a visit.

Foodie Lovers in Lisbon Rejoice!. You've got it made at the Time Out Lisboa market place as a foodie. There is everything you could ever possibly want there. I would recommend the sushi as the fish is so fresh it's absolutely the best you'll get outside Japan.The desserts are amazing, the peri, peri chicken is superb. I could go on and on but you just have to go hungry and you'll be extremely satisfied, especially since there are so many choices.
Great choice of food and good quality!. Lots of restaurants with good variety, excellent food, some very nice deserts and chocolates!! highly recommended!!

Hard to choose where to eat. The major problem with this renovated place is to decide where to eat and what to eat! It's a very trendy place since it opened and it's always a good place for lunch, dinner, or maybe just a glass of wine or a nice beer!

Time Out. What a brilliant place. Some of the top chefs in Portugal and local specialities be cooked. All you have to do is sit in the middle and pick which one(s) you visit. Value for money too. I'd eat here every night if i could. Brilliant place and a great atmosphere with students to much older all welcome.

Dont expect "La Boqueria" but much to commend. As I have said in the preamble if you expect that this will be a full on La Boqueria (Barcelona) experience you may well be disappointed. Mercado da Ribeira! has its own charm and has given itself over to some major evolution and what a pleasant surprise it is. As you approach the Market building which is located close to the sea front/docks area of central Lisbon, nothing will prepare you for what the city has created here. In one of the two major market halls you will find a traditional local produce market that has remained largely unchanged for a century or more but in the adjoining Hall you will be amazed to find a tastefully modern food Hall that manages to blend seamlessly into the fabric of this historic building, whilst managing to tap into its personality and the ambience of its history.The variety and quality of the food is quite exceptional for the most part; we tried a platter of cured meats(including Black Pig) Breads and delicious local cheeses all washed down with a Douro Valley red.Others in our group raved about the outlet selling a bewildering variety of Tartar dishes two of which I got to sample and they were superb.The differing cuisine's on offer here are too numerous to mention but I seriously doubt that anyone would fail to find something to delight there taste buds whether it be seafood, pasta, Asian, local, Mediterranean etc.The ambience is relaxed with music playing in the background The design is people friendly with the majority of outlets being around the outside of a large inner seating and standing area. There is ample room to sit and relax and enjoy the surroundings and the food.We stayed for about 2 hours before travelling on to the airport. Originally this was to be a way of killing time without being hemmed in at the airport but it turned out to be a thoroughly enjoyable stimulating experience that enhanced my whole stay in the greater Lisbon area.When I return to this beautiful city next, I will be making my way on more than one occasion to this unexpected and charming market.

Tourist market. Nice area but very touristy. No Lisbon feel to it. It offers a big range of food shops with a predominant Portuguese offer. Copy of the trendy food markets in big cities. On the first floor, west side of the market there is Pap'Açorda a very nice trendy restaurant that made me cross the market a couple of times to go and enjoy a dinner away for the noisy big troop of tourists in the fancy food court.

Eclectic place to eat. This is the place "in vogue" in Lisbon to eat and spend some time.It has lots of restaurants and some of them from Potuguese chefs.You can find a great range of meals, from pastries to seafood.It's not very cheap, but everything worths the price.If you're visiting Lisbon, it's a must go!

Perfect for trying out everything!. Loved the concept of this market. Great when you are with a large group of friends and you want to avoid the hassle of picking a place to go. Here everyone can get exactly what they want! In addition to the excellent restaurants and snack bars, I also strongly recommend the wine shop and the Santini ice cream.

Casual high quality food market. It is very crowded but very much worse trying all food is of excellent quality and there should be something for any taste!We liked it, only 4 of 5 as you might need to wait quite a while until you find a seat and clean the seats yourself before the service people manage to come around.
Great market. Good place to visit and taste various samples of food from around the country. Well organised and food cooked to order quite touristy but worth a visit
Full of tourists with no real attraction or purpose.. If i want an open mall i could have stayed at home, no kind of welcoming people, terrible food! A place to avoid at all cost!

Great food court in Lisbon. A popular place in Lisbon judging from how difficult it was to get empty seats during dinner time. Lots of varieties of food an drink. Portuguese or the rest of the world (Asian). From sea food to ice cream, tequila to orange juice. Good quality, nice atmosphere. Recomennded
A have-to-go place in Lisboa. a great selection of street food places all around in this market. If you are in Lisbon, you have to go there!

Great taste of Portugal!!. This is an open food market, you have many types of food places to eat at, very casual, some wine shops as well. Great for a quick bite and a chance to taste different types of food.

with four boys of varying ages and tastes it was a fantastic find. Time out is an enormous market place made up of lots little cafes, bars, restaurants and delicatessens that serve delicious local food to the tables which are set up in the middle of a huge hall.

Seriously scrumptious . Think of the ultimate food hall- this is it- large area in the centre of the market with many stands serving lots of different foods- but all fresh and high quality. Spaces are at a premium for Saturday lunch- so watch carefully for anyone who looks as if they are leaving and grab the seats immediately. Lots of stalls from tapas, to gourmet salads to wicked desserts ( salted caramel tart to die for). Washed down with beer or local wine of your choice.Cool atmosphere mixing locals and tourists. Easy, affordable- good for singles, couples, groups and families.
Great lunch. We loved this place we went back again. Great variety, good value, lovely atmosphere. Easy to find and a definite must if you are coming to Lisbon.

Very chilled out.... We were told this was a "must go" prior to our visiting Lisbon, and we certainly were impressed when we visited the place. The atmosphere is quite vibrant and you are spoilt with choice of food all well priced, especially if you are on a budget.

Great spot with lots of choice!. We visited here a few times during our stay - once for lunch, once for a drink and once for dinner/snacks. We weren't disappointed any time. We tried food from a good few places and it was all really good. The best thing about it is that there is so much choice, you're not tied down to eating at the same place as your partner, friend, etc. Great range of price too! It's not a replacement for some of the great Portuguese restaurants we visited but definitely a great addition and worth at least one visit if not more! It can get packed but we never had a problem getting a seat, people are coming and going all of the time so if you arrive and it looks too busy don't let it put you off!

If you don't like this place you don't like food . A bewildering array of choices. We chose to let the chef choose. A great way to go for folks like us that are willing to try anything twice. I will go back at least twice more despite only being in town 8 days.

Wander in the morning, enjoy on the afternoon. We went there in the morning time at about 11:30 AM. It was rather quiet and nice to look around. Then we went there at 2PM - whole different place! It was full of people trying to get some food! Luckily we found a place just outside - much more air and you could look at the people while enjoying a humongous plate of seafood!

Wow! You will find something to suit your palate. We heard it was a good place. When we arrived it was like 'wow' this is massive. Plenty of different types of foods. If you are looking for a quiet, calm, sit at your leisure meal, this is NOT the place. On the other hand, it is an experience. We stopped at one stall and waited to order...we were ignored and were finally told, 'we have sold out' so can't serve you. All part of the experience :)

A chef's lunch. On our last day we decided to have lunch at Timeout.The design and ambiance of this place is awesome.The food selection is pretty big and we decided to go to one of the little shops managed by portuguese chefs.We had mostly fish and we loved it! We had to wait a little bit but it was so worth it!We also had fresh fruit juice made in front of you and bought some great wines to take home.

Something for everyone. We checked into our hotel quite late when we got to Lisbon and we were a little disappointed because we wanted to go out to eat so we came here on a recommendation!This market was huge and served food and drink until late! They really do have something for everyone - it had a really nice buzzing atmosphere. A great place for a group of friends especially! We came here a few times over the period of our stay, sometimes for a quick bite or to pick up some pastries to take with us!Would definitely recommend checking this place out.. Even if it's just to walk through and explore :)

You must visit this place at least once !!. This vast eatery is hopping with eaters but you must get there early if you wish to be seated ! It really is a must do when in Lisbon, if only for the fun of it !!
Unmissable!. Wonderfully atmospheric place to eat shop and drink. the vibe is so buzzy and yet relaxed. The choice of quality food is huge, and you can easily lose ntrack of time.

Great place for lunch!. You can find here a lot of stalls with great food and drink. The place can be very busy at lunchtime but it's definitely worth a wait. Don't forget to finish your meal with delicious Santini ice-cream :)

Excellent food at great prices. We visited the market on a day trip to Lisbon, and not knowing what to expect, we were amazed by the different stalls, foods and atmosphere. We ate food which was delicious and of a high quality - at a reasonable price.This market is very popular and gets very busy very quickly.We would definitely visit again.

An assault on the senses. Definitely worth finding this gem, it's unique and full of atmosphere. We ate so well for such great value. The producers/chefs are all artisan and do a wonderful job of bringing sublime Portugese food to life.
Bring a large appetite.. Great place for grazing, with lots of different styles of food on offer. Reasonable value for money. Get there early at the weekend.

A food haven. An odyssey of food stalls and a difficult decision to make if a foodie. In the end I opted for Ox cheek and sweet potato mash. It didn't disappoint but nor did it fill me up either. The size portions are on the smaller size. Good for lunch but if ravenous, I think you'll be heading around again for dessert, which isn't necessarily a bad thing ! : )
Nice Market. Nice market to go and have a taste of local portuguese food. Recently renew by Time Out. Go earlier if you dont want to fight for your place

Great varieties... Different local cuisines..
Many shops at one stop..
Not cheap, not too expensive..
You ll find alot of people here enjoying their meals in the closed area..

Lunch!. I had lunch here while my husband napped off the jet lag. There are lots of high quality options and the prices are very affordable. Free wifi and clean restrooms. Despite the crowds, this place is sure have something to please the whole family!

Good variety of restaurants. The Time Out Market Lisboa is a great place to have a full meal or a quick snack in Lisbon. The market is located just by Cais do Sodré, a major metro/ trams/ bus/ train station, so it's quite simple to get there. The market has a wide range of restaurants, including Portuguese, Japanese, Chinese, Mediterranean, Steak house, Vegetarian, Bakery, among others. The market obviously has an area to buy food, flowers, and other goods. A very good place to visit (and where to eat) in Lisbon!

Great atmosphere. Indoor communal dining hall experience. Great choice of quality food outlets around edges with tables in the centre. Lots of people of all ages. Music, including live dancing last night. Stayed opposite and went here after long days sightseeing. Tip - find a space at a table before ordering your meal. Lots of people wandering about with trays !

Great if you are from Lisbon. Don't expect anything that local. This is a cool place to hangout for locals or anyone not that bothered about seeing Lisbon. Not bad on a rainy day too. It has plenty of tables and a selection of food but if you are in Lisbon to see what is quintessentially Portuguese, you won't find it here. You feel like you could be anywhere in the world.
Great selection of foodstuffs. Fish, port, wine, produce, meats, everything all on display. Come for lunch or a snack. Have a seat and watch lisbon walk by. Good for an hour of excitement and awe.

Amazing selection . I can't fault the choice. A little difficult with a small baby due to it being so busy, a bit of a struggle to get seats, it was a Saturday lunchtime so maybe should have been expected. Would definitely like to return. Food hall was great.
Ultimate gourmet food options. The market is comparable to Fanuiel Hall in Boston with multiple food stalls. We tried 3 different vendors and they all were very good. Fun atmosphere.

Delicios Cozinha da Felicidade. Time Out Market was great, just as good as the similar one in Madrid. We ate in Cozinha da Felicidade and Manteigaria Silva. Food & wine was soooo good, this place you have to try!

The perfect place for lunch. Really spacious. Great variety of food. Inexpensive. I had Portugese -style chicken at Miguel Laffan - so tasty . Another day I had a delicious fish pie at Henrique Sa Pessoa
Lively. Went here having read reviews and not disappointed. Great variety of food, drink and people to amuse us. Definitely worth a visit , we went back in the evening too on another day.
Delicious food for everyone. We came back to this place three times during our short stay in Lisbon. We were positively surprised with a choice ans quality of food.

Seems to be a Trend but great fun. Similar to the Mercado de San Miguel in Madrid, lots of various food and drink stands and usually busy with locals and visitors - a bit expensive but worth a couple of trips

Tourist only, not many locals.. It's a big foodcourt with over-priced items.
