Food is okay, but expect to pay tourist pricing. I went there around 11 am, had to wait to till 12 pm before I can order any hot food items. Not worth your time, unless you happen to be near the place.

An exciting food and drink concept. The Time Out Market is on the waterfront highway opposite Cais Sodre (South Quay). The old produce market has a large central hall, where fish and vegetables were sold. Now this central hall has communal tables, bar stands in the centre, and multiple restaurants around the outside of the central hall. One can order different courses from a wide variety of different restaurants, and bring them to one's eating place. It is a brilliant marketing concept, as one is not tied to a single restaurant, and the restaurants are forced to compete in one space, with their prices on display to every other restaurant. In the side-galleries there are some restaurants where one sits on bar stools, and orders from that restaurant. We tried several suppliers and were pleased with the quality and price. The only exception that I would make is that for a wine-producing country, the wine prices, at E4.50/glass are high. The only downside is that it gets crowded very quickly, and it then becomes difficult to find seating. Best place in Lisbon for people-watching.

First lunch in Lisbon... Food poisoning . My girlfriend found out about this market during her research on the city before we arrived. All of the pictures and the concept seemed very cool- much like the group of food trucks that will gather in different cities. Many food choices all under the same roof. At first all the food looked delicious, and tasted delicious... Then 7 hours after eating at Miguel E Castro Silva's booth that all changed. I was throwing up in the allies of barrio alto and we had to leave a fado show early because my stomach was in full on attack mode. I am still sick from the food at the market yesterday and it has ruined our day today. There must be some issue with the food storage at the market because each booth is so small and I'm not the only one to have this reaction to the food here. Choose something basic when you visit this market. It's a cool place but not worth losing the next day over due to a very long sickness.
Interesting place, great food!. Don't miss it! All sorts of food and drinks, cool industrial style mercado, very crowded and noisy, but that's why is so interesting.

Wonderful surpise for my last dinner in Lisbon. Was in Lisbon for a 4-day conference, and the two dinners I had were both very good and authentic.My spouse went on a dinner tour the night before and suggested we go to Time Out since it was recommended by another acquaintance she met on that tour. I'm glad to have visited as the food was excellent, the price was reasonable, and it was unlike other 'food emporiums' that you might find in Farmers Markets in the US, such as The Grove in Los Angeles, Reading Terminal Market in Philadelphia, or (yuck) the Lexington Market in Baltimore. This place is much more upscale!Yes you have some 20 or so vendors of all kinds of food, from sushi to hamburgers to pizza to classic Portuguese dishes, arranged all around a giant open space with long bar-height tables. You get a buzzer for when your food is ready, you get a tray with real plates and silverware. (I noticed all the plates were standard sizes, easing the mechanics of clean-up and distribution of the tableware.)In the center is a bar area where drinks could be ordered - as others have mentioned a bit overpriced at 5-6 Euros. Great choice if you were traveling as a family; as a couple we really enjoyed both the meal (try the roasted, salted peppers, they are great, and had some great pork loin), and the atmosphere (at 8pm on a weeknight in April it was full, it took some patience to find a seat). Open till Midnight Sun-Wed, open until 2am Thurs-Sat!Hmm, if I had the 'munchies' at midnight this would be an awesome choice.

Great spot for Gastro fans. This is a old market converted into a market of restaurants of high quality that exist in Lisbon. One can just pick small dishes from different ones and try a huge variety of flavors and styles. To help the wine and beer selection is also very diversified.

Gourmet drligjt. Fantastic place to eat with s very chilled atmosphere. Good value and excellent choice of high quality good and drink.
Would thoroughly recommend this for anyone.
Can't wait to return!
Unusual and unique attraction for foodies!. Lots of lovely stalls serving high quality dishes- A posh food court. Everyone was happy and not too pricey.

Choice from the best food outlets in Portugal. We had excellent food, including a piece of very rich chocolate cake. You can sit on bar stools at some of the outlets, making it more of a restaurant feel. There's something here for everyone.

Arrive early as it gets busy, very busy. So good to see such a busy and wide range of food and drink for sale. Down side is the price of the wine that can be bought for a fraction of the price in good quality restaurants just off the main square in Lisbon. Think the bar tenders put a tourist tax on it at €6 a glass when even 4 star hotels only charge €3.50 locally. This lets it down as you feel you have been tourists ripped off. Seats to eat at can be difficult at lunch time so eat elsewhere if you want to take you time and relax rather than shovel your food down.
Great place to eat. Time out has a lot of choice for food. The quality of the food is high and the prices are reasonable. Highly recommend visiting here after a day of shopping and sightseeing!

Many flavours in one place. Lots of really good food and drink in one place. And for those who are looking at buying the essence of Lisbons food excellence the meat, fish, fruit and vegetables that make it up the market is next door. I've bought the food from the TimeOut market and the fish and meat and veggies from the market. Both outstanding,

Great for strolling around and trying typical dishes. This food market is great for trying all the different culinary delicacies that Lisbon and Portugal offer, plus some more general mediterranean dishes. The dishes are, as always on this kind of markets, not very cheap. But it's a great way to try a bit of everything
Fun place to enjoy all kinds of local cuisine.. Very fun place to go. Huge variety of local food and drink. Great music playing. Just a fun place to hang out with family and friends.

Amazing . Just popped in to cower from the rain and am really regretting eating a big breakfast. Haven't seen a single dish that doesn't make my mouth water. Plus a just fantastic atmosphere. Will be back.

Foodies Delight. From sushi to pasta. Every type of food stalls are under one roof. Weekends are packed with people. Midweek is the time to really walk through are select your dining experience. One visit is not enough.
Omg. Go to this place. Insane food court with untold local cuisines. Great wine choices and foods and smells entice you to each stall. Can get a tad busy, but there's no surprise when it's this good.
a great place for lunch. make sure you go early or late. from 12-2pm this place is a zoo with people fighting over tables. otherwise it is fun and a great way to check out diff foods.
Wow, as soon as you step inside!. What an exciting atmosphere. Great system with a bleeped to order food ☺️ Superb choice of food from Asian to typical Portuguese. Good value and good tastes.

Some of the best food I have ever had!. The timeout market is a hot spot for foodies, so much choice and all the food is 5*. The market is a combination of pop ups of the best restaurants in the city, so if you are looking for some tasty food, this is the place to go. There is also a food market on next to the timeout market where you can get some tasty fruit!

Sumptuous foodie heaven. This was such a great place that we went two nights in a row. Every top Lisbon restaurant in pop ups, so you can try something from the best food places in town. We enjoyed slow cooked eggs, soft shell crab, amazing steak and much more. Fabulous buzzy atmosphere. And a simple system - order, pay, wait for your beeper to go off, collect food and enjoy.

Awesome place for food and cheap!. If you can not find food here that suits you, then leave Portugal, or better yet, go back to where you came from. This place is fantastic. The crowd is a mixture of tourists and locals. The food is delicious. Everybody was almost licking clean their plates.It does get crowded and you will have to search for a table, but people are constantly coming and going.Don"t miss this place. You could eat here several times with all of the choices.
Restaurants Galore. A great place in Lisbon to eat, drink and be merry. An extensive choice of top notch food and drinks. Lively atmosphere. A great place to chill after your busy day sightseeing.
amazing food market. What a find! Great choice of food from tapas, sushi, burgers, cakes and authentic Portuguese dishes. Very busy and popular but worth the wait for a table. Great atmosphere.

A must for any holidy trip just to experience the market and different good quality food stalls.. This was not in any of the guide books but stumbled across it down by the river front. Although called a market it would be better described as a large food hall serving lots of different choices where you can sit anywhere and eat from any of the vendors.

Worth a visit.. Definitely worth a visit of you like food and drink. It has everything you could possible want to eat all in one place and drinks a plenty. Everything is fresh and seemingly made to order, or near enough. The only reason it doesn't get a 5 is that, coming from the UK, these sort of places are not unusual and I'm seeing it for what it is. A very fun and hip canteen, with some really cool places to eat.

Worth a visit.. Definitely worth a visit of you like food and drink. It has everything you could possible want to eat all in one place and drinks a plenty. Everything is fresh and seemingly made to order, or near enough. The only reason it doesn't get a 5 is that, coming from the UK, these sort of places are not unusual and I'm seeing it for what it is. A very fun and hip canteen, with some really cool places to eat.
Gem in the city. Imagine having 12 of the best restaurants in the city under one roof, and you have to choose. This is the market. It is a wonderful concept for any time of day

Lots of Option but tough to find a seat when busy. We came here for lunch after getting of the train coming back from Belem. It's only like one block away from the rail way. Great place to grab some food as there is so many options. Highly recommend.
Brilliant. Excellent selection of food from all around the world. Great super bock experience trying all their different beers. Place is great for food and drinks and also to spend a few hours
Quality & Quantity. Excellent selection of top quality food and drink all under one roof. Great location and atmosphere, certainly a step up from typical food court offerings.

good place to eat. The choice of food and drinks is excellent.it was very busy when we went (Sunday evening) so we had to take it in turn to get our food otherwise we would have lost our table but still worth a visit.

Food poisoning.. I liked the converted market food mall and walked there a few times - until I got food poisoning from an under-cooked octopus dish.Tip there are dark toilets upstairs - something for which I was very grateful as I spent a couple of hours there.I did not go there again after that, but chose to use more traditional restaurants elsewhere.

Foodies, rejoice!. Come here to taste small plates from some of Lisbon's best chefs. Servings are affordable. The atmosphere is friendly and convivial. Every person in your party will find something that appeals. There are long high-top tables with comfortable stools, all in warm wood. Beer and wine available!

Ok but not really a market. We visited the Time Out Market with high hopes, given the reviews. Perhaps we didn't read them closely enough but the market is basically some fruit and veg stalls on one side and some food outlets / small bars on the other. Thus, not really aimed at a family with young children, no stalls for them to look around etc. So we left again pretty soon. I''m sure it's great for other kinds of travellers but I wouldn't recommend for families with young children.

Mix and match. Fell upon this on our 1st day in Lisbon and it was a good place to shelter from the rain. It was not busy on the Friday lunch time that we were there. What was nice is that everybody could go to the various stalls to chose what they wanted and then eat together. I enjoyed a nice selection of three salad for just over E5 and tea from another stall. Close to the metro and trams and well worth a visit.

Good food, but...You have to be in the mood for crowds. I guess I wasn't really in the mood for the scene at the market the day we went. The food is all good quality, and the range is excellent. The problem is crowds. We were there in March(!) and at least 50 people were standing to eat way off to the side because they couldn't get tables. I love market dining, but this is market crowds (or more like food court crowds) without the market prices. For what I paid, I'd rather have a bit of space to sit and hang out with my group.

Foodie Food Court. This is a great place to sample food from many different interesting restaurants. Lots of options including a wine bar. The only negative is the limited amount of seating during busy times which is often since it is a very popular dining spot. We thoroughly enjoyed eating here!
Perfect for foodies..... No clues what and where to eat in Lisbon? You find most famous Portuguese restaurants in mini forms here, be patient enough and you will enjoy the tasty food there.

Great food, friendly people. This is like a food court for serious foodies. One can find stalls run by very good chefs. The locals call it the Ribeiro market. Ideal stop when coming back from Belem. Great fish grilled in front of you, chicken etc, even pizza and hamburgers. Wine, beer also available.

Best part of my Lisbon trip!! . Amazing food!!! Went 4 times in one trip! The seared tuna over chilli noodles is great, delicious sushi cones, great chicken, unreal gelato and so much more. I could go every day and get something new!

Wide choice of differnet food stalls. Typical array of fast food shops surrounded by communal tables. Good, simple food, and plenty of choice. Also shops from the tinned fish factory, and a few others - but mainly food to eat on the spot.

Delicious local food and wine. Brilliant place to eat and drink. Important to get there earlyish as it is very popular. Once you have secured a seat then you can relax order a glass of wine and decide which of the amazing food you are going to pick. We did it in stages! Went there twice thoroughly enjoyed it.

Highly recommended. Really interesting market place. Lots of options from slices of Serrano ham and wine to hamburgers. It was very busy on Saturday night ~ hard to find a seat. So perhaps avoid busier times. Nice Portugese desserts too!

Finest in Lisbon under one roof. Go for lunch! A easy food Hall with so many varieties to choose from:hot dishes of stewed beef, roasted chicken, grilled bass, grilled octopus, sandwiches of all sorts, beer on tap, coffee made just for you. And then there's desserts from almond tart to pavlova. Something for everyone. Make sure you stop by the stall that sells ham; same one as in the old city.

Had better in Lisbon. This is a great place to visit - the concept is certainly interesting. Not sure I'd eat there, the queues were humungous and the food didn't look as good as other places we have been in Lisbon

Had better in Lisbon. This is a great place to visit - the concept is certainly interesting. Not sure I'd eat there, the queues were humungous and the food didn't look as good as other places we have been in Lisbon

Awesome Food Court/Market. We had a fun time trying some of the restaurants at the Time Out Market (Ribiero Market) in Lisbon. There are about 30 different restaurants represented there and it is a great way to sample various Lisbon chef's dishes. The only downside was that it was difficult to find a place to eat your meal. I would suggest finding a place to sit first and then get your meal while someone holds your spot. It seemed to be less busy around 2:30 pm
Hipster touristic. nice place to eat, but super crowded, not very cheap...and super touristic.still worth coming to try different food types. my sushi was perfect

Good place for lunch . This is the best food court ever! There are so many options and all freshly made which means you will be waiting for your food for about 10-15min. Check the hours before you visit as there are days it closes earlier than others

Nice burger, shame about the bun... I was recommended this place by our hostel owner. Needless to say, there is a wide choice of stalls and I can only judge the one I ate from - Alexandre Silva. All I can say is that I was disappointed. Having indulged in traditional Portuguese fare for several days, I ordered an "Ox burger"...what could go wrong with a burger you may ask? Well, a lot: with this one there was a distinct lack of bun! In other words the beef paté, which was rather nice, was stark bollock naked! Now, I'm not an expert on Portuguese culture but I'm pretty sure that burgers in 99.9 % of the world, including Portugal, come in buns, or at least this is the expectation...an expectation propagated for better or for worse by fast food chains such as McDonalds. Now, not only did the poor beef paté have nothing but a lettuce leaf covering it's modesty, but there was also no tomato sauce to keep the rather lonely side order of wedges company...Ronald McDonald would be turning in his grave!

Loved it. Great place to hang out and enjoy some nice food by local chefs. We had menu of the day from one of the vendors which included a plate of lovely roast beef and potatoes with spinach, a glass of very nice house wine and a pastry sweet sardine for all of 12 euros. Yep you can pay less or more elsewhere but I really enjoyed the atmosphere and it's open all day until the early hours. There's something for most palates. Have been twice already and will probably be back as the octopus dish looked amazing.

Delicious Portugese food in vibrant market. This fun food market appeals to both tourists, or travellers as we would prefer to be called and discerning locals. Sitting on long communal wooden benches drinking local wines and chatting about the day's events is a very pleasant and relaxed experience. There is considerable variety in the fare on offer and although my daughter and I are not very familiar with Portugese wine and food, stall holders were most helpful.A highly recommended activity when in gorgeous Lisbon

Nice to see. An old market building that's been transformed into a modern eating hall. Nice to see, and a nice place to sit down for a bit. I can imagine this is the kind of place where you easily meet new people.
Impressive food hall and product market. Good selection of food outlets in the food hall; obviously gets very busy at lunchtime, so plan accordingly.
Amazing. Huge market, very clean with lots seating available. I loved that every where I looked someone was eating something different. Free wifi and a wide selection of foods-sweet and savory!

Good for quick lunch. The first place we visited in Lisboa, it was quite nice- there is a big choice of different kind of cuisines - From famous Portuguese bacalao to Asian noodles, seafood, pizza and chicken wings! We didn't have to wait long even when the place was packed! Can't say it's great for romantic dinner or business meeting, but it's good for quick meal! Recommend!

Just go there. There are cooking stands for absolutely anyone's taste. It's all fresh and it all looks irresistible.We went to a place which I think was Alexandro somebody in the far left hand corner when you enter from the main street. We had a delicious black risotto with crispy seaweed, and wine from the next door boutique. You put in your order, stroll around the hall and they buzz you when it's ready. You take your tray and eat at tables in the middle of the hall.

A must visit place similar to Mercado San Miguel Madrid. We have been here a few times. One one side is the traditional food market. On the other is a foodie heaven of a large range of pop-up restaurants. It is a large open space with the walls lined with small restaurant kitchens. In the middle are rows of communal benches to sit and eat at. You order your food from whatever kitchen, and if I a group try various ones, then wait for your electric buzzer to ring to say that your food is ready. Food is consistently good but if for different kitchens will not all be ready at the same time. There are famous chefs represented and they didn't disappoint. In holiday season it is very busy but when we went back in Janaury there was no problem getting a seat. It is similar to San Miguel Madrid but here in Lisboa the focus is more on plates of food where as San Miguelmis more tapas or pinchos. Highly recommended for a group of friends. Easy to find and a short walk from the metro.

Popular spot which can become rammed - opens at mid-day. The Time Out market restaurant section is adjacent to the produce market, which is open in the mornings. Apart from some concessions, serving drinks and snacks the food 'hall' doesn't open until midday when there is a wide choice of different types of foods to be had. Every person in your group can have something different which would suit the carnivore, vegetarian or even vegan diner. The ability to get good wines and beers at different outlets means that you can have as good a confection of a meal as possible to satiate everyone. The communal dining thing is very attractive but, at peak times, you have to hang onto your space so that someone in your party stops your seats from being pilfered whilst you go off to collect food, drinks or go to the loo. A lovely environment with a real buzz at a price that you have ultimate determination over.

good choice of food. We didn't have the best of experiences here because there were too many people for too few seats. The meal took over half an hour from ordering to arrival and then it wasn't exactly as ordered. When I asked the stall to refund me for wrong items it was done with bad grace
Fun vibe... Great vibe, nice food and drinks. Fun place to explore local food. Great place for lunch or a casual dinner. Come wander around and choose from a few stalls and share.

perfect place to find various tastes. It is across Cais do Sodre metro station and near Praça do Comercio. It's a big market area including different tastes like chicken meals, sushi, vine, traditional food, sea products, desserts, souvenirs. Sitting area is in the middle of the market and open for everyone. So it's always so crowded and often hard to find a place to sit. I tried bacalhau (famous fish) burger, salmon sushi, and chicken noodle, all of them were pecfect. I definitely recommend anyone who likes tasting different food.

Perfect and delicious!. This place has variety of delicious and diferent kind of meals. For fish lovers I would recommend grilled fish with rice (with garlic scent) You will definitely enjoy it!After the meal traditional portuguese almond cake as a dessert was the best choice for me.

Something for everyone. Great place to eat. Basically a food court with only the best vendors. Dozens of stalls to choose from. We had soup from one vendor then followed that with prosciutto melts from another. This is not fast food, some dishes take a while to prepare, didn't see anything ready made. All was excellent. Everything was very clean including the water closets.
Great atmosphere. Great communal atmosphere - dozens of places to buy food and/or drink and sit at long tables chatting to strangers from all over the world.

A great place to grab whatever kind of lunch you want. Most market lunch counters are sort of grungy affairs. Not so in Lisbon's central market. A large selection of restaurant counters offer all kinds of cuisines at reasonable priced.
Wonderful place. Great atmosphere and brilliant place to stop for lunch and a drink. Can also recommend the amazing pastel de nata at Aloma

Good place to try out Portuguese food. Conveniently located this market offers a wide selection of reasonably priced and very varied local food. Opening hours are long and virtually everyone speaks some english. It's a great place to try small plates of local food and drink.

Plenty of choice. One hall of a green market (Mercado do Ribeira) has been transformed into a large food-corner. But you will not find the McDonald's or the Burger King here. Although it's pretty much fast food it has a different approach. Most of the restaurants will offer some local dishes (like soups, ever-present dishes of "bacalau" - codfish, so you'll have plenty of choices to go for local specialties), but you will also find a sushi restaurant, pizza cuts, and delicacies such as local ham and local cheeses. You'll also have an opportunity to choose a drink - from freshly squeezed juices or local beer to good wine selection. Perfect spot to make a lunch (or even early dinner) break while you are walking around old city center. It's right there on the river bank (hence the name of the market) alongside Cais Do Sodr train station. Price ranges vary depending on the restaurant - but you can eat tasty food for a very reasonable sum of money. The only downside - it may be crowded on weekend during lunch hours.

A wonderful place to eat out. We ate several times in the market, choosing dishes from various stalls. It was so refreshing to find a food hall with, instead of fast food chains, cuisine offered by Lisbon's best chefs. Fantastic bacalao. Excellent wines and coffees.

Foodie Heaven. What a great idea a food court that actually offers a fantastic selection of proper food expertly cooked freshly for you at sensible prices Well thought out system for serving it as well.Visited twice during our stay and on both occasions had different foods Sat on long tables with friendly locals Very enjoyable experience

Fabulous!. We visited this market twice during our visit to Lisbon. It is full of gourmet food stalls with many choices of foods and beverages. It was fun to get a bunch of items to share and enjoy a glass of wine and a cocktail. There was plenty of seating. It was a great place to eat when we wanted an early dinner as most restaurants in Lisbon do not open until 7:30 pm.

Nice lunch spot. We stopped here for lunch on our last day in Lisbon. I think there's a big hype about this place, and it was a really nice lunch, but I don't think its a big deal if you miss it. The food was great, there was a lot of choice. The service was pretty quick (especially seeing as we were there during lunchtime), the cleaning staff were super quick at clearing tables. There weren't enough toilets for the size of this place, but there was a lot of work being done to the rest of the building. There is a cash point which is handy and the cooking classes looked really fun. If you're looking for a place to eat, this is a great choice due to the variety and the quality of the food, but if you're looking for an authentic Portuguese experience, I don't think this is the best place.

Best food court in an upcoming neighbourhood!. Grab a meal from a top chef and walk around from Cais do Sodré (where you can take the train to Cascais!) to Santos district. Perfect lunch or dinner spot!

Very disappointing for vegetarians . We were really excited to try this place but could find next to nothing that was vegetarian. We ended up only having pizza (admittedly very nice) as there was nothing else. Also found it very overpriced. If you are a meat eater I'm sure it would be great, but veggies should steer clear.
Great place for foodies. Went here after a recommendation from our hotel. It was well worth it. Great choice of good quality food and drink in very pleasant surroundings. Loved it.
Excellent variety and quality. Excellent variety and quality, great fit a high quality casual meal. Everyone got something different, very good gelato to finish.

Yes! Yes! Yes!. Time Out Market also called Mercado da Ribeira is a place not to be missed out while in Lisbon. A place of utmost importance for any foodie. A large food court with various top chef stands and top chef dishes at good prices. You could easily spend the whole day there, having breakfast, lunch or dinner, having a cup of coffee while reading the newspapers, a glass of wine while doing business.. It's a place suitable for everyone and for any time of the day. Oh, and the food is... of course delicious.
Good food good ambience!. It's like a food court but with freshly prepared food - food is good and there's something for everybody!!! Try it and you'll go back again!!!

Really nice food served in a cafeteria like you had in school.. This is what every mall in America wants. A food court with outstanding food. The eating ambience ruins a good portion of the food quality. Prices are quite good for what you actually eat and how it is prepared. 10 euro is high in this place

What an amazing concept!!. They have taken the best restaurants in Lisbon and opened small booths of each one in this huge "arena" area. Such a wonderful atmosphere!! Food and drink were amazing!! We went back on several occasions. Our guest house was directly across the street!! We highly recommend it - so many choices!!
A great concept and great food. Go! Time out market is a food lovers dream with numerous 4 and 5 star restaurants like in one complex. Food reasonably priced And excellent. Highly recommend.

Epicurean Delights. This is a great space where they sell food and drink from stalls for eating in a communal setting. It's really well organised and decently priced with an amazing choice of food, soft drinks, port, wine and beer. You can have anything from a snack with a glass of wine right up to a full and lavish meal.
Too much choice!!. Am amazing place to lunch or eat in the evening with a fantastic array of foods from all over the worls at reasonable prices. A buzzing atmosphere and kept scrupulously clean.
Fantastic selection. Spent an afternoon trying out 5 dishes All delicious. Difficult to choose from so many great options.

Nice food market. Just like you can find in other cities, an upscale food court. Nothing special, but a great place to crash on a rainy day! And a nice place to visit if you haven't been to other similar markets. Not a lot of options below €10,-
Has wifi and toilets.

Go for lunch and enjoy the variety. Perfect market for a quick lunch in small or large groups. Plenty of variety of food from seafood to tapas and wine bars to offer something to drink. A must do in Lisbon if you're into your food.
Mix of chef cuisines. Nice atmosphere with large tables for people to sit after picking up food in one of the shed restaurants. A must to try stake "prego" with foie gras

Great selection. Myself and a couple friends went there after a day of sightseeing and all of us had something different. Loved the different possibilities and options. Highly recommended for people who can't agree on one place where to eat!

Everything to eat. spectacular place to eat, whether for lunch is at dinner, very well located within the Cais do Sodre market, deserves a visit to both sides of the site.First you can visit the market and get to know the fresh produce sold there, some Portuguese typically. Good choice for those who want to cook your food, here you can buy all products.Second you can eat all meals with great quality in the space reserved for it. Here we were not sure hungry.

You must try this!. The Mercado da Ribeira (to give it its non-sponsored name) is a great place to stop for lunch in the middle of your sightseeing day. The big open rectangle has hundreds of tables set out in the centre, with perhaps 20-30 different food choices around the outside, mostly offering traditional Portuguese food from baked cod to steak or spicy chicken. But there are also fusion options with sushi, ceviche, noodles and much more.The atmosphere is very cosmopolitan, the food very reasonably priced and incredibly tasty
too busy, too much noise , average food , not for an eveningdinner.. Too busy, too much noise , average food , not for an eveningdinner.It's more like a walking dinner. It's all a hype,

Great place, but watch out for thieves and assailants, as the security guys won't help.. Hi, We LOVE Lisbon. We have been many times and the Time Out Market is always gets at least 2 or 3 visits while we are in town.HOWEVER, last Saturday, March 12th, 2016, my back pack was stolen (along with wallet, cash, cards, drivers licence, etc.) from under my chair in broad daylight, while sitting outside, enjoying the sunshine at the Time Out Bar in the park. When I reported it to the security guard, he lit a cigarette and told me to go to the Police station to report it. I contacted the police via phone, sent in a report via email and 5 days later, have STILL not been contacted.* ADDITIONALY, the last time we visited in September 2015, my 28 year old niece was intentionally KICKED by a man who asked her for money while she was in the market hall.* AGAIN, the security guards showed no interest.* So just a heads up folks, its a great place, but keep an eye out for trouble.

Great place for a meal. This is a wonderful place for lunch but try to arrive early before the crowds. There are lots of varieties and everything seems to look and smell wonderful. If only my stomach is as big as my appetite! We had the fresh mussels in white wine sauce (superb!) and a wide selection of seafood and meat dishes, too many to mention here but do not miss visiting at least once for the buzzing ambiance, the market next door and the selection of uniquely Portuguese household items and souvenirs sold in the centre shops.

Buzzing Place. We visited this market a few times whilst in Lisbon, as it was a 5 min walk from our hotel. Once for lunch, once for a drink and once for dinner. Big and bustling. Walk around all of the food outlets and see what takes your fancy. You will find something, there's a fantastic variety of food and drink. Find somewhere to sit, then one of you go and get the food and drink. If you're by yourself, get your food and drink, then find a seat. Definitely worth going.

Not sure what food you fancy? Lisbon has the answer. I can't think of a better place for food lovers or a group of people who want to dine together but all have different tastes. Outside facing the square you have a handful of restaurants. We ate at Azul for the seafood. Service was super friendly so you forgive the wait time. Inside is where you get the market effect. 3 walls lined with places to order food from. Discover some great dishes from talented chefs. There is also a shop to buy kitchen or food souvenirs from. This is the place for food lovers.
Favourite place to eat in Lisbon. Fabulous variety of gourmet foods, reasonable prices. Went there twice in 3 days! My favourite was the risotto negro with scallops!
Nice food and nice environment. Located on a old market this new market allows everyone to enjoy the best of food on a nice environment.

Great stop for food and drink. This is a modern and great concept, where you can wander and choose from some excellent cafe and restaurant styled meals. There a bars offering great Gin and Tonics, including the local Gin which is stunning. Slick and organised food service.

Great place to sample variety of different cuisine. Highly recommend a visit to the Time Out food hall near Chaido. Food was excellent and you're just spoilt for choice. I'm sure we'll be back before we leave!

Nice offer in gourmet food and a bit noisy. The market itself is quite interesting and the menu offer is quite diverse and affordable. When is full it is quite difficult to get a place and to keep a conversation. It's worth the visit and a nice place to eat once in a while.
Bon Apetit.. The best place to eat in Lisbon. Typical MUST VISIT. It offers great opportunity to eat tasty dishes served by local Chefs.

Wow, what a great place for food. Walking into this warehouse type building, I was a bit overwhelmed but settled in and walked around to see what the food/drink vendors sere offering. I had a hard time deciding but found a wonderful avocado salad and delicious duck confit. I would come back and spend more time.

Gourmet experience!. We visited Time Out on our first day in Lisbon. The idea was to sample the local cuisine and choose the restaurants we wanted to visit during our trip. The choice is extensive and the food is very good. The prices were reasonable for the quality of the food. We chose a seafood restaurant and enjoyed fresh oysters, clams and prawns. It was wonderful. After lunch, we bought wine from the wine store in the market and learned about the different regions in Portugal. We ended up with several bottles from the Douro region and some excellent port to take home. Overall. we were very impressed with the use of the space and the quality of food available. Saude!

If you like excellent and varied food at a good price - get ready!!. More choices of food than you can ever imagine at very good prices! Wine/beer and soft drinks available all round. A very relaxed and vibrant place that once visited, you will return for to try more food delights.

Yep average food not bad nor good at high price that goes with the design. Design and food promises.Design is there without fault on this renovated industrial court. The food well hum some (1 or 2) proposed see food and fish, and aside the sushi most of all are fast food with not poor but average quality, includes 1 liter of oil & salt per every 4 dish. With paying a little more attention to the details it could change from an overall poor/average to great idea. It missing some Portuguese food stand. I think that it is a perfect wonderland for teenagers.Too bad the idea was great
Foodie paradise. See my review under Mercado de Ribera. Hats off to Time Out for this creative use of space and helping to revitalize an old market. I'd like to take this place home with me!

Best off going to a local restaurant. I didn't think the market was terrible, but it's a genuine tourist trap. Tourists make up the vast majority of the patrons, and I think it's because you can get food that's a better and cheaper from most of the local cafes and restaurants that are on every street corner. I spent two weeks in Lisbon, and that was my experience. The food I had was small in portion compared to what I had been getting from local restaurants, and almost twice the price. It's really busy too, and difficult to get a spot to sit. If you are time poor, it's a good place to go to get a lot of variety.

Hustle & Bustle. This is a great place to eat for a market like experience where you can walk around the numerous restaurants in the hall and choose just about anything to eat from local cuisines, fresh seafood, meats & cheeses of course endless wine.You could eat at this place 10-20 times and have a different meal each time. On my first visit unfortunately it was just too busy and crowded and not what I was after on the day; however, I came back and gave it a try on another day and it was a completely different story with plenty of places to choose to sit and barside seats available at the restaurant fronts. We chose a seafood bar and the seafood was fresh and the service was wonderful with the lady taking the time to offer her suggestions of both menu options and pairing wines. The tiger prawns were huge!!A must visit to experience the new modern style of Portuguese city life and cuisine.
Food Paradise. A paradise for food lovers, Fish or Meat at your discretion.Great offers from well known Chefs at reasanoble prices. Great atmosphere too.
Funky Modern Place to Eat. Loads of variety of good value tasty food. Really great find. Just off the harbour so easy to find. Would recommend to any traveler.

Great food at great prices. A must visit if you're in Lisbon. Some real gems in here and you'll never believe the bill. Had the most delicious confit pork belly with pea puree on bak choi for €9.50. Also some great bars with lovely wines and charcuterie, again very reasonably priced. Located near the water too.

Foodies paradise...... This place is just perfect to stroll around anytime of the day, just make sure you go hungry!! Grab a glass of wine or pull yourself a beer and just take your time and try everything!! All the food stalls were delicious and there is a fantastic choice on offer. A must in Lisbon after walking around the hilly streets!!!
The best restaurants in one big place. Well they gathered the best restaurants in portugal and put them in one big hall. You can taste fine dining food with low price. This is just amazing.
Don't miss this treat. This foodie market will satisfy the most demanding of visitors. Superb choice, great service and value for money.

Amazing buzzing place!. We went for lunch and drinks here and ended up having dinner and drinks too! Food is amazing and so much to choose from. All staff lovely and friendly. It was busy at lunchtime but we did get seats together. Everyone must visit here when in Lisbon!

Many choices of FINE dining!. This place is packed with many local offerings. We had the most amazing octapus dish and chocolate cake that we've EVER had. We stopped by the place two different days and tried different food in different little kiosks. All fantastic, don't miss out!

Amazing place. This more of a restaurant market than a traditonal food market.
In the middle there are plenty of tables and chairs, then around the edges there are LOADS of stalls selling restaurant food. All the stalls looked great but the seafood looked especially good.
I would definitley recommend this to everyone.

great food, great market. It was frustrating to only find this after we'd eaten lunch! great local restaurants all under one roof. Came instead for desert seeing we'd already eaten and wow, just delicious cake selection and great coffee. Would be a great place to escape the rain. It is very busy around lunch time so get there early to reserve a table.

Good location and variety. Visited this market on Sunday in hopes of early lunch, but most of the food stalls open only after 12. However, we managed to find some soup and pastry. After 12 the place was totally crowded and bit noisy. Food was maybe bit pricy, but quite tasty.
Excellent. A great place to have a good night out with food and drink. Plenty of good atmosphere great for a saturday night.
awesome. the market was great. very supprising , thought it was going to be a pick pocket heaven. Instead this great place for food and drinks . all the top places in lisbon. highly recomend
Holy Moly!. Philly's Reading Terminal Market in Lisbon - except this place was more organizedm les crowded, more gourmet, more delicious. I wanted something from every stand...
A lively spot for lunch. This market isn't as big as the central Barcelona markets we've been to before, but we had a good lunch here and some very decent red wine.

A great find. As we wandered back to our hotel from Mercado de Campo de Ourique we came across this venue. We had a wonder round checking out the variety of food stalls & decided to return for dinner. It was great to be able to have high quality food with lots of variety, much better than British food halls. My husband had sushi & I went for Thai both were delicious and finished off with a chocolate torte and a glass of red wine. Great quality, reasonable price with a mix of tourist & locals. Well worth a visit

lovely old market !. this is a lovely old market selling fruit , flowers , fish etc -in a lovely historic building -many bars and eateries to choose from-good if it,s raining and handy for the train station opposite

Wide choice. A great place to have lunch or dinner we visited several times at various times always busy always good quality food being served. my favourite was the Roast suckling pig with sweet potato puree WOW that was from Henrique sa pessoa, I had lovely Scallops from Sea me, Burgers from Honorato are up there with the best we have ever had. Great place to visit has the choice is wonderful you can not fail to want to return, because has you sit down to eat your choice someone will walk pass with something that also looks stunning that you will want to try.

Great spot for relaxed dining. We ate twice here during our visit to Lisbon, each time from the chefs' kiosks which are at the far end of the hall. There are five chef "names" represented here. The food was very good, decent portions and freshly cooked. Wine is also available at good prices. Some reviews indicate that the food is expensive, but we didn't feel so (we generally paid around 30 euros for 2 main courses and a bottle of wine). And we had the most lovely Portuguese almond tart for 3.50 a portion. Yes, it's a food court, but a pretty classy one, and we enjoyed people watching and relaxing here.

Did someone say good food and wine?. Went here whilst on a weekend break in Lisbon , this place was definitely a good experience. An array of food and drinks choices so much so I think I walked around twice before deciding what to have. I ended up going for some tempura green beans and some piri-piri chicken and washed it down with some Sangria. The market is quite busy but is set up really well to deal with the crowds that go here. I would definitely recommend a visit here if in Lisbon

A lively new venue with a great choice of food and drink.. Half of the famous Ribeira Market has been converted into a trendy collection of small eateries and retail outlets selling Portuguese produce. A great place to eat if you are coming back on the train from a day out in Cascais, as the market is just across the road from Cais do Sodré train and metro station.

World food. We rented an apartment just across the market. It's very touristic but still there is enough to enjoy the local food. A bit pricy for Portuguese standards but they should get it out of it since there a many tourists.
All the food you can imagine. All the food you can imagine, great place even just to visit, it is a great atmosphere, very different.

Wide selection.. Excellent selection of food and wine. Priced still reasonable although perhaps a little more of a 'tourist trap'. Quality of food I had was excellent (octopus salad & Grilled squid) free wi fi makes it a perfect place to catch up on e-mails and social media over a nice meal with a glass of wine!

A place for foodies, quite expensive though.. Nice variety of food stalls, I can recommend for lunch! I don't remember the name of the stall I had my lunch from but I had fish dish it was good. The place was a bit growded and busy, but in my opinion it was part of the thing and the athmosphere. The portions are quite expensive compared to normal price range in Lisbon. Wine prices were reasonable.

A lot of choice, bit expensive. Went here a lot as it is a great place to eat if you're alone. It's a foodcourt but with class. I liked the idea of 'cheap dinner' combined with luxury. There is a lot of choice in food and the ambience is nice. I got the feeling that both tourist as young Portugese locals are eating here.

Amazing !. This place is where you have to see and eat. The place is buzzing with an atmosphere and excitement that gets under your skin. The army of food and wine on offer here is quite something. We could have eaten here every day but that would mean missing all the other great places to eat. Definitely highly recommend you eat here.

Foodie Dreams. Such an awesome place. It has all the food you can imagine though the prices do range. I recommend the steakwich - very good. You can spend a good few hours here trying the different foods and drinks. Highly recommended. I'll be back.
Delicious. Lots of variety, lots of seating. Very great option if it's rainy or if you're really hungry. Everything I tried was amazing

Busy but such a great place to try different foods. Perfect place to go when your wife prefers a light vegetarian salad, one kid asks for a burger, the other one fancy a sushi and you wish you could enjoy a plate of Portuguese ham and cheese with a glass of wine.I noticed that the place is not only for tourists but that many locals seem to enjoy it as well. Definitely worth a stop but arrive before 7 pm to make sure you find seats for all.
Great food selection. Food for everyone and at good prices well worth going to for lunch or in the evening, really good feel about the place.

Fabulous Market and Food Court. The fruit and flowers here are an absolute treat, then alongside is every type of food you could want - not fine dining, but fast and cheap, amidst the buzzing vibe created by the surroundings.

Such a great choice to eat.. We ate twice here for lunch, it is a brilliant experience. Apparently the food has to be approved by an independent committee before the stall holder can offer it to the public....seems to work, all we had was very good.

Great for groups. The market was the perfect place for our group, as there was something for everyone. There's traditional Portuguese food, an Asian bar, a sushi place, burgers, seafood, dessert shops, and more. I can vouch for the food at Miguel Laffan, which was a chicken place. I ordered the chicken with traditional Portuguese sauce and chips. The chips are handcut and made in house and the chicken was well seasoned.I also had dessert at Santini, which was some of the best gelato I've had. They use in season fruits to make their gelato. I had the kiwi and forest fruit over a mini cheesecake. D-E-L-I-C-I-O-U-S!*This is a free wifi spot, so my friends and I were able to regroup and figure our where to go next. It's conveniently located across from the train station.

Every town should have it's own!. What a great place! What an amazing choice of foods. Everything is freshly prepared, very modern and creative. Every member of the group/family can choose its own preferred food from one of the numerous food booths and still sit around the same table. However individual portions are affordable, prices feel generally higher than the average in Lisbon. With such a large food and wine offer, the place could become a dangerous time and money trap ;) One can easily loose track of time, enjoy the ambiance, try different cuisines and wines and end up spending more time than anticipated and a lot of money.In the upstair's room, some fabulous events are happening, sometimes concerts. It would be such a unique experience to be able to also hear the same music in the food court!

Very nice variety of food in a posh food market. We tried this for lunch on a Friday just for fun. There is quite a lot to choose from. Lots of fish specialties, pasta, pizza, burgers just to mention a few. Then just add a glass of wine and you are all set. Very tasty food in an international atmosphere. There is also the old type of market to in adjacent buildings where they sell fresh fish, meat and vegetables. All in all very well worth a visit.

Tons of choice, good food.. Great food, though the quality in some other smaller restaurants was better for a cheaper price, especially fish, like calamari. However, a lot of the food is sublime. Good beer as well and great deserts. Hard to choose, so I had to come back 3 times.

Great place to add to your itinerary - if you are interested in Food. The Time Out Market is located along the waterfront about a 10 minute walk west of Praca de Comercio. The produce market, which sells fruits and vegetables was closed as we were there late in the afternoon. What was open is a number of food hall stalls - with many branches of local restaurants serving portuguese foods as well as bakeries, canned fish store and wine stores. It is a good place to go at the beginning of your trip as it provides an overview of the local food and wine all in one spot.
A Nice Find. This very trendy market was a nice discovery located very close to the station. There are lots of places to sit and eat; and many vendors selling both savoury foods and desserts.

Decent time out here. A wider array of food at competitive prices made this a pleasant place to while away a couple of hours. Service was attentive and friendly. The market was comfortable, safe and clearly being enjoyed by friends and families, both local and tourists. Well worth a visit.

Great quality food and drink!. A good value option for eating very good quality food. A good way of sampling different delights in an informal way. We went twice during our city break and ate very different items. Not cheap but then you don't pay cover or service so all in all, good value! Of course, you have to be prepared to wait and collect you food when the buzzer goes which I guess can be a little annoying, especially if you have ordered from several different outlets (part of the fun is trying different things..).

Great place to try different styles of food. We visited the Time out market several times and tried a variety of different food stalls. It seems that every stylish/good restaurant in the city has a dependence on the market. We definitely recommend I try the sardines nigiri at Sea Me an the egg cream croissant at Aloma. We also had amazing beef tartare at the Tartarine. 30 vendors - everybody will find something.

Heaven on Earth!. Where should I even start? Well, firstly the Time Out market is just full of small stands of restaurants and there are just so many options to choose from! Perfect little spot for lunch especially for foodies. I got oysters for a starter from one place, then I had an amazing octopus dish from another and lastly sushi for dessert and everything was priced very reasonably. I would definitely say you get your moneys worth and that its quite cheap especially for what you get. Highly recommended!

Such a huge choice of cuisine in just one location. Very hard to beat this!. This should be the worst kept secret in Lisbon! The ambiance of this covered food hall is second to none. We entered the building by the vegetable market, which in itself is worth a visit. Off to the side of the building is a huge hall which must have about 40 different food vendors situated on the outside edges of it, offering food cuisine from across the globe. In the middle of the hall, is the communal seating area which seats a couple of hundred or more people, I think at a guess! I won't go into what we had to eat, but we used two different vendors and sat in the communal area together and enjoyed an excellent meal, probably one of the best in our Portuguese trip experience. You could quit easily forget the rest of the restaurants in Lisbon and come to this place to eat every day for a month.(Perhaps that's a bit extreme!)Don't leave Lisbon without visiting this venue!

Expensive to eat, nice to see. Its not really a food market that serves local food at friendly prices so be warned. The quality of cooking is pretty good, but it is also priced like it, and most things are halfway to restaurant prices. The pizzas look good, they have slices for 2-3 Euros, and the roast pork was delicious.On the fresh produce/meat side, things are actually cheaper and reasonably priced though! Go before noon as by then the freshest things are all gone and half the shops are closing.
Perfect for foodies. If you love food and drink, this place is perfect for you. We hid from the rain and feasted on croquettes, gyozas, pizza and Aperol Spritzers. Thoroughly recommend!

Something for everyone. In four days in Lisbon we ate here 3 times--for morning coffee, for lunch and for afternoon pastry. It is a vibrant, humming, hip spot, as great for its variety of people as its variety of food!

Omg food. This place is great. Modern, clean trendy and spacious and so much great food and drink. If you like eating you could spend all day in here. Is easy to believe some of the best chefs in Lisbon are here and you can choose from small plates to get a taste of different cuisine or full meals. There is also a little shop to get some souvenirs and a fresh food market next door (although that was shut when we were there)

Great Buzz - Lots of Food Choices - Must Go Place to Eat in Lisbon. This is a terrific food market contained in a converted warehouse - Huge area has terrific choice of small food kitchen restaurants that you order from and then dine in a very large seated table area. Place has a real buzz with great choices. Has some nice bar and coffee places as well. Lots to tempt you from great tapas to fish, meats and asianWould definitely recommend for the atmosphere and style - although if you like peace and quiet it might not be for you

Great sampling of Lisbon's best . Portugal is famous for it's food, so why not try it all in one place. It's clean, very cute and has a great atmosphere. Last night they started dancing in the middle of the market

Great variety and fun atmosphere. We really enjoyed eating at Time Out Mercado while in Lisbon. Having so many choices in one place for food was a great option while in Lisbon for just 3 days. We were able to try 3 different types of food all in one place. It was nice to dine and hang out for as long or a little as we liked. At each vendor you order at a counter, and then find your own seat within the crowd. Everything you might want they have - Portuguese meats and cheeses, fish, hamburgers, wine, and other traditional dishes with a modern twist.There were a lot of locals here eating as well as tourists. We ended up chatting with some other visitors for a few hours while enjoying wine. A great place to eat for lunch or dinner in Lisbon!
It's a good option. You can find a lot of restaurants in a good price a quality. You'll find more modern portuguese food.

more like fast food dining than "top chef" standard. This new food court at Mercado da Ribeira – Lisbon's biggest fresh food market opened in 2014 and I understand has become a firm favourite among the locals as the first permanent foodie venture for Time Out. The market hosts a total of 35 kiosks – all branded in the same black and white signage selling regional specialities, including Azeitão sheep's cheese, plates of ham from the Alentejo, and custard tarts from award-winning cafe Aloma. Tins of sardines in beautiful retro packaging at the Conserveira de Lisboa, wines from Garrafeira Nacional or chocolates from Arcádia make great presents to take home. In addition, five top chefs have restaurants here, offering clever dishes playing with Portuguese flavours from €5 (marinated mackerel with gazpacho at Alexandre Silva). Settle yourself at one of the high wooden benches and it would be very easy to while away a few hours eating your way around Portugal's culinary highlights. The original fish, fruit and vegetable stalls on the other side of the huge 19th century building still sell their wares every day, except Sunday, until lunchtime. Must say though although we found the Super Bock Draft stand a great addition I found the food to be very over priced and quite sub standard to many of the Restaraunts we had dined in other parts of the City So to sum up great for choice but lacking on quality and quantity more like fast food dining than "top chef" standard.

Keeping the pace with Europe's best food markets. Mercado da Ribeira is one of the oldest food markets in Lisbon. A couple of years ago it was refurbished and turned into a hotspot for the best eateries in Lisbon, the new chefs and the coolest food business ideas. It's a great place to sample the best that Lisbon has to offer (food wise). You can dinne there or simply have some snacks and drinks. Or just buy some nice souvenirs to take home.

Pricy but still worth the trip. Everything is pretty expensive (for Lisbon) but the idea is really great and every vendor I visited spoke fluent English with no problems. A little bar kiosk is the only place I found in Portugal that has Ginger beer also.

Cool place for good lovers. Great variety of Portuguese food and drink. Come here hungry. It's not the cheapest place in Portugal but still you can get well fed and experience local food and hospitality. Free wifi to use as well.

Great Chef's food at cheap prices!. Very very trendy place. Very lively with events going on there. Chefs' GORGEOUS food at cheap prices. There's no food anywhere like in Lisbon and like in here! It's the place to eat.

Great choice of food. We went for lunch. There is a huge range of options - wander around and choose which food appeals from the many restaurant stands. Watch it being prepared and study the menus. Order and find a seat at central tables. A buzzer will alert you when your meal is ready. We arrived at 12.25 (early for lunch by local standards) and it was 80 per cent empty. We left an hour later and it was 80 per cent full, but that still meant there were plenty of seats. Well worth a visit.

Foodies Heaven. A massive food court with a huge variety of different restaurants. Choose what you want, order, find a seat and enjoy the different types of cuisine. There is also a fresh produce market and a wine shop.

Delicious food & nice atmosphere. We got a bite to eat in Time Out Market. It was the best option for lunch in the city. You can choose from asian food to burgers. We also bought good Port wine in one of the shops.

Buoyant Busy Beehive. These large eating halls are popping up all over Europe I think. They ar fun. She gets a sale from The Salad King and he gets a fish on a bun from from Freaky Fish. These are fake names, but in line with what you might find there. Its nice, you get your food, look for a place to sit and enjoy the food and view of people, lots and lots of people. All friendly and in the same somewhat awkward situation as you; Sharing a table with strangers. I Highly recommend going.

Do NOT miss this wonderful converted fish market which has mounds of gourmet delights. This is one of those places that you want to sit and keep eating. All the food was delicious. There was a wait because some stalls had working Lisboans grabbing their business lunch. But when it came, the ox burger or the pork cheeks or the salmon tartar was delectable and beautifully set out. It's not super cheap but it is not expensive - and it is where you will rung shoulders with locals who know their famous chefs and want to treat themselves to a delicious lunch on the run, and indulge their inner gourmand...

Love it. As We live in Lisbon, we have been there at least 10 times and the food and above all the choice is amazing...one of the best is Honorato with wonderful hamburgers ( from 6,5 euros to 9,95euros).Do not miss Santini where you can have a slice of the best chocolate in the world (3,10 euros) or a home made ice cream (2,90 euros with 2 flavours)!

Great Eating Experience . You will be spoilt for choice in this self service market diner. This is set within a market and at the centre is a seating area surrounded by all the best local restaurants. You can choose from any- will suit all tastes from Portuguese, American, Sushi, vegetarian etc etc. Delicious food in an informal dining atmosphere.

A menagerie of tastes and flavors. Walk in and be tempted by the aroma of foods .Lots of choices for even the pickiest of eaters and always a bustling place. We loved stopping in after long walks or trips and prices are reasonable. FOOD? ?.yummmmmm. A great use of the traditional market for fresh fruits, veggies , etc with the addition of a place to showcase the gastronomy of Lisbon!

Great selection of food. Cozy, lively food court to eat in the center of Lisbon.Place to be for foodies!Multiple food stands offer great selection of traditional and less traditional Portuguese food. Very affordable.
A gastronomic delight. A must see place if you are visiting Lisbon, so many different food stalls, wonderful to browse and enjoy a quick or a lingering lunch!

Good vibes, but not good selections of food. We went to Mercado de San Miguel in Madrid, so we thought this would be similar in selection and quality. It is not even close. The food selection is poor, overpriced and the atmosphere is not as lively. You can walk in a check it out, but should probably eat somewhere else.

Lovely evening out. There was a great atmosphere here with all ages wandering about checking out what each stall offered. We had good food from six different places. Quick service and all very clean. A system where you are alerted that your order is ready. Great fun! Good wines and beers too. We will return.

Absolutely recommend Tartaria. I love Mercado da Ribeira, lots of great options and really nice relaxed vibe. My absolute favourite though and the reason i keep returning is Tartaria serving excellent Tartar steaks, both meat, salmon and tuna. I have tried and highly recommend all.

Brilliant place for lunch and people watching. The Mercado da Ribeira has a superb choice of places to buy drinks, snacks and meals, and it's very easy to get to by public transport, metro and eléctrico (tram) for example. Our lunch was delicious.
Delicious! . Delicious food with so many options to choose from. Pata negra ham was amazing, if a little pricey. Francesinha was excellent.
Some much to choose from. Went here twice in 3 days for lunch. Tried small plates from 4 different market stalls. The food was amazing, great quality and reasonable price.
Lots of choice. Visited a couple of times. Plenty of choice for all. Tried lots of different Portuguese specialities. Place was very busy at lunchtime.
Very nice food. Excellent choice... Dozens of restaurants to taste every kind of dishes with high quality. Strongly recommended...Try fish which was very fresh...

Informal eating with family. I met with some Portuguese family members for an informal get together. We brought our own wine and only bought food. The variety a quality of food was excellent and the system for ordering a collection is very efficient. All menus are in English and Portuguese and staff were helpful.

Words can cheat.... ...because 'mercado' means 'market' and this a very unusual market. Silent, clean and cheap eats.
Look at the 'azulejos'..extremely beautiful...The first floor was closed, they were renovating

Great place to eat and drink . On the 15 tram going back from Belem, we felt a bit peckish. Decided to get off opposite Time Out Market and have a little graze. Lots of choice of food here. The kids had pizza. We had tapas and grilled fish.

Welcome to cool Lisbon!. If you visit Lisbon without visiting the Mercado da Ribeira, you´re definitely not part of the trend. A vibrant ambience where you could experience the best of the Portuguese cuisine.
Amazing!!. This place is AMAZING!!!! The food and atmosphere is just awesome!! This really is a foodie's delight!
Fantastic collection of eateries. Very busy, especially on Saturday night. Good variety of food and drink at reasonable prices. What's not to like?
Fanrtastic place to eat.. The market place is a perfect place to have breakfast, lunch or dinner. You can choose from many little kitchens. The atmosphere is great
Traditional Portuguese steak with a fried egg on top. Good food, nice ambience, good company and conversation. Enjoyed the wine as well. Close to the River Tagus. Well worth the visit.

Excellent place for enjoying Portuguese food. We stayed very close to the Time Out Mercado da Ribeira and therefore have dining here several times. There are good options of local food and the taste were good. Lot of space that you don't need to care about the seat problem.
Nice market . A nice hall with a loads of opportunities to eat seafood or burgers with fries. Hard to catch a seat at lunchtime or at weekends.

Great find. We had read about this in a travel magazine and went to find it. What a great place. Huge number of different food outlets selling massive variety of food and drink. Something for everyone and really worth a visit for good, fresh and reasonably priced food.

Delicious. This is not to be missed in Lisbon, the food is fantastic (there is a large variety), very reasonably priced, and they also offer a large variety of drinks! Grab a table, order a drink and some food, and enjoy...

Great food with many choices under one roof. Called for lunch and was able to sample a selection of small dishes with nice wine at a bargain price.
good set up with buzzer given to let you get seated and be informed when your food is ready
Extensive selection of different cuisines. Buzzing place. From seafood and traditional Portuguese through to Asian and hamburgers. There is something for everyone's tastes here. Well worth a visit.
Great experience for foodies. Wasn't too busy when I went and enjoyed a meal from one of the vendors. Lots of selection and a ton of Portuguese options!

Mediocre fast food. The concept of the place is nice and the building is well-conceived BUT we were not at all satisfied with the quality, savor faire, of the expensive fast food. We also experienced some unfriendly service. It's a pity.

Fashion place, realy expensive for non traditional nor fantastic food. It's just one of those places that is of the fashion now. It's more like the restaurants at a Shopping than something really original. They try to look as they are some new wave stylish super gourmet food, but somehow creates an atmosphere that is too noisy, to crowded,and the food is not the best for sure.

Enjoy Portuges cooking!. Enjoy Portuges cooking! Old market with big food-cort in the middle. A lot of small national & international cookings around with wooden tables inside. Free Wi-fi. Evertying fresh & very tasty with reasonable prices. Very genuine place!

Amazing place, totally worth a visit. Amazing place with so many different types of food. Slightly limited opening hours, with some stalls selling out early, but worth visiting whilst you're in Lisbon.

Michelin starred food at market prices. Absolutely amazing 'food market' in the center of the city. All the food we tried was absolutely delicious. Particular highlight was the tasting menu from Marlene Vieira. We could have stayed all day and sampled an offering from each chef. They also had a great selection of wines and beers.

Market full of life.. It was the market that supplied Lisboa. Nowadays, besides the fruits, vegetables and fish, you have small restaurants by trendy chefs at a reasonable price. You can buy your food and then eat at the available tables in the middle.

Great place for a foodie. Visited this place on Saturday afternoon and it was buzzing. It is a former market that now has a series of small restaurants around the interior with the central area reserved in the main for seating to eat whatever takes your fancy. The central area also includes a champagne bar, a Gin bar and others. I would highly recommend this place to anyone visiting Lisbon.

Interesting, good food and drink- visit later in the evening.. We came here as a group of friends with different eating habits (ok, I am the awkward vegetarian!) Everyone had a great time, there is all kinds of food and drink available here in a nice convivial atmosphere. Reasonable prices- choose your food and beverages, bring them to the communal tables and enjoy the atmosphere! Livened up considerably as the evening wore on...worth a visit!

A must. My husband and I stumbled upon this on our way home from Belem. So many food options. We had dessert one afternoon and went back for dinner and wine another night. They have everything from ice cream and cake to hamburgers, pizza and seafood. A lot of fun even though it is always super full. Really easy to get to with metro, bus and even by foot.
Nice and unexpected. Busy and diversified foodcourt, you might struggle to find your spot but it deserves some patience. The food options are wide and everything is delicious and affordable

Fantastic !. This is a collection of small local restaurants in an old market. It's really fabulous as there's a huge selection of things to eat and drink ( great for groups where you can't agree on what to eat) in a picturesque setting. There's also a cookery school, and a real fish mosh and flower market during the day. The place seems popular with locals as well as tourists from the amount of Portuguese I heard spoken. Good value too

Huge selection!. Tremendous marketplace where you can buy food, clothing, wine, soaps, oils and much more. Many of the foods are things that can be eaten there at tables throughout the large market. All things seem to be more tapas style, there was also a beer station for a glass of beer and many choices for glasses of wine or places to buy bottles of wine. Nice place to try things.

Excellent choices. An excellent choice for a meal as there are many different foods on offer catering to all tastes. We chose to dine around 6 30 pm to beat the evening crowd. The prices were good and it saved a lot of walking trying to find just the right restaurant. Here we had the choice of fresh food of many types all under the one roof. The taxi from Rossi Square was under 4 euros so it is easily accessible for travelers.

Charming and fine Food!. Nice location, very well set and serving huge variety and sophistication of Food and local Portuguese specialties. From fresh raw fish to cold cuts and Beef of highest quality and taste. Very recommended!

More foodcourt than market. We went here having been to many other markets in Spain and France where there usually is a market with a few surrounding food stalls. This market, however, is almost exclusively food stalls some related to Lisbon restaurants serving similar food at considerably higher than market prices. No actual market sellers so far as I could see.I had a salmon burger from one stall that was good but our deep fried tempura from another stall was a touch on the greasy side. Wine from the wine stall was lacklustre and the guy selling it couldn't have been less interested in us. A far cry from the excellent but unrelated mercado in Madrid.

Worth a repeat visit if you are greedy. Timeout everywhere else in the world - take note! This is a great example of keeping old school local markets and yet still making it appealing for local yuppies and tourists alike. Traditional market opens bring and early in this lovely old building. But come 10am til late, this covered market comes alive with some awesome food options. While not the cheapest, the weekend crowd should be some indication it's not terribly overpriced by local standards. Similar concept to Food Republic in Singapore which tries to house some of the most popular local restaurants under one roof, it's a fantastic one stop place to sample some food from Portuguese chefs (unfortunately Jose Avillez is not represented) and other popular brands like Cafe Sao Bento, Sea Me, Honorato burgers, O Prego Da Peixaria - you only need to google some blogs on food recommendations to find these names repeatedly come up. Mercado da Ribeira saves you the time hunting down these individual outlets by allowing the opportunity to sample them all at the same place. You'll be back for more...

Awesome place. An awesome place with so many food options to choose from. Literally food from all around the world but also typical portuguese dishes. Seats in the middle and each one can choose his liking and then eat with friends or family. Also good options for drinking.

A Must-Try for Food Lovers. WOW. The food was out of this world. Every stand seemed to have its own specialty so wait and see what everyone is ordering to get the best dish. Incredible, incredible food at decent prices. I plan to go back every time I'm in Lisbon in the future.

Great Food. After traveling Metro reached Time Out Mercado Ribeira. Had lunch and drinks. Food was amazing and Sangria was one of the best that I've had. Their is so much food to choose from and the quality of the food is a ***** Star.
Foodie heaven. We are dyed in the wool foodies - and this was heaven. So many options from so many reknowned chefs, great atmosphere...came back three times in two days.

Amazing food / restaurant market. Time Out refitted and restored a section of this flower and vegetable market which now offers a large selection of food and drink from some of the best restaurants in Lisbon. There are also a few shops including a wine shop, sardine shop and gift shop. It seemed to also be lively at night. If you like food, go here! I loved it.

Unique - so much choice, so much to look at. Very interesting place and easy to get to from central Lisbon - a large hall with high ceilings, modern wooden tables with high or low stools, surrounded on all sides by counters serving different dishes by a variety of chefs. Prawns, suckling pig, pizza, chicken, all cooked to order - you are given a little disc to take to your table, which pings and flashes when your food is ready for you to collect - a fun and practical idea.A huge advantage to eating here rather than at a sit-down restaurant is that each member of your party can choose something from a different stand and then sit and eat together. This is a brilliant place to eat for a family or group of friends all with different tastes.It's quite informal - choose your own seat - and relaxed. No-one rushing you to move on. Unmissable just for the chance to sit and watch what's going on, and to wander around the food kitchens/counters, window-shopping with your eyes and tummies.My daughter had grilled fresh sardine fillets on crusty bread with tiny diced fresh vegetables atop. She loved it. I had warm, deliciously moist and tender suckling pig in a fresh bread roll. Each dish was about 5-6 euros - you could pay up to 10 euros for more luxurious/larger plates of food.We are definitely making this a regular stop when we return to Lisbon later this month!There was also a craft and gift shop within the hall - I did a good deal of Christmas shopping here as the items were unusual and beautiful - flavoured salts, notebooks, chocolate, kitchenware - a well-chosen range and definitely not overpriced - some of the same items were sold in the Alfama shops at a higher price.

Yes yes yes a must visit . So while trying to find a good place for lunch we stumbled upon the mercado da ribeira and I think you should add it to your itinerary. At the market you get to explore a large variety of restaurants and cuisines in a single very enjoyable spot. Come here for lunch, and venture yourself try many dishes!
Well.... I belive it`s nice if you're a hipster. Regular food, relatively high prices.I personally recommend the collectors fair held in the same place, every sunday.

An experience. This should be a must for anybody who is new to Lisbon and don't know where or what to eat! The godown converted into a big food hall with many well known eateries under one roof. You can pick from fresh oysters to Portuguese hamon, to steak sandwiches or roasted chicken. The place has high ceiling and is neat and clean. You would be spoilt for choices! After filled your stomach, you can buy local produce like the canned sardines, tuna, cod fish to olive oil. Tip: several of the eateries open for business at 12pm. On Sundays, the other section of the market selling fresh produce is closed.
