Great spot!. The refurbished old maket is definitively a must go, as you can enjoy a "local" experience and enjoy a now trendy spot with friends.All sorts of food and drinks. Cool environment and great prices.A place to have fun.

Good choice of food in relaxed atmosphere. A great self service food outlet close to the river.Food served every-day & the local market is open 3 days a week.Good choice of food & drink at reasonable prices. Beer @ c. €3, wine from €3 a glass & food from €5 for a main course. Fantastic desserts from c. €3.I had a plate of cheese & meat for €10 Seating is what's available on clean wooden bench style tables with high stools.Well worth the trip & nearest tube is Cais do Sodre.

A market with a difference. Not a typical market - Although there are market stalls and plenty of the usual market product this market is also a showcase for many restaurants. It was taken over by 'Time Out" some years ago and some of Lisbon's best restaurants have an outlet here where they serve a limited menu from their restaurant at a fraction of the price. The main area is decked out with high stool seating and formidable wooden tables to enjoy the culinary delights of the vendors and there are a number of bars on site as well. Unlike other markets which start early, Mercaso da Ribeira doesn't open till 10am and it stays going till midnight I think (never stayed late enough). The first day I arrived in Lisbon was a Sunday and the streets were relatively quite. I knew of the Mercado so I set out to find it - all quite outside but when you enter its a different world - alive with sellers and buyers, many of whom were here to dine on the delicious offerings. Its busy all day long and well deserves the custom it gets. Its located just opposite the metro and Ferry terminal.

Great food and cocktails. The rum, basil, ginger cocktails were amazing, as were the garlic prawns with dipping bread. The pizza was average. The food selections were good and it's open until midnight. Prosecutors at the pizza place was on drought and not very nice but generally had a great time here and it's a good thing to do as a couple of group of friends. Imagine it's extremely busy on a weekend.

Something different. Huge market hall with food kiosks. Some of best resturants offer option to taste their super food cheap with a kiosk concept. Order food and take it to tabels in a market hall and enjoy companies. Concept by Time Out. Very special atmosphere.

Great fun. These old food halls,with their vast space and high ceiling,offer a great variety of food,including two Michelin starred places,as well as Portuguese traditional cooking,seafood,burgers,everything.We went for lunch,in the evening,it may be even better and a lively crowd.
Every city should have one. Amazing choice, amazing quality, great prices, a great idea - to sum it all up: Every city should have one or more locations like this.

Something different. Huge market hall converted in an open space for food lovers with different little restaurants around, different cuisines, where you can buy your food and drinks nd take them to any of the tables in the central open space. So this concept allows you to buy different dishes from different places.
Very busy, but big choice of food. Great place for lunch, hard to find a table but a huge choice of food and a wonderful place to people watch!

Take a time out from your life. How to describe it... Imagine a big and fresh hall, previously used to sell fish, vegetables, fruit, ... turned into a foodie hangout, surrounded by some of the best and biggest names in food and drink throughout Lisbon.If you appreciate really good food and want to find the best ones in one single place, then pick this place! They will be next to each other, literally!Tips: take a careful look around first and plan your menu. Parking: There is an underground (payed) park next to this market, so you will find a parking slot for sure.State of mind: Relax, Eat awesome food, time out your lifeI'll give you my options for a wonderful sensorial evening (without pointing any specific names):Look for the croquettes in a cornered shop. These are awesome to start your evening. Get a couple of croquettes (they are very big) and a glass of red wine.Then jump off to your main course. Next to this croquette store there are several stores with more than enough choices to pick from. e.g. go for a fish dish and take a glass of rose wine. Finished here, take a look around and find a dessert store that sells sweet slices of wonderful joy. Pick one slice and also pick a glass of white wine.

best food in Lisboa, by far. This place is a killer ! dozens of small stands where you can buy various type of food for reasonable prices. Some stands have cooks chiefs. I tried sushis, pastas, oysters, iberian ham, portuguese steak,... and all were super good ! For me the best place to eat for lunch in Lisboa.

a little bit too expensive. One cannot say it's bad or tasteless. The idea is right: many kiosks too choose from and different kinds of food and specialties. But all in all it's too expensive. A dish costs 10 Euro or more and you really have plenty of places in Lisbon where you can have a good meal for less. But if you want to try different tastes and new ideas, this is a place for you.

Pleasant experience. A perfect place to taste many different delicate dishes with friends that have different taste. 35 different small places were you can buy all kinds of good food and vines. Find a table, take a long time to pick up different small dishes. We tried oysters, dumplings, piri piri chicken, goat cheese and many more. To recommend for big groups, because the place is huge and noone needs to wait while others order their food. It is als possible to buy delicate food to take home.

Great conversion but no market spirit any longer . Great for a group of friends of whatever generation to share different cuisines, go for different dishes according to individual preferences, taste wines...very friendly and informal atmosphere which allow nice social gathering. Don't look for a "street market" spirit specially in the evening, it's rather a middle-upper class fusion food court, freshly prepared. Open till late.
Grab A Snack. Nice place where a number of different foodshops are located. If you are hungry and don't know what to eat. Just go there and be amazed :-D
Super trendy. Crazily trendy place. As though Lisbon looked at all the old-school markets around Europe, chuckled, and made one for the zeitgeist. Great spot.

Absolute Must Do!. On our recent trip to Lisbon, we decided to give the Time Out market a try - and ended up loving it so much that we went back several times.First, it's a great way to kill a few birds with one stone. Not only is there food, but you can pick up your bottles of Port there, but canned fish from the Conservaria and buy local goods at la vida portugesa.The food however is quite outstanding - really great gourmet fare all based on the Lisbon theme - this is no mall food court. We ate steak tartare, drank sangria, and watched the locals commune drink and eat.The atmosphere is set up so that you can take a place at a huge communal table and then grab different bites from all of the various vendors. When you order from a vendor, they give you a pager so that you're free to roam or return to your table while your food is prepared - you won't find any chafing dishes here - everything was extremely fresh and prepared to order. It's a great place to go if you have a diverse group that wants to try different things.Highly recommended!

I LOVE Time Out Market!. I go to Mercado da Riberia every now and then cause it always provides something different for you. it is so diverse and has something offered for everyone, from vegeterians, fish, meat to dessert and also some other little shops like a pretty alternative souvenir shop, a gardening and plants shop, etc. Prices vary and there is something for every budget. YUMMY

Two Delicious Dinners!. We enjoyed two delicious dinners here while we were in Lisbon. We loved it because we got to try a number of dishes from a variety of great restaurants in a relaxed environment. We enjoyed a tuna dish, piri piri chicken, garlic shrimp, croquettes, and some delicious sangria. The second night we went, we met friends was a baby - this was an easy places to bring a baby because it's a bit loud and casual - but has great food. Highly recommend!

Great transformation from market to eating. Fantastic number of individual cafes catering for all pallets. Great arrangement of seating within the central area with all the food outlets around the perimeter. Have visited 3 times and have always enjoyed the food and liquid refreshment. Great atmosphere, especially at night.

Great Concept . What a great find this was. Attached to a traditional market this eating place is s great concept. It is made up of lots and I mean lots of different food vendors from chocolate to coffee and beer to sushi there really is something for everyone. Seating is all in the centre and leads to a great communal feel. If you are passing at lunch time or even for dinner definitely give this place a try.
If you enjoy eating then DON'T MISS THIS. Something (high quality) for everyone. Wonderful place to eat, drink, people watch, socialise.......and generally "hang". Visit once and you'll be back!!!

THE Food Hall Experience!. Loved by locals and by tourists, Timeout Mercado da Ribeira is by far the BEST food hall I have ever been to! The variety of food on sale goes from local to Asian and the value for money is good. The tables in the main hall can accommodate a very large number of people, so that one can find a place to sit even at rush hour. I went there once for dinner and once for lunch and, both times, I walked out of there very satisfied. Also, if you are a fan of the Portuguese soap opera "Laços de sangue", you will be able to enjoy the place even more as many scenes were filmed in this very place! Have fun!

A Chef Carousel. Time Out has taken the idea of street fairs and food markets like Boqueria in Barcelona and figured out a way to showcase Lisbon's star chefs in a fair and deserving way. Unlike Shmorgasbord in Williamsburg, which is outrageously expensive for the bite size portions with mediocre cooking, Time Out got it just right at Mercado da Ribeira. The crisp black and white signage is hip and alluring to a young hipster-esque crowd yet inside you will find is packed (not uncomfortably) with people of all ages. The seating is communal style and first come first serve with the exception of some restaurant kiosks having counter seating. The market is sprinkled with wine bars and cocktail stations as well as non-local cuisine vendors. The choices are endless and the prices are phenomenally cheap. You could eat piles of food and have a bottle of wine for around $30-$50. It is open during flexible hours and is a sought after venue. Now, if only Time Out would do something similar in NYC....

Foodie heaven!. A fantastic project, a local food hall with so much choice from around the world as well as local food. Nice and clean, well organised, good atmosphere and well priced considering the quality of food. Great for a lunch stop to rest your feet!
Awesome Food Stall Market, High Quality Food. High quality foods provided by top restaurants. May be hard to get seating sometimes but the meals are inexpensive and worth it.

After 3 or four fantastic visits the first not so good experience.... Had dinner with my wife and an American friend at Monte Mar on the 12th January. My choice of "Prato do dia", Açorda de Gambas was not up to the name, and very far from my expectations for a €11 course. The octopus rice my friend ordered, was whatery small portion, and not worth the €14 Monte Mar charged for it. Time Out who imagined the place and authorizes the restaurants must be warned to use the "greed" detector to ensure that the place and concept does not suffer from one "bad apple"
Absolutly fantastic. I would love to go back there a lot to try all the different stands Unfortunatly we just came back twice and the experience was fantastic
Best place for food in Lisboa. Great experience with a wide variety of kiosks Fromm foods to gifts to handmade items. Don't miss this treasure.

Fantastic place - great idea! . This market is very close to the Cais do Sodre station so you can maybe enjoy it on the way to or from Belem. Apart from being a beautifully restored market building, it also houses a selection of stalls representing some of Lisbon's best restaurants and food providers, selected by Time Out critics. You buy food at the stalls and then eat at central tables and benches. It's very popular as the food is good. Finding a seat at peak times can be difficult but not impossible if you're patient and watchful. We had a great lunch there, ordered from the Cozinha da Felicidade and Pizza a Pezzi stalls. Definitely not street food prices, but the quality was excellent and the experience was fun

Fun, Busy and Tasty! . We visited just after Christmas and had a great time shopping, snacking and sampling our way thru the market...it's clean, has decent restrooms and interesting things (and people) to see!
Groceries.. Fruits, seafood, some wine and very imposing food court in the middle. Basically place for a food lovers.
Nice concept. Here you have the possibility to sample food from various Lisbon restaurants etc. It is very crowded so best to come outside the normal eating hours.

Restaurant market hall. The best place for tourist to spend at least one evening with good food and wine.The place is full of different restaurants and few food-/spice-/wine-shops. You can order food around the place from edged and people eating in the center of place. Doesn´t matter how much there is people, because you always find the place and cleaning service working all time.Price-level is not the cheapest, but not expensive.

Fantastic spot for lunch/snack or just a drink. We liked this so much on our visit to Lisbon that we visited it 3 times! It is a few steps from a metro stop so you can keep coming back. This place is like a really posh food court. Lovely places serving all types of food (with many Portuguese specialties) surround a seating area, with booth selling various types of drink on the inside. It was always busy, but possible to get a seat as people come and go. We had an assortment of foods from pigs cheeks, to Thai curry, to cheese and a pizza slice, washed down with great reasonably priced wine and beer. Also the espresso was the best I had in Lisbon.

Delicious, fun, try to get a seat!. Positives: DELICIOUS food choices, variety, wonderful drink choices, variety, a tour of Lisbon's best food and drink, passion for flavor, and variety of choices. GO HERE.Negatives: tough to find a seat and lunch, but I didn't mind standing. Fun, local atmosphere. Some review it as expensive, but they're bringing you all the best the city has to offer, so I still have to give it 5 stars. GO HERE.
for a dinner.... Go there for a dinner: it is just a little expensive...but you can order dish from different stand, the same for drink....and taste different dish!

Interesting although I found food expensive. The mRket was very good and I would highly recommend. Though I found the food hall a lot more expensive than I would have though. I was disappointed at the prices

Nice popular portuguese market with several food choices. It seems to be a very trendy place now in Lisbon. It looks renovated and new. They have several small places to buy your food and then there is a big area with tables so you can seat and eat. Some of the places are run by chefs, so it is very interesting. All the food seems to be top quality and very fresh. I definitely recommend it.
Cool. It's a cool place when spends some time and eat very good food and dkrink wine or beer!!! Not to be missed for turist!!!!

Best food in town. You can find here all the good food from the best chefs in town. It is a bit expensive, but it is never a disappointment! You can find pork, hamburgers, ice cream, salads, sushi and all kinds of drinks...
Abundant food court. This upscale food court has it all! The look and feel are very modern yet warm and inviting. The food vendors are all top quality. Definitely worth a visit!

Great palce to eat and hang out. Went here my last day in Lisbon. I got here in time for lunch on a rather rainy day. After walking through the actual market I looked to get some food. The first place I tried was the Croqueteria. I tried a couple of their croquets. Very good. I followed this with some slices of pizza at Pizza a Pezzi. Delicious. After words I had some good drinks of the adult variety that were on offer while I just relaxed for awhile. Later on that day I came back for dinner, since I was still in the area. This time around I Gyoza and Pad Thai from Asian Lab, as well as some more beer. Delicious.I would highly recommend anyone in the area check out this market. It is a great place to go for lunch or dinner, or even just to hang out.

Great food and drinks at moderate prices!. We loved this place. Didn't even know it was there and have been to Lisbon several times before. Oops? This is a great way to eat moderately priced items designed by Chefs with Michelin Stars. An incredible selection of wines, some craft beers, and everything from €1 tapas to €150 seafood dishes, with tons of things in between. Something for everybody, as well as handicrafts, gift items, some art, and free wifi. 100% recommended.

A great & original place with lots of tasty food!. We visited this place with friends and kids. The choice of food and the quality of food made it a great experience. The place is very popular... probably not the good place for a quiet dinner but definitely a great night out with friends and family ..... A lovely place to take your kids!

Great concept, poor delivery.. Our apartment was 50 metres from the market so we were keen to enjoy its reviewed good food. The first impression is very good with a great building and a large choice of food options. At any popular time the experience wanes with lots of people looking to find a space to sit. For two it is less of a problem than for four, but it's still not easy. People lurk behind anyone who looks like they might be finishing their meal.Having found a space the next challenge is selecting what to eat. The variety might seem a good thing but queuing at several outlets takes time, and the delivery time for food is unreliable. Putting together the combination you are looking for is long winded.For some reason the service is surly and slow, and the food when it arrives is not impressive. I went with real real goodwill and ended up feeling irritated. I enjoyed several tapas bars much more and didn't have to assemble a selection of food and wine over a long period of time.. Worth looking at but not a good dining experience even at lunchtime.If you hit the place at a quiet time and choose your options carefully you could have a pleasant snack in a lively atmosphere and very attractive space. We found a lot of very good tapas and wine bars in Lisbon which were a lot more enjoyable, and for a full meal much better restaurants.

Transformed Marketplace- Amazing. Visited the old market several times but last year visited the new Mercado for food and drinks. It has an amazing atmosphere, so friendly and welcoming with great choice of fresh local foods, freshly prepared and at reasonable prices.Can't wait to visit again in 2016.
great for lunch. terrific food and wine choices, inspiring atmosphere and reasonable prices. Great place for a quick lunch.

Plenty of eateries. Choice of eateries and price should suit most people I think. Restaurants have clear awnings that you can sit under at night & when the weather is poor, with heaters - so dining out on a coolish evening in mid October was fine.
Easy to access, but we prefer the smaller "Campo de Ourique". Easy to access and very popular among tourists, but we preferred the smaller "Campo de Ourique" market
Awesome place to get food.. One of the best markets i've ever been to! So many great options to choose from! Enjoy some great Portuguese food!

Time Out Mercado da Ribeira. So many delicious options and shockingly inexpensive. I wanted to try everything, unfortunately, I was only physically able to have about three meals during my one visit, plus dessert. It is crowded and you have to share your table space with strangers, but the stalls did not have long lines or waits. Also, the hall has well-maintained, free bathrooms. Highly recommended!

A place to visit and eat. A place that joins a lot of excellent portuguese restaurants. You can go with friends and each one chooses the restaurant they want and what to eat and then just sit together tasting the food and drinks.
How to revolutionise an old market!. Lots of independent food stalls. Great fun and a big variety of wines, food and gifts. 2 mins walk from Cais De Sodre station.

Lot of good choices to eat but crowded. You can have a mix of food choices from a single place. Almost every known restaurant of the moment in Lisbon have a booth at Mercado da Ribeira.The only caveat is the crowd. It is difficult to grab a table and the noise makes it almost impossible to have a conversation.

This place is a must while visting Lisbon. My friends and I stumbled upon this place right around dinner time. It was such a cool find for us! It's a big market with a TON of choices... maybe too many. We had a great time ordering from the various vendors and sharing all of our finds at the communal tables. My favorite was the cake (bolo) place. We ordered 3 different kinds of cake and we were all blown away by every single one. I wish we had made it back to this market before we headed out of Lisbon but we didn't. Someday I hope to make it back... until then I will dream about the charcuterie plate, sardine toasts and the life altering strawberry nutella pie. Make sure to bring your appetite and get a little adventurous!
Market with lots of Portuguese food. A nice place for lunch. Mostly Portuguese. A bit on an expensive side for Lisbon. Food good, staff nice, can find big selection of port wines. Do visit if around.

Rainy Day visit. Like markets? Come here. Like good food? Come here. Like a good atmosphere? Come here. This is an awesome fresh vegetable and fish market with so much on offer. Split into two there is the market side and then there is the bar and restaurant/cafe side. Reasonably priced eats and drinks. Reminded us of the market in Barcelona or Borough Market in London
Excellent lunch place. went here twice on a three day stay. Nice variety and perfect when you want to eat something other than your company. Perfect place for lunch
Spoiled for choice. Great food in a lovely building. Everyone can find something for yourself there. Communal dining, so might get busy.
tartare de salmon. super place to visit - a must - it is full of with the best of what Lisbon can offer you , very friendly staff serves you

Something for Everyone!. Can't decide where to eat because everyone wants something different? This is the place for you. Over 30 food vendors, flower market, food market, wine and beer. Prices a little above average but food was excellent. We visited 3 times and each vendor we interacted with were friendly and helpful. Bring small denominations of euro! Crowded and can be difficult to find a seat at times.

"Well worth a visit, especially if your hungry !". We wandered around this amazing market on New Years Day and had great fun. Its good to be hungry (and adventurous !) Great place for a tourist to sample different Portuguese food and wine. There is so much choice its hard to make a decision on what you will eat ! It was very busy when we were there, so getting a seat and the shared table was a little difficult. A local advised to try and avoid the normal lunch or dinner time (12.30 -14.30; 20.30 -22.30), we understand the market is open until 2.00am from Thursday to Saturday and until 0.00 the rest of the week. We tried a hamburger, pizza and Ice-cream, along with a glass or two of wine ! Its not exactly cheap, but overall from what we saw, food and service is very good and its great to have so much choice and atmosphere in one place. We will definitely rerun before our trip is over to sample some more.

Such a great concept. I came here the evening I arrived in Lisbon and this place offered so many different options- there must be at least 30 different stalls open for dinner. It meant that he whole family could go off and choose what they wanted. The prices were also very affordable, I paid €7 for a large chickpea salad which was very nice and filling. There aren't vegetarian options in every single stall but the ones that do have vegetarian options all sound great. Definitely check this place out!
A must-see/try. It was so great! You can choose whatever food you like, and even though it was crowded, it was still really nice.

Great atomesphere and even greater food. Too many choices being the only downside, this place is a must visit. We went with a toddler on New Years Day. It was absolutely packed but we weren't deterred, though seats and tables were hard to come by. Food is beyond amazing and price is very reasonable. Some stalls have menu in English so I stuck to them.

Good place to eat. There is a good selection of food, local and international for an affordable price. The whole environment is appealing, not suitable for romantic dinner though as it can be quite noisy when busy and the place is busy most of the time. We enjoyed all food we ordered from different vendors, everything was freshly prepared from good quality ingredients. I can only offer for anyone.
Superb. Amazing place to eat/drink in Lisbon, not too affordable, so prepare your wallets. It's great to go once or twice in a month.

Foodys Paradise!. This is a superb food hall, a beautiful building and a choice of anything you want to eat. It's busy and buzzy and you can choose from any of the various food stands and sit at long tables with high stools. Difficult to make a choice as everything served looks amazing. Not to be missed.

Super! . Nice foodmarket appr 10 minutes walk from praca commercio. A lot of choice, fresh food from 20 or So vendours. Pick a table in the center and enjoy the food and atmosphere. Also craft beer from tap.
Must stop bty!. This is the old market that has now been remodeled and transformed into a giant food court/marketplace. We had lunch here and had tábuas and sushi. Loved the atmosphere!

Wish every city had this. This is a great sampler of Lisbon cuisine at affordable prices that offers something for everyone in your group. At first glance, you might think this is just a regular food court with some hip branding to make itself look a little fancier. However, this market actually represents some of the best restaurants and chefs in Lisbon at affordable prices in a very friendly atmosphere. My girlfriend both ordered from the same restaurant, and our fish and ceviche were superb. It was really hard to choose from all of the the different options because everything looked so good. I wish that more cities had a space like this.

Awesome place for anyone that enjoys food.. We liked this place so much we came here all three nights. It opens late, has a variety of food options and lots of options for alcohol. Food was reasonably priced and you get to try a little bit of everything and you get to skip the service part of going to a restaurant especially when you're travelling and don't want to dress up. Husband loved that beer was under 2 euros a glass.

A good place to sample Portuguese specialties.. If you don't have time to research where to eat this may be the perfect solution. Most Portuguese dishes including a large variety of fish, meat, desserts, drinks can be found in this large, clean, noisy enclosed Food Court. Finding a seat at the long, shared tables may be difficult at lunch and dinner time. It is a great place to strike a conversation with locals who frequent the market in large numbers. The food is not of restaurant quality but it is not fast food. Prices are reasonable, about one half of the cost at a restaurant. It is definitely worth a visit.
Lots of great small vendor food in one place. Such a great place to sample lots of small plates! Wine, beer, tapas - I highly recommend the tartare place and the Jamon iberico stands! A must try

A fun way to graze on food and drink. Most of the stalls sell Portuguese food and you really are spoilt for choice...from seafood to posh burgers, from cheese boards to pizza. Also a huge selection of good quality wines, spirits and cocktails. If that isn't enough you can indulge on artisan chocolate! Fun dining...you can stroll around, sample lots of small plates and eat casually at benches.

Good selection of food . Good selection of food, clean & bright marcedo setup and easy for us especially after a tired day.Go for this local authentic Portuguese's shop. I like their Octopus rice which was so yummy. .The dish to go when you started missing home and wanted to eat rice.
Best market ever.. We started our Eat Drink Walk tour here and discovered some wonderful places to eat and to buy to take back to our apt.
Awesome "food court" with top end food and wine. This was one of my favorite spots in Lisbon for a quick bite or a full meal. Interesting food choices, all kinds of clients, tourists and locals.

Gluten-Free Options Galore!. If you are Celiac like me, I am certain that you have found that restaurants with real "chefs" versus "cooks" are often a safe bet. This market is essentially over a dozen restaurants in one, all with "chefs," including some with incredible press. Many of the restaurants had great gluten-free awareness. Very creative and fun dishes. Unlike some of the other reviewers, I felt the food was a great value. Most of the places use local and/or organic ingredients. Kitchens are open so you can see them prepare your meal. The atmosphere was the best in my opinion- lively and conducive to meeting new people. Give it a try - you will love it!
Visit if in the neighbourhood. vegetables, fish and meet market reconverted into new style. Great food and great ambiance. The coquettes counter is divine

Loved this place. Only just found this place after a previous trip. Fascinating selection of dining choices with brilliant food. Can be hard to find a seat at peak times i.e lunchtime and evening. A must see.

nice but expensive. Great gourmet market near the centre of Lisbon.
lots of food shops and some presents ones too.
next to the gourmet markets is the more earthy and traditional food markets where the locals shop for food, good if you rent an apartment and want to cook.
The gourmet market is not cheap though , even for Portuguese standards
Something for everyone!. Excellent choice, excellent quality, open late, budget friendly, an absolute must for eating out in Lisbon!

Great fun, great food!. This was our favorite adventure in Lisbon. In fact, in the five days we were there we visited this Mercado twice. We are very serious foodies- one of us is a professional chef in the U.S., and we literally ate our way through the market on both occasions. We tried one of everything and shared. We had sushi, pizza, pastries, pork belly, Tempora string beans , mushrooms stuffed with quail eggs, lots of beer ($4.80 for 3 large drafts) oysters, and on and on. The food stalls are all around the perimeter of the giant market, each representing a well known professional chef's work, and in the center there are tables to sit and eat.It's noisy and busy and very casual. We met a couple from Germany and sat for an hour and chatted about travel.There is also a large area with beautiful fresh flowers, but you couldn't eat them so we weren't much interested in them.

Different and amazing!. This place is very modern with many options regarding food and drink. I had a burger that was delicious! I was here with a friend of mine and we had a great time together because this place also has music and so it's a bit having dinner and having a night out together at the same time and place. Prices are diverse but I think they are a bit like having a meal in a shopping centre in Portugal. A must in Lisbon!

Affordable variety. Although there are many nice places to dine out in Lisbon, the Ribeira market has a special flair: more than 20 different restaurants, from fish, meat, poultry, portughese , a wine bar and a coffee shop, and also a souvenir shop with local delicacies.There is no wish open regarding the choice and all at an affordable price.

A great place for food and drink. As good as expected. Spoilt for choice and perfect for picking from the various outlets. The two stalls we eat from had relatively small portions for a non-trivial price. But very tasty.

nice place to hang out with friends. It is available lot of options of food from pizza ( that I strong recommend, it is delicious) to fine food and wine. People get well dressed and have fun. You can see Portuguese people hang out with friends in regular night out. You can also have an experience to taste a great ice cream at "Santini". You can get access this attraction by metro station "cais do sodré" , Train and trolley car. A negative point is a little bit difficult to get a place to sit because at weekends there are a lot of people there. So be patient and enjoy it. It worth.

A lot of choice and a great ambiance. This place offers a wide variety of foods and possibilities to eat, drink and spend some quality time with your friends or relatives. During a visit in Lisbon, this place is a must!

I've been several times with friends, mostly with foreigners.. All my friends have been delighted! The space is pleasant, very animated and there are lots of delightful food to choose from, all of it fresh. Also great deserts and even a shop with great souvenirs (Vida Portuguesa). Not expensive,

Take Time Out to visit!. So much food to eat but so little time! Every cuisine you can think off served from small independent stalls and a lot of very talented chefs. You could snack, feast or drink on meats, cheese or chocolate - whatever you desired actually seemed to be represented in abundance.The buzz was superb and I believe they have live music sometimes. It opens all hours we were told. The various cuisines we tried did not disappoint and it really was a foodie haven or should I say heaven!You simply must go and try it out - down by the sea not far from the Roman Arch and maritime square.

Surprise yourself!. If you are a gourmet visiting Lisbon, you'll be spoiled for choice - yummy food can be found anywhere, at great prices. However, the revamped Mercado da Ribeira is rather unique - imagine an upscale food court, where a huge number of choices of haute cuisine are offered at accessible prices, in a lovely environs. It's a short walk away from Terreiro do Paço and Downtown Lisbon's premier shopping area at Chiado.
Big market , Different dishes , meat. fish, sealfood, vegetarian. Great place and nice decoration and atmosphere , quite big , You can eat whatever you want .Come on go

Great and unexpected find!. Amazing old building which has been beautifully renovated; great atmosphere and a wide selection of all different foods to chose from. Had to make a circuit twice to make final decisions! Famous local chefs and local produce feature.

Great variety of places to eat in this food hall.. We ate here on several occasions and enjoyed the atmosphere as well as the food. There are many food outlets serving a great variety of dishes, Portuguese cuisine of course but other countries are well represented too with many Asian outlets. You order and pay for your food, they give you a disk, you find seats and when your food is ready the disk flashes red lights and you return to collect your food. We enjoyed the variety of chicken dishes at Miguel Laffan's outlet in the bottom right hand corner of the hall. The chicken hearts were particularly tasty!

Excellent Food. This is a food court with excellent restaurants. We had the prego with shrimps (steak sandwich), it was excellent. If you are staying downtown Lisbon it is worth the half hour walk, great for lunch.

Good quality food priced like a food court. The old mercado da Ribeira has a new area that works like a fancy food court. Here you can enjoy some of the best food, drinks and deserts available in Lisbon at a fraction of the price. For families is a great choice since you can eat Top quality food at a reasonable price and a relaxed atmosphere.

Too trendy. It is "the place to be seen" and feels like NY, but I'd actually come to feel like I was in Lisbon. Food might be good, but it was too happening for my tastes. Checked out the vendors, but the crush of the crowd, the noise and the "everyone in black" vibe prompted me to find a neighborhood place for a more laid back fish dinner.

Cosy and trendy. Very enjoyable stop after a long day visiting museum. An atypical experience with a very interesting range of food and drinks. Come with friends and family even young ones without problem. Price range 5-20€

The best food in Lisboa. It has become my favourite place for dining in the city. It has so many stands that you need to go around at least twice. First, to check out every stand. Second, to decide what you want. It is very hard to choose, because everything sounds, looks and smells absolutely delicious. We ended up there at least 3 times during our stay, but I wish it was even more. I can't recommend one particular stand, because all of them offer great food, but try a prego sandwich there, for sure!
Adult Food Court. Awesome spot for casual dinner. Beer, wine, sangria, cocktails, and many different cuisines available. Good mixed crowd. Mostly 25-40 year olds. Reasonable prices.

Too crowded, sterile and expensive. One of the best things about Portugal is that you can get excellent food in traditional restaurants for little money. For this reason, introducing Time Out was a mistake. I went there at dinner time and there were way to few seats. We spent half an hour cruising around the hall to find a place (and I am not counting in the time spent waiting in line to order) and we ended up eating a cold meal standing up. This wouldn't be that bad if the culinary quality was great, but the fact is that it is merely average and you do not get to enjoy an interesting atmosphere. It's just a sterile ambiance and expensive food.

Wow, What a Great Location and So Much Choice!. This is a fabulous place to enjoy a real quality meal from a wide variety of top quality chefs and eateries; probably the best choice in Lisbon! We enjoyed a piping hot, freshly prepared meal ar around midnight in this buzzing and welcoming location. We dined from Miguel Castro E Silver - a fabulous duck dish and a veal risotto, both meals were outstanding and great value accompanied by a very decent white wine (vino verde) at just €3 a glass, excellent. This is a must visit destination for any to Lisbon.

Great adventure . Time out market is like a food court. All kind of dishes Portugese, Seafood, Brazilian even Japanese is available. Everything is freshly made and tastes delicious. The hardest thing is to make up your mind what to eat next. We just ordered 1 dish at each restaurant and this way we had all kinds of different dishes. You also have choices of all kinds if draft beer and of course many delicious wines. For the beer we had the Munich Dunkel and for the wine we had Vino Verde. Both were delicious. This is a real fun place to visit. There are also many places for desert items. Like Pastel Denate, icecream and so on. After 8 pm it will get busy but it is still very nice. It is absolutely worth to vist and to enjoy.

An ideal amusing spot. The Mercado da Ribeira is for Lisbon what the "Halles" used to be for Paris. Recently renewed and refurbished, many Portuguese chefs opened small spots there wher you can taste great regional products., going from wines and sprits to pastry or sea food. You can wonder around just for the fun of it and also visit the proper "market "places from fish mongers to flowers and vegetable spots. A must in Lisbon

Unmissable experience when visiting Lisbon!!. Every kind of food available to order. I was in Lisbon for a friend for a weekend and we are used to the UK street food culture but this was on another level. Wonderful dishes cooked to order and served on proper plates with metal cutlery and glasses - it was restaurant experience food but without table service. The benefits are that each diner can order as they wish, the food is very reasonably priced and the building itself is wonderful and there was a great atmosphere.
Amazingly tasty food. One of the best places to eat fresh and tasty food in Lisbon. Prices are not high and the variety is very high. The place is very clean and modern.

Why cant we have this mercado in my home town!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! superb. hi visited this upmarket foodcourt twice on a recent city break in lisbon ,nothing like a foodcourt in a shopping mall its an old market hall where all the shops around the outside are now all different food suppliers ,all is cooked fresh and after ordering you are given a bleeper to tell you when to return for your meal and everything is a bit classy no kfc or macdonalds crap,all of the middle is wooden bench seating and we spend a pleasant few hours here in the afternoon partaking of some lovely red wine,a favourite spot was a gin bar where you could have a g&t made with gins from all over the world with the barman putting on a bit of theatre in the making of the drinks also loved the cured ham stall with the ham and cheese making a perfect afternoon tapas.my only complaint is why this cant be my local market hall it was superb

Great selection of local and international food. A covered market with a stunning collection of food styles, allowing the visitor to sit and graze from various chef outlets.There were local chefs offering traditional food to that with a twist, excellent seafood, fast food, cold meats and cheeses, desserts, wine, cocktails, beer - the list goes on...An excellent venue if with a group of friends or as a couple. Grab and seat and then wander to choose what you want to eat. You will then be given an electric pager that will announce when your order is ready.Well organised, clean and efficient - an excellent food night out.

Delicious food, bad architecture. Time out Mercado do Ribeiro is a food market located in Tagus river's shore (Rio Tejo), very close to the subway station Cais do Sodré. It has around 20-25 different restaurants which serve different types of food...Italian, Japanese, American, Mediterranean, Portuguese and so on. You have wide range of taste and a small shop for handcarafts. However there is a dissappointment about this place. It is like a food court rather than a "mercado". If you go to other food markets around the world (in New York, Philadelphia, Montevideo, Tokyo, Paris etc) the place is designed as a labyrinth and you walk around between the shops. This place left the main hall empty and filled it with tables, so it gave me a feeling of a shopping center. The board signs and even the areas that every shop has is are the same so it killed the feeling a little bit. But if you only care about food, you won't be dissappointed.

Amazing range of food . This is the best palace to go and eat when you can't decide what you feel like. So many options. The chicken place in the back right corner is great and get a croquette from the little place next door.great range of food, fun atmosphere and central location.

A food market worth visiting!. We visited lisbon last November and have been to Mercado da Ribiera 3 times. It has every sort of food, from portugese to asian to desserts to fresh juises and coctails. I had the chicken piri piri the first time, but the second time a had a burger that is definitely on the top of my list. The bread is black because it has ink from squid in it and a salmon crab burger with seaweed salad. Absolutely AMAZING!!!The restaurants are open every day, extept the actual market witch closes every day at 2pm and is closed on Sunday.

Great idea. Came here on 2 nights so much choice of high quality and varied food styles you could come every night for a week!!! Good central beer and wine outlets.nice atmosphere friendly and informal. There will be something to keep all tastes happy.lots of locals mixed with visitors.

Excellent place, excellent food. Honestly from the outside we didn't have too good expectations, but after entering, we were amazed. The atmosphere is very modern and cozy in the same time, there are several different types of food to choose from. We had dinner at Cozinha da felicidade.
Foodie heaven. Brilliant food court in old market, and we aren't talking KFC and Mickey D's. Local, fresh and fabulous. Drop in for a meal, a drink or people watching. Not expensive either.

Brilliant place to grab a bite to eat. We stayed in a hostel just across from this place. Great range of all different types of food, can get very busy and hard to find seats together if there is a group of you. Ate here a few times and was never disappointed

Never after 7 PM. Delicious place. You can have dozens of different dishes or snacks (mainly Portuguese) along with any drink that you wish. Perfect to go with a group and share. Never, but never, try to go there after 7 PM. The place is so crowded that you will not be able to ear what you are saying.

Great food all day (★). What a neat idea - a selection of mid- to upscale restaurants in market format. No, it's not like the food markets in Asia, nor is it cheap per se, but the fact that it's different is what makes it special.With many restaurants closed for a portion of the day, the TimeOut Food Market ensures that you can find great food at any time, into the night. We've visited for lunch (usually late, around 2:30-3:00 PM so as to avoid the crowds) and for late night snacking, and we've never left disappointed. Several popular restaurants have stalls here, including Sea Me & O Prego da Peixaria. There's a good selection of local & traditional Portuguese food. Some restaurants, e.g. Marlene Vieira, have a daily menu which is good value for money. We can recommend the beef steak on Fridays. The Asian Lab serves great food, too, if you'd like something different. Their gyoza was particularly tasty. There are drinks stalls, too, and places where you can buy local products to take away, e.g. olive oil.We've been to the TimeOut Food Market several times and it's been a great experience every time. It may be a little too fancy for a food market, but that's not a criticism in my book. Great food, good location, ample space to sit down and enjoy! We'd be interested to see whether TimeOut decide to implement this idea elsewhere.

Fantastic Place For Lunch. This place was a real gem! We initially came here to pick up a few things from the market and maybe a couple of gifts. What we found was a spectacular array of food vendors all housed under one roof. We bought a variety of items from multiple spots and sat and enjoyed a really good lunch. Try to work this place into your itinerary!
Whatever your heart desires. A great place to eat whatever you might be craving. A casual, bustling setting but with high quality food and drink.

Great place for lunch . We stopped in for lunch and were grateful for the number of options. The food was very good and it was fun to eat at the shared tables. We also enjoyed a little shopping for food and other small gifts to take home.
Great food . I loved the concept . Lots of very good quality food to choose from. Convenient location reachable by buses and metro last stop of verde line. I truly enjoyed my visit today.

The best tartar in the world. We went to this place after the recommendation of our friends who had been here last year. They said we had to try tuna tartar. Indeed, it is the best tartar I have ever tried in my life and I have been to many many places in many many countries. To sum up, it's a must-visit in Lisbon.

A bit too official, nevertheless great food. Having seen food courts/markets around Asia, as well as Europe (e.g. La Boqueria) I felt sort of the distance at first glance of Time Out. It has a feeling of a well organized machine, with almost no soul in it. It's hard to explain, but somehow this food court lacks a special lively vibe and a bit of chaos. And the way I saw it, it's more like a touristy spot than locals' choice. But the food defends itself pretty well. Lots of vendors to choose from, definitely worth a visit. Foodies will be pleased, but only those with deep pockets. Prices are well above Lisbon's average, including alcohol. My personal recommendations: Tartaria with one of the best tuna tartars I've tried in my life and Cafe de Sao Bento. The latter serving superb beef - try it in a classic Portuguese Prego sandwich or as a grilled entrecote steak - melting in your mouth and leaving you craving for more.

Great atmosphere, great food - the ideal lunchtime spot. This is not to be missed. The market closes early afternoon so arrive early if you're shopping for food to cook at your apartment. The eateries stay open though and offer a huge range of food. We tried food from three different places and all of it was wonderful - and all cooked to order. There is a good vibe, I could have sat and worked here quite happily for hours. Miles of seating as well so no problem at all getting settled.

Must in Lisbon. Great place to visit after a walk along the Tage river. There are two activities. The first is the market itself where you you can find veg, flowers, meats and obviously fish/seafood. Quite interesting.The second one is the food court, a mixture of local traditional Portuguese food and the rest (Asian, Sushi, burger, ...). It always busy and we like the atmosphere. Enjoy

A fascinating place. This was not what we expected but we had a great time deciding what to eat from the huge selection of eateries in the market and then afterwards we went shopping at the food stalls

What a trip. Visited this adult food court last night at the suggestion of the staff at hotel we were staying in. What a fun evening. Several dozen small but exquisite eateries with amazing selection of small plates and great wine. Wonderful vibe with a mostly younger crowd we still felt very welcome despite our age. It's not Alice's Restaurant but you can get anything you want. Communal eating areas where we shared a table with an English couple and had a great time.

Stunning cross section of Lisbon eateries. a collection of 30+ separate food and drink vendors, this is an excellent option for reasonable priced meals and selection of drinks day or night - tends to be heaving by 7 pm and you'll need to be quick to score a communal table seat. Best to have a partner grab the food while you secure seating. Great family vibe, and its about 60/40 Locals to tourists. Daytime is somewhat more laid back, and you can take in the local portuguese merchandise shop, the fish mongers, butchers, and produce vendors. Definitely recommended.

A fantastic food court for fine dining or cheap bites. After a long day visiting Belém area - monuments and museum, we spent a really relaxing moment, sharing large tables with other visitors and sharing our touristic experiences and addresses.We found this place by surprise on our way from Tram E25 to Chiado area.This food court is presenting a lot of different dining specialties.We selected local cold cuts, drinks, fish, delicious meat pies, cheese, Portuguese gazpacho, delicious fruits and desserts.

Amazing Food Market. This place was our best find in Lisbon. We loved it so much we went back the next day.
Its a massive posh food hall where you can buy lunch from loads of various outlets (restaurant quality food), and sit down on big shared benches. Amazing food and wine.
A must for any tourist.

Interesting, great vibe & food is very good!!. The concept of this place is very exciting - you can try many different things from different places! We had some oysters, fish with chickpea puree, portugese grilled chicken - my fiancé said that it was the best chicken he had ever tried. I would definitely visit this place and very glad that someone has recommend it to us.

Foodie Heaven. What can I say, we stumbled across this during our first afternoon in Lisbon.... thought I'd died and gone to heaven... This is the best food hall I've ever been to. Probably close to about All good quality outlets of freshly cooked & prepared food to order. You can choose from every type of food imaginable from every corner of the world... Noodles, Chips, Fish, Tartare, Meat, Cheese the list is endless. With wines, ports and beers to match the quality but all at affordable prices. The concept is great, you go up and order the food at your desired outlet, they hand you a flashy thing... you find a seat and then when your food is cooked your flashy thing flashes.... ta dah! Means you can go out as a group and all eat different things if you wish. Loved it

Far too many fantastic dishes to try!!!. This is like no food court I have ever seen. On my two trips to Lisbon I have eaten some stunning food at Mercado da Ribeira. The trouble is, as there is so much choice you cant sample dishes from every stand!A few of the dishes we had were:- Shrimp tempura with curry mayonnaise from Marlene Vieira's stand. Gigantic, meaty prawns in a crisp batter, served with a rich curry mayo.- fried cuttlefish in black tempura from Sea Me; tender, melt in the mouth cuttlefish in a squid inked, crispy batter, served with a sharp vinegar dressing. - Pork cheek from Henrique Sa Pessoa's stand. This was like the best comfort food you could ever wish for, pork cheek that melts in your mouth, with a creamy mashed potato, topped with perfectly cooked cabbage which balances the texture with a little crunch.- The Café de Sao Bento Filet Mignon. This steak was so tender, we were given butter knives to cut it with. This cream sauce it lies in is incredible; decadent and buttery without being heavy.We also had some delicious desserts. The overall quality of all the food at Mercado da Ribeira is very high, and the equivalent in the UK would probably be at least double the price.I'm absolutely certain that there are 100s of amazing dishes from other stands, but we just didn't have the time to try each restaurant. I would have loved to have tasted some fresh lobster. I definitely need to return!

GREAT DINING EXPERIENCE. This was just a few minutes from our hotel and was a great surprise. We ate there a few times during our stay. You can choose from many outlets around the huge hall selling wines, local produce and food from around the globe.

Easy to find, good to experience, and great food. After exploring the wonders of Lisbon, we were more than ready to have a meal. Timeout was a short tram from Commerce Square. We arrived after 7:30 to find the building full of busy kiosks that were well attended by other hungry folk. A foodie paradise featuring local and international delicacies. We opted for Trincas, a restaurant counter behind the main area. It was intimate and a most welcome shelter from the populous main market. We had a delicious steak (topped with an egg) served with spicy sautéed potatoes and a salad. Our host Sebastian provided a guide of the local fare his chef was making. We sampled a wonderful red Quinta dos Carvahais and white Alvarinho Laureiro, too. Though we stayed indoors, Trincas has a lovely terrace outside. We had an excellent meal at Trincas.

Friendly service, good food. Really interesting vibrant place to visit - lively atmosphere. Great choice of food of all types. We had a really good lunch, well cooked steak sandwich and garlic prawnsA must visit location

Adult food court . This is a trend that I have been seeing a lot more of in the United States so I am glad I got to experience it in Portugal as well. There are rows of eateries and pastry shops that form essentially a square so your options are limitless. There is anything from Portuguese cuisine, Asian, sushi, oysters, pizza, chicken, jamon, cheese, etc. it really is great for foodies! Each restaurant is hand picked and by a board because they have a certain standard to upkeep. They said that 2 out of the 14 Michelin stars chefs of Portugal have a place here as well! That's pretty wonderful!

Brilliant seafood and vibe. Ate here on a fresh autumn day. Hake , prawns, scallops and cuttlefish all done to perfection. Very tasty and reasonable prices. Fresh juices were very good as well. Highly highly recommended and a terrific outing. Combine it with a seaside walk at sunset
Great atmosphere. Great place to wander round & get something to eat. Good selection of different food stalls all served fresh. A bit prices compared to out side but fun.

Brilliant idea. Stumbled upon this when out wandering. Had a sampling lunch from one of the chef stalls. Absolutely fantastic and great value for money. Went back one night time and had a few nibbles and some great wine. What a great place.
Great atmosphere and food. The food was excellent with many choices available. Environment was very unique and loved by both my wife and I. Definitely a must to visit on your trip to Lisbon.

A food court with a diversity of food + others. There are many food stalls in this mercado. You can have a substantial dish, or order several smaller dishes. Oysters, seafood, tapas, charcuterie, wine bar, pizza, Japanese food, burgers, cakes/pastry...in a casual, lively atmosphere. When we were there, there were people dancing on the floor, enjoying themselves. The food is good quality and inexpensive.

Very tasty. This place was a feast for the eyes and all the senses. So many styles of food to choose from. We ended up sitting at a counter and were entertained by watching the staff at work. It was like a ballet. They were all doing their own thing but then it all came together in the presentation of delicious plates of food. We chose a few tapas style plates and they were lovely. Wine was great and we shared a delicious bitter chocolate mousse which was not like mousse as we know it. It was so dry and crumbly and possibly the best chocolate dessert I have tasted. It was a great experience and I would rush back in a minute. Very reasonably priced too.

A quality spot. Part traditional indoor market, part food hall. Much more than that though. Beautifully restored every food outlet tempts, making it very hard to choose! Freshly prepared and delicious we returned several times and all that we tried was delicious. Plenty of room to sit and decide. Clean toilets. Good coffee, fab cakes, endless savoury choices.
Delicious. If you like your food (and drinks too) then you really need to make a visit to Mercado da Ribeira.Go with an empty stomach and be ready to taste all sorts of Portuguese fare.
It will be busy. It was a Friday night, the place was alive and full of life.We had food from a variety of the outlets and it was delicious. Definitely worth a visit.

O Prego da Peixaria. An afternoon walk at downtown Lisbon, with a particular destination in mind, this turn the infamous Mercado da Ribeira. An old market close to Cais do Sodré, transformed into a dinning venue, with an endless variety of Portuguese flavours, from the most consistent meals to finger food and snacks. I wanted something simple, fast and uncompromising. I’m very fond of the national snack called Prego. A thin and tender steak, flavoured with garlic, rare or medium rare. That’s what I had. The lady asked - Homemade Chips? - Curious, I said yes please. - And to drink? - A glass of Red - “Tinto do Prego”. Marvellous combination, meat was of great quality, done the right way, juicy and tasty. Chips, really homemade style, yes. The wine just completed the lightness of my snack. Very good! Recommended!

Great fun place for lunch. There is a great range of food choices here to suit all tastes and budgets. The main seating area is long tables for everyone to share so at busy times you have to search for seats together but the advantage is people in your party could all get food from different outlets. If you are lucky you can get seats at the counter of the restaurant of your choice so that you can watch the chefs at work. The atmosphere is great as are the bars if you want to stay longer to avoid a rain shower as we did!!
Food experience. The best food experience in Lisbon. Very clever concept, best salmon and tuna tartar in Tartar-ia and nice staff everywhere! Not go there you lost time in Lisbon.

A Brilliant Place to Eat and Drink!. We stumbled across the Time Out Market by chance but were very pleased that we did! The choice of food is amazing and very reasonably priced as are the drinks! There were four of us and we could go to different places to pick what we each wanted and once you have ordered you get a "buzzer" to take back to your table ,which "goes off" when your food is ready! No "Chains" here! All top Chefs providing amazing food!
Foodie Heaven. We stayed in Lisbon 4 days and ate here every day. There are around 50 different outlets, all serving top of the range local cuisine. Good prices too. Nothing we ate disappointed us.

Great Concept with a HUGE choice offering!!. This previous old warehouse and fruit/vegetable market has been fabulously converted into an environment offering a eclectic mix of cuisines to accommodate all palates. The different cooking styles and choices of dishes made available through a multitude of 'kitchens' makes it a 'perfect choice' for anyone wanting 'something different'.Time Out is a casual eating-place which is open from early morning (for breakfast) until midnight (7 days a week).If visiting Lisbon, don't miss the opportunity to eat at Time Out as you're bound to 'love it', and probably return (as we did) several times during your stay!

Spent 3 nights in Lisbon, had to come here 3 times.. If you love food there is no way you can visit Lisbon and not come here. The market is a large hall with booths on all sides and a large seating area in the middle. Each booth represents a restaurant and serves some of their menu with most of it being delicious. Prices can, however, be quite high.

Novel concept, great choice of eateries. Worth visiting this open market area, offering a wide variety of restaurants in the same place. Casual, fun and plenty of dining options. Central seating and bar. Browse the various vendors before selecting choice of food. Watch the staff cooking through the open kitchens. Memorable.

Variety ! . I really enjoyed eating at this place. The choice is amazing and the quality good. The atmosphere is really vibrant it's busy , you find a seat on long benches sitting next to strangers watching what people have chosen to eat. Also can get a decent wine or G&T to go with your meal from the little bars

Great food and experience. What an incredible idea to turn an old market into a food hall! There is so much choice that you don't know what to go for. Impressive variety and good quality. We had slow roasted suckling pig, ice-cream, pizza, burgers and bought port wine, bread, salami...The only down side is the seating arrangements, it was really difficult to get enough seats together for our party of 6.

Up market hawker food.. Just returned from a 5 night stay in Lisbon.Wanted to visit the market and also try the food.Unfortunately we went on a Saturday afternoon and a Monday morning when the market was closed except for some fruit and flowers.However we still got to try the food hall where there was so much choice we had every good reason to go twice.We had heard about the seafood in Lisbon and were determined to try as much variety as possible and that's exactly what we did.I think if we'd stayed any longer in Lisbon we would have have had to have a new "wardrobe" as the food was so good.it was definitely the case of "sea food" and eat it for all our meals!

Great food/ great experience. I went there after a long sightseeing day around Belem.The mercado is a great space. The choices are too many and cater to all tastes. All great chefs under one roof! Had hard time picking what to eat. The prices are very affordable and excellent for the quality you get.easy system and nice staffWould recommend several times. You can do late lunch or dinner.Must do while in Lisbon
Great place for having lunch in Lisbon!. Great place to have lunch and to enjoy the impressive variety of high-quality local food. Especially loved the Tartar-ia place!

Delicious food and amazing experience. This place is full of all sorts of food. I tried the prawns in garlic sauce from one place and pad thai from another. Both were amazing, especially the pad thai. The cocktail shops weren't that impressive but the variety of food was excellent.

Wow - what a superb place to while away a couple of hours. Top quality food providers in a food court that is stylish and interesting. Great food is available - choose small plates from many stall and you will curate your own culinary journey through Portugal. Excellent but not entirely cheap although good value.

Amazing place for a meal anytime of day. We visited this market several times. There is just too much to try. You honestly can't go wrong with any of the choices, just make sure to take advantage of the drink specials offered from each kiosk. Shopping is great as well, but food is the highlight.

A fun night in Lisbon. Definitely visit this market while in Lisbon. It makes for a really fun night out and lots of great food options. They have literally everything here. Portuguese options, sushi, pizza, hamburgers and more.
Foodie Heaven. We came here three times on a 10-day trip to Lisbon and Cascais. We loved the variety on offer but most of all the food-hall atmosphere.

Overrated. Fa(s)t food, almost cold. Had a hard time to find a seat. We might have had bad luck with our order, but it was clearly not "just portuguese" as advertised. You might have a better time with other booths in there although.

Great choice. A modern trendy interpretation of the food court, it's well worth visiting this re-use of part of the market building. Spend the evening sampling an array of Portuguese (and other) specialities. We enjoyed garlic prawns, steak sandwiches, and the most decadent chocolate meringue cake with ice cream. Roll me home!

So much more than a food court... Recently was in Lisbon and heard small notions of this place but after my first time I went again and recommended it to a few others. What a brilliant idea and so much fun and such a different mood from the no rush norm of Portugal. Finding tables was tough but that's all in the fun of the atmosphere. Will be going back to say the least. So much fun for families and friends.

Mass Produced Rip Off. Prices similar to international food malls in San Francisco, Berlin, etc. for mass produced average to disgusting food. Best experience was in outer ring at a small seafood bar whetre good shrimp scampi and wine with pleasant barkeep was $13. Average was the Asian fruto do mer with mostly noodles, with wine at $13. Disgusting was Miguel Laffan\s stale, cold, greasy chips. When I returned them to the unhappy staff saying I expected hot, fresh chips, I was told to get the fries if I wanted hot fresh potatoes. They were also tasteless other than the grease, and not vey hot, suggesting they preboil their potatoes and only dip them in hot oil.

trendy but authentic. Very crowded on sundays, nice atmosphere, design, style and good food. Authentic Portuguese food you have to find elsewhere, this is more world kitchen with croquettes, serano, thai, noodles, hamburgers, shusi etc.Beautiful spot, still worth a visit even when you're not hungry.

Great place for the evening meal after a hard day of siteseeing. Great variety, great prices! A very pleasant environment! We had supper here 2 or 3 nights. I especially enjoyed the "pour-your-own" beer booth.

Nice variety, excellent quality. This place may seem chaotic, but it is very well organized. The food has been chosen with care, and everyone can pick and choose what they like. If you are too overwhelmed, as we were the first day, we got some bar seats at one of the restaurants edging the market and had a great meal.
Spoilt for choice. This place has everything under one roof and every type of food imaginable. The prices are great value and each stall offers amazing choice.
Time out fantastic. Best food hall we have been to. Great food, great prices. Great atmosphere. Spent several hours as a group of mixed ages from 10. Must go to in Lisbon!

Is this Prahan?. Not what we expected but not disappointed either. This is an old seafood market that has been given a complete overhaul and now looks and feels like a large delicatessen straight out of Melbourne. Well done whoever it was who restored this place. There are a large selection of food stall with beautiful presentations and sign boards. Everything looked great and the food was of a high standard. Mind you it wasn't cheap either by Lisbon standards.

Awesome possum approved food court. You can find some great food here at quite reasonable prices (though it's not cheap cheap). Had some great food from Henrique Sa Pessoa and Cozinha Da Felicidade. The curry from Asian Lab was very average in comparison, hardly any flavour. Stick to the more Portuguese food I guess. The cakes at Nos e Mais Bolos are epic.
Nice market!. Great to see how shopping used to be like.Great place to eat out and sample local food!It's near the Cais do Sodre, so great if you want to dine after a day at Cascais!

Great place for a large variety of food. This is a very nice somewhat upscale-looking marketplace with a variety of grocery stores (which close early) and a larger number of eateries: beer places, cakes, coffee, seafood, burgers and many more.We chose a seafood and a Portuguese place and enjoyed the food. Prices were decent, service good and it is a great place for people-watching.
A highlight of stay in Lisbon. This place is a great option for eating out in Lisbon. Enormous choice and great value. Great atmosphere and a mix of locals and tourists

not cosy, but special. Several and different types of restaurant food, so everyone can eat their favorite dinner. Bit chaotic and crowded, but the food is excellent. Especially the bacalhou-variations of Riberalves 30!

Many tatses. Came by on recommendation from a friend and glad we did. So many things to chose from.
Great for groups who cannot decide what they want. There is something for everyone.
LOVE the beer, wine and cocktail bars!

Amazing place with excellent food! Go there!. We have been here three times, it is a new market with all kinds of different types of food. You can just sit on a big table and enjoy the good food!Everyone can choose their favorite food, such as croquettas, portugese food, pizza's, thai food, iberico ham, sushi etc etc.Everything we have been eating here was excellent, very tasteful and fresh food for very good price!Very kind service and very good cleaning service, when you are ready your dirty dishes are taken care off!Excellent vibe to enjoy very good food!!
Best food and wine in Lisbon!!! . So glad we found this little peace of heaven in Lisbon!! Multiple visits and the best food and wine in town. Busiest on weekends so leave early to get a seat.

Brilliant foodie experience. I lunched here today and it was brilliant. All these wonderful restaurants and providores all here together in a very comfortable environment. To start we wandered around to take a look at all the stalls. The restaurant stalls often had two sides, serving to the central eating area on one side, and bar eating on the other. You can see all the kitchens, so if you are keen to see how it all goes together you can get a great view. My partner and I chose tasting dishes from different chefs and shared all the yummy experiences, over four different glasses of wine (there is also beer, juices, bar, coffee etc) We then wandered over and finished up with a gelati - just a great was to get a wonderful meal and sample as much of Portugal as you possible can in one meal. Very affordable, easy to get to (its on the Hop On Hop Off bus routes, the down town tram and the Metro) and all round awesome experience. Im thinking seriously about doing it again tomorrow.
Several choice . This place is real good you can eat and drink everything you want (asian food,portuguese food,tapas,wines...)

Overwhelming, but delicious and fun. Not to be missed in Lisbon. The gourmet food court has a dizzying array of food, drink and dessert choices. Go hungry. It is noisy, crowded and getting a seat (which you should not give up once you have snagged it) can be a challenge. Go with at least one other person who can hold the seats. Walk around and buy foods and pair wine by the glass from the myriad vendors. We ate here our last night in Portugal and it was a perfect ending.

THE place to go to try everything!. We stumbled in here after a long plane flight waiting for our rental apartment to be ready. This was the perfect place to go to get a glass of wine or a beer and sample many different kinds of Portuguese food, as well as desserts, coffee, pizza or gelato and desserts. We returned several times to try things from the various stalls and none of them were disappointing. All had outstanding food, especially for something that is considered a "food court." We had an amazing octopus and rice dish from one of the stalls. Definitely give this a try; great for lunch. Note that it gets very busy and can be hard to find a seat.
Great for lunch!. Great place to meet friends for lunch/brunch. Large choice of different food and drinks, I recommend the rice lager from the central "beer experience"!

Great food and environment. Great place to stop after Belem, is kind of like San Miguel's market in madrid! with Portuguese food! and some other international gourmet artisanal foods. Nice place to have one. Not expensive at all in fromt of the riviera.

Lisbon downtown a great food and beverage experience !. very good, central and cosmopolitan ambiance, food and beverage quality in Lisbon. One of the best in Europe, in a recovered old market, next to Cais do Sodré railway station, night clubs, Labirinto Lisboa terror house and Santos night clubs. An area not to miss and a place to eat at the measure of your financial capacity with great quality and affordable prices.

Disappointed. A large building a short walk from the Placa do Comercio, we had high expectations but were disappointed. Maybe it is busier on other days but when we went, the main hall is a fruit and vegetable market, and the hall on the left is mainly a food market offering different foods to eat. Benches and chairs available to all.

Little hyped up for what it is. This is one half of a fish and veg/fresh produce market. During the day, fresh produce is for sale in one half of the hall (large!) whilst in the other half there are small stall/restaurants and craft stalls located round the sides. The food stalls are all vetted for their menus, what they sell, how clean they are, etc, which is good. There are stalls catering for many different tastes in cuisine, which is good, so you won't be stuck for choice. You order, take a buzzer/light thing, which buzzes and lights up when your food is ready and then you eat on the long refectory style tables laid out in the centre area. If you want 'fine dining', this isn't for you but if you are after a quick meal that is nice but not too filling (for that, read mingy, really!) then this will serve the purpose. Apparently, it has a good reputation among the hip and trendies.

Must go . Great foodcourt where you can enjoy a very large range of different cuisines from typical Portuguese dishes to more international ones... You'll also find great gin and Wine bars in the center of the market !

A must go to place if you're in Lisbon!. This was a great market that I highly recommend and easy to walk to. Lots of wonderful foods sold by restaurants in stalls that are all next to one another with dining tables and chairs in the middle with music and great lighting. It's a fun atmosphere to dine at and have various tastes from different restaurants. Wines well priced by the glass and it's fun just to go and watch! Easy walking distance near the water's edge and great hours. Pretty much open every day until evening hours (I think they're open till 10pm but double check- the info I was given previously was incorrect and pretty such they stay open for dinner hours)

Every city should have one. I had read about this market and we set off to find it on our first day in Lisbon. It's basically everything we love - good food and drinks with lots of choice under one roof and lots of opportunities for people watching.On the first day we went just after midday and it was quiet enough. We started with really tasty tapas and wine and made our way around a few stands enjoying some sushi and gyoza and delicious tempura.We also went back one night and it had a totally different atmosphere. Really busy with a great vibe and everyone enjoying themselves. Again we had some really good wines and beer and a selection of food.There was lots of choice for both savoury and sweet food and I thought there was plenty on offer in terms of drinks as well.It is probably not the cheapest place to eat in the city but it does offer great variety and it has a really lovely atmosphere. It's the kind of thing every city should have!

Great place to eat and hangout. Great selection of food and drinks. Great for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Too many good places to list but can cator for anything your after. Good selection of Portuguese and world wide foods.Great coffee bar in the centre and finished off with an ice cream! Definitely worth a visit if your in Lisbon.

Nice place for Lunch (Monte mar). We come for lunch - we tried a few dishes from 3 places but one stood out which was Monte Mar (i think they have a place in Cascais) we had garlic prawns and rice dish with octopus which you find all over Lisbon but this was superb. We had some croquettes and Prego / hamburger but wasn't great. But would definitely recommend Monte Mar for there seafood dishes!

Open all day. If you want to eat something between 3 and 7pm this is a right place. An excellent selection of restaurants, vine and porto shops. We strongly recommend Cozinha da Felicidade for food and vine.

Top food from all around Lisbon. This is a great place to get a taste of Lisbon food. It'll almost definitely have what you want. We tried five of the mini-restaurants and each was excellent. Make sure to try the Portugese tart from Pastelaria Aloma - even better than Belem, I thought!
brilliant for food any time of day. An excellent selection of restaurants around a communal eating area. Majority are very good standard - we visited 3 of them. Also wine / beer stall in the centre
So fun!. So many options of delicious food and drink! We planned on making just one stop there but came back over and over again.

Great choice under one roof . Great place to go if you're not sure what you fancy or if you and those going with you want something different. Portuguese, Italian, seafood, burgers, Tapas, Asian, Veggie, cakes, icecream and much more. It's a gourmet food court. Non of your naff food stalls here. A selection from some of the best City places.
