Wander round and pick what you like take it back to your seat with your buzzer and when it's ready go get it and enjoy.We visited twice in the evening and once for breakfast.One by one we'd wander off and bring back a suprise eat to share, Mini Chicken & mushroom pies, prawn croquettes, pork cheek with sweet potato, sirloin steak & mushroom, gorgonzola burger (rare), chocolate meringue cake and icecream. Lots of choice for drinks from soft drinks, fresh juice, beers, wine, spirits, fancy cocktails ..tea and coffee. .you want it they've got it somewhere. Reasonable prices too and if I had one of these near where I live I'd certainly be a regular.

Amazing choice, great atmosphere. Recommended by two friends, this was definitely worth a visit. There are various (high quality, not street food) food outlets all set round the edge of a large seating area. You order your food, get a buzzer, take a table and collect your food when your buzzer goes. What's great is if you are with people, you can all get different things from different places but sit together. Quality of the food was really good, and not expensive.It is located in half of a food market, but even though it is a beautiful vaulted building it isn't really loud and echo-y, you can still have a conversation without raising your voice!

Go on an empty stomach!!. We were told about this place by a friend who visited previously, It wasn't on our guide book. Boy am I glad we went, for anyone who enjoys their food this place is a must, there are numerous stores selling food from local restaurants, what a great idea! And the food was amazing

So much in one place!. This market was an incredible value. We stopped by before dinner to have a snack and a drink, the place was hopping! about 25 different vendors serve different foods as well as drinks. During the day it is also a produce and flour market. When our dinner plans fell through we ended up circling back and making our dinner there! definitely need to get there early if you don't want to wait for tables.

Really great atmosphere but often crowded !. This food court is amazing : long tables with a great choice of food / drinks / starters / cheeses, desserts ! However, the place could be really full of people and it could be annoying to wait for a free place to eat. Anyway, you have to try it !

Munchie Madness. Amazing food market in Lisbon. If my husband and I didn't just eat and had a reservation for dinner we definitely would have vegged out here. A lot of the popular restaurants had booths here and there was plenty of room to sit and have a drink. If I am ever back here I would definitely make a pit stop here for a quick snack or lunch!

Stunning food experience. We got addicted to this perfect choice of great food at one place. A good idea for couples of people is to share the food to have the chance of tasting different things. The Super Bock Beer Experience isn't that exciting, but the wines nearby a good.

An Absolute Must....this is how food courts should be!. We were recommended to try this by a friend, and if you are reading this I am recommending this to you...This place is fantastic, a super choice of different foods to suit all palettes, wines by the glass available in abundance.Simply select which store has the meal for you, place your order, choose your preferred wine and then wait until your individual timer flashes to alert you to your meal being ready.You then sit on long tables with your friends and friends yet to be made and enjoy the food, wine, company and the superb atmosphere.

This is what food courts should be !! A wonderful casual meal.. Whilst this is listed a "shopping" it is really a collection of excellent restaurants gathered in a very large food court.If you head to the group of restaurants on the furtherest wall (as you enter the Mercado) there are a number of "named" restaurants. They didn't mean anything to me but I was told that they are some of the better restauranteurs in Lisbon. We put together a meal from 3 of these places. The food appeared cooked to order (or at least finished to order). We waited for 10 -15 minutes whilst it was prepared.This is not a fine dining experience, it is communal seating and I could imagine it could get very crowned and noisy on a Friday or Saturday night.Our food was excellent and very fairly priced for what we ordered. It was a great experience and somewhere I would recommend both for the food and the atmosphere.

Great food, desserts, wine, beers choices. Great choices of food, desserts, wine, beers, etc. with some of the best restaurants represented in one place. Great space, large enough to cater to groups. Great for buying flowers too! Perfect after Belem visit.

Interesting !. Something different for a night out.This place gets packed ,so walk around have a good look,grab seats where you can while one person orders the food.We had a very long wait for a very average steak sandwich but were able to wash it down with a very good red wine .Fun for one evening but wouldnt rush back ,a little too packed and not that comfortable bench like seating .

Worth a visit. They serve nice food with lots of choice and plenty of seating. Range of prices and dishes. A few nice bars. Not as friendly as some I've been to and doesn't quite have the right atmosphere bit still pleasant enough for a quick bite to eat.

BEST place to eat in Lisbon. This is THE place to eat in Lisbon. Not because it's trendy, although I understand it is, but because the quality of the food and the choice available is fantastic. Just opposite main train station Cais do Sodre it's easy to get to, clean and just a great place to eat and visit.

Excellent!. Finally, there is somewhere you can eat to please everyone! We've not had great food experiences on previous trips to Lisbon but the food hall at Mercado da Ribeira is an excellent place to eat and drink. I was able to have a delicious veggie Chow Mien and my husband had a very juicy chicken with rice etc. It's reasonably priced and the staff were really helpful. Perfect.

Don't just walk by . Found this market by accident, on the outside doesn't look like much but inside we were amazed with the variety and quality of food on offer. For what you get most places a very reasonably priced, I suggest going right on lunch or for early dinner as it gets quite busy. We visited twice and suggest to definitely try pouring your own beer at Beer experience and a tart from the bakery store near the cooking area (forgot the name but you will not miss the array of delicious tarts and cakes in the display). There is also fruit markets to the side and an art display upstairs.

Foodie heaven. Lovely spot to stop off for a quick bite to eat - or a profound gastronomic experienceit's apparently the Only known market, where a prospective eatery's fare is sampled and rated by a panel of judges - to meet a required standard before being granted space to trade!! You can sample dishes by top Lisbon chefs for a fraction of normal restaurant Tories here. Definitely worth a visit.

Fantastic - don't be overwhelmed by choice when you arrive, take time to enjoy. This is an amazing epicurean addition to Lisbon and one of the best food halls (a title that doesn't do it justice) I have ever been to. Don't be overwhelmed on your first visit by the number of options and people. Best if there are two of you. Take a few turns to decide on what you want and one person stay with your seats while the other goes for their food. There is a relatively good turn over of people so you shouldn't have to search too long for a place but at the weekend it will probably be hard to find spaces together for 3 or more. Also not so sure if you have small children but great for the evening out. So many great options - fish, sushi, burgers, meat, Asian. Also most of the franchises have really good wine but for beer drinkers on one brand of beer but several different types.

Go early -stay for a meal. Wonderful insight into Lisbon shopping for fresh food. Good selection if you are in a self catering accommodation during your stay in Lisbon. The fresh fish stalls are especially good with a great selection of shellfish as well as the fish choice. Stay for a drink or quick snack if you are around at mid-day.
Awesome food hall. There is a wide selection of food in this food hall. Food are of good standard and at affordable prices. It is spacious too.
A great culinary space. You can try dishes from 5 top Portuguese chefs at a fraction of the cost at their restaurants. Great value!

Outstanding Food Hall. This is a fantastic place. We had incredible steak sandwiches from Henrique Sa Pessoa and amazing chicken at Chicken All Around. It's open all day so you can have a great lunch/dinner at the time that best suits you and do it relatively quickly. Leisurely meals are great, but for the busy tourist trying to see the city, sometimes quicker isn't a bad thing.

Great place. Fab place at any time day or night lots of small stalls to buy all manner of Portuguese food. A tip look at other peoples plates and if you see something you like ask where they got it from as it can be overwelming as so much food. Prices around 8 euros.

Fantastic - definitely GO!. WOW! What a lovely foody space! Lovely indoor food outlet space, with all kinds of amazing food and drinks to choose from. We weren't sure about it until we went but when we got there we LOVED it. We had some beautiful jamon washed down with a glass or two of port - and we tried another couple of the restaurants; a croquette bar and another bar that made amazing little light bights with egg and cod, steak, etc - all beautifully cooked and presented and all at decent prices. Definitely worth a visit, whether you're ravenous or just fancy something to take the edge off your hunger.
Pricey but nice. Great place to try some of the high end Lisbon restaurants. Bit pricey but the food is all very good, there's something for everyone so good for large groups

A must to go see and eat. I really enjoyed the market. I ate a steak appetizer with garlic and bread. I also had a side of fries and a glass of rose wine. It was very good. They also have a shop with items all made in portugal and I bought two port glasses which were very inexpensive. There is also a fish, fruit/veggie and flower market as well. It was very busy and my husband tried to order and a man just pushed in front of him. Very rude. He was done with the people at that point and just had a glass of port from a wine bar in the center of the market.

OK for a quick lunch. Went for lunch which was OK but hard to get a place to sit together and a bit disorganized due to everyone taking a different amount of time to get there food. Some were done prior to others even sitting down depending on lines. Food quality varied from OK to very good by vendor. If it is really busy I would recommend not trying to get a meal outside of a snack you can eat on the go. The shopping was OK but again nothing special or worth a special trip. If you have kids and you are getting all your food from one vendor it would not be a bad option. You can also go outside and get table service from a few of the food vendors which works good if everyone wants the same thing.

So Good, We Went Back. We really enjoyed this market. There were so many good eats. And there was so much variety--expensive and cheap, rich and simple, etc. There was something for everyone. We enjoyed it so much, we went back (the only place we ate at twice during our trip). It was such a great way to sample the many flavors of Portugal.The downside was that the seating was very crowded. We had to really work to find seats together the second time.

An ok place but way too crowded............. Its a nice enough place but nothing for a group of friends [ we were 5 ] and hardly any of us ate together. All the stalls need their own different times for their dishes and if you wait then food becomes cold and you may not necessarily find a table with 5 empty chairs. All depends what time of the day you go. Food was good, no doubt but think of it as a tester platter/dish than to go there for an evening out with friends. Its on the higher side of reasonable enough but without the full prices. Plate presentation is still top class and I suggest to stick with the few local celebrity chefs than go for anything else.In short its a place to go try once or spend a late afternoon if you have nowhere else to go in this city with fab food! :-)

Great ambiance in this foodmarket. We arrived in the morning in Lisbon and with a tip from a local, we went to this nice food market for some lunch. It is lovely, because it is cheap, close to the sea, open the whole day, great ambiance and there is a lot of variety... and the food is amazing!

Fresh food... so good!. Try the market because it is cheap, close to the sea, open the whole day, there is a lot of variety... and food is amazing! Fresh, simple and tasty. I wish to eat rice with pumpkin cream, rocket and goat cheese again!

Top notch but chose wisely. What a great place. We found it during the day and returned for a blow out eve. We sampled as many as our bellies would allow. Marlene 5 tasters was a bit of a dissapointment. The oyster bar was great. Tartar salmon brilliant.The pastries fantastic. Cheese and meats were the business. London.... Get one. Please.
Great place to visit!. A must-visit place for all food enthusiasts! Not only you can buy local delicatessen there, but you can try them as well, as they are cooked in front of you. Go there hungry!!!

A great spot to escape the sun. Firstly if you have never been to a genuine Portuguese market, then this is a must. All of you who buy supermarket food in Northern Europe will be amazed at how fresh, large and tasty real local produce is. The restaurants serving in the food hall are great and too many to list here. You can each chose a different vendor, but all sit together at long wooden tables. We loved all the places we tried over a couple of days. Walking is easy from the city centre, and being behind a major tram/train station is easily accessible.

Foodie extravaganza. A culinary highlight during our time in Portugal. An upscale food court with trendy locals led to great people watching and even better food sampling. Half of the fun was exploring the various stalls from top chefs as well as dessert, wine, and cocktail stands. We started with croquettes from Croqueteria and selected mains from Marlene Viera. We had our first francesinha and I'm certain it was the best one in the city. Succulent roast meats on toast with melted cheese and a fried egg on top; covering it all was a rich gravy for the most decadent creation ever. We had a pumpkin, goat cheese and arugula rice dish that was nearly as good but not as unique as the francesinha.

Wish All Cities had a Varied Market Like This. One part fresh fruit and veggies , another meat and wonderful fish but the best for tourists is the wonderfully varied food building.about 20 unique venders of food and drink and large wooden tables to sit and eat. Spotlessly clean. Don't miss. By River and train station.

Some of the city’s favourite food shops and restaurants brought together. Think (La Boqueria market in Barcelona but relatively cleaner) with less crowds depending on arrival, as this is were many 'hipster' locals like to eat; the ones in keeping with their culture who appreciate good food without flare or snobbery. The market is more than the culinary delights of Henrique Sa Pessoa's stall as if you are on a budget you can have for instance fresh oysters for about 2 Euro/£1.46 each or just browse around the shops and market/fish stalls who's roots go back as far as the 13th Century.

For those who prefer big crammed spaces….. Time out got recommended by several people to me as a must go to in Lisbon. Having read up a bit about it I suspected it wouldn't be my cup of tea but still wanted to try it out. The market was closed since it was a Sunday which probably changed the atmosphere slightly. I didn't like it but put it down to personal preferences or in this case the dislike of big crammed spaces. Since we didn't eat there I couldn't comment on the food either. There is for sure something for everyone.

A must visit eating spot in Lisbon!. A must visit in Lisbon! Especially Henrique sa pessoa's stall! Prok belly, pork crackling, pesticos, bacalhau! You will get everything under one roof and the vibe is just really great! A good stopover as well if you want to head off to Belem right after, the train station is just across from here.

The place to be!!. Great food and drinks and electric atmosphere! Every city needs a place like this!! You can order from numerous places and gather with friends to eat and the communal seating. This place offers food from all around the world and everything I tried was excellent quality! A great place for foodies!

Don't miss. I couldn't be happier that the tram stopped right in front of Mercado da Ribeira and the driver told everyone to get out. We decided to check it out instead of going to our original destination in Rossio area. We had hamburgers in Honorato and it was delicious! The market hall is super cool and nicely crowded on Saturday evening :)

Don't miss it. An amazing marketplace selling delicious food and local specialities. Think of it as indoor food carts. It is impossible to go here and not find something you love. Everything my party ate was absolutely delicious. I only wish I had discovered it on my first night in Lisbon rather than my last.
Foodie heaven. This is a great way to try different dishes and specialities. It's something you should definitely do when you visit Lisbon.

Just go!. A beautiful, tendry place to go with your friends or the other half. Seriously there is no way you will not love it!! You will find the best that we can do in Portugal, good fish, good food in gereral, for all tastes since fast food to natural and organic. Taste the burger in bolo do caco in Prego da Peixaria. Go to "nós é mais bolos" (we are more about cakes), drink portuguese cider Somersby and buy organic in quinta do arneiro.

Trendy, cool, delicious!!!. This market place is funky, modern, super chilled and cool! The food choices are plentiful, the wine is cheap and very good and the whole place just feels so trendy! Make sure you make time to eat here at least once..... it's busy (you may struggle to find a seat - we did at around 8pm on a Wednesday) and the seating is at long communal benches. This is honestly one of the coolest things we did whilst in Lisbon. It's not expensive and portion sizes are great! It's walking distance from the Baixa area. Be sure to go and see it yourself. Dress nice and prepare for deliciousness!

A great example how to make a market hall to a streetfood temple. This market hall is a streefood temple . A perfect place for a lunch an the way to or from the atractions in Belim. We tried the great iberico ham with cheese and wine. Than we took at an other place a tapas degustation with 8 different tapas. both of the plates were of highest quality.

Such an excellent idea and a delicious foodie adventure of Lisbon. This food court style market is genius. Having lived in Asia for the last 5 years, I am very familiar with eating in food courts and love them. I believe there is no better way of dining than going out with a group of friends, selecting a handful of dishes and then sampling and sharing food. Lisbon has taken the concept and invited local eateries and restaurants to have market stalls making it possible to have a foodie adventure of the entire city all under one roof.If you visit Lisbon - don't miss this.

Enjoyable. After walking around the building and reading the many menus, we settled on a restaurant and had a very good dinner of octopus salad and braised pork cheeks. Great spot for people watching too.

This is a Must in Lisbon. This place needs to be on the Must visit list of your Lisbon trip. The market is in Cais de Sodre just opposite the metro stop and ferry terminal. Tram no 15 passes by here as well. The market is divided into two parts. One part sells fresh vegetables and fish whisky the other has cooked food, (various stalls) all freshly prepared, cocktails, port, wine and santini ice cream. You can get a drink or food or both and relax and enjoy!

Top of the foodie to do list for Lisbon. Excellent food, easy to get to, great atmosphere, amazing wine, did I mention great food? Tried the chicken from a 'stall' that says 'chicken all around' and it was great, and the crepes for desert were very tasty. Tip of the day: The bock beer experience, where you get to pull your own beer.

Great place to visit. Lovely food and wine stalls. Great way to see loads of things and try them. Staff really helpful answering questions.
Bought some lovely sausages, wine and olive oil to take home. Well worth a visit.

ALL in ONE place. This is the best way to get a taste of everything Lisbon has to offer in cuisine The top Portuguese chefs have a bit of their menus available, and it is reasonably priced considering the quality. I dare you to walk through and NOT try something.

Fun spot to go with friends. A great place for a casual meal in the best food court I've ever seen. It's become a hot spot for families in the daytime and adults in the evening. I was there twice in the middle of the afternoon and it was hard to find a seat, so it must be crazy at mealtimes!

Dining with a market twist, very good quality!. Event dining, good choice, amazing quality! Try the black squid ink risotto!!!! Nice for a night out with friends or business. Could have eaten everything... also nice deserts, port wines, gift shops, even plants! Don't miss it if you are in the city!!!

Great place to go and have a glace of wine and some typical portuguese snacks. The Mercado da Ribeira is an old food market (main food market in lisbon - open in 1892) which, since 2014 had added inside a group of restaurants, most of them with traditional portuguese cuisine and snacks (a type of portuguese tapas). The food market during daytime and the restaurants are open from 10 am to 12 pm (from sunday to thursday) or 2 am (from tuesday to saturday).I love it! I went with two friends and is was full of people, from portugal and many other countries. On weekends it gets really, full specially after 8.30 pm).It has a central court with long tables where you can go and take your food or you can stay in a restaurant. Because I love to try everything, I prefer get the food first and then eat at the central court.

Great place for lunch . The fish burgers here were delicious. The black bread they are served on compliments the fish. Although beware a lot of places in here only take cash. The chocolate cake was also delicious do shop around and take your pick . Whilst sat there one place was delivering frozen food to there establishment. So take your time and be choosy where you eat. I would recommend here for lunch.

a find!. an amazing place for breakfast, lunch and (no frills)dinner.clean, bar-style or communal tables seating with numerous gastronomic options literally around you. some high end restaurants represented as well as smaller cookeries and a few bars, including the wine bars. very reasonable prices and as a rule, an excellent food quality. portions more of petiscos size but that makes it possible to try food from more than one food stall. overall, a very positive experience.

Nice place. Good food.. I liked the place. Uniform design, good food. I ate at the Asian lab and i loved the food. I liked the idea of having so many choices of restaurants in one place. The food is ready fast.
Funky foodhall. Totally unexpected from the outside appearance of the building. Great choice of dining options. Definitely going back!

Most affordable and efficient way to experience Lisbon's cuisine. If you don't mind perusing multiple menus before dining, elbowing your way into lines at each restaurant, or sitting next to total strangers, this can be a really fun and cost-effective place to have dinner. It's kind of like having a bunch of tapas restaurants all under one roof. You can pick and choose items at stalls from some of the city's best chefs at a fraction of the price and enjoy some great beverages at reasonable prices as well.My favorites were Chef Alexandre Silva for cod and gazpacho and Manteigaria Silva for various meats and cheeses. Try some gingingha while you're there too--you don't have to go to Obidos to enjoy it!Everything we tried was delicious, but the desserts were a bit disappointing, so I would go elsewhere if you have a sweet tooth.
Easy and quality food. Fantastic quality, fresh food and for a very reasonable price! Always easy to have a big selection with all sorts to choose from. Highly recommend a stop here

Foodie paradise!. If you're a foodie, this is a top destination. Everything has the same branding so you base your decisions on what looks, smells and sounds good. With the highest of standards of chef's we spent an afternoon here drinking great wine, trying ginja, and hopping from Portuguese to Asian to Italian. Would highly recommend the mozzarella stand - to die for!

So good we came back - 3 times!. Stumbled upon it our first night, although we had heard good things and had a fantastic meal and loved the open plan space, the variety of foods available and the convivial atmosphere. So good, we came back for lunch the next day and for dinner again. Definitely worth a visit!
Super location, clean and great idea. What a great place to duck in for a quick snack/brunch/full evening dinner and drinks. I was certainly not expecting this right in the center of town!

Fantastic place to visit . We visited the food market once on our trip and wish we had gone back again. Absolutely lovely food and so much choice. Beautiful long tables to sit and eat, bars down the middle to have a drink. I would definitely recommend the steak sandwich and the hand made chocolates were beautiful.

Great food and atmosphere. Had a blast at Prego da Peixaria booth. The bolo do caco is simply amazing as well as the maionese the manjericão. Don´t forget to try the Santini ice creams, one of the best in my opinion and head to Vida Portuguesa to buy some interesting and different souvenirs.

Lots of flavours and atmosphere. Market was recommanded by local friend and it's a recommandation I'd like to pass on. Great for lunch and diner, lots of choice and atmosphere. It can be busy so you might have to wait for an empty seat.

Good idea, not a good experience. This sounds like a wonderful idea - so many different food experiences to choose from under one roof. Unfortunately, it's very badly designed. The food court is huge, with long tables all the way down the middle. Hundreds of people were eating there when we arrived. The noise was deafening, here weren't nearly enough chairs, and people were almost fighting for somewhere to sit down. We managed to find enough space that we could at least at least put our plastic plates down, but couldn't get seats - even though we were standing next to a family who had finished eating, but just grinned at us and continued to sit and watch us the whole time we were eating. In such a busy place, someone should make sure that people move on when they've finished and let other people sit down. We'd picked what claimed to be a very well-respected fish restaurant outlet to buy our meal from, and it really wasn't very nice - the chips were hard, the fish seriously undercooked and everything was cold. The only good things were that the wine wasn't terrible and it was all very cheap. Not cheap enough for us to want to return, though. We were glad to leave.

One word "awesome!". Wow, it's a delight to visit with small booths around the edge of the building each serving a different kind of food, from tapas to traditional Portuguese food.There was plenty of choice, reasonably priced and good quality. For drinks I recommend the Superbock stand different types of beer and who knew that they did so many types!Great night with benches to sit at, as a tip get a seat first then order your food, difficult if you are on your own!Fantastic and well worth a visit!

Great food market. Everything about this food market is really good! The decoration, the environments are very nice. Most importantly the foods are super nice here with so many variety of choices and almost all of them are so delicious and serve very fast. We came back here 3 days in a row for our lunches. Great seafood. A must visit in Lisbon.

Love this place . This market is absolutely fantastic, with so much variety on offer and excellent quality. It's reasonably priced too - e.g. a 30cl beer cost just EUR 1.60.Can't believe that one reviewer not too far down from this review decided to rate the entire market negatively because the cake from one stand was poor. Get a grip! Might as well rank the entire city 3 stars because that one lemon cake was poor.

Go eat and drink here while in Lisbon!. This market is fantastic! It's in a huge building that houses many food stalls, and also has a flower and produce market. There is tons of seating and food choices for all appetites: seafood, meat, sandwiches, salad, pasta, desserts and ethnic foods, plus loads of beer, wine and coffee choices. There is plenty of seating so you don't have to eat standing up. Fun atmosphere and great selection. We ate here twice in one day!

Super Bock and food court. The food court at the Mercado da Ribeira is worth the visit, the food market is not. The food court has a considerable selection of eats and drinks. The Super Bock table is an essential stop!

Superb venue and choices. Read a few positive articles about the market and was not let down. Situated off the centre of Lisbon the market offers several of the city’s best and well known restaurants all in one place. It can be incredibly busy, particularly at night so be prepared to have a fight for a seat! Lots of options both food and drink wise which just means you have to visit more than once! Definitely worth a visit for some good food.
Impossível to seat. Good food But impossible to seat. Their System is not working. I recommend not to go! You will Be Walking With your food on tour Hand for 1hour

Try it........you may not go elsewhere again. We stayed for 3 nights in Lisbon and came back here each night - that says it all. Great concept, wide choice of food to suit kids, teenagers and adults alike. Cocktails, wine and 'the best chocolate cake in the world' all sampled with delight. everyone town/city should have one of these

so much good food i can't make up my mind. so lucky i found this by accident on our last day in lisbon. It's been so long since I''ve been in a food court i was so excited. I had loads of orange juice (the orange juice is lisbon is amazing, everywhere) a few slices of margarita pizza, an actopus and potato salad. My husaband had the pad thai. and for dessert we had cake. All was yummy. Wish we had known about it sooner. Could have gone there more for our meals. There are also other stalls sellling flowers and theres one selling canned sardines in vintage can. i bought a few. too cool!

Don't eat anywhere in Lisbon but HERE!!. When I visit new cities, I like to try new places, but I'm sorry, I couldn't help but come back to Mercado da Ribeira for 2 lunches and 3 dinners during my 4 nights in Lisbon. It reminded me of London and the Gold Coast with the upscale indoor food markets. You can bring the whole family to the one place and try out a new cuisine every night. Make sure you buy a meal from a different place for each visit. I never got bored, and the quality was beyond excellent. Such a random find, so I'm glad my friend recommended me here! Not too far from the water also, but feels hidden once you come across it. Will recommend all my friends to come here also :)

Awesome place. So much variety, real great vibe with people from all walks of life. Lots of great food and some great portuguese kitchens with young innovative chefs, and everything is really fresh. A must see for anyone who loves food and is visiting Lisbon....

Great place to spend some hours and gain some kilo's. I wish I had something similar in my hometown with such affordable prices. All sorts of great food tents. Don't miss the fried calamari at Monte Mar, nor the pasteis de nata at the tent behind it.

Unexpected treasure. This was a lunch recommendation by a guy working at our hostel and it really didn't disappoint. The food was fantastic with great selections of wine and very reasonable prices.
I would definitely recommend!

Best food in Lisbon. I dont say this lightly, but this may be the best food in all of Lisbon. The timeout magazine was our go to on our three day visit and it did not disappoint. While there is not a ton of Lisbonia food here, it was simply very good food. There were lots of vendors, so I recommend going more tapas style, but you really cant go wrong with any of the booths. Over two and a half days, I must have tried 3/4ths of them and they were excellent. Its also extremely well located. My wife and I followed up dinner with drinks by the water. Its also right on the metro and for the younger crowd in the middle of a great nightlife district. You will not be disappointed if you spend a dinner here.

Cakes were aweful. Came for a quick snack and bought lemon meringue pie and apparently "the best sponge cake in the world" from Nos e mais bolos. It was horrific.I do plenty of baking and expect good quality cakes. The so called best sponge cake in the world tasted like paste and the lemon meringue pie was too sweet and the pastry was underbaked. Lovely presentation but it was such a waste of €7. Just avoid.

better than borough market in london. the variety of food is great, good prices and great variety. so far, had sushi, ham, cheese, and am now going to have oysters and champagne. a clean, buzzing experience. am skipping breakfast at the hotel tomlrrow morning. london needs to wake up to what streetfood really is.

Do not miss the steak tartar! . Amazing food at all the stalls worth easily spending a day there with an empty stomach! Affordable food from the best of Lisbon's food scene and talented chefs. Do not miss the steak tartar or the croquettes!

Great vibe, food and shopping!. What a nice place! Great during the day for a coffee, fresh squeezed juice, ice cream etc. The A Vida Portuguesa concession has a great selection of items, check that out. A great selection of eateries for casual and informal lunches and evening meals. Be careful, if you get in too late it can be very hard to find a table for large groups, but the nature of the marketplace means the turnover is pretty quick so smaller groups or couples should be able to get seated! Highly recommended.

Eat and shop. We arrived here not knowing what to expect. We were very impressed with what we saw and what we purchased to eat later at our apartment. Very interesting space with shops on the perimeter and eating within the middle. So many interesting choices of cuisine and food. Plus, you can purchase fresh stuff to take home. The bathrooms were super clean. No lineups and easy to navigate and figure out what you wanted. We could see why this place was packed when we arrived. Very close to Cais do Sodré station.

Something for Everyone!. Visited here on a recommendation from the Guardian travel pages and were not disappointed. A great opportunity to try a variety of different cuisines and allow everyone to choose what suits them. A range of different stalls offered everything from sushi to Portuguese specialities and the octopus I had was probably the culinary highlight of my first visit to Lisbon. Particularly enjoyed the opportunity to wander round making our choices with a cocktail or a glass of wine, however there were also plenty of families with young children eating so the venue caters for everyone. Highly recommended.

Mercado do Ribeira. A nice variety of restaurants you can order all sorts of food and drinks.Fish chicken tapas tasty Portuguese food.Long tables and seats you can sit any place you want.Keep it mind it's super crowded between 8-10 at night.The only negative thing about its quite expensive for the amount of food you get.

Excellent choices, great atmpsphere. Loved it here, such a fantastic place with loads of food choices, plenty of seating for all and a great atmosphere. We loved our pizza and ice tea from Pizza e Pezzi, good value, nice staff and very tasty and fresh. Nice that you can be in a group and people can enjoy different cuisines whilst still sitting together.

Amazing. 1. Different corners providing different types of food
2. I have been there both for dinners and lunch, and tasted different foods, most of them were tasty
3. The issue is that it is hard to find place to sit. So you take your plate and walk until tou find a place.

I can't get enough of you ... :). Do you know this song? :) this is what came to my mind when I decided to write a review about this place. First: great selection of food. If you are hedonist like us... this is heaven for you :) we ate lunch (pork+ strawberry cake) and at the night we came back for dinner ( seafood at the side of the market+strawberry cake again)You can buy great wines great food and whatever younlike to eat or drinkDo not miss!!!

Brilliant. Arrived on Saturday into Lisbon, hungry and tired…I know of this place by friends who live in Lisbon.One of the best food courts I have been too, tried various establishments and all was very good, too much to write about each one but I fully recommend, there must be something, even for the most fussy eater.Need to go more than once!Need something like this in UK!!!

Sea Me in Good Hall. This place is a great place to eat. The atmosphere is amazing in the afternoon. Very buzzy, people from all over the world and the range of foods available is staggering. We are at the Sea Me concession. We had oysters, scallops in curry and mango tartar and octopus in black ink batter. Delicious, fresh as you like and served in a great atmosphere. Well worth a detour.

Plenty of choice - It would appear that you get a beer included in the price in most of the eateries. We went to the food court on a Wednesday afternoon about 12.30 and it was quite busy, by 13.00 it was very busy. I ordered fish and chips with home made tartare sauce, while my husband ordered Thai green curry. My fish was delicious but the chips were a let down so I went to another counter and ordered rustic style potato wedges which went better with my battered seabass. As for my husband's Thai curry there was only chicken and rice. On the whole well priced but could be better!

A very cool concept. A fun experience. There are loads of restaurants to choose from and the whole place looks and feels very trendy and fun. Portions are very small at most places so it's not cheap but it's not too expensive either and it's really fun to walk around and check out all the different menus.

Good food.. This is a place to eat in not to look at (although it looks great). Number one point of interest for foodies when coming to Lisbon. Save 2 hours and try to taste food from at least 3 restaurants (you may seat at one table and bring food from many counters). May be very crowdy.

good selection but select carefully. Tried a few vendors and although most were friendly and the food good it does vary depending which place you go. The seating situation can also be an experience during lunch so if you are a couple walk around and pick the places you are going to try an have the other person save your seats. We had some rude locals who told us to move down so they could accommodate their party. Any seat in that area they pounced on it even if others were waiting.Anyway the food was good and fresh but one of the stores 'Chef Miguel Laffan' the place that sells chicken in the corner has to learn some customer service. We were told they were not ready for us and to come back in 10 minutes even though a number of their workers were absolutely doing nothing. Most of the other stores at this point were open and ready to do business. When I came back and placed my order the cashier was rude and indifferent. The food itself was good so no complaints there but they definitely need to have some additional front end training.
Great family dining experience. Great experience. Amazing variety and quality of food. Great way to sample many different types of food and drink. Good for family with many different tastes.

Outstanding in every way. Possibly one of the most exciting food destinations I've ever been to. Dozens of individual mini-restaurants occupying a converted market building next to Cais do Sodre station. Loud, buzzing, energised atmosphere that makes every visit feel special. Terrifically diverse food & drink options on a quite breath-taking scale - from lovely traditional Portuguese & local staples through to adventurous global fusion and beyond. In a seven night stay we came back three times - which given how good the Lisbon dining scene has become is quite telling. Feels like a concept that could go global, given the right city and the right crowd.....Well done Time Out!

Amazing Seafood - great value, worth the wait. Loads of places to eat here. We sat outside in a seafood restaurant on the left corner of the market. We had garlic prawns & clams in wine to start followed by a seafood platter containing lobster, mussels clams, crab etc. With a fair amount of good Portuguese green wine it was €40 per head which considering the quality and it's a European Capital city is amazing value. We didn't book and it was hard work getting a table and the staff were a little slow, all completely forgivable once the food and wine arrived. Other places inside the market look good serving a range of Portuguese food (not just fish). Worth going just for the spectacle, but I bet you end up eating even if that's not the plan!

Excellent place for anyone that likes food or beer. This market is a must for any person that wants great food, drinks and a good vibe. Try a range of traditional and other types of food any enjoy the scenery. Get there early to find a place to sit! Loved it!

Makes me Proud!!. Great place to enjoy a huge diversity of quality products sided by one of the most traditional markets of Lisbon.Great selection of producers, chef's, bartenders.... a must in Lisbon.
Foodie heaven. Excellent selection of local food, at tapas or full meal size. Every possible type of food and clear information.

Some many great Food Choices. This place has some of the best food in Lisbon under one roof. We tried a little bit of something from a few different stalls to get. Long communal tables, great food, get there early to avoid crowds, and most places take cash.

Casual upscale dining. Great way to try a lot of what Lisbon has to offer. It's an upmarket food court and we had lunch here. The beer stand was lovely, wifi worked welł, and it's perfect for a casual dining experience. It's sponsored by TimeOut so it has that hipster-live-like-a-local vibe.
Make sure you turn up hungry. Fantastic food market in Lisbon with plenty of food and drink to choose from and a great atmosphere.

More calories!. Both a restaurant and an attraction - this place includes some excellent specimens of Portugese and international food!Some of the shops offer a "Tapas" tasting dish with a variety of dishes ranging from seafood to beef, pork and even a specialization in Tartar!Just be sure to get a seat before you order as it was quite crowded.

Loved this Place! Great food choices and fun atmosphere.. I stumbled upon this place my first nice and went back on my last. So many food choices I wasn't really sure where to start. It has a fun vibrant atmosphere and dishes that will please almost everyone.
Great place. everyone who loves great food-especially sea food,but not only,should go there!!!!also u can have really nice wine or different types of drinks!!!!amazing atmosphere!!!!
Favourite Lisbon attraction. I went twice in 3 days in Lisbon so that really says everything. Great selection, fantastic quality, buzzing atmosphere, reasonable prices... can't recommend enough.
go go go!. great food, nice atmosphere. Cant wait to return! Try everything, we were never disappointed! Not to miss.

Amazing Experience. Great food! Great Atmosphere! A must visit! A fellow traveller told us about this place and we just had to visit it. We were so impressed the first time, we went there 3 times during our 4 day stay. Definitely recommend this to everyone and I will be going back the next time I'm in Lisbon.
You must eat here. Amazing food and brilliant atmosphere. Easy to eat each course with a new chef. A brilliant place any time. Will be going back again.

"The" place to eat. OMG! This is amazing...
If you really enjoy great food, just spend a couple of hours exploring and tasting everything you can.
Seafood, wines, jamon iberico, you name it.
All the best food in Lisbon in one place. A Can't miss thing!! Just go, you won't regret it! Remember to try Cafe De Sao Bento's signaturen steak! Amazing!

Delicious food and a cool hangout place. THE place to eat in Lisbon no matter if it's lunch, dinner or between. Also has a great vibe so if you want to have a break from the old city and have a snack/desert/drink this is the place for you. Our kids also enjoyed it. Don't miss it on your lisbon visit! Seafood dishes at Monte Mar were great, also the humburger place and and the drinks we had.

Nice, cool inviting place.... I remember 3 years ago when this place was under construction. Now it is a super place to chill out and have cocktails, food or ice cream. I really like the energy and vibe of this place. The food, wine and sangria are yummy too.Just what Lisbon needed!!!

THE place to eat if you fancy a bit of everything.. Fantastic contemporary covered foodmarket with stalls with excellent freshly prepared food, ranging from traditional Portuguese food to fish, to hip Burgers, sweets stalls to meatlovers paradise. Stalls are grouped around a central sqaure with seats and tables. Very clean! Not really cheap but definately worth it. Eventhough just outside citty centre it seems everybody finds it..locals and tourists alike.

Great seafood rice at Azul restaurant. We found this the most appealing of the food stalls that had seating available when we walked around. Our seafood rice was excellent and was made without salt as requested. We also enjoyed some excellent thin hand cut chips and the cover included dark jamon and garlic bread which was very tasty. We enjoyed our meal very much.
Fabulous!. Tuna tartar from Tartar-ia. Was a masterpiece- so brilliantly executed and so delicious! Easy for all family members to find something delicious to eat. Five stars!!

Super fantastic dining experience. Time Out have produced a brilliant eating experience offering a wide variety of local cuisine and drink in a lively and exciting environment. With over 35 businesses offering non-expensive food, including some lovely sweet options, bars for beer, wine, cocktails, etc., there is surely something for everyone. We went three times and on each occasion it was packed with a very lively (and quite loud) atmosphere. It does get very busy so you wouldn't go here for a quiet meal and as a result, it can take some time to find some seats. But we got some drinks on arrival, took some time walking around the hall looking for our preferences (different places for starters and mains on some occassions) and then found some seats while the food was being prepared.The Mercado da Ribeira offers a fun and not expensive eating experience - one of the best I've experienced in many years. We will definitely be visiting again when we are next in Lisbon and I would recommend this to anyone who's into good food in a great atmosphere.

Amazing food experience in huge market hall ! . What a great place near the Cais do Sodré !! Amazing young Portuguese chefs provide you with a mix between traditional Portuguese and modern international food. Even if you are not hungry you have to go there simply to experience the great atmosphere in this huge market hall ! A must do in Lisbon !

Great Food, Lots of Choice, Fantastic for Kids. We ate here 3 times during our 10 day trip - it was fantastic. Great for a family - something for everyone. High quality food. Space for the little ones to walk around and stretch their legs. Also a playground right outside. It is also perfect to stop here after taking the train to the beach and back, if you are staying in this Area. Great way to end a long beach day.

Duck for two, sweetness down your soul. Strange to think that we survived so many years without Mercado da Ribeira : by day a traditional covered market with Portuguese bounties, at night until 2 a:m from Thursday to Saturday an extraordinary hub of tall wooden tables, for teenagers to seniors alike, sugar pies and witches, rappers and suits. Lined with eating stalls and specials from every corner of the country, at more than affordable, salivating prices. A glass of champagne. A "pato as bras" (duck Ribeira style) for two. Make your day. Pay and wait, 8 minutes for the duck, until your buzzer starts twinkling and steal the show. Have coffee in the special area. A little sugar in your bowl, some seetness down your soul, as suggests Nina Simone. And make your evening unforgettable just walking in the nearby street, brand new painted magenta pink...

Eclectic but still truly Portuguese. Very good tapas market. Excellent for a light dinner or aperitif. You can definitively find something for everyone, and still have a good taste of the local cuisine. I would recommend tempura bacalao, Porto and chocolate brownie at Miguel Castro e Silva, bacalao with chickpea purée at Enrique sa Pessoa and fried potatoes at Pao pao.

What a great idea to have so many great restaurants in one place. This place is a great find as one can find many great restaurants offering top notch cuisine at really great prices. I really recommend going a few times to try the different places.

Outstanding!. Without a doubt this is one of the best places in Lisbon. Basically it is a huge hall filled with food stalls. Grab yourself an area to sit down at (you may have to jiggle seats around), leave somebody to guard your seats (it is a very popular place), and go off and order what you want, food and drinks-wise, from the dozens of stalls that fill the hall.
good food and atmosphere. Indoor food market has a great food and drink selection and offers a place to seat, eat and hang out.

Don't miss the fun . Time Out magazine really has upscaled a traditional meat-fish-produce market into a lively hip foodie place! Top chefs of Lisbon each have a booth where you can sit on stools and watch them prepare your meal. Or you can take it to the vast central eating area. Something for everyone. And buy up a sample of cheeses and cured meats they'll vacuum pack for the plane so when you get home you can invite all your friends over for a Portuguese wine and cheese party!
fantastic place. In the middle of Lisbon we have found a fantastic place with great food and terrific people. Highly recommended.

Go here now !! If not immediately ! . Soo cool - basically a huge food hall with funky music - quality drinks at a brilliant price point ! So much choice !! Great for singles family's or even couples ! There's so much choice it's hard to decide ! Caught a uber there for €3 .. I enjoyed this experience better than any local restaurant ! * I ordered the octopus and mash dish and also the beef and potatoes from the vendor in the corner (next to the chicken bbq place) it's was amazing !!! Highly recommended - sorry I can't remember the name of the vendor . Have a great night

Seat hunting does not make for a great food court. My Lady and I visited Time Out Mercado da Ribeira. The food court is too crowded. Every seat is either occupied or being saved for someone in line buying food. This environment forced us to eat at one of the ‘restaurants’ outside the food court that had a few seats for its patrons. To purchase food and have no place to seat down and eat it is a ‘poor’ environment to us. Perhaps adding some seating on a platform above the current court might alleviate the congestion.

Excellent concept. I was happy to find this place across the park close to the apartment I am staying in. Good selection of food, especially like their sushi. Anyway all is good. The only challenge may be to find a seat at crowded times. Perhaps they should reserve small tables where people can stand for eating instead of walking around with the plate and trying to find a seat. It seams that some people first reserve a seat then get to order and start waiting their meal for fifteen minutes or more while others who already got their meal could finish.

Loved it. After traveling throughout Portugal for three week I did not want to see another plate of sardines or bacalao. The venue has something for everyone with a vast choice of kiosk type restaurants.

Spoiled for choice. Best to get here early as this popular eating place gets very busy by 9pm and then it can be hard to find a seat. Every variety of food is available from local specialities to Thai and Japanese so it can be difficult to choose. I had a great salad of Portuguese ham and melted cheese with figs, the best salad I have tasted in Lisbon, and an excellent duck risotto. Both were reasonably priced and we had excellent wine for just 2 euros a glass. No good for an intimate meal but great for people watching and a fun place to hang out with friends.

If in Lisbon, You Have To Go to the Mercado da Ribeira!. I read about this Mercado and decided to go check it out. My goodness, this is such a wonderful place. It has a food court with over 30 stalls. I can't call it a "food court" because in the US, food court connotates fast and subpar food. Not this place. This is like a fine dining food court. It was so hard for us to decide which stalls to try. We ended up trying 2 stalls: Monte Mar and Henrique Sa Pessoa. We ordered the mussels at Monte Mar and it came out steaming hot with beautiful tomato and onion sauce. The mussels were beautifully cooked; meaning it was not overcooked. They were sweet and so good. We ended up getting an additional order because my son basically didn't give us a chance to eat the first order. :-) At Henrique Sa Pessoa, we ordered baby bass tartare with avocado, mango and salmon roe and also 24 hour confit suckling pig with sweet potato puree. The baby bass tartare is what you would get at a 5 star restaurant; it's beautifully presented. Did I say this was from a food court? Then the piece de resistance. OMG, the suckling pig was SO GOOD! My husband and I pigged out!! Ha! I wish they have one of these food court in Houston. I would eat there every day and try different stalls every day. This is ingenious! Can you tell how much we love this place. I wish we stayed in Lisbon longer so that we can go back to this Mercado!
HIp, trendy and tasty!. Great selection from numerous chefs. A great way to sample local cuisine without feeling intimidated.

Only for tourists. If you want a noisy crowded schoolyard with hundreds of tourists fighting for a place in a common table to eat casual-fast food served in plastic plates and prized as Michelin stars, this is your place. If you want modern and high quality food, go to the real restaurants, not to their market 2 m2 simulation. Or just go to any of the traditional small coffees all along the city and taste the dish of the day. They are excellent and, most of all, real, not a tourism attraction for well intentioned but misled visitors.
If you are a foodie, you will love this place. Extensive choice of food, range of prices, busy place with locals and tourists. In Lisbon this is a must.

Excellent food, great choice, great value!. Me and my husband are quite picky when it comes to food. This place has everything that you could possibly be looking for. Gourmet little portions will make you discover local products at their best.
Visited in June 2015. Amazing concept all family member can eat different type of food all are so good will visit soon if I go back must visit time out 😄👍

A must if you love food and drink!. The perfect place to get an idea of Portuguese food and Lisbon restaurants. Lots of small outlets, most linked to fab restaurants all over Lisbon , sell fantastic food to sample. In addition you get a great selection af wines and some speciality food shops. In the halls next door is also a fruit and veg market.

We ate here 3 times. This was a really fun place to people watch and to eat. We ate one meal at a seafood counter while watching them prepare the food. Another meal we sat in the center amongst the throngs of people. I wish my city had this!

Pleasantly Surprised. My friend and I went here on our last night and were happily shocked at what we found. This place is filled with restaurants that provide some outstanding food for a pretty reasonable cost. The environment and atmosphere of the place was something that I hadn't experienced before. The caliber of food that is turned out at such a rapid pace is pretty amazing. The only slight issue I had was attempting to find a seat. There are a couple of signs that say please find a seat after you receive your food (or something close to that). But that's not really possible nor do people pay attention to it. If you go there with a group of 2 or more, find a seat first and then order your food in waves. Otherwise you might be eating standing up. Besides that, the environment is lively, the food is great, and you can drink wine/beer/sangria in what is basically a food court ... What else can you ask for.

A food market with a difference!. This indoor food market with its extremely varied choice of restaurants and informal eating atmosphere really had the “wow” factor for us. You can choose to eat at a host of long wooden benches and choose from the numerous eateries surrounding them or you can chow down “tapas style” at the seafood counters. It sums up everything I love about European markets – they are not just places to buy produce but to meet, socialise and enjoy good food too. This one was reminiscent of one I went to in Budapest. A few of the kiosk-style restaurants are run by well-known chefs and we decided to try different foods from a couple of these. Husby went for a gourmet burger which was thick, meaty and very flavoursome. I had always wanted to try a Francesinha (a stacked meat, sausage and melted cheese sandwich floating in a meaty, spicy sauce with a fried egg on top – yes, a heart attack on a plate and forget the diet!) with chips and it was awesome, an explosion of flavour and the chips were really good too. I struggled to finish it all and husby was happy to oblige! This place is for anyone who loves informal dining, from simply grabbing a bottle of wine from one of the kiosks and sitting down with some cheese, bread and sardines to trying out one of the well-presented, chef prepared dishes. Good stuff!

Great food, great night out. The mercado da ribeira is a great place to go out at night for a versatile dinner and a great time with friends or loved ones. Great dynamics, very lively and a huge selection of great flavours. Highly recommended

Good place for lunch. Went there for lunch during our time in Lisbon. The market is similar to a food court - you have 4 walls with various vendors and rows of tables in the middle. All vendors are very different and offer a range of foodstuffs from traditional Portuguese fare to sushi and everything in between. Both times the food was very good, considering you end up paying <10 euro per person. Highly recommend.
Worth a visit. I really like the atmosphere at this place and there is a huge range of food on offer. The croquetería is particularly good, as are the various cake places.
Great ambiance. Lots of selections . Love this place. Lots of food selections. Go before 7pm to avoid the crowd. Wish there were more English on the menu or pictures showing the dishes.

Cool place to eat!. This market is next to fresh food and flower market. We wanted to go there too but liked the Time Out part so much we never made it over there! There are 20-30 stalls of restaurants around the perimeter of this space and each one looks more interesting than the last. There is a huge variety of food from sushi to croquettes, ice cream, cake, organic, and the prices might be higher than average in Portugal, but having just left Switzerland, they looked like a bargain. We had some amazing ha, cheese, bread, and wine at one of the Silva Places. I wish we had a place like this in our town.

great for the entire family - love the quality, variety and the prices. I'm not sure how someone can compare this to a for court at a shopping mall or claim that it's expensive because it's not. Basically, it may look like a high end food court but the caliber of the establishments serving the food is high quality. In fact, several of the best chefs in Lisbon such as Alexandre Silva, Henrique Sá Pessoa, Miguel Castro Silva, to name a few, have a presence here. These chefs have expensive restaurants throughout the city but offer the same high quality food for less at Ribeira Market. We each tried at least 2-3 different places every time we visited and haven't had a bad meal yet!Since there are so many choices, you don't have to pay top dollar for a meal, unless you want to. You can have tapas for as low as 4 Euro or Pizza for 2 Euro or a great tuna dish with Cozinha da Felicidadfor 9 Euro and the wine choice is spectacular!! The best part is, if you are traveling with a family of picky eaters, this is one place where everyone can find something to suit their taste buds. It may not be the fanciest ambiance (but it's definitely not bad) but the quality of the food, the prices and the variety make this a must if you are traveling with a family and want to experience the local cuisine.

Great atmosphere. A little overpriced spot where in the past was an old market. Very open space with good food and music but gets a little crowded.Average plate might be around 7-9€ but there are cheaper options like the "Pizza a Pezzi" which serves square pizza slices that are 2.50-3.50€ each.Any beer (stout or wheat or lager) was €2.50 in the center area in the Super Bock stand.Great atmosphere.

Great choice. I would say you can eat like a local here, but I think that the prices are slightly inflated. If you are in the area it is definitely worth a visit though. A nice buzz and a good selection of foods.

Great food with so much choice. Lovely old market place with ample choice of Portugeuse and world foods. Great taste at low prices. Is self service environment but means have loads of choice. Fun atmosphere with loads of sharing tables. Been twice in one day and will certainly be back as open until late every day. Well worth a stop.(Had black risotto with scallops, steak and egg, gelato, charcuterie)

Always Enjoy Coming Here.. Not sure why there are some negative reviews. To each his own. Have been here a few times and it seldom disappoints. Though my recent visit here I felt as if the portions got smaller. While the cost remained the same. But this is part of the experience as you can always venture to another store front and order another meal. Allowing you to sample a variety. Do like the open space and communal seating. Allows you to meet others and get into the spirit of the place. Not all the best chefs of Lisboa are represented here. And that shouldn't be expected. It simply allows you to try many curated dishes in one space. This is hardly a food court experience and the reference to McDonalds is a bit hyperbolic.

Fantastic spot to sample local cuisine. Great spot in a converted market in Lisbon by the waterfront. Seating and a beer station in the centre, stalls around the edge grouped into types of cuisine makes for a great opportunity to sample some of Lisbon's more interesting restaurants. I particularly enjoyed the croquette stand - delicious, fresh croquettes, including cuttlefish and game options.

Great food. We had great fun at the market. There was a great buzz and the place was busy. Lots of choice. Our food was excellent and we could see lots of satisfied looks around us as people tried their different dishes from different stalls. Good prices too. A lot of tourists but plenty of locals too. We tried a similar place in Madrid but it was too chaotic whereas Mercado da Ribeira is busy without being manic. There were always places to sit at a table. And the stalls give you an electronic device to let you know when your food is ready to collect (yes, they make it fresh to order). Definitely a "must see" for lunch in Lisbon.

Dinner on the town. . What a wonderful open market. There are 30 or 40 small restaurants to sample. If you are looking for fish, ham, Portuguese specialities or just a great hamburger, this market is a great place to dine and be seen. We sat next to teenagers from Switzerland, a couple from Germany, and tables full of locals. We had a wonderful time.

This Market is Worth a Visit. Saw this market on Andrew Zimmern's 'Bizarre Foods' and thought we'd give it a try while in Lisbon. We were not disappointed... good variety of selections for our family of five to choose from. There's a fresh food market (it was closed when we were there) and stores upstairs selling Portugal goods. Prices did not seem too high and we especially liked the central beverage self serve station where you can pour a Super Bock Original for €1,60, a Super Bock Stout for €2,50 or a Munich Dunkelberger for €3. Don't miss the ham at Manteigaria Silva.

Like a Food Court in any American Shopping Mall. If you've been to the Mercado on the Ramblas in Barcelona skip this one. I guess it's nice for the local folks to have a place like this but there's nothing unique about it for tourists. We went thinking we were going to be able to have a little something here and there sampling the food from the city's better restaurants. Everything was new, nothing in the place looked authentic Lisbon, it could have been in Cherry Hill, NJ. If you traveling with children and need to control costs and quantities this place may be a bonus. Otherwise wait 'till you get to Barcelona.

Disappointing. Have been to many versions of this market througout the world and this one just doesn't get it right. Saw from some reviews that it was over-priced and touristy, but it was a rainy day and thought it would be a good place to wander around for a bit. Very sorry I wasted my time and money. If you are looking for a place where all the restaurant staff speak English and you want familiar foods (i.e. hamburgers, noodles), or don't mind paying double what you would for meal in a decent local restaurant, then this is the place. Additiionally, the seating is uncomfortable (high wooden stools) and the hard edges on them and the tables don't exactly make it a place where you just want to sit back and enjoy a leisurely meal. Lisbon is filled with so many great little restaurants that it just seems like a wasted opportunity to eat here.
Disney World for Food. The better Mc Donald's. For people with money. If you like this kind of place you might enjoy it. I did not.
Good food!. awesome food...it has something for everyone, as well as just drinks if you are not hungry. The food is gourmet worthy and well made. I ate at chicken all around...very tasty!

The way all markets could be. Lovely bright open space enclosed by a variety of places to eat, drink and be merry. We ate food from three different stalls and bought our wine from a fourth (this was especially good value - €17 for a bottle of crisp alvarinho, €5 deposit for the wine bucket which I reinvested in a glass of the strawberry and juniper berry sangria on offer). My guess is that you could buy gifts here (€1200 bottle of 1937 port, anyone?) but it's more one half a place to eat and socialise, the other half a market proper with fruit, veg etc. Very good variety and the building itself is gorgeous from the outside. Nice traditional tiling visible in places

Dozens of good bistros. As you can see on the pics it's a gastro market. Small bistros, different cuisines, from sushi to burgers or portugal food. You go there and can't decide what to eat... you want all!We had 2 starters, a glass of wine, 10 EURs. Don't plan a romantic lunch or dinner, it's crowded, you have to look hard for seats, but nice atmosphere, vibrating, friendly and good food.
perfect. . everything is sublime at the mercado- food, drink, location, price and atmosphere. we visited three times during our trip to Lisbon and loved it each time. not to be missed!

Don't miss, something for everybody. Happy and busy. Hundreds of options. We ate at Marlene Vieira's stall; grilled octopussy and a tasting menu (5 diff.). Great flavours and good value for money.Don't come here in case you don't like a lot of people or you feel ancxious when there is too many options.

Great food in a fun atmosphere. For those of you who have not visited, this is kind of like an American food court on steroids. The restaurants are great - several by famous Lisbon chefs or small branches of famous restaurants in Lisbon. It's great fun to walk by all the restaurants, reading menus, checking out the food as it comes out. There is also a small store that sells exclusively Portuguese items - and if you get there early enough, you can walk through the Mercado and see the food, fish, etc.We enjoyed it so much, we ate three lunches there in our 5 days in Lisbon.If you are looking for a very reasonable lunch, where everyone in your party can order exactly the food they want, it's definitely worth checking out.

Fantastic market in Lisbon!. Fantastic place to explore! Easy to walk here from the city center, only about 15 minutes alonside the river, lovely walk. You have so many options to eat and drink, it is hard to decide really. You definitely will be going back several times, while in Lisbon, because you just have to try as many dishes as possible :) Do try AZUL, the oysters and seafood there is the best!

Fantastic experience! . We went here for lunch at around 2pm on a Sunday and it was absolutely rammed! This is a real experience, if you love your food and your drink and are in a group of people you can't go wrong.Each stall has something different to offer, you can easily get carried away, so go hungry! It's a thumbs up from me :)
Excellent point. excellent pointthis market there is a variety of locations for a diverse tasting all to eat in Portugal . The place has beautiful people and quality food and drink

Lisbon Must-Do!. The Mercado is close to the water, centrally located. The food hall is superb, and offers a wide variety of food. We were there for lunch on a Friday and managed to find somewhere to sit; members of our party went back on Saturday evening and struggled a bit. However, the food is fantastic and we were able to try a range of things from pizza to prego rolls to seafood to smoothies. Lovely atmosphere and a great way to get an idea of Portuguese cuisine.

Great food at Henrique. We loved it. Very busy and crowded..a great place to feed people with varying tastes. It is not cheap but the variety made it fun. We ended up sitting next to friendly people and enjoyed ourselves immensely.

Expensive and not so authentic. We visited recently. It was a nice area with lots of restaurant near the market. However, the food quality is not very outstanding (you can easily found better alternative in Lisbon. But the price is very expensive. Very touristy!

Great location for dinner. Definitely recommend this place if you are looking to sample a variety of foods. A little difficult if you can't speak Portuguese, but still managed to try some tasty options

Great Place for Lunch. We ate here three times over the course of our week stay in Lisbon. I liked trying all the different foods and there was a huge selection. The wine was reasonably priced. It has a festive atmosphere and free wifi. I highly recommend a meal at the market.

Visit the local produce section. We wandered past here early in our week in Lisbon and had a drink in the newer food hall section. So many choices for food and drink. But make sure you go to the market stalls in the morning - that is, the local produce section. This area closes (I think) around 2pm so visit in the morning. We bought amazing salmon steaks as well as fresh vegetables, fruit and freshly made bread - a large meal for 4 of us for under 20 Euro. If you have cooking facilities where you are staying, defiantly visit the local produce for an amazing meal.
Fab. Good food with lots of choice, good busy atmosphere. Can be daunting to find a table as very busy and sometimes a bit of a squeeze.

Unusual quality dining. This has to be one of the best food courts anywhere. Multiple outlets providing high quality food at very reasonable prices. From pies of piglet to amazing prawns in garlic, it is all of the highest quality, not to mention the best gin & tonic we have ever had! If in Lisbon do not miss.

Time out Central. Thank God for Mercado.Was struggling on the food front in Lisbon as not a great lover of fish.We happened on Mercado by accident and it was like walking into heaven.Beautifully set up market, clean and modern with food stalls catering from basic to food prepared by stalls owned and run by some of Lisbons top chefs.Multiple bars selling everything from beer to the top champagnes.The space is simply relaxing and easy, not something that is easy to find in Lisbon.Nice thing here is you can eat authentic Portugese food or if you prefer the modern spin on authentic Portuguese food, or any other cuisine for that matter.Do yourself a favour, if your feeling a bit frazzled, take a load off and relax here,prices are great to boot. Cheers!!

Lisbon highlight. This wonderful place has just turned a year old and I believe it's a definite place to visit in Lisbon. And old market has been converted into a foodie paradise. Many vendors are set up here and they are all high quality. Every food group is catered for and you can get a great selection of wines and beers. I went here for dinner and had a great burger followed by some Santini gelato.

Excellent food, great ambiance!. Walked here our first night in Lisbon, a little difficult to find but so glad we did. Converted old open market with food for purchase along the outer walls and high tables with grouped seating all in the center (scan be hard to find seats when it is busy). What was surprising is how tasty the food was, and at a price that doesn't hurt your wallet. Enjoyed our meal here even more than at a more famous Lisbon restaurant!

The highlight of our holiday. I struggle to believe that some reviewers have awarded the Mercado fewer than five stars!The Mercardo was set up just over a year ago to rejuvenate an old market area of the city. Many of the city's top restaurants and bars (including two with Michelin stars) have semi-permanent booths at the market. Some offer bar-style seating, but many don't. Where the restaurants don't offer seating, you can take your food to the communal benches in the centre of the market. We ate in the Mercado on several occasions. It is perfect for eating in small groups - everyone can choose to eat dishes from different restaurants. It might be a little stressful to visit the market as a large group as there's no guarantee that you will find seats together. The market is clean and lively, plus has cash machines and free toilets.

Nice local market. We went there in the morning, so unfortunately we were not hungry, but either go there in the morning to see all the locals do their shopping or go there when you are hungry.One part reminds me of "Torvehallerne" in Copenhagen, where you can get delicious food and cakes. Then there is the fish, meat, vegetable and flower market, where the locals shop.

Don't miss it!. Excellent gathering of city's well know restaurants, in a cool and low key place. Good to eat in groups, couples or alone (like I did). Staff keeps the place clean, although most people are careful enough to remove their own treys. One downside: bathroom - at lunchtime on a national holiday - had no toilet paper.

No brainer for lunch. A great place for food in Lisbon and definitely worth a stop. Inside the buzzing market space there are a bunch of restaurants catering to all different desires. Prices are good, service friendly and plenty of space to sit. Some of the restaurants are by some top chefs in Portugal so well worth sampling some of their dishes. We went back here twice as it was a guaranteed good meal and wanted to try more of the dishes as there was so many tasty sounding items to have.

A must-visit!. A clean, spacious food hall beside a local fresh food market, this Mercado should be in everyone's Lisbon travel list. Lots of food options on offer. I especially liked the roast suckling pig and the croquettes. The fresh food market and the surrounding stalls for butchers, fishmongers, etc are also definitely worth checking out.

Foodie fair. In an old market a magazine organized an established show of several restaurants and bars. You buy your food at the counter of your choice and sit like in a cantina. The prices are reasonable and you have Great variety. If you like icecream, Santini's one of a kind.

Great atmos, excellent variety of food & drink. Satisfied a big group of us with a variety of different dietary requirements. The food, drinks and service were excellent and not too pricey and the atmosphere was buzzing. The only complaint is that its quite tricky to get a seat at the tables so move quickly!

I could eat there every day. We went expressly for the food court but we were still surprised by how many wonderful options there were. We finally chose the chicken place and had a fantastic club sandwich and a Mexican chicken salad. This is great place to find great choices.

What a surprise!!!. We arrived in Lisbon very late and we were starving, my beautiful partner already knew of this place, so he said I have a surprise. It was a surprise indeed. We arrived around midnight, the place was buzzing, full of life, people of all nationalities, enjoying food and drink. If you love food and wine, you must check this place out!! Great!! Well done Lisbon!!!
Some great food!. Lots of choice, and some really good food. A little over priced. Nice atmosphere and a great social place.

Food for everyone. Got the metro from town, easy to find. Lots of choice, meant our kids could have chicken and fish with chips while we could choose something more adventurous. Bustling atmosphere, long benches to share so a good way of making friends. One of our Lisbon highlights.

Found by accident. We wandered into this place while walking back to our hotel from the waterfront. We enjoyed the variety of food choices, and tried many small plates of different foods. If you prefer service and a sit-down meal, this is NOT the place for you. Others mentioned the price as a negative. We got plenty of food for $15-20, including drinks. The atmosphere is open and wandering through is easy. Downside- only cash, and most food menus were in Portuguese (obviously) so we had to ask for information about the food rather than just reading the menu.

great variety of food, though a bit expensive. This place is like a food court with great variety of food from sweets to steak.
