As a solo traveller I loved this place as it didn't feel uncomfortable to eat alone. Food quality is great (I visited three times, and tried three different restaurants), though I would say that, on average, the price is quite high. For instance, to eat a main menu with a glass of wine/beer, it is about 13-15 euros. As desserts, I recommend Aloma's egg tarts as I think these are the second best after the ones from Pasteis de Belem. They are quite cheap too (6 euros for one box of 6 eggtarts).

Loved it. Yes it is busy, yes it is in a food market but the food and service was excellent. We started with fried sardines on carob bread - just delicious - and went on to braised tuna with sweet potato and stewed octopus. Quite outstanding and well worth a visit.
Nice place, average quality to price. This is a nice place, but with so many excellent and less expensive restaurants in near neighborhood, the Mercado is not my first choice.

Cool Spot for Food / Drinks. Dropped by before dinner one evening - very cool place with virtually any food or drink option you could ever want. Great spot to hang out and people watch at the very least.

So Many Delicious Choices!. My husband and I visited here more than once during our trip to Lisbon. There were so many options, and we did not have one bad dish. The food was great and the wine was poured generously. Some of my personal favorites were tempura green beans, duck fried rice, and tuna tartar. Definitely worth visiting!

Terrific market food court. Fill your boots! Any number of upmarket food stalls in a renovated indoor market. Order your preferences and sit at one of the long, family style tables. We all ate from one booth with Portuguese specialties: grilled octopus on wilted greens and mashed potatoes, a five mini-course tasting menu, and a green salad with ham and cheese and other tasty bits. Great value... You could easily eat lunch and dinner there for a week without repeating one dish. A real success story frequented by tourists and locals alike.

Lots of choices. We visited three times during our stay in Lisbon. Lots of things to eat and buy here. Highlights include Conserveira de Lisboa with its famous tinned seafood that makes good souvenirs, the soup and octopus rice from Alexandre Silva, and entrecote from Cafe Sao Bento. The piri-piri chicken from Miguel Laffan was dry and not so good, however. The accompanying sweet potato mash was also quite poor and we barely touched it.Do note that while the market opens early, most of the food stalls only start serving food from noon. Many also do not accept credit cards or only accept Portuguese credit cards.

Loved it. Visited this place twice. Got the burger and fries first time. Amazing taste and perfectly cooked. The aioli was the best fries dip I ever had. Had some kind of shrimp "summer rolls" and tempura my second time, which also was amazing. An absolute favorite spot in Lisbon!

Great discovery. I am surprised no one wrote in this market. Perhaps no one went since its restauration. Great place to discover portuguese food, you have more than 20 place to choose from, its a place even locals will hang out to...try it its worth it

Good fun. If you're in Lisbon for a few days this place is worth checking out. It's not far from the centre of town.It's quite a different experience from your normal sit down meal and there is a great atmosphere. If you have a family with very differing taste buds then it's definitely worth a try. Our kids really enjoyed the buzz and option to go different stalls.The food was great — but it didn't feel like the 'best' Lisbon (or Portugal) had to offer as the marketing suggests. Because of space constraints a number of the stalls looked like they relied on 'pre-fabricated' dishes. They also have Santini ice-cream without the massive queues.Couple of notes: 1. You can end up eating at different times if you order from different places.2. I would go fairly early as it can get really busy and finding seats (especially if you are with a large group) can get tricky. Some of the locals were getting a bit tetchy, and would hassle you for your seat, all part of the fun I suppose.

Great place for foodies! Old market environment turned into a trendy place to go for a bite and drink. This market is close to the city center. Next to the old market where you can find all sort of food and stuff Time-out did an incredible job renovation an old and vaste market hall. It looks great, modern and full with light. For hipster, but also for tourists, foodies and young people it is for sure nice to pass by and have a drink or some food. You have like thirty food stall all around the market and some healthy stuff and drinks in the middle. There is a lot of place to sit and watch others doing their thing. Prices are reasonable and yes, there are many people working there and not all very friendly. But that should not stop you enjoying this spot. It's on the way to Belem so a great chance for lunch?

Good Food Great atmosphere. This renovated market is well worth a visit. Great selection of food and drink at a reasonable price. Communal seating, with both locals and tourists enjoying the great atmosphere in upmarket surroundings.

So much to choose from..... Its right next to the metro... Marques de pombal ...doesnt look as sleek but once inside and in the middle of the market house is where the magic stands out. Food magic. very affordable for three dishes. I had tbe bull burger eith roasted wedges (no buns). Sausages. Bread. Hubby had black risotto. Three beers and two beverages. All for 38 euros. definitely a place to visit. Search for stool-like seats where you can sit with your children. There are places with high seats and another with low seats incase you get discouraged with seating ... there is hope for us with kids hahaha!

I'd love to visit it everyday?. I won't say the price is cheap here because you can find really cheap food in Lisbon easily but the price is absolutely reasonable. Considering their quality, I think it is a total bargain! So many different options and dishes to choose from! Definitely my favourite spot in Lisbon and no doubt, I visited it at least once everyday during my trip in Lisbon. If you love food, you can't miss it! You can't easily get food with this standard with the price. Each dish costs around €8-10 in average. My favorite dishes are grilled octopus and black pork cheek! UNBELIEVABLE! ( and you can save service fees!)

something to discover. this place was once in a bad shape but has been renovated in a cool way.You meet - rural people,e.g. the granny buying some fish and vegetables in one part of the building, a place where everybody seems to know everybody else- tourists , in another part of the building, stylish, spacy, fancy ...and TASTY don't miss it,, it's a bit off the center, but very original !
Great food court. This is a great food court with lots of choice, very well priced and great atmosphere. The food quality was excellent.

Food court gone wild. Right in the heart of Lisbon, but easy to overlook. Its a giant food court into the repurposed and still active market. one half is veg and meat and fish and flower market in the mornings, the other half is some of Lisbons finest foods and booze. Collect a favourite dish from one of the 20 or so on offer and reconvene at the common tables in the middle. Great fish, great meat, but also chinese and pizza and ice cream, something for everyone. Its not the best value, you will pay more than in most restaurants, but everyone gets what they want.

great gourmet food hall and market. I visited this market with my friend who had visited before. The market has numerous food outlets varying from Portuguese specialities from celebrity chefs, gourmet burgers, seafood, pasta, fish, meat, tapas, cheese, wine, port, beers etc. Whatever you fancy you will find it here in one of the outlets. The food is excellent quality and you will not be disappointed. Very reasonable prices. Easily reached by exiting Cais de Sodre train or metro station and crossing over the main road.
Great place to visit. My wife and I loved this mercado. Great food, good people and just and all around good atmosphere. Something for everyone and a great place to visit and enjoy. Highly recommend
Outstanding Food Court!. A number of Lisbon's best restaurants have small stands with some of their best dishes accompanied by wines and beer! So many great foods to choose from!April 29,2015

Place where you can eat whatever you like. The name Mercado da Ribeira means Stream Market and as the name indicates is it in a market that during the day sells daily and fresh products and in the evening opens with several bars and restaurants. You have all kind of food and prices. You can eat sushi, hamburgers, pizzas, seafood, fish, cakes, ice-cream. You can drink all kinds of wine, gin and other soft and cocktail drinks. If you go as a group each of you can choose what to eat and seat in the longer tables in the center of the market.

Great choice of food and drink. Visited the market and food hall for lunch one day. Quiet when we were there and very nice to wonder around. Hard to chose which food to have as all the food outlets looked appealing. Good choice of drinks too. Would recommend a visit.

Couldn't get enough of the food!. We came here by chance as a group of 10 guys on a football trip, and so glad we found it. The choice is unbelievable and quality of everything (from Burgers to Pork Cheek to cakes) was top notch. We came back every day. Come here just once at least and you will come back!!

Trendy place with loads of options. This is a place that is easy to go because you'll be able to find something for everybody. The prices aren't cheap but they also aren't expensive!! And you get the chance to experience some different tastes. Have already tried tuna and dried tomatoes croquettes, cuttlefish croquettes for starters and also the salmon burger with cuttlefish in a flat bread from the Madeira Island (bolo do caco) made with ink from the cuttlefish.And there is oh sooooo much more to try... ;)
Night out in Lisbon. We came with a large group from Florida. We had a fantastically experience!! Food was out of this world in this fun and energetic place. Please do not miss this!!

The Most enjoyable part of our holiday in Lisbon. We were told to visit this market by a friend of ours and were so delighted we did. The market is bustling and has a great atmosphere but more importantly the food is amazing and you have so much choice. We are planning a return trip to Lisbon just to spend more time here. Not only can you eat from whichever food stall you like but it is all served on proper plates and with nice cutlery. The seating is comfy but when it gets busy it can be hard to get a table. We sampled some great wines and super cocktails at very good prices. We had dinner here and wished we had gone the first night. An experience not to be missed!!

Amazing place. I wish we had had time to investigate this place for longer, we visited on a Sunday and had the little custard tarts and coffee, and the rediculously cheap price of €4.40 for both of us, and they were fantastic! Sundays seem to get super busy, and so it was very hard to find a table, I found it a bit overwhelming but I would love to go back again and sample some of the fantastic food on offer.

Sting the tastebuds with pleasure . This place blew me away. Dozens of restaurants packed into a converted shed with the myriad of options that one had the consider their options carefully.Or return 5 times during ones visit to Lisbon as we did. I suggest the pork dishes from I believe 'Henirque' and the strawberry crumble with yogurt sorbet! The ceviche starter is bold and refreshing and worth a try. Also, the sorbet is divine from the sorbet stall! We loved almost everything we tried and some of the best meals with have ever encountered!
Always a pleasure to return to this place. So many options of delicious food and quite a laid back vibe. The wines served by the restaurants are always delicious and very affordable. Very nice place.
Wonderful place and food. We tried many dishes, everything was delicious.So far we had the best meal of the trip here.And the market is very beautiful.Highly recommended.

Perfect place for lunch or dinner. Absolutelty really stylish place with so many restaurants, where you can taste various of good prices. I can recommend this place for tourist. Mercado is on my private "top 10" of Lisbon.

Great concept. Creative idea and really fun casual atmosphere. The variety of food choices is vast and most are priced very reasonably. Ate here twice during our stay in Lisbon and would highly recommend a visit!
Good Food. Good food, excellent atmosphere! Lots of different places you can try.There were lots of seating and something for everyone.

Must Visit!. Super cool idea! 40 of Portugals restaurants turned into a trendy stalls in this urban cafeteria style food hall. It was so good we went back second time. It was such a great way to explore Portuguese cuisine! We loved the beer pouring station and the Portuguese rice dishes. Yum!

Brilliant Idea!. I visited there twice with my husband during our 4 day trip in Lisbon. Time Out apparently have done an excellent job transforming this traditional indoor market into a miniature of excellent Lisbon restaurants/shops. It's fun, casual, clean and full of seats.

A must place to eat in Lisbon. A fantastic selection of around 20 quality food vendors in a sophisticated environment. You can get everything from traditional Portugese through to contemporary Thai with great wine to wash it down. Don't miss it.

Should be one in every city. An incredible choice of quality food at very affordable prices. Have a starter, main and dessert from 3 different restaurants. Canteen style tables lend themselves well to solo diners.

Cute market. Adorable market within walking distance of the city center. Reminds me of something you'd find in Brooklyn. The food is pretty high quality, fancy too. Even though it's a cafeteria style, there's really cool food, moderately priced (8-12€ for a meal).I would recommend for a lunch, there are much better restaurants in Lisbon for you to spend a dinner here.
Eat Drink and Relax. Fantastic place - every city should do the same. Great atmosphere and such good value for food and drinks . Great relaxed vibe and a must when in Lisbon

WOW YUMMY! Foodie Heaven. Consider your mind blown when going here. Half is a fresh market, the other half, top chefs chafing up some of the best food in Lisbon. Meats, cheeses, seafood, wine, beer, cocktails bread, desserts, it was an orgy of food. You can't stop eating. We spent 3 hours there. Schedule your time and go here for lunch and take it all in. I was bummed this place didn't come up in our search for restaurants. My wife found it just by seeing it when we passed it on the tram.

100% worth a visit. Stumbled across this food market. Its like a gourmet food court (a little Jamie Oliver-ish). We went once for somewhere to chill out on Saturday night away from the busy street bars full of people. Had a lovely cocktail in Cinco Lounge. The barman was very nice and introduced us to a few of their special cocktails. I'm not a big fan of sweet cocktails but I enjoyed my refreshing gin cocktail with fresh basil and black pepper!Went again for lunch at Sea Me, fresh oysters to die for, tuna sandwich highly highly recommended, a very generous tuna bruschetta. Please give them a try!

Vibrant, alive and fresh.. As a youngster I used to go to this market for hot chocolate after a night out. Then, it was just a market with a cozy and small cafe, which the market traders used, but great after a night out as it used to open at 04.30!!! Had not been back since it re-invented itself into a trendy and vibrant place with various kiosk type food outlets. Wow! The food is excellent and varies from the traditional Portuguese to the best of international cuisine. There is also an excellent wine counter where you get a lesson in Portuguese wines, juice counter, the best ice creams and desserts, the list goes on. It's not cheap but the atmosphere is worth the extra cost. What an amazing place, definitely recommend a visit. Don't rush as you need time to decide what to eat and drink and at busy times there are short queues. Not a place for small children. You could be anywhere in the world as you meet people from all corners of the planet but it is a true Portuguese venue full of delicacies, friendly staff and yummy food. Will be back!
Excellent place to eat in a vibrant atmosphere. Really enjoyed our visit here; lots of choice; good vibe; pleasant people. Would recommend it to anyone visiting Lisbon

Hidden Gem in Lisbon. Good reviews on Tripadvisor and we decided to go. This turns out to be a remarkable evening in our trip.We went there late, all the fresh product stores are closed but we had dinner there.It's a great concept to have different rest under one roof so that you can choose the unique concepts from Lisbon in one go.We had super fresh oysters from "Sea Me"; yummy beef tartar sandwich; seafood pad thai from "Asian Lab" and a perfect "The best sponge cake in the universe" as the finale.Highly recommend to put this in your itin!

Fabulous Concept - try Monte Mar in particular!. My wife and I visited here twice on a recent trip to Lisbon - it's a great concept focusing on quality food and drink with a large number of different outlets under one roof. On our first visit we had sushi and a glass of wine at Sea Me which was great quality and very fresh and tasty. On our second visit we had a full meal at Monte Mar which was excellent. We had clams, octopus rice and grilled king prawns. All of these were excellent as was the service from Mary Jo the chef and Laughlan the waiter/barman. Highly recommended.

Good food and good atmosphere. . We had a great dinner here-there's a good range of different cuisines and the interior was clean and tidy. Nice wooden benches in the centre and it got pretty full so the atmosphere was good. Good value too including the drinks stalls.

The greatest place not on the turistic maps. We accidentaly cam across this place, right outside the Cais do Sodre. We realised it was a market that was already closed(at 7 pm) -mercado do Ribeira. We still entered just to pass through and we had the greatest suprise: on the left hand, with no sign, there was a large hall full of all kind of restaurants you can immagine, all in equal squares. More than 500 people(locals 99%) were siting in tr large hall, having dinner with friends, fammily or just enjoying a glass of wine. The food is excelend and is for all tastes and pockets. I tried the fresh oysters for 2€ each and the shrimps in order to taste some local dish and the nigiri from a japones restaurant. The latter one was average (I paid 10 € for 6 pieces) but the first 2 courses were absolutely delicious. I liked the best the atmosphere: young couples, old couples, families with childrens, friends, all at the same long wood tables having a nice evening. I do recommand to buy a bottle of wine instead of a glass. We had Dalva, by Miguel Castro e Silva and it was one of the finest one we had in Portugal. The bottle was 15€, but one can find cheapest wine or more expensive ones, depending on what kind of a "connoisseur" of Portugal wines are you. We just chose from medium up. Do not miss this one!

Lovely place for a lunch. The venue is a big coverd market were you can buy fresh and simple cooked food from around the world: Portugese, Italian, Indian, Asian, etc. There is a large selections of wines and beers also, different kind of sweets and you can purchase for home a large variety of Portuguese sardines, cheese, jambon or nice quality souvenirs.The atmosphere is great, the concept is similar to Covent Garden in London or San Miguel in Madrid, you can eat, drink and socialize wit other tourists you never met before. The food is very fresh and good quality, not expensive, the wine we tried was excellent.As it is close to Chiado shopping area and near Cais do Sodre Metro station, as it has also the estuar of the river over the road, it may be a wonderful break during the day.Warmely reccommended for people enjoying this kind of happenings.

Fabulous food hall.. Something sorely lacking in the UK, a friend and I stumbled across this high end food hall whilst enjoying a city break in Lisbon. Lots of interesting stalls serving great food, the octopus and rice was divine.

High-end food court. This place is just right opposite the Cais do Sodre railway station and easily within reach by walk from Baixa area. There were quite a number of food stalls here selling different varieties of food. The food court was big and quite crowded. What's good about it is the opening hours, you can still get to eat here very late at night.

Great. Brilliant choice of food, i had an amazing salad and my husband had pizza. Lovely atmosphere with lots going on. They have Ikea high chairs which was a nice suprise; out made me feel like my 8 month old would be welcome. I think I'll go back while we are here.

Great variety, great food. This is a huge food court offering a large variety of dishes, some of them very creatively offered and at very reasonable prices. We had a combination of Portugese (bacalhau), Sushi, Thai (pad thai) and Indian (paratha with cod) food and were delighted with the quality. There were great choices of wine, beer and cocktails too. Would certainly go back.

Great Variety and Space. Have been here several times. Many good options for food in a huge open space. Service is generally quick and attentive. Can eat at one or enjoy several different meals within the Mercardo. Aside from food there are desert stalls as well as wine and other beverages. Wonderful place to relax and sit back after a trip to Belem or anywhere else in Lisboa. Its easy to find just across the Cais do Sodre Metro/Train station.

Fantastic venue. His is a fantastic venue made up of smaller restaurants that lets you experience all varieties of portuguese and international cuisine. Open until 2am on the weekends if you are looking for a late night snack.Close proximaty to pink street to for a fun night out in lisbon.

Good lunch. Stopped here twice for lunch and not disappointed. Tasty sardines on first visit and well cooked and presented pork cheek on the second. No wonder the place was crowded if this is the standard set. Great to wander around the fresh food market and enjoy the sights and smells of something we have lost here in England. Well worth the visit.

Overrated. It's a cool concept of a huge food court with "something for everyone". If you don't mind crowded spaces and average food then you might enjoy it. Lots of tourists, can't imagine what it looks like during the summer. It took a while to find seats for four. But the real issue for us was the food. We tried a few different vendors and the price simply does not justify the quality, or lack of such. We could have gotten much better food for same price (maybe less) at a restaurant, sitting down and with a waiter. Visited it for the experience since there was so much buzz about it. Not planning on going back or recommending it.

fabulous!. This place is right up my street- a large food market and next to it little stalls selling fresh made food at reasonable prices, informal atmosphere, lots of choice. Came here starved after a long day of sight-seeing and had an amazing lunch at Alexandre da Silva's stall - some kind of Japanese soup, fish with soy sprouts and mushrooms and a spectacular chocolate cake with ginger ice-cream. Will definitely come here again.

Great Shopping Center!. Mercado da Ribeira was recommended to us by the owner of the rental we stayed in while in Lisbon. It was about a mile and a half walk from our accommodations but came highly recommended. We were so happy we made the trek, Mercado da Ribeira is a swanky market with a great food court, art and fresh produce and meats. We went right at opening time (10a) and had no problem getting in, having breakfast and purchasing fresh food for our stay. I would highly recommend!

Great choice of food.. Visited this market a couple of times when we visited Lisbon. Great selection of food plenty of choice with reasonable prices also great choices of wine and beer. Lots of long communal tables which are cleared regularly.

Fantastic idea. What a great idea, this is a big covered market with a produce section of the market selling vegetables, fruit, fish, meat etc. but also another big section of the market which has lots of communal long tables with all different food and drink outlets around the outside. The fantastic thing about this idea is that it allows you to try lots of different things, and if you are a family, one of you can get pizza from one place, another person can get sushi from somewhere else, but then you can all sit together in the middle and eat your different dishes. The choice and quality of the food is amazing, noodles, sushi, croquettes, pizza, pretty much everything is available. Also a lot of the outlets have restaurants elsewhere in the city, so it's a great place to go early on in your trip as you can try places out here and if you like the food decide to visit their restaurant, as we did with the Sea Me outlet. We loved it here, it's such a simple, good idea, it's also great because sitting at the big tables in the middle, you can see what others have chosen to eat, and there are lots of "where did you get that from?" moments when you see delicious things others are munching.

If you want a good lunch come here.. I love visiting markets when I travel, and this market is worth visiting. It has the usual fish and vegetable stalls but it also has a large food hall. The food hall has lots of different outlets selling there own menus really great choices of food at reasonable prices, and great choices of wine to wash them down. Its very modern in the hall, rows of wooden tables to sit down on after you've bought your food at the stall. Its situated opposite the main railway station easy to get too and its all indoors.

Great place to go. A traditional market hall converted into a hub for restaurants with communal tables in the centre. Lovely food both Portuguese and international on offer and a range of bars too. Definitely a place to go if you like browsing and trying new foods. I would definitely recommend the macaroons on offer also - delicious

So much choice. What a great concept! The closest I have seen to this is of Chelsea Food Market in New York. There are a total of 35 foods kiosks including, five top chefs who have restaurants in the city. We were spoilt for choice. We opted for spicy pizza slice, fish & chips with a yummy tartar sauce and burger & chips. We also tried a duck turnover and tempura prawns with a creamy curry mayo. All washed down with a few glasses of vino. Whilst we were not necessarily too adventurous with our food choices there were certainly plenty of local Portuguese delights on offer.We will definitely be returning again and would highly recommend it to anyone as it suits all tastes.

Worth a visit. Upon entering this vast old market hall you are taken aback by the hustle & bustle of the place. We had lunch on a Saturday sitting at one of the food stalls, one thing to note in winter months wear a warm coat as can be cold. Our steak meal with the traditional Portugese sauce was out of this world,washed down with some red wine. We popped by again on Saturday evening just for a drink and the atmosphere was amazing with the centre floor space given over to the locals doing the tango to some fado music. Unfortunatly on our next visit on Sunday things went downhill for us. We were taking some pictures(is this not what tourists do?) and the owner (I presume) of the hamburger outlet took exception to this and told us to stop. We saw no signs in the building pointing this out. I then went on to have some sushi from the stand next to the hamburger stall and within two hours I was taken ill with food poisoning which meant having to spend the rest of my stay in Lisbon confined to bed which ruined our holiday. Now back home I am still off work with the illness.

Delicious Fresh Food. The concept behind this place is just pure genius, you get a wide variety of top restaurants and all cooking fresh and delicious food. You can find anything you crave at this place from Burgers to Sea Food. A couple of great places for fresh juices and mouth watering desserts.

Paradise for food lovers ! Well worth a visit !. By chance we saw reviews in Trip Advisor otherwise we would have walked by here without realizing what was inside! It is a large warehouse building with more than 30 different restaurant kitchens and an unbelievable choice.Everything from local fish to Portuguese pork sandwiches to scallops and mango chutney to Thai food, tapas, sushi, cheese, top class wines etc. Right next door to the dining hall is a fresh produce market. I would go back every day and try something new.

A lot of Hype!. We came here after seeing an article on the Guardian boasting that this was one of the ten best places to eat in Lisbon. What a disappointment! Apart from the fact that it is supposed to have regional Portuguese cuisine, so what are sushi, pizzas , hamburgers etc doing there? I think roughly only 50 % of the cuisine was regional. The design of the market hall was very cool but at the same time soulless, very pretentious and quite expensive for the experience we had. We went to a kiosk that had a variety of croquettes and although they were quite good, some of them were cold when they should have been served hot.Then we went to another kiosk and I ordered some grilled sausages and pineapple skewers and again they were lukewarm but this time I complained and I was given some more with no much enthusiasm from the staff. The sausages were a touch too hard with a strong flavour, together with a strange unidentifiable sausage/pate which I found weird and unpleasant. The thing I enjoyed most was the grilled pineapple! I wonder if the place has always served this kind of food or when they opened not so long ago it was more dedicated to regional Portuguese cuisine? By the way the best thing was a slice of a margherita pizza. If you want to eat authentic Portuguese food head towards the Alfama district. The food is so good and the prices are so cheap that they make you feel embarrassed.

Excellent Concept. Loved this place visited a few times during our stay at various times of the day, the food and drink places all serve a variety of food for all tastes and it was such a pleasure to sit,eat and relax amongst locals and tourists alike hearing many languages.

Something fresh for everyone. With over 30 stalls to choose from, there is something fresh for everyone to enjoy. Fish, pork, gin and cocktails. It's a bit chilly so dress warm and if you go in the evening be prepared to wait for a spot. It was an excellent introduction to Portuguese cuisine and was clean, spacious and friendly. We even returned a second time. If visiting Lisbon do not miss this experience! A tasty new addition to the Lisbon food scene.

Excellent eating location. This is an amazing place to eat in Lisbon. You can try all sorts of different Portuguese cuisine and it also offers other foods i.e. Pizza, hamburgers for those who are more picky. There are several stalls from famous Portuguese chefs at reasonable prices i.e. 10 euro for an evening meal. The place is very clean with long shared tables running down the centre. I ate here for three meals over my trip and thoroughly enjoyed all of them - would highly recommend!

Lunchtime favourite. Such a great place to have lunch - and everyone knows it! Around 3pm on a Saturday the place was packed with people from different countries. You can get a really nice traditional Portuguese meal with local wine with only a little over 10 euros. Really relaxed feeling and great service.

Really good.. This one is highly recommended. Indeed, tiny bit crowdy, but that's ok. How some locals say, the best what Lisbon can offer under one roof. First of all was tiny bit skeptical, but when I saw dishes of others and tried mine - pleasantly suprised. Not very expensive, wide variety and vibrant atmosphere.

Great idea!. We were staying very close to this in our apartment and enjoyed eating there twice on our stay in Lisbon.A large, refurbished market hall with wooden bench tables, high stools and chairs. There are over 30 different counters to selling food and drinks around the room of a very high quality..Try the wonderful ham and cheese platter with a glass of wine from Manteigraria Silva to start. Very good.When we were there in January it was busy with locals which is always a good sign. It can be a little cold in there in January as it has large open doors and the wooden seats get a bit uncomfortable after a few hours. Would love to see some soft seating in the centre. The shop A Vida Portuguesa has a small shop there which was good as the one in Chiado was shut for renovation. Great shop. Well worth finding the big store in Intendente in an old tile factory. If you like Anthropologie, it has a very similar feel. Beautiful items all made in Portugal to take home as gifts.

An up market food court with artisan flavour. I visited here twice on a weekend to Lisbon. Every small food outlet has a specialty e.g. the organic salad bar where all ingredients are grown/made by the owners or the charcoal bread specialty burgers at the burger unit. Something for everyone here at reasonable prices. Very busy at the weekend though. A top tip is to have a scarf with you to 'claim seats' so that you can look around at the stalls but not lose your place. Also the metro stops just outside.

When In Lisbon...Do Stop By. Okay okay, it depends on what you're looking for as to how you may feel about this place. I stopped by for a small bite and a glass of wine. The range of choices is huge, and the seating allows for relaxed eating, chatting with friends, and good people watching. When in Lisbon, do stop by.

Fantastic upmarket food concept!. Fabulous! Very well refurbished area in the old market at the river. The best chefs, restaurants and tastes of Portugal all in one spot! Nicely done and clean! Well done! A must-see/ taste while in Lisbon....

Great food and shops, all under one roof!. We went to the market to sample local food and drink, and had a great surprise! Huge selction of foods and drink to try and buy, plus the added luxury of sitting in a nice open, friendly atmosphere.There is also a A Vida Portuguesa shop in here, with quality products, at good prices and friendly, knowledgeable staff. Great place to visit.......

A showcase of Lisbon's best chefs, wines, and Ginga. From the outside its an unassuming looking food market. Inside a showcase of local food in upscale "quick" food presentation with fantastic choices of wine. Modern safe setting makes it comfortable to purchase quality products as well.Great for lunch and across the street from major transportation station by the water.

Best oysters and tuna tartare in Lisbon. This repurposed market is decked out with a dozen or so local vendors _ including stars like SeaMe Seafood _ and every one we tried (including the pizza) was so good we came back for the New Year's Eve party. A great way to eat and drink a la carte at high-end picnic tables with a nice communal vibe most any time of day.

Dry Red Wine with a Smile!. My grown son & I were on our annual road trip - this time in Lisbon.I spotted the market by the harbor, and I thought that it might be likeBarcelona's Mercado w/some food stalls. It's actually split in half with the market in one half & the new food hall on the other side.We ate lunch at Marlene Vieria where they offered menu of the day as well as small plates. Everything including the wine was offered with a smile. Returned another day in the evening to buy gifts and found the hall somewhat chilly and a bit empty BUT come spring - it will be packedwith people once the word spreads.

So many options so little time. This is a great option for a daily lunch, if you are in the area, great way to try many of Lisbon's famous restaurants without worrying whether or not the restaurant is open. Also a great option to buy charcuterie, cheese, and other goodies for a picnic. If you don't want to go over to the Conserveira for tinned fish, there's an outpost here. Right across is a delicious fermented veggies vendor. Wash it down with fantastic juice blends (in the center). Can't make it to the Sea Me restaurant in Bairro Alto? There's an outpost here.

Gourmet Food, for good money !. Great food of your choice, anything really, enjoy lunch, dinner and happy hour, any time just stop there and grab a bite! Try the hot salad at Favorita ! Best atmosphere ever!

Amazing find!. This place is a hidden gem - not visible from the street apart from the neon Timeout sign - we ate at Alexandre Silva - delicious burger and even more delicious desserts. We also had scallops at Sea Me and sushi beside the pizza place...wine and coffee at other outlets in there - it's a fab concept where you can eat from any outlet and sit anywhere. Maybe not the best option for a large group and requires a bit of coordination, but it's so cheap and tasty! It also allows you to sample food from some pretty full restaurants...many of the chefs also run restaurants elsewhere in Lisbon. Great atmosphere - Go!

Looks great but mixed quality. The Mercado looks great and offers a wide range of options however once it is busy the experience ends up a bit like a big food hall. It takes a couple of visits to pick out the better offers which can lead to some disappointments. Good if you want to eat early or are in a hurry otherwise stick to the restaurants on the hill above for quality dining.

Loved it. Go to Cozinha da Felicidade for food.. We went to this food hall after reading about it. WOW. It had a really buzzy atmosphere. We managed to get seats at the Cozinha da Felicidade kitchen and the food just blew us away. the price was minimal too. Absolutely FANTASTIC.We even bought some goods from a stall in the Mercado too.

a market to visit. This market is divided into two sections - good shopping and good tasting! You just can't go wrong with visiting it! Great food everywhere at reasonable prices, and friendly people!

Quite a mix of traditional and non traditional portuguese food. If you want to try a bunch of different things, this is the place to do it. But expect to pay more than you normally would in other spots.
The "Prego de Atum em bolo do cacao de Alfarroba" (tuna sandwich) from SEA ME is a must.

Fabulous, unexpected food!. Found it once, visited twice during our three days in Lisboa. There are several difference cuisine selections to pick from. You want to try a little something from each stall. Beautiful, large tables for family style dining. Trendy, upbeat atmosphere. Simply the best for foodies because everything is right at your fingertips. You get off of that without breaking the bank. We ate + drinks for 18€ total. Enjoy!

Not your average food court. The food court has a great selection of stands/ restaurants providing a wonderfully varied seletion of Portuguese food, wines and beer. It gets busy at peak times, but the rotation of sitting space is fast enough that you won't wait long. Will definitely go back.

Lisbon is getting trendy. this place is really a gain for Lisbon. Good food. Good atmosphere. Good varaity of small restaurants. I had both dinner and lunch there. The service in the two small restaurants i tried was in the top.The whole setting is very cool.

Lisbon at its most trendy. The food court here is fantastic. I was surprised to see it practically deserted on Saturday lunch time, but we came back again in the evening and the place was crowded. It's a great place to wander around, as you can sample bits and pieces from some of Lisbon's top restaurants without committing to a full sit down meal. My only criticism would be that the price in the market seems a lot higher than other places in the city, but you do get what you pay for and absolutely everything we ate was fresh and of the highest quality.

Definetely want to check the food court out.. I was in the pub when my friends told me they went to this food court, It sounded really good and thought that it would definitely be worth checking out. We went to the food court and it was actually sick.Ollie Ball

Wonderful!. We were so lucky to stumble into this place - I was looking for a farmers market - the one here is pretty meh, but then we noticed the side of the market that's all done up with restaurants. We ate here three different times while in Lisbon - I'm not even kidding. There were so many places we wanted to try. We had so many great meals here - and sample gin and tonics, ginja, beer, cheese - really we just ate our way through here, repeatedly. It's a great option for a fun night out.

Entertainment, atmosphere, incredible choice!. Four of us visited the food court on a Saturday night before heading out to the Jazz Club. It was a great start to the evening! Don't go here if you want an intimate night out - the building is huge and has an industrial feel to it, but it's a very contemporary atmosphere with a great buzz. All the food stores are round the edge, cooking a variety of fresh, tasty food to cater to all tastes, including the more discerning ( the choice includes: burgers, Asian, Italian, seafood, crepes, waffles, ices, cocktails, fine wines) You sit on stools in the centre round long, high tables. We thought we'd never find a seat - it looked so crowded, but we needn't have worried. Take your time choosing your food first, it's such a pleasure - and you're bound to find somewhere to sit - even on a Saturday night. It's a great venue for everyone as the choice is huge - families with young children, teens, couples, solos - it's a social food experience! Enjoy!

A must when visiting Lisbon. The locals only start arriving for dinner after 21:00. Great atmosphere, many of the the top chefs in Lisbon have opened satellite stalls in Mercado da Ribeira so its a great way to try local produce and high end meals at a reasonable price. It is a great way to start the night prior to going out for drinks.

Eat something from the best chefs in a very nice atmosphere. This place results from the recovery of one off the most important markets in Lisbon where the small commerciants gets fresh fruits, vegetables, ... to sale later on their shopping places. After this recent recovery half of the building keeps their original purpose and the other starts one of the most fascinating activity in a space like this, allowing people to choose what they want to eat from the best chefs in a common space, i.e. you can chose to eat from one place and your friend from another and you can seat in the same table. Tables are in the middle of the space with the drinking (wine, beer, gin, cocktails ...) where restaurants are around this area. Try to split the meal with colleagues in order to taste as much as possible keeping in mind that "Prego de Atum em bolo do caco de Alfarroba" and "Almondegas de Salmão com choco" from SEA ME is a must.For the desert take the "Melhor bolo de chocolate do Mundo" or the ice cream from Santini. Enjoy!

Really cool. An old market refurbished now reunites some of the best restaurantes / food places in Lisbon. A place to visit and have a wine, a fresh juice, a nice cocktail and try some really good portuguese food. I strongly recommend Sea Me (the vieiras with mango chutney) and the chocolate cake from Arcadia, but everything I tried there is delicious. Keep in mind it's not the most comfortable place (no table service) and may get really crowded and noise sometimes. If possible, avoid weekends.

NOT TO BE MISSED!!!! Like, 4 real!!!. We plan this trip to Lisbon for many reasons. First because we have a friend that´s from there and he was bragging big time about his hometown. Second because I have already been there and I totally loved it, but big time. And third because it was meant to happen. I mean, I write, for fun and for profession. I had to write an article about an interesting capital in Europe and Lisbon, along with Zurich, was the option that I loved the most.The article is done, very well done if I must say. I´m humble and down to earth, but I am also able to acknowledge the fact that a paper is well done when is that way, you know, because I wrote it with passion and with lots of love, also, I was so grateful with life for taking me there, I was totally ready for this trip. Third time in Lisbon and felt like it was the first one. Such an awesome place, such kind happy people there being nice and welcoming, all capitals in the world should be inhabited by this kind of people, you know, the kind that make you love their city even more, the kind that make your trip an even better experience and turn something that could have been very nice to a very beautiful and unforgettable memory. This trip to Lisbon is one never to be forgotten.lately I have been using Airbnb for all my stays, I´m kinda addicted to it, it´s so efficient. You end up staying at a house (or an apartment of course) of someone that really lives there and see and experience the place you visit starting with the fact that the place you go to bed to and wake up in is not a hotel, made to be liked and enjoyed by anyone, but in a space that some considers its home, an actual inhabited space, built and decorated with the heart and dedication of the person that gets to enjoy it on the regular basis. That makes a huge difference. So we chose a handful of options and gave it to our Lisbon born friend to choose the area and place. he settled with a very peculiar apartment that resembled a labyrinth with a lot of elements that were familiar to me but also new.You see, I´m an architect (also interior designer), and the huge apartment we stayed in was a gigantic place owned and (obviously) designed by an architect, and probably built as well, because a lot of things looked very hand made, you know what I mean? the idea was perfect, the execution pretty "manual". But all in all it was a great place to stay, perfectly located in Barrio Alto, a neighborhood that´s like Lisbon´s Soho, you know, the place to be. So, we were across this little square with a church and all and the structure of a market seemed in they bottom of the street that was perpendicular to ours, just 100 meters (300 ft) away, very nonchalant and unassuming, just there, as if it had had been there since a very long time (it was just inaugurated on the 1st of january of 1882... No biggie). It turned out this humble quiet place was the Time Out Mercado da Ribeira, a new concept sponsored by the super well known Time Out brand. Very low key but really a wonderful super cool place.Awesome place and cool concept for any kind of food in Lisbon. Yes, this is the new place for foodies. There´s everything you can wish for related to food in Lisbon. Mostly Portuguese stuff but with a few splashes of italian and two or three places for sweets.We had Marlene Vieira, a fantastic Lagareiro Octopus, grilled with a side of spinach and potatoes, plus salad and dessert, with a complementary glass of white wine thank you very much; not the best white wine, but the intention is so noble and the price so affordable that I really donut care. 12 euros for the whole thing and it was more than enough, not the finger food size that you get in Paris in places like the Fish Club, there, Oh God!! They seem to be playing little kitchen, ridiculous amounts of food for a super expensive price, big "no no", meaning "no, don´t go there, with the amount of money you will invest in that place, you could probably buy a round trip to Lisbon from anywhere in Europe, that affordable Lisbon is and that expensive Paris. Although I still love Paris very much and always say "Paris is always a good idea" and "We´ll always have Paris" and stuff. So, you can say I love it very much. But lets focus in Lisbon and this wonderful market, shall we?For dessert we had this amazing Lemon Merengue and these milk and cinnamon like truffles sooooooooooo good. Oh!!! And since I was super duper hungry when I got there, that I went to this place in one of the corners named Croqueteria and got two chicken croquettes, so unbelievably good, super unexpected, like I sorta knew how they would taste, only they tasted like a thousand times better and had this hints of chorizo, only it was only chicken, it was all the work of spices and a mastery in the art of making croquettes. Not an easy task.I´m super stuffed because I just had dinner and my mouth is still watering, can you believe that? Of corse tomorrow waking up I´ll have my 750 mlx of green tea and then I will be off for a run, at least 7 miles, doesn´t matter how cold it is, I need to put this calories off and get ready for my gastronomical adventures in the healthiest way possible. So, in case you find yourself in Lisbon and have no idea what to eat. Narrow your options and go to this super cutting edge atmosphere place, you have a great arrange of options, and if you go with your partner or a group of friends, even better, that way you can all order something different and all taste everything!!!!! Great idea, right? Well, don´t thank me, just book your flight to Lisbon and enjoy the super positive warm attitude of the people in the capital of Portugal and the beautiful city they have built for themselves. they are so lucky... I could totally live there. For real.

Don't Miss When Visiting Lisbon!. Stumbled on this great addition to Lisbon's food scene on a recent visit. After a juicy, delicious suckling pig sandwich from the Leitão da Ribeira stand we were hooked. It is barely open 7 months as of 11/14, and I subsequently learned that even many locals have yet to discover it. We went back several times during our stay, as it is a feast for the senses and offers something for everybody - especially if you have a group, morning, noon and night. Don't miss it.

Loved the food. The huge hall with lots of different small restaurants, some of the finest chefs in Lisbon have a spot here serves their specialties, dream of a foodie! Henrique Sá Pessoa was the favorite. Market hosts 35 kiosks selling regional specialities and great wines. Great place!

Great afternoon yuppie hangout. This is yuppie tourist playground filled with nothing but stands with all types of food and drinks. Cosy lighting and bar-like tables with high chairs and stools create the right atmosphere for a long and unvaried indoor afternoon where a steady flow of Iberian snacks and draft beer slowly but surely degrades the otherwise classy women to a garden of low-hanging fruit you wouldn't find in month full of Sundays - this is exactly what you look for on a drowsy day in Lisbon. Also, the restrooms are kept clean and the place is easily reached by taxi.

The new place for foodies!. I hope the people of tripadvisor read this, so they can change its catogory. It's just rebuild and changed into a great place for foodies! There are about twenty small restaurants/bars, from tapas, to asian cuisine, to fish and of offcourse some local specialties. Don't forget to taste the wine too ;). It's really great, surely a place you wouln't want to mis.

Lunch at Marlene Vieira . The whole concept of the market is brilliant - it is a vibrant and fun place to eat - a wide selection of all kinds of food and drink - we lunched at Marlene's twice - brilliant local dishes - the 5 course tasting menu is perfect for lunch - you really must try here !!

I want this at home... What a veritable feast..Delicious way to show off wonderful produce.Came here for lunch and was back for dinner.Thank you to the lovely owner for her birthday salutations, cup cake and the mouth watering herring tartare..Impressive and bustling.Happy kitchens.Friendly diners.Not expensive.This will become a destination point for every visitor to the city.

Great Example.... ...Of how to rejuvenate an old market. This has been restored and filled with a collection of food outlets and judging by the numbers has been given the thumbs up by local food lovers. Huge choice including spin-offs from noted local restaurants. Just a tad on the pricey side compared with local competition. This and other enterprises are beginning to revive Lisbon's seafront district and is exactly what something like London's Covent Garden Market should be.

A good place to visit and eat. If you are near Cais do Sodré you are a 2 minutes of Mercado da Ribeira. A Market of fresh produts to eat but where you can find na área of restaurants making a square . Young chefs of Cuisine show theur cuisine with a low price and some fun moments.Fresh produts, wines, cakes, Ice cream everything with good quality and in a very friendly way enjoy a meal. You will pay about 12 euros ( 2014) per person for a meal with with coffe, drink and sweet.see more in " time out" who managed the place.

Food Paradise in Portugal . The market place is absolutely stunning. It sits along with the normal food bazaar. However at night it just transforms into a paradise for all foodies. The place houses about 35 kiosks selling all different varieties of foods. I have been eating here for last 4 nights and I haven't been disappointed. All the outlets I have visited serve top quality stuff with very reasonable price than what we get outside. It is a definite must visit place.

Fun place with friends!. Mercado da Ribeira is a high quality food court type setting. Long wooden tables, high ceilings, loud/fun atmosphere - we could have spent the whole night there. Everyone was able to get what they wanted (everything from tuna tartare to croquettes to salmon burgers) and everything was delicious with impeccable presentation.Everything about Lisbon makes me want to go back, and when I do I will definitely return to Mercado de Ribeira for a meal.

Foody Heaven. If you love food and drink this is a must whilst in Lisbon. Right opposite the railway station at Cais de Sodre, blink and you'd miss the entrance! What a fantastic place, grab a pew and a drink from the bar then peruse the many and wonderful food stalls in this atmospheric market hall. A really wonderful atmosphere, we visited on a Sunday afternoon, lots of locals and families - what a shame we can't reproduce something like this is the UK. A great affordable and fun afternoon. Lots of people watching and scrummy food.
Really great concept- lovely food.. One of the highlights of my visit to Lisbon.Amazing food, cocktails. Brilliant concept, just wish it could exist in London!

A new foodie gem!. The Mercado has only been open for a few months and so is not yet overwhelmingly crowded. But it will be! The food stalls represent the best restaurants in Lisbon. It's so easy and fun to sample wonderful food. It's easy to find space to sit in the central atrium. Many places also have exclusive counters on one of the side hallways. And it's open all the time. So, for tourists whose eating schedules are out of synch with those of Portugal, you don't have to worry a restaurant's opening hours.

Great place for lunch. We had Sunday lunch in a charming shellfish restaurant here, but could have eaten whatever we liked from the impressive array of food and drink stalls in this historic market. A must for lunch while in Lisbon.

Great concept!. Great place offering the freshest fish, vegetables of the day and great food court which is what we loved the most! The foods available at the stands range from local seafood to steak sandwiches, burgers, ice creams, delicious cakes ans sweets. Menus are just fabulous! You can mix as much as you want and take from each small shop on your table. Love the concept and the food, not to be missed!

Really wanted to love this place, but its average at best. On the face of it, this appears to be a fantastic concept. Its basically a large warehouse within which sits a market and the central part has been developed into an open seating area centred around several bars with a series of kiosk type restaurants around the outside. It does look fantastic. Started off having a good wander around the place and most of the food outlets had interesting menus. Kicked off, inadvertently, by ordering 3 sliders (thought they were tapas dishes) which comprised green bean tempura; fried fish and onions (almost like jellied eels) and pork cheeks in a light mustard sauce. This ended up being the highlight as all where delicious fillings within a light, swishy, bread bun. Then moved onto the outlet with the longest queue and tried the confit of pork with sweet potato puree. This was a major disappointment as it comprised an average bit of pork belly which had congealed and included lots of sinewy bits. Almost inedible. Missus had the 65 degree egg which was honestly just a bowl of tasteless gloop. When my youngest daughter woke up I took her over to the deli place selling the mixed cheese and meat boards. Both the cheese and meat were a bit of a pile of sweaty mess but didn't taste too bad although were majorly overpriced for 10 euros a pop. All in all, whilst the place looks great the quality of the food isn't too far away from a shopping mall food court. Really felt like I wasted 2 meals worth of food eating here. I recommend you pop into see it but just have a snack or a drink and move on.

Excellent food in a very cool atmosphere!. We discovered this very nice place where you can buy food but where you can also eat wonderful portuguese specialities at a very good price. We loved the atmosphere of that place where tourists and locals go to with friends and families to enjoy a good meal and have a nice vino verde, or sangria, or porto-tonic… We had some excellent fish, seafood, meat with cheese plate, delicious gelato. We enjoyed it so much that we went there a couple of time during our week in Lisboa.
Great place for lunch. Newly revamped food court attached to the market. Great place for lunch from one of many stalls - central seating area so you can mix and match. Also food souvenirs.

What a pleasant surprise!. We found this place by chance today and loved it. It's basically a food court but with nice surroundings and restaurant food instead of McDonald's. We got our food from Asian Lab. Potstickers, beef vindaloo, seafood phad Thai and a beer for €31! We also sampled a local drink called Ginja. We definitely recommend.

Excellent place for lunch. We went for a visit to the market and then came back for lunch. Liked the variety of choice very much. Sat at the bar at one of the places behind the food court and had an excellent lunch. Will definitely go back if we get to Lissabon again.

Bang on!. If you have a passing interest in food than this place is a must see! So well conceived, the layout is inviting with excellent decor and well presented restaurant fronts. The choice of food is wide and encompassing and you'll just about find everything to please anyone, but the focus in on Portuguese food and with so many places putting their own spin and twists on dishes it creates such a wonderful buzz and vibe that you could come back here again and again without it ever feeling tired or mundane. I wish london had an upmarket food eatery like this, you must go!

Sample many foods under one roof. Great concept and good execution! A big, open, airy and high-ceilinged mercado (market) has been renovated. Wood tables and stools in the middle to eat at (sit where you like). Along the sides - lots of little outlets of eateries, each offering different foods, drinks, desserts - self service. Drinks counters everywhere, including a tap-your-own Super Bock stand. Ie everyone in your group can eat what they prefer, sitting together in the middle. Food ranges from Portuguese seafood dishes, to Asian and sushi, to slightly fusion seafood plus desserts.oWe especially enjoyed these: Tartar-la's tuna tartar, Henrico's bacalhau on chickpeas and their couscous salad, Sea Me's seaweed and sea bass salad; and MBD's dessert - brigadeiros (small balls of soft lemon toffee covered with little sweet white squares). A little pricey but worth the experience!

Great Concept.. The Time Out Food Hall is in the Mercado da Ribeira, one of the old seafood markets in Lisbon. Should be listed in Food/restaurants and "things to do" too. Can eat your way around Portugal for a very reasonable price. We loved the concept and so do lots of others. Was very crowded the 2 times we were there. Once for late lunch and once for dinner at 10pm. Easy access from Metro Cais do Sodre. We ate from 6-7 food stalls and never had a bad dish. Everything is Very fresh and made to order. You could eat here daily for weeks without repeating yourself.

If I could go back to one place in Lisbon, this would be it!!!. I don't know why (it is basically a canteen style food court so not the most romantic location) but I just absolutely LOVED this place!!!! Perhaps its the multitude of high quality chefs in one place, using fresh local produce to create amazingly awesome food and the relaxed laid back atmosphere. I had to hold myself back from just going here for every meal after our visit (not something I like to do when away as I like to test as many places as possible). Not only can you and your party select food from multiple vendors and eat together you can get your drinks from another and pick and chose different courses from different chefs as well. No booking, no hassle. We had the Bijous (right at the back of the hall, far right hand side) as there had been positive reviews of these. You can order a taster selection of these mini sandwiches and the fillings are FANbloominTASTIC! I wish I could re-create them at home. Whilst these were the most expensive sandwiches i've ever eaten they were also the best and I look forward to returning if i'm ever in Lisbon again! In the meantime I will simply dream of bijous....

Super! A very good idea, executed in a great way! Cool ambience!. This is relatively new and it was a nice surprise for me to find out when returning to Lisbon after 8 months. You can find everything from traditional Portuguese cuisine, to beers, cocktails, wines etc.all set together in a nicely arranged space of the Market. This is just cool and it deserves a try which I'm sure you will be returning the nest evening like we did! You can have your food or snack from any of the stations plus your drink (a little scientific way of self service) and have a sit on the tables in the middle. We enjoyed the vibe, the liveness and beat of the place! Design rocks! Well done and I wish it keeps attacking people! Surely returning!

One of the culinary highlights of Lisbon. Great choice of all different kind of high standard quality food set in a very attractive location. The perfect place for lunch, brunch or dinner, especially on a rainy day! Love this place!
Simply Awesome.. Great variety of food. We ate here twice during our time in Lisbon. Options for everyone at very reasonable prices. Would love to have a place like this where I live.

super vibe and great experience. The Mercado was 2 minutes from our apartment and is a great place for a drink,snack or full meal.The range of kitchens means that you can have starters fro one chef,mains from another and desserts from a third,together with a variety of bars all at reasonable prices make the mercado a place to go and it is open unitl late

Variety at reasonable prices. Not as varied as the central Market in Madrid but still a very good variety of outlets. We are at Marlene Vieira and found it very good. My wife had duck rice and one of the traditional sandwiches. Tasty all round and good inexpensive wine

I will have to come back here. Great place. Plenty of room to just sit and watch. Many different types of stands where you could pick up food of your choise. Meat and fish, cakes, too. Good selection of wines and a cocktail bar. Not the lowest prices, but not expensive either.

Make time for "Time Out". A 5 min walk from our hotel, we found this market place while exploring Cais do Sodre. The fresh food market houses an eating area "Time Out Lisboa" featuring the best gastronomy experiences Lisbon has to offer - best chefs, best restaurants. It opened in April 2014.This is an annex to the food market which is in an old conserved building. High ceilings, very airy, very clean, lots of seating, visitors will find this place a very positive experience. One of Portugal's best chefs has a counter there - Henrique Sa Pessoa's 'Food Corner'. Henrique came to Singapore showcasing Portuguese wine and cuisine during the World Gourmet Summit in April 2014. We had attended his gourmet dinner. "See Me" is another restaurant represented there.Besides Portuguese food, there were Japanese, Italian, Thai cuisine, fresh seafood, dessert counters as well. We had breakfast and lunch there on different days. It was fantastic. One could buy different plates from the different counters and bring them to the open long tables to eat. The 4 of us had samosas and pastel de bacalhau for breakfast and pad thai for lunch. Mercado da Ribeira is less than 5 mins walk from the train station 'Cais do Sodre', and about 10 mins from the lower station of the 'Elevador da Bica'.Business hours: Sun-Wed 10am to 12mn; Thu-Sat 10am-2am.

"Marlene Vieira" is NOT a chef as you cant eat raw chicken!. Had the 28 euros chef's pick, and it has no flavour, badly presented and the chicken was still raw. Had it replaced, and it was still cold/uncook inside. Well, you can't teach a pig to play chess, so we left. Very disappointing meal and almost sickening. Had some shellfish from the Azul restaurant, and they were lovely.

Professional chef food court!. We have eaten there two nights in a row and may even go back tomorrow! There's so much more we want to try! Tonight I had the blackened pork cheek with mash, gravy and cabbage and it was delicious! (Henrique Pessida) Been travelling for 2 months eating out a lot and this may be the best meal I've had the whole trip. My partner had the Thai green curry from Asian lab, he said it had really good flavours but too much rice. Yesterday I had crispy prawns with basil and curry mayo which were also very good. Great place to go when everyone feels like something different. Restaurant quality food for cheap prices!

Lot of fun!. Had lunch there with my friends. I love the concept because we bought food from three different vendors and it was really great. I went to Sea Me and my friends went to other stalls and then we sat all together and shared the delicacies. No rush, nobody is pushing you to go away and free the place, you can sip your wine at ease….Much better than eating in a restaurant, so many options and they are all good. Lots of desserts to choose from and coffee too. I'll be back.
Great food. Great place to taste different flavors, we ate bacalao, an amazing seard salmon, a wonderful salmon sashimi and a very good wine, we also appreciate the free wifi.

Must try, interesting concept. After arriving in Lisbon, my wife and I were quite tired from the long flight. We decided to walk down to the Mercado da Ribeira for dinner as we heard it was more of a 'market'/casual environment. The market is only about a 10 minute walk from our rented apartment in Chiado. Note the walk there includes a walk down a pretty steep hill. As well, the walk and surrounding areas were quite dark and secluded. Being our first night there we were mindful of our environment. Despite the quiet surroundings, the market itself is quiet bustling. The food was good but I would not consider it a highlight in terms of food. What really stood out for me was the concept, something I'd yet to stumble across at home or my previous travels. It was fine dining in a food court environment. The seating area are wooden benches with accompanying sitting benches or stools. The vendors were fine dining in feel. Chef this and that. Wine glasses in plastic trays and seafood of your choice. Not your usual shopping mall food fair. We ate at Henrique Sá Pessoa. We had the tuna tartar, slow cooked with truffled mash potatoes and a Portuguese style steak and egg. Also a glass of wine. Food was good but I wouldn't call it great. Bill came out to around 30 euros. So not bad value. I think the mercado is a must try. Walk around pick your food and wine. It's a really neat concept.

Loved it; very crowded. Great concept, nice facilities and excellent food. Despite being very crowded, everything had excellent quality. Went for the sushi at Confraria (better than at the restaurant), burger at Honorato and the ice cream of Santini. Recommended

Mercado da Ribeira - paradise for food lovers. This is a truly amazing place if you like food of all kinds. Large warehouse building with more than 30 different restaurant kitchens turning out top quality food of all kinds. Unbelievable choice and great value.Everything from local fish and leat dishes to noodles, sushi, cheese, top class wines etc. Right next door to the dining hall is a fresh produce market. Unique experience - highly recommended and stays open until 3.00am on weekend nights. Don't miss it as part of your Lisbon visit.

Great local market. The news look of that market is very nice. I like that style of shop and desing of shops. You could find there many interesting food restaurants and shop. We bought sardinhas in very nice boxes. I recommend you visit for sure this place.

A fun meal out. This is a funky place to have dinner and has a wide variety of food - from sushi to Portugese prok sandwiches to scallops and mangu chutney to Thai food - all small unique boutique food outlets. Well worth a visit!

Wish we could have come back. I could have walked by here without realizing what was inside! We went for breakfast but I wish were able to stop by again to try out more. Plenty of seating at all the long tables in the middle. The food we got was excellent and super fresh. The quality was apparent and there were a decent amount of choices between all the shops inside.

Great food experience!. I'm sure the locals won't like this expression but this is a great place to go "tapeo" or tapas hopping I'm Lisbon. There are a bunch of great food stalks here along with creative bar tending and good wine that will get you through a good meal. According to the staff, weekends can be crazy, but somehow that can work with tapas!

Great option for lunch - cheap, quick, delicious!. Lots of different food to try - very good quality and reasonably priced: 6-12 euros for a meal. All the "stalls" sell beer and wine, but there is also a wine stall for more choice.We ate there twice. Great for a tasty, quick lunch. Good mix of locals and tourists. Wish there was somewhere like this near where I work!

Asian sensation in Asian Lab. Everything has been said in other reviews about the vibe, buzz and business of this food market – but when you go here, pay attention to the team in the Asian Lab booth: They make an outstanding pad thai with chicken that you can enjoy from bar stools while studying team work looking like time-lapse on speed.

Exceptional food. Cozinha de Felicidade in the food hall quite simply served us the best meal I've had for years. Totally stunning and recommend it! Black pork cheek with sweet potato was superb as was the goats cheese salad with honey ice cream.

Loved this place, go on an empty stomach!. The hall consists of little private food stalls, all Michelin star worthy and all very affordable. About 7-10 euros for a main meal. Each place also has a list of wines and craft beers. In the middle of the hall are rows of wooden benches. We wandering around to each place, reading each item on the menus before making a second lap and had to sit. We couldn't decide what to get. From modern Portuguese, to tapas, to seafood and meat dishes, it took us 3 laps before finally deciding.24 hour slow roasted pork on a bed of pumpkin purée and greens, with a glass of wine was possibly the best meal of my Europe trip so far and only set me back 11.50 euros....the same dish and presentation usually costing €25+ anywhere else. If I was in lisbon longer, I would go back every day and try something new. It caters for all diets and has a great atmosphere! Opens at 3 pm and was not busy so an ideal time and place for lunch!

Loved it!. Loved this place, a great way to sample some of the most popular restaurants in Lisbon. We actually preferred eating here than going to the restaurant itself. There is so many to choose from, plenty of seating and really friendly staff. It has a really relaxed laidback atmosphere.

Modern ancient Market!. Very beatiful brand new market. It has an old atmosphere with a lot of different small restaurants. Most famous Portugueses chefs are here. Weekends are always full. I enjoyed a lot a famous rosted "Leitão"(pork) of the chef Herinque Sá Pessoa.

Great choice of food. We have now eaten several times at this place, and enjoyed each and every meal. Yes, it is busy, yes, it is noisy - but that is what it is all about. If you don't like the concept then stay away, but we will be back. Asian, sushi all great and will be trying others while we are still in Lisbon.This is Portugal - a warm, friendly and courteous country and one which in we feel very comfortable, and the market is an extension of this.
Options everywhere. Tons of vendors to pick from. I walked around before deciding on what to eat. I went with a prego sandwich from O Prego and it was delicious.

excellent place to eat. This place should be listed under restaurants really, not shopping. The food hall is the main reason to come, for lunch or dinner, great wines, excellent choices of food cooked to order, great buzzing atmosphere. We ate here twice as it was so good. Its not been open long, go now before it gets into the guide books, as it might get too busy then!

Great food court !. I really enjoyed the food court ! You have a lot of different stalls so a lot to choose from. The food was very tasty and the place is quite nice to stay in. It is like a big canteen so it is very noisy and there is no actual service, but if you like this kind of place, you should definitely try Mercado da Ribeira ( similar to Le Marché des Enfants Rouges in Paris or the Markthalle Neun in Berlin).It is quite a busy place so there is a bit of waiting but it's worth it.

A must see in Lisbon. Mercado da Ribeira is a must visit if you even remotely like food. We stumbled on it by accident as it has only been open since May 2014, but wow, the variety of cuisine is mouth watering. Perfect for lunch are the many tapas restaurants with wonderful takes on traditional Portugese dishes. Highly recommended to taste the main dishes from one of the 5 chefs restaurants. Prices are more than reasonable for such high quality food. Best time for lunch is after 14hrs and dinner around 20hrs. The atmosphere is casual, lively and exciting.

Just awesome. . Was here several days for the atmosphere of a nice big food market, and the option just go nextdoor for a huge genuine fresch grocery market with local fruits. There is many ways to have a snac or a meal here, jump from one store to the other. AndI do have to recommend tl try the pizza slices, probably the best ones I have ever had, and finish with a nice espresso and a sorbet de limão. Magnificent!
Fantastic place to eat. This ia really what I was looking for, great food, local people and lots of atmosphere! Just love it! Will recommend this to all of you traveling to Lisabon.

Chef Vitor Claro Bijous. Must try the Bijous, portuguese gourmet sandwiches with local and fresh ingredients, from Chef Vitor Claro, one of the best Lisbon Chef's. End with Berlim Bijous, the perfect dessert.

Go here for snacks and drinks. Great place to go for a drink and a bite to eat. All sorts of food available! Dont expect this and dont compare this with a lunch in a restaurant. This is very good and fresh food for reasonable prices. If you are not at the busiest time of the day you can pick your food and drinks pretty quick and its nice sharing at the large tables! I would recommend this place!

Not bad, not outstanding. I've been here two or three times and honestly, with all the fuss about it, I was expecting more. You have a lot of variety but I find it suits only a very specific public. Of course, it has a very trendy atmosphere and it is interesting to see people from all ages and social groups.If you go in busy hours you'll have a hard time finding a place to sit and you'll have to wait in mildly long lines for most restaurants and then for drinks.It's somewhere I recommend going once, so you have the experience, but most restaurants you can find in other much better locations.

Sea Me and Asian Lab they do not take foreign CC!!. Both of these restaurants stalls serve good food.Sea Me is much better that the big Sea Me Restaurants and we enjoyed a good salmon salad, Deep fried shrimps and Oyster Rockefeller with a good bottle of wine. Recommendable. Asian Lab. Good Pha Thai and a good spicy Curry Chicken. We will try their other restaurant Sushi Café.I requested a side soya sauce and a Phrik chi fa, พริกชี้ฟ้า, and got it after some discussion!!! Why do they not take foreign credit cards? In a tourist area!! That is very questionable indeed.

not worth tracking down. Seen earlier reviews so decided to try it for lunch. For a self-service restaurant in Portugal it is overpriced, and you need to join the queues for whichever stall you pick.This takes considerable time pushing through the crowds to see what is on offer before you can select your food . The cheapest from any of the stalls was 8 Euros plus. This would be considerably more than in England I would suggest, and somewhat surprised it was so very busy-and noisy. You have to hunt to try and find a gap in the benches to eat your choice-then join another queue for drinks. You can be served in a restaurant by a waiter/waitress at your own table for less than this in the centre of Lisbon. I felt it was poor value and not worth the walk from the centre of town. Not good value for a self-service set-up.

Great place to have a drink. It is a traditional market which was renovated and received a lot of restaurants and bars. It´s a very cool place where you can find signature dishes from great portuguese chefs for an acceptable price. You can also enjoy a glass of wine or a cold beer eating portuguese snacks. Very recommended for a night in Lisbon.

Wonderful find by chance !. wandered in here searching for a loo ! and stayed for a couple of hours, really buzzing place. Market stalls of meat, fish and veg on one side of building and in the main hall stalls all around the outside cooking various types of food. In the centre of the hall was tables and benches to sit and enjoy the wares being cooked. Recommended for a lunch, we had a couple of beers for just over 3 euros and a slate of bread, portugese cheese and ham for 10 euros and it was delicious

A very fun and tasty food court for exploring tourist. I visited the Mercado last month while vacationing with my wife and friend. We were told to go here by our Portuguese friend, and also told to try Vitor Claro's food (many chefs have their own "stalls" that you can order food and drink. We also had great food at Marlene Vieira's stall, and explored the shopping as well. Very busy for a Friday evening, it's great to see it successful.
