Special Food Court. One of the halves of the Ribeira Produce Market has been transformed in a very particular food court, much like a food court at a shopping mall, but not really. This is a project of the weekly magazine Time Out Lisbon, but the other side of the market is still functioning as usual, and you can go there to buy your fresh groceries. Loved the idea although there are a few things that pass as a little bit pretentious. Aspects of the decoration, some abuse of English words for common use concepts and the overall posh ambience that contrasts a lot with the market's "real" wing. And although I love the location it's really noisy, one can't hear oneself think...What saves it all is the excellent quality food and plenty to choose from. I ate a Tiborna, a sort of elaborate toast with traditional Portuguese ingredients and pork cheeks with sweet potato purée. Yummy! For desert, as it was hot, nothing better than an ice cream at Santini.There are all sorts of cuisines to choose from, from seafood or hamburgers to snacks or deserts, focusing mostly on Portuguese flavours, with known chef's stalls. Contrary to the mall's food courts, you choose what you feel like eating and not what type of food you usually have. At Mercado da Ribeira quality and flavour are guaranteed!There were also some small stalls with some crafts and merchandise, sadly most of them weren't Portuguese and not so crafty.

Good vibe, great range of food & beverages. My first time to visit this Portuguese Food Hall and on a Thursday night, it certainly had a good vibe. Our group was impressed by the range of food & beverages available, and whilst not everyone was completely happy with their order (me), we certainly enjoyed the atmosphere and the busy nature of the place.I look forward to heading back there and trying out the many restaurants that our group did not try.Hint: Finding seats/table first is advisable, then grab a drink and wander about (not your entire group otherwise you will lose your sport) to find the food that suits your appetite.

stylish food court in market hall. This is great: every person of your party picks out the food she or he likes and eat it together at one of the tables at the court. If you have trouble finding it: it's right opposite the metro station of Cais do Sodré. We loved the ham and cheese of Manteigaria Silva, the squid in tempura (spanish style) of Azul, the croquetas of croquetaria, the meat of Henrique sa pessoa and don't forget the delicious cakes and pies of 'nos e mais bolos'. We had a lemon pie with merengue and a raspberry chocolate merengue pie; they were both heaven!And since this place opened in may 2014, you don't see to much tourists here, it is packed with portuguese and that's a good sign.

Not to be missed when in Lisbon. Our Portuguese friends took us there for dinner and we found the venue to be very good. A market type of place with various restaurants booths featuring sometimes celebrity chefs. We ordered from various kitchens including Avenue, Marlene Vieira and the food was very good. This was complemented by a bottle of Terra a Terra. Thanks to the wide variety of food featured, it is a must try when in Lisbon.

What a great concept and what great food!. Wow how many idiots give this amazing place a low rating as they ordered food before finding a seat. This place is somewhere you visit in a group or as a family not the place you would go on your own.. Now anyone with a brain would finds seats first, and then one or two people stay behind to look after the table while the others go and order food - very simple! A very modern, spacious, clean, well lit and ventilated space, with and friendly and bubbling atmosphere. Now as for the food you have the widest variety that would make any critic happy, everyone can decide on either from meat, to fish, to sea food, to vegetarian, to sushi whatever you like.. cake stands, drink stands I mean the list goes on and on this place is a fantastic experience, I could visit there every week as there is so much to choose from and each stand makes changes to their menu regularly so you will never get bored. Prices are not cheap but not expensive either as you are getting restaurant quality food and presentation, in fast-food time and at a lot less than you would pay at a decent restaurant. Also most places do meal deals so you can get a glass of wine and a dessert for next to nothing on top of your main course. Anyone who does not visit this place while in Lisbon has lost their mind! Thoroughly recommend!

Be carefull with the restaurants... "Sea me" never again !. The new mercado is a very nice thing to see but be carefull with the restaurants. We tried "Sea me" which advertised a nice prego de atum. Bolo de caco bom atum bom mas um pedaço de vergonha... and they charge 12.5 euros .... shame shame shame ! Sea me.. never again but other places to try !

Busy. Azul was the restaurant outside. Inside the market was very busy but can be a good experience taste all different foods available, you can pick from different places like mix and match and then sit on the long benches. Can be very interesting if you are visiting Portugal for the 1st time and you can sample all varieties of foods but also a light meal for locals. There is also a fresh food market that one can see and buy good products and overall not to expensive.The restaurant Azul outside is nothing special we sit outside very enjoyable fresh seafood a bit on the expensive side. But location also counts. After the meal you can scroll along the river and in a summer day is just delightful.

Great foodie location 35 tempting food offers! - (tripadvisor's map is incorrect!). Famous local chefs and loved by Lisboans.... Located just alongside the train station in Av 24 de Julho and not between the station and the river where tripadvisor's map shows it - thankfully we found it as kids were getting a bit fed up of wondering around! (with your back to the train station ticket barriers walk out of left exit turn left and walk for 50m back alongside the tracks and it's on the opposite side of the main road) And well worth finding, especially the ham stall which we visited twice - a selection of 'pata negra' ham (presunto ibérico), bread, olive oil and a bottle of vihno verde can't be beaten. If you are lucky you may see a whole ham being prepared and cut which is interesting. Get there for early or late lunch or early dinner to avoid the crowds. Have a look about at the 35 stalls, find a communal table, which you may need to take turns in saving, and then 'dive in' and place your orders! I think it's more of a lunch venue as lacks some atmosphere and if you're all off choosing from different offers it can get a bit complicated as people wait for food. Albeit as a late night post drinks food venue I guess it takes some beating! (open until 2am Thurs-Sat, midnight other times) There are some proper resturants located in the venue too, as opposed to the tasting stalls, so perhaps starters outside and mains in the restaurants is an evening option too. Each day except Sundays, until lunchtime, there is also a traditional fish, meat and veg market there that's worth a look. A great way to start or finish a days sight seeing in Lisbon.

Nooooooo!!!. Ok, how can I give my feedback without being too demotivating? ....The place looks like the streets on the movie Blade Runner but instead of oriental people serving oriental food you have trendy stalls, owened by the today fashion chefs, serving portuguese food.Although it was packed, I can't see why people enjoy going to one of the stalls, buy food and then have to search for a place to sit with tray on their hands. Specially when most of the sits seem to be taken. It's a huge canteen with fancy and a bit overpriced food. Let's imagine that during your meal you need another drink.... you'll have to go and queue in front of one the stalls to get it and leave your tray at the table in the middle of hundreds of people you don't know.Ok, it can be a very trendy concept but just not for me.

Wide range of food. On a trip to Lisbon we ate at the new Mercado da Ribeira, once for an evening meal and once for lunch. Both times the food was very good and choice was exceptional. We ate from one of the chefs stalls on the first time, both having a lovely steak based dish, and then followed this up with a cake.The 2nd time we visited I had an amazing Burger, and my partner had Pad Thai, again these were high quality

Be patient , it's worth it.. My first visit to Mercado da Ribeira was a little of a mess. During the first week of grand opening, they haven't calculated the number of people who join to experience this great place, so after you grab your food be patient until you find a seat to eat.The food is great, you have many high-end kitchen and chefs, which means you won't be disappointed.The market is renewed, and it's very well designed. The only problem again, it's the seats. Some people stay on the table without food just waiting for their friends to arrive, this is not good behavior and it should be monitored by security.

Love this concept of eat well anytime. Before this kind of place exist in Lisbon, if you want to eat out of lunch time, your only option was the mall. Fast Food or boring not so fast food. But now, we can have a great time, in a great place, with lots of options to eat!!! Yeah!!!5 chefs let us try their expertise with low cost, and other restaurants let us choose what our hungry wants to.I love the "Croqueteria". The alheira one is perfect! And tuna with dry tomato... hummmToday my husband tried Henrique Sá Pessoa's pork cheek. Delicious! Perfect mashed potatoes.I order a "bacalhau a Brás" from Miguel Castro e Silva. It was ok... It was served with raw egg yolks mixed with the rest of the ingredients. Not bad, but... I expected more.I finished my gourmet day with a chocolate fondant that taste like... how can I say? Heaven?? So many options, great place.Worth it. Everything.

Foodies heaven!. This unique "all-in-one" venue takes the food court concept to a completely new level. This one of a kind market is a great dining experience that will allow you to discover what some of Lisbon's top chefs and restaurants have to offer. Whatever the restaurant you pick, the overall quality of the food is excellent - and at very reasonable prices! P.S.: Don't leave the market without having a Santini Ice Cream!

much ado about nothing. Time Out is now the new lord of Mercado da Ribeira. A new venue in downtown Lisbon where you can find dozens of small restaurants. The problem here is that everything seems so artificial. All restaurants name paltes are in black with letters in white (ok these are the colours of Lisbon's flag), giving the place a very orderly and padronized look. Tables are not enough, the noise makes imposible to follow what your friends are saying.If you like to mingle among wannabe lisboetas this is the place to go. If you rather prefer a simple tasca or a a restaurant where locals go just for the pleasure of being together and not for the sake of seeing and being seened, go to Ramiro, a Tosca, taberna as Flores, Café no Chiado, Cervajaria Trindade and the sort.Mercado da Ribeira best value is the gigantic red quisoque just in the garden outside.For a "gourmet" kind of eatery is fine, but is lacks true character.

That's what I call a food court. New trendy concept in Lisbon.Various Portuguese chefs offer great food at very reasonable prices in small stylish food shops. You take your food and eat it at one of the many wooden tables you share with hundreds of other people.Moreover, in the center of the large market, wine booths offer various wines to taste by the glass or the bottle. Great concept that you definitely have to try.I was there with friends on a Friday evening, with a large screen showing the world cup football game between Brazil and Colombia, so the place was a bit hectic, but we loved the atmosphere.

Excellent gourmet food market concept. So good we visited here twice. This amazing food hall / market is not your average market dining experience. The food hall is decked out with nice clean wooden benches and a lovely light atmosphere.... The food selection and the quality of the food on offer was something else, all food fop rom local business and served Tia. Very high standard. It's a place where you can sample a little of everything you fancy, sweet, savoury, alcohol. Visiting here is a must...it's open until the small hours and is equally as buzzing at night time than it is during the day. EPIC

Love this place. Five top chefs have restaurants in this lovely place, former market hall. Nowadays it's a collection of restaurants and food shops, all has a same kind of brand and signage, very stylish. You can taste regional specialities and try even fine dining with budget. We ate at Alexandre Silva, marinated mackerel was sooo tasty. Starter with 'bacalhau', codfish, was also splendid. In lunchtime this place is very crowded, so it's better to enter it just before.

Something for everyone - you'll be spoilt for choice!. My friends & I went to eat here quite a few times during our 4 days in Lisbon. It is perfect for a group when you all fancy different kinds of food - there is something for everyone! I love the concept - there are 35 kiosks selling different types of food & drink so you'll be spoilt for choice & never bored. I had Pad Thai from the Asian Lab, which was very delicious & freshly made whilst I waited. I definitely recommend the cocktails at Chinco & you must have a traditional Portuguese custard tart from Aloma. Everything is freshly made to order & very cheap considering the quality! This place is very trendy & popular so be warned it gets busy & times it can be a struggle to find somewhere to sit especially with a big group. The only thing that lets it down (the reason I didn't give it 5 stars) is that they need to employ more people to clear up the trays & clean the tables. We saw people piling up trays on the table so that they could sit. I personally prefer going at lunch for this reason! Either way you can't go wrong with the food experience. We were surprised at how late they were open...on Saturday is was 2am & they were still serving food. Overall, great food, brilliant experience - worth going to again & again!

Really good place to eat; nice atmosphere. We loved this place. It's an old market which has been converted (in part; the old market remains in the other half) into a food hall with 20-30 different outlets. They're all top notch and the food was lovely - you can have anything from traditional portuguese dishes through to hamburgers and sushi. Really nice atmosphere - they showed World cup matches on a large screen and it was a good fun.
Good range if food. Quality tapas, salad and desserts from the stall we chose. Many businesses to choose from. Great concept.

pleasant ambience and good food. This is a public market that has been refurbished to include a range of different restaurants and a large area with tables. It is a nice place for break after walking all the way from Rossio.

Follow the yellow tram. In Ribeira Market, i chose the restaurant Chef Vítor Claro and i'h marveled at the decor and the food quality. The space is very traditional with yellow tram in decor. The bijous are the best I've ever eaten in Lisbon: fluffy bread with traditional flavors. Loved the pork cheek and tempura. very, very nice :)

learn from my mistakes. I went to Mercado da Ribeira on a Friday night and it was very busy. We had a tough time getting a table that could fit our group of 7, and getting chairs for everyone was a bit challenging as well. Once we were all seated, we took turns to get food at restaurant booths so that there was always someone saving our seats. I got stuff from three booths, and it was a bit challenging to manage. It would probably be best to get food from just one place. I ordered and paid in the first and then went on to the next one to order and pay and so forth. Then I had to wait at least 15 min for my food to be ready and I went to collect it to each of the booths i had ordered from and took it to the table. In the meantime, I had to go back and forth several times to check if my dinner was ready but there is no better way of doing it (they should be introduced to those vibrating pagers). Staff was friendly and polite but the service was very slow and several specials had already sold out in some of the booths. The best food I got was from Sea Me (sardine nigiri, oysters and scalops). I think it is probably to visit Mercado da Ribeira in a smaller group and order all your dinner from just one booth. Prices were fair but be warned of small portion sizes which were very unusual for Portuguese standards.

If you aren’t on a hurry, it’s a good place to eat - Hot spot. Timeout is managing the market that was restructured in terms of space. In one parte it still be a market (vegetables, fish, meat, etc.) and in the other side has several restaurants and different gastronomy. There are also 4 Portuguese chefs well known. In the middle of the nave exists specifics corner with wines, other with beers, others with juices. Since it opened in end of May is always full of people, it is better to go earlier.I have eaten in the Asian Lab, it was so good and not expensive at all.

Unique Dining Experience. Timeout Mercado da Ribeira is a unique dining concept that allows you to experience the most famous portuguese chefs creations in just one place. This is exactly a "dining warehouse" where you have different restaurant booths and a Beer Experience just in the middle surrounded by dining tables in a "eat & go" style. If you're visiting Lisbon for a short period of time I strongly suggest you to go here if you would like to have contact with most of the portuguese delicacies. The closest MTR station is Cais do Sodré (the opposite site of the road) or if you're in Chiado area go straight to Praça Luís de Camões (near Bairro Alto) and go all the way down on the river direction (Cais do Sodré), Mercado da Ribeira is just located on your right hand side. It will be a whole new dining experience which you won't regret. Suitable for family with kids or for a romantic & casual date.

Food Frenzy Disaster. This new hot spot was recommended to us by our B&B. We got there early on a Saturday night (6pm) and found the last open seats for a party of 3. We spent the next hour and a half fending off desperate diners who hovered over us waiting for us to leave or trying to take the chair of whomever in our party was brave enough to go forage for food. The lines were long, the wait for food after you ordered was extreme and the prices were outrageous for the portion size. Half the stalls we tried to order from were unable to use their credit card machines and the ATM in the Mercado was non functional. Quality was high and food was fresh but who could enjoy it under such stressful conditions?The Food court had only been opened a few weeks at this time and they were CLEARLY overwhelmed by the number of people. Not enough seating, not enough food, not enough workers and failing technology. A total FAIL and unfortunate way to spend our last evening in Portugal.

Something for everyone. The "old" market part is big and with lots of fresh vegetables, fruits, fish, meat etc. Then there's a new, modern part with a food court with great variety and ok prices. Here everyone can find something they like. Outside there's a fun playground for the kids and a sandwich bar. I like it a lot!

The reinvigorated Mercado da Ribeira. When booking into our Lisbon apartment our host mentioned that the revamped section of the market was opening on the following Sunday. We went twice during the following week. The older original produce area of the market looks a bit tired and a lot of the fruit etc looked second grade. They did have fantastic apricots though.The new "food hall" though was a different matter with many booths run by the "best chefs in Lisbon". Here you could get a huge variety of local and international dishes. Seating is mainly benches and stools, with only a few tables and chairs.Both times we were there it was packed and it took a bit of hunting around to find seats.As well as the fantastic range of food available there are also bars and coffee etc available.The seafood risotto from "Alexandre Silva" was the best we have ever had.Located just across the road from the Cais do Sodre railway station it is the perfect spot to have a quick meal.

Mercado da Ribeira by TimeOut. Yesterday we got the chance to go to the oppening of the Ribeira Market by TimeOut! I am delighted to say that this one is a winner! Although yesterday was the oppening of the first stage of the project, and there is still much to do, it already breaths World class. The selection of restaurants is endless, so the choice was nothing but difficult. First stop had to be Tartaria – the Tartar joint by Dieter Koschina from Vila Joya named the 22nd Best Restaurant in the World by San Pellegrino & Acqua Panna. Afterwords I took a chance on Vitor Claro for the second time and once again I was very happy with my roastbeef and foie gras bijou! A delicious burguer from Alexandre Silva, some guiozas from Asian Lab, a selection of cheeses and pata negra from Manteigaria Silva and last but not least an ice cream from Santini… All this and so much more underneath of a mid century Market roof that is sure to become an icon of Lisbon!http://cantcooksowhat.com/2014/05/19/mercado-da-ribeira/

Disappointing ambience, expensive food. The markets are enjoyable to walk around but the new eating place is disappointing. We chose the Henrique sa Passoa, but the food came cold in tiny portions. The chips accompanying the fish were small matchsticks and tasteless. The suckling pig was belly pork, which was delicious, with a smear of cold sweet potatoes and a couple of segments of orange. We realised we had been charged for the most expensive wine - contrary to our order. The service was disorganised. As it's new it might improve, but it's difficult to recommend at the moment.

The Ribeira Market Revolution. Being part of Lisbon life for Centuries, the Ribeira Market entered its most flourishing moment. Partially renovated it now includes some of the Best Portuguese Shops like Manteigaria Silva and Santini Ice Creams but also some of the Best food concepts like Monte Mar Fish and Seafood, Chef Claro Sandwiches or Honorato Gourmet Burguers. Recently opened it is already a must Taste!

Get here early in the day!!. address is Avenida 24 de Julho 1200-479 Lisbon PortugalOpposite the main rail station.. this is an assault on the senses. Split into different avenues, meat,fish, vegetable , flowers , bakery it has something for everyone. The cafes inside are a pleasure to eat fresh food cheaply. Judging from the number of backpackers eating , we are not the only ones who know. The stallholders were patient and explained the local foods, including the pear shaped cheeses.
